Subsection Title: EU PRIIPs Regulation/Prohibition of Sales to EEA Investors

Section Title: NOTICE TO CANADIAN INVESTORS
Subsection Title: EU PRIIPs Regulation/Prohibition of Sales to EEA Investors
Subsubsection Text: Each Initial Purchaser has represented, warranted and agreed that it has not offered, sold or otherwise made available to and will not offer, sell or otherwise make available the Senior Secured Notes to any retail investor in the European Economic Area (the “EEA”). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID II or (ii) a customer within the meaning of the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID II. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (the “EU PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the EU PRIIPs Regulation. vii -----

Section Title: NOTICE TO CANADIAN INVESTORS
Subsection Title: UK PRIIPs Regulation/Prohibition of sales to UK Retail Investors
Subsubsection Text: Each Initial Purchaser has represented and agreed that it has not offered, sold or otherwise made available and will not offer, sell or otherwise make available any Senior Secured Notes to any retail investor in the United Kingdom. For the purposes of this provision, the expression “retail investor” means a person who is one (or more) of the following: (1) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA; or (2) a customer within the meaning of the provisions of the FSMA and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014, as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the “UK PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the United Kingdom has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom may be unlawful under the UK PRIIPs Regulation.

Section Title: NOTICE TO CANADIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Each Initial Purchaser has represented, warranted and agreed that: (1) it has only communicated or caused to be communicated and will only communicate or cause to be communicated an invitation or inducement to engage in investment activity (within the meaning of Section 21 of the FSMA) received by it in connection with the issue or sale of the Senior Secured Notes in circumstances in which Section 21(1) of the FSMA does not apply to the communication; and (2) it has complied and will comply with all applicable provisions of the FSMA with respect to anything done by it in relation to the Senior Secured Notes in, from or otherwise involving the United Kingdom.

Section Title: NOTICE TO CANADIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes may only be offered or sold in any of the provinces of Canada pursuant to an exemption from the requirement to file a prospectus in such province in which such offer or sale is made, and only by a registrant duly registered under, or exempt from, the applicable securities laws of that province or by a registrant that is relying in that province on the “international dealer” exemption provided by Section 8.18 of National Instrument 31-103 Registration Requirements, Exemptions and Ongoing Registrant Obligations (“NI 31-103”). Furthermore, the Senior Secured Notes may only be offered or sold to purchasers purchasing, or deemed to be purchasing, as principal that are “accredited investors” as defined in National Instrument 45-106 Prospectus Exemptions (“NI 45-106”) or subsection 73.3(1) of the Securities Act (Ontario), and that are “permitted clients” as defined in NI 31-103. Each Canadian purchaser hereby acknowledges that any resale of the Senior Secured Notes must be made in accordance with an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the prospectus requirements of applicable securities laws and that it shall be deemed to represent and warrant it is an accredited investor, a permitted client, was not created or used solely to purchase or hold securities as an accredited investor and is purchasing as principal (or deemed principal) for investment only and not with a view to resale or redistribution. Securities legislation in certain provinces or territories of Canada may provide a purchaser with remedies for rescission or damages if this Offering Memorandum (including any amendment thereto) contains a misrepresentation, _provided that the remedies for rescission or damages are exercised by the purchaser within the time limit prescribed_ by the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province. The purchaser should refer to any applicable provisions of the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province of residence for particulars of these rights or consult with a legal advisor. Pursuant to section 3A.3 of National Instrument 33-105 Underwriting Conflicts (“NI 33-105”), the initial purchasers are not required to comply with the disclosure requirements of NI 33-105 regarding underwriter conflicts of interest in connection with the Offering. We and the initial purchasers hereby notify prospective Canadian purchasers that: (a) we may be required to provide personal information pertaining to the purchaser as required to be disclosed in Schedule I of Form 45 106F1 under NI 45-106 (including its name, address, telephone number, email and the number and aggregate purchase price of any Senior Secured Notes purchased) (“personal information”), which Form 45-106F1 may be required to be filed by us under NI 45-106, (b) such personal information may be delivered to the securities regulatory authority or regulator in the Canadian purchaser’s jurisdiction (the “Applicable Canadian Securities Regulator”) in accordance with NI 45-106, (c) such personal information is collected indirectly by the Applicable Canadian Securities Regulator under the authority granted to it under securities legislation, (d) such personal information is collected for the purposes vi ----- of the administration and enforcement of the securities legislation, and (e) the contact information for the public official who can answer questions about the Applicable Canadian Securities Regulator’s indirect collection of such personal information may be found in Form 45-106F1. Prospective Canadian purchasers that purchase Senior Secured Notes in this Offering will be deemed to have authorised the indirect collection of the personal information by the Applicable Canadian Securities Regulator, and to have acknowledged and consented to its name, address, telephone number, email and other specified information, including the aggregate purchase price paid by the purchaser, being disclosed to other Canadian securities regulatory authorities, and to have acknowledged that such information may become available to the public in accordance with requirements of applicable Canadian laws. Upon receipt of this Offering Memorandum, each Canadian purchaser hereby confirms that it has expressly requested that all documents evidencing or relating in any way to the sale of the Senior Secured Notes (including for greater certainty any purchase confirmation or any notice) be drawn up in the English language only. Par la réception _de ce document, chaque acheteur canadien confirme par les présentes qu’il a expressément exigé que tous les documents faisant foi ou se rapportant de quelque manière que ce soit à la vente des valeurs mobilières décrites aux présentes (incluant, pour plus de certitude, toute confirmation d’achat ou tout avis) soient rédigés en anglais seulement._

Section Title: NOTICE TO JERSEY INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: No person shall, without the consent of the Jersey Financial Services Commission unless a relevant exemption to such consent applies, circulate in Jersey any offer for subscription, sale or exchange of the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: NOTICE TO LUXEMBOURG RESIDENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Offering should not be considered a public offering of securities in Luxembourg. This Offering Memorandum has not been approved by, and will not be submitted for approval to, the Luxembourg Financial Services Authority (Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier) for purposes of public offering or sale in Luxembourg. Accordingly, the Senior Secured Notes may not be offered or sold to the public in Luxembourg, directly or indirectly, and neither this Offering Memorandum nor any other circular, prospectus, form of application, advertisement, communication or other material may be distributed, or otherwise made available in or from, or published in Luxembourg, except in circumstances where the offer of the Senior Secured Notes benefits from an exemption from or constitutes a transaction otherwise not subject to the requirement to publish a prospectus pursuant to the Luxembourg law dated July 16, 2019 on prospectuses for securities, which applies the EU Prospectus Regulation. viii -----

Section Title: NOTICE TO DUTCH INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes that are the subject of the Offering contemplated by this Offering Memorandum are not and may not be offered in the Netherlands other than to persons or entities which are qualified investors as defined in article 1:1 of the Dutch Financial Supervision Act (Wet op het financieel toezicht or the “AFS”). Each purchaser of Senior Secured Notes described in this Offering Memorandum located in the Netherlands will be deemed to have represented, acknowledged and agreed that it is a qualified investor (gekwalificeerde beleggers) as defined in section 1:1 of the AFS. For the purposes of this provision, the expression an “offer of Senior Secured Notes to the public” in relation to any Senior Secured Notes in the Netherlands means to make a sufficiently specific offer addressed to more than one person as referred to in section 217(1) of Book 6 of the Dutch Civil Code to conclude a contract to purchase or otherwise acquire the Senior Secured Notes, or to issue an invitation to make an offer of the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: NOTICE TO SWISS INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum is not intended to constitute an offer or solicitation to purchase or invest in the Senior Secured Notes described herein. The Senior Secured Notes may not be publicly offered, sold or advertised, directly or indirectly, in, into or from Switzerland and will not be listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange or on any other exchange or regulated trading facility in Switzerland. Neither this Offering Memorandum nor any other offering or marketing material relating to the Senior Secured Notes constitutes a prospectus as such term is understood pursuant to article 652a and/or article 1156 of the Swiss Code of Obligations or a listing prospectus within the meaning of the listing rules of the SIX Swiss Exchange or any other regulated trading facility in Switzerland, and neither this Offering Memorandum nor any other offering or marketing material relating to the Senior Secured Notes may be publicly distributed or otherwise made publicly available in Switzerland. The Senior Secured Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in Switzerland. For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is a retail client as defined in Article 4 of the Swiss Financial Services Act (the “FinSA”). Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (or any equivalent document under the FinSA) has been or will be prepared in relation to any Senior Secured Notes and therefore, any Senior Secured Notes with a derivative character within the meaning of article 86 (2) of the Swiss Financial Services Ordinance may not be offered or recommended to private clients within the meaning of the FinSA in Switzerland.

Section Title: NOTICE TO ITALIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The offer of the Senior Secured Notes has neither been registered with, nor cleared by, the Commissione _Nazionale per la Società e la Borsa (“CONSOB”) (the Italian securities exchange commission), pursuant to Italian_ securities legislation. Accordingly, no Senior Secured Notes may be offered, sold or delivered, directly or indirectly, in the Republic of Italy, nor may copies of this Offering Memorandum or of any other offering circular, prospectus, form of application, advertisement, other offering material or any other information or any other document relating to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or the Senior Secured Notes to be issued, be distributed or published in the Republic of Italy, either on the primary or on the secondary market, except in accordance with Italian securities, tax and other applicable laws and regulations. Each Initial Purchaser has represented and agreed that it has not offered, sold or delivered, and will not offer, sell or deliver, directly or indirectly, any Senior Secured Notes or distribute or publish any copy of this Offering Memorandum or any other document relating to the Senior Secured Notes in Italy, except: (1) to qualified investors (investitori qualificati), as defined pursuant to Article 2, paragraph (e) of the EU Prospectus Regulation; and (2) in other circumstances which are exempted from the rules on public offerings pursuant to Article 1 of the EU Prospectus Regulation, Article 34-ter of CONSOB Regulation No. 11971 of May 14, 1999, as amended from time to time, and any other applicable Italian laws and regulations. ix ----- Any offer, sale or delivery of the Senior Secured Notes or distribution of copies of this Offering Memorandum or any other document relating to the Senior Secured Notes in the Republic of Italy under paragraph (a) or (b) above must be made: (a) by _soggetti abilitati (including an investment firm, bank or financial intermediary permitted to conduct such activities in Italy in accordance with Legislative Decree No. 58 of 24 February 1998, as amended from time to time (the “Financial Services Act”), Legislative Decree No. 385 of September 1, 1993 (the “Consolidated Banking Act”) and CONSOB Regulation No. 20307 of February 15, 2018, all as amended from time to time); and (b) in compliance with any other applicable laws and regulations or requirements, including any limitation or requirement that may be imposed from time to time by CONSOB, the Bank of Italy (including the reporting requirements, where applicable, pursuant to Article 129 of the Consolidated Banking Act and the relevant implementing guidelines of the Bank of Italy, as amended from time to time) and/or any other Italian competent authority. Any investor purchasing the Senior Secured Notes is solely responsible for ensuring that any offer or resale of the Senior Secured Notes by such investor occurs in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.

Section Title: NOTICE TO SPANISH INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes may not be sold, offered or distributed to persons in Spain nor may any subsequent resale of the Senior Secured Notes be carried out in Spain, except in circumstances which do not qualify as a public offer (oferta pública) of securities in Spain, in accordance with article 35 of the Royal Legislative Decree 4/2015, of October 23, approving the amended and restated text of the Spanish Securities Market Law (Real Decreto Legislativo _4/2015, de 23 de octubre, por el que se aprueba el texto refundido de la Ley del Mercado de Valores), as amended_ and restated, and the Royal Decree 1310/2005, of November 4, on the listing of securities, public offers and applicable prospectus (Real Decreto 1310/2005, de 4 de noviembre, por el que se desarrolla parcialmente la Ley 24/1988, de 28 _de julio, del Mercado de Valores en materia de admisión a negociación de valores en mercados secundarios oficiales, de ofertas públicas de venta o suscripción y del folleto exigible a tales efectos), as amended and restated, and any_ regulations developing it which may be in force from time to time. Neither the Senior Secured Notes, the Offering nor this Offering Memorandum and its contents have been approved or registered with the Spanish Securities and Exchange Commission (Comisión Nacional del Mercado de Valores), and therefore it is not intended for the public offering of Senior Secured Notes in Spain.

Section Title: NOTICE TO FRENCH INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum has not been prepared in the context of a public offering of financial securities in France within the meaning of the EU Prospectus Regulation and, therefore, has not been approved by, or registered or filed with the _Autorité des marchés financiers_ (the French financial markets authority (“AMF”)) and does not require a prospectus to be submitted for approval to the AMF. Consequently, the Senior Secured Notes may not be, directly or indirectly, offered or sold to the public in France (offre au public de titres financiers) (other than to qualified investors and/or a restricted circle of investors acting for their own account), and neither this Offering Memorandum nor any offering or marketing materials relating to the Senior Secured Notes may be made available or distributed in any way that would constitute, directly or indirectly, an offer to the public in France (other than to qualified investors and/or a restricted circle of investors acting for their own account). The Senior Secured Notes may only be offered or sold in France to: (i) a restricted circle of investors acting for their own account (cercle restreint d’investisseurs agissant pour compte propre) in accordance with Articles L. 411-2 and D. 411-4 of the French Code monétaire et financier and/or to qualified investors (investisseurs qualifiés) as defined by Article 2(e) of the EU Prospectus Regulation. Prospective investors are informed that: (i) this Offering Memorandum or any other materials relating to this Offering Memorandum have not been and will not be submitted for clearance to the AMF; (ii) in compliance with Article L.411-2 of the French Code monétaire et financier, the restricted circle of investors subscribing for the Senior Secured Notes should be acting for its own account and (iii) the direct and indirect distribution or sale to the public of the Senior Secured Notes acquired by them and the qualified x ----- investors may only be made in compliance with Articles L. 411-1, L. 411-2, L. 412-1, L. 621-8 to L. 621-8-2 of the French Code monétaire et financier and applicable regulations thereunder. Investors in France and persons into whose possession offering materials come must inform themselves about, and observe, any such restrictions.

Section Title: NOTICE TO AUSTRIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum has not been and will not be approved and/or published pursuant to the Austrian Capital Markets Act (Kapitalmarktgesetz), as amended, and has not been passported into Austria pursuant to the EU Prospectus Regulation. Neither this Offering Memorandum nor any other document connected therewith constitutes a prospectus according to the EU Prospectus Regulation and neither this Offering Memorandum nor any other document connected therewith may be distributed, passed on or disclosed to any person in Austria other than as permitted in this paragraph. No steps may be taken that would constitute a public offering of the Senior Secured Notes in Austria and the offering of the Senior Secured Notes may not be advertised in Austria. Any offer of the Senior Secured Notes in Austria may only be made to any legal entity which is a “qualified investor” within the meaning of Article 2(e) of the EU Prospectus Regulation; and provided that no such offer of the Senior Secured Notes shall require us or the Initial Purchasers to publish a prospectus pursuant to Article 3 of the EU Prospectus Regulation. For the purposes of this provision, the expression a “public offering of Notes” means any communication (whether originating from the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or a financial intermediary) to the public in any form and by any means, presenting sufficient information on the terms of the offer and the Senior Secured Notes to be offered (or an invitation to subscribe such Senior Secured Notes), so as to enable an investor to decide to purchase or subscribe to the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION General
Subsubsection Text: We present in this Offering Memorandum certain financial information for the Senior Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries, including historical information for the Group, which consists of the Senior Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries. The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum includes certain audited and unaudited financial statements, non-IFRS financial information, operating segment information and other information, each as set forth below. For an overview of the entities in the Group, see “Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing _Structure.”_ The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer with no revenue-generating activities of its own or material business operations, and its primary assets relate to its shares in Acquisition 2 and its primary liabilities relate to inter-group balances with the Senior Notes Issuer, commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the issuance of the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the guarantees of the Existing Senior Notes and the Transactions. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales as a private limited company on September 3, 2020 and re-registered as a public limited company on December 18, 2020, for the purpose of consummating the LBO Acquisition (as defined herein).

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION General
Subsubsection Text: All historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the Senior Notes Issuer. Accordingly, unless otherwise stated, all references to “Asda,” “we,” “us,” “our,” the “Company” or the “Group” in respect of historical financial information in this Offering Memorandum are to the Senior Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries, collectively. The Senior Notes Issuer is a public limited incorporated under the laws of England and Wales on September 3, 2020 to act as an intermediate holding company for Asda and the immediate holding company of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. It is a holding company with no revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, and its primary assets and liabilities, respectively, relate to an intercompany receivable of £1,683 million, its shares in the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the issuance of the Senior Notes. Consequently, no separate historical consolidated financial information of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer has been included in this Offering Memorandum. The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum includes: - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 prepared in accordance with UK adopted International Accounting Standards in conformity with the requirements of the Companies Act of 2006 (the “2021 Financial Statements”); - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 prepared in accordance with UK adopted International Accounting Standards in conformity with the requirements of the Companies Act of 2006 (the “2022 Financial Statements”); and - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Senior Notes Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 prepared in accordance with UK adopted International Accounting Standards in conformity with the requirements of the Companies Act of 2006 (the “2023 Financial Statements,” and together with the 2021 Financial Statements and the 2022 Financial Statements, the “Financial

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The 2021 Financial Statements and the 2022 Financial Statements have been audited by Ernst & Young LLP, as set forth in their audit reports included elsewhere herein. The 2023 Financial Statements have been audited by KPMG LLP, as set forth in their audit reports included elsewhere herein. Unless otherwise stated, no other financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum has been audited. xii ----- In this Offering Memorandum we present certain financial information related to periods prior to 2021. Prior to 2021, we presented the financial information of Asda Group Limited and its subsidiaries. The financial information for periods prior to 2021 has been presented herein for illustrative purposes only and investors should place no reliance on such information. This Offering Memorandum does not include the audited financial statements for any period prior to 2021. There can be no assurance that, had such information been audited or reviewed, there would not have been any discrepancies (including material) compared to the financial information presented herein. In addition, all historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the Senior Notes Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries. However, the financial results of the Senior Notes Issuer do not include a full year of trading in the year ended December 31, 2021, as it acquired the trading group Asda Group Limited part way through the year on February 16, 2021. As a result, results for the year ended December 31, 2021 for the Senior Notes Issuer consolidated group do not constitute a full comparative period. In certain instances, to provide a more meaningful comparison, the results for the year ended December 31, 2021 down to the level of operating profit are presented on an annualised basis as if Asda Group Limited had been acquired by the Senior Notes Issuer on January 1, 2021. Such annualised results are derived from the financial statements of Bellis Finco plc for the period ended December 31, 2021 and the actual results of Asda Group Limited from January 1, 2021 to the date of acquisition of Asda Group by Bellis Finco plc on February, 14 2021. Following the closing date of the EG UK Acquisition on October 31, 2023, the results of EG UK were consolidated into our results. Following the closing of the Arthur Acquisition in October 2022, the CMA implemented an initial enforcement order (the “IEO”) and consequently, management concluded that the restrictions imposed by the IEO meant that the Group did not obtain control of the Arthur Business at such closing date. On May 30, 2023, after accepting our proposed remedies of disposing of 13 of the acquired sites, the CMA lifted the IEO and the results of the Arthur Business were consolidated into our results from that date. Our results in 2023 have been impacted by the revenues and expenses of the acquired business starting from the relevant date when we started consolidated the results of the applicable acquired business. The preparation of financial statements in accordance with UK adopted International Accounting Standards, as adopted by the United Kingdom, and in conformity of the requirements of the UK Companies Act (“UK **IFRS”) requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying our accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to the financial statements, are disclosed in the Financial Statements. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Critical Accounting _Policies and Estimates.”_ In making an investment decision, you must rely upon your own examination of the terms of this Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Prospective investors should consult their professional advisors for an understanding of: (i) the differences between UK IFRS, the International Financial Reporting Standards, as adopted by the European Union (“EU IFRS”) generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”), UK GAAP and other systems of generally accepted accounting principles and how these differences might affect the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, and (ii) the impact that future additions to, or amendments of UK IFRS principles may have on our results of operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability of the prior periods. The financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to comply with the applicable accounting requirements of the Securities Act and the related rules and regulations of the SEC, which would apply if the Senior Secured Notes were being registered with the SEC. There could be significant differences between UK IFRS and U.S. GAAP, as applied to the Senior Notes Issuer. We neither describe the differences between UK IFRS and U.S. GAAP nor reconcile the Senior Notes Issuer’s UK IFRS financial statements to U.S. GAAP. Accordingly, such information is not available to investors, and investors should consider this in making their investment decision. The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will impose no obligation on us to reconcile the Senior Notes Issuer’s future financial statements prepared under UK IFRS to U.S. GAAP. See “Independent Auditors” for a description of the independent auditors’ reports of Ernst & Young LLP and KPMG LLP. xiii ----- In accordance with guidance issued by The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, the independent auditors’ reports from (1) KPMG LLP for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2023 and (2) Ernst & Young LLP for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, state that neither KPMG LLP nor Ernst & Young LLP, as applicable, assumes responsibility to anyone (including holders of the Senior Secured Notes) other than the Senior Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer’s members, as a body, for its audit work or the audit reports or opinions it has formed. Each of KPMG LLP and Ernst & Young LLP has undertaken its audit work, in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006, to state to the Senior Notes Issuer’s members those matters that it is required to state to them in an auditor’s report and for no other purpose. Investors in the Senior Secured Notes should understand that in making these statements, the independent auditors have confirmed that they do not accept or assume any liability to parties (such as the purchasers of the Senior Secured Notes) other than to the Senior Notes Issuer and its members, as a body, with respect to the report and to the independent auditors’ audit work and opinions. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the Securities Act or in a report filed under the U.S. Exchange Act. If a U.S. court (or any other court) were to give effect to such limiting language, the recourse that investors in the Senior Secured Notes may have against the independent auditor based on its report or the consolidated financial statements to which it relates could be limited. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters—The audit reports of Ernst & Young LLP and KPMG LLP included in this Offering Memorandum include statements purporting to limit the persons that may rely on such reports and the opinions contained therein.”_

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The Group has undertaken a detailed review of its application of IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets in relation to testing for impairment of non-current assets. In particular, the Group has reassessed the application of the IAS 36 with respect to the following stages of the impairment review: - Identifying Cash Generating Units (“CGUs”) which exhibit impairment triggers; - Calculating the carrying value of CGUs which are tested for impairment; and - Calculating value-in-use (“VIU”) as part of determining the recoverable amount of CGUs. As the reassessment of the Group’s application of IAS 36 has been applied in order to provide more reliable information about the carrying value of the Group’s non-current assets at the balance sheet date, the Group has applied judgement to conclude that the effect of the revised allocation of central costs to both the assessment of impairment triggers and the forecast cashflows used in the value-in-use calculations and the allocation of central assets to CGUs should be applied to the impairment review conducted at December 31, 2022. This results in a pre-tax impairment charge for the year ended December 31, 2022 of £377.4 million (posttax £312.2 million) of which £357.5 million (pre-tax) was not previously recorded in the 2022 Financial Statements. As this amount results from a change in application of the requirements of IAS 36, the Group has recorded a prior year adjustment as per the requirements of IAS 8. The Group has also carried out the same impairment review at December 31, 2021 and concluded that no changes in presentation are required as there were no significant changes in the property values in the period since the LBO Acquisition in February 2021 to the end of 2021. The net recoverable amount of the CGUs which was subject to impairment in the year ended December 31, 2022 increased in the year ended December 31, 2023 leading to a partial reversal of the impairment recorded in the year ended December 31, 2022. This resulted in a net pre-tax impairment reversal of £225.7 million (post-tax £183.4 million) being recorded in the income statement in the 2023 Financial Statements. The opening deferred tax liability includes the restatement for impairments, resulting in a reduction in the opening deferred tax liability of £65.2 million. In 2023 the Group identified that hardware assets with a net book value of £39.2 million were originally classified as intangible assets. These have been reclassified to plant, equipment, fixtures and fittings during the year ended December 31, 2023. xiv ----- During the year ended December 31, 2023, a non-operating distribution property with a carrying value of £20.5 million was reclassified as held for sale within current assets. It was determined that this asset met the criteria for being classed as held for sale. In addition, the Group’s presentation of the year ended December 31, 2022 has been restated in the 2023 Financial Statements to separately show amounts classified as other income and to present an updated impairment value Other income comprises concession and commission income and rental income. Rental income relates to income earned by the Group as a lessor from sites located in the proximity of certain stores. In the year ended December 31, 2022 and in the 2022 Financial Statements, rental income was netted against operating costs. However, in the 2023 Financial Statements, rental income has been included in other income. Other income as disclosed in note 4 of the 2022 Financial Statements was £42.5 million. Following a detailed review, amounts totalling £15.0 million of concession and commission income, which were netted against operating costs in the 2022 Financial Statements, have been reclassified in the 2023 Financial Statements and included as £57.5 million in concession and commission income, to better reflect their nature. For more information related to any restatements or reclassifications see the notes to the 2023 Financial Statements included elsewhere herein.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsection Title: Unaudited Pro forma Adjusted Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: We present in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited financial information adjusted to give pro forma effect to the Transactions (“As Adjusted Financial Information”). See “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial _Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators” and “Capitalisation.”_ The As Adjusted Financial Information included in this Offering Memorandum has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards. The assumptions underlying the As Adjusted Financial Information have not been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. The As Adjusted Financial Information has been provided for informational purposes only. Results indicated by certain of these measures may not be realised, and funds depicted by certain of these measures may not be available for management’s discretionary use if such results are not realised. Further, the As Adjusted Financial Information does not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or our cash position or financial position as at any future date. The actual results may differ significantly from those reflected in the unaudited pro forma financial information for a number of reasons, including, but not limited to, differences in assumptions used to prepare the As Adjusted Financial Information. The As Adjusted Financial Information should be read in conjunction with the information contained in “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial Data,” “Selected Consolidated _Financial Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”_ and “Risk Factors” and the financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, is calculated by adding back to the Group’s profit for the period income tax (credit)/expense, interest, amortisation and depreciation. See “Summary Historical Consolidated _Financial Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: EBITDA Margin means the Group’s EBITDA as a percentage of total revenue (including fuel) for the relevant period.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, means the Group’s EBITDA for a particular period as adjusted for other income (such as (gain)/loss on disposal and gain/loss on sale and leaseback), certain historical income and costs certain impairment charges, actual EBITDA attributable to Arthur Foodstores Limited from closing of the transaction on October 30, 2022 through the CMA lifting the IEO on May 30, 2023 (as relevant for the given period), asset-write offs, the elimination of IFRS 16 impact to reflect a rental charge for all leases in Adjusted EBITDA, prior year ATM rates, tax saving pass throughs, pension buyout losses, asset retirement obligations (“AROs”) provision release, rental income associated with the Starbucks freehold properties acquired from the EG UK Acquisition, TSA prepayment unwind costs, the cost of servicing the Ground Rent Facility, the cost of settlement xvi ----- share-based payment liabilities, income from one-off legal settlements, one-off colleague incentive payments, one-off incremental separation costs associated with the implementation of standalone IT infrastructure and integration payments, restructuring adjustments comprise one off provisions relating to facilities management restructuring, instore bakery proposition restructuring, management and back office restructure and closure of Heston & Dartford depots, one-off costs relating to the LBO Acquisition, the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, other advisor and integration fees, the impact of purchase accounting, restructuring costs from significant restructuring programmes and an add-back related to the management incentive programme.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA Margin means the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of total revenue (including fuel) for the relevant period.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: _Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, means the Group’s Adjusted_ EBITDA for a particular period as adjusted for the impact of the disposal Arthur Business sites following the CMA decision; synergies from the Arthur Acquisition; annualisation adjustments (based on the actual results for the period from January 1, 2023 to October 30, 2023 of the Acquired EG UK Target Group (as defined herein)) for the EG UK Acquisition; synergies from the EG UK Acquisition, and the annualisation of rent costs and servicing costs associated with the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. The Group believes that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA (collectively, the “EBITDA Measures”) provide useful information to investors about its results of operations for the following reasons: (a) they are, or will be going forward, among the measures used by the Board of Directors and management to evaluate the Group’s underlying operating performance, review business trends, identify strategies to improve results and make day-to-day operating decisions, and (b) they allow a comparison of the Group’s results across periods and results across companies in the industry in which the Group operates on a consistent basis, by removing the effects on the Group’s operating performance of its capital structure (such as the varying levels of interest expense), asset base and capital investment cycle (such as depreciation and amortisation) and items largely outside the control of management (such as income taxes). None of the EBITDA Measures should be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of the Group’s operating performance reported in accordance with UK IFRS. The EBITDA Measures have limitations as analytical tools, some of which are as follows: - the EBITDA Measures do not reflect the Group’s cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or contractual commitments; - the EBITDA Measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, the Group’s working capital needs; - none of the EBITDA Measures reflects the interest expense on the Group’s debt or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on the Group’s debt; - although depreciation and amortisation are non-cash charges, assets are depreciated or amortised over differing estimated useful lives and the assets being depreciated and amortised will often have to be replaced in the future, and the EBITDA Measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; - the EBITDA Measures exclude certain tax payments that may represent a reduction in cash available to the Group; - the EBITDA Measures are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in the Group’s income statement; xvii ----- - other companies in the industry in which the Group operates may calculate their own EBITDA measures differently than the Group does, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures; - our calculation and presentation of the EBITDA Measures in this Offering Memorandum is similar to, but different from, the calculation of Consolidated EBITDA under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the Senior Facilities Agreement. In particular, EBITDA reflects the adoption of IFRS 16 by the Group effective January 1, 2019, while Consolidated EBITDA calculations under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement may not. Accordingly, the EBITDA Measures do not provide precise indications as to the level of our adherence to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement; and - certain adjustments made in calculating Adjusted EBITDA and Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA contain estimates that management believes reflect the underlying results of operations and are therefore subjective in nature and reflect certain adjustments for anticipated cost savings, synergies and other estimates that may not be realised, whether in part or at all.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Like-for-like sales (excluding fuel) is a measure of annual growth of sales calculated as current year comparable sales excluding fuel (excluding VAT) versus prior year comparable sales. Current year comparable sales includes all revenue except fuel sales, sales generated from stores in the first twelve complete calendar months following grand opening, sales generated from stores that have permanently closed, sales generated from stores that have been temporarily closed for more than two consecutive calendar months within the previous twelve full calendar months, financial services commissions, ‘toyou’ sales and George international franchise sales. Sales are net of Asda Rewards earned and other discounts. Like-for-like sales growth at category level (food, grocery and merchandise and clothing) includes an allocation of Asda Rewards earned and discounts to sales, but excludes any allocation of financial services sales, and breakage on gift cards.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Free Cash Flow is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditure KPI (excluding capital expenditure associated with the implementation of a standalone IT infrastructure as we separate from Walmart (“Project Future”)). The Group uses Free Cash Flow as a liquidity measure to monitor cash flow generation. The Group presents Free Cash Flow because, in the Group’s view, it provides investors with useful information about the Group’s underlying ability to generate and extract cash flows from its various subsidiaries in order to make interest and principal payments on the Group’s debt, including the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby. Free Cash Flow is not a measure of liquidity under UK IFRS and has limitations as an analytical tool, some of which are as follows: - it does not represent the residual cash flow available for discretionary expenditures by the Group, particularly because, in the case of pre-tax free cash flow, the Group’s various tax payment obligations are not deducted from such measure; - it does not deduct cash flows used by the Group in financing activities; - it is not a direct measurement of cash flows and attempts to derive and measure the Group’s ability to service debt from income statement data of the Group. Accordingly, it does not directly correlate to the actual collection of cash. In addition, Free Cash Flow does not take into account changes in working capital of the Group that are otherwise factored in when calculating its net cash from operating activities; - it does not deduct certain other items settled in cash; and xviii ----- - other companies in the industries in which the Group operates may calculate Free Cash Flow differently than it does, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure. Underlying Cash Flow From Operations Underlying Cash Flow From Operations is calculated as Free Cash Flow plus Movement in Net Working Capital.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Movement in Net Working Capital for the year ended December 31, 2022 and year ended December 31, 2023 represents the sum of the movements in trade and other receivables, inventories, trade and other payables, and provisions as disclosed in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows. Movement in Net Working Capital for the year ended December 31, 2021 represents the sum of the movements in trade and other receivables, inventories, trade and other payables, and provisions as disclosed in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows and which have been annualised as if the Senior Notes Issuer had consolidated Asda Group Limited and its subsidiaries from January 1, 2021.The Movement in Net Working Capital for the year ended December 31, 2021 has been further adjusted to remove the impact of business rates of £251 million accrued by Asda Group Limited at December 31, 2020 and paid in the year ended December 31, 2021.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Cash conversion is defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Capital expenditure is calculated as the purchase of property, plant and equipment plus purchase of intangible assets.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Capital Expenditure KPI is defined as the total cost of assets classified as property, plant and equipment and intangible assets that the Group takes ownership of within a financial period (as opposed to the UK IFRS measurement of capital expenditure, which is based on cash flows). It excludes capital expenditure on Project Future, our investment required to separate from Walmart’s IT systems, and timing differences.

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: _Pro forma net debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s pro forma indebtedness in respect of the_ Senior Secured Notes, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes (as defined below), the Senior Facilities and the guarantees relating to the Existing Senior Notes, net of the Group’s cash and cash equivalents as at December 31, 2023, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. See “Capitalisation.” Pro forma net debt assumes that 100% of holders of targeted Existing Senior Secured Notes tender in the Richmond Tender Offer. A total of £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes were not targeted in the Richmond Tender Offer (the “Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum the Group presents certain financial measures that are not required by or presented in accordance with UK IFRS (the “Non-IFRS Measures”). The Non-IFRS Measures included in this Offering Memorandum do not alone provide a sufficient basis to compare the Group’s performance with that of other companies and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for an equivalent IFRS measure (if applicable) or any other generally accepted measure as an indicator of operating performance or liquidity. Such non-IFRS financial information has not been audited or reviewed by either KPMG LLP or Ernst & Young LLP. We believe that the presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures provides investors with additional useful information to understand our operating performance and our ability to service our debt. In addition, we believe that EBITDA is a measure commonly used by investors. The Group’s Non-IFRS Measures may not be directly comparable with similarly titled measures used by other companies. The EBITDA Measures (as defined below) and related leverage and coverage ratios are not measurements of financial performance under UK IFRS and should not be xv ----- considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with UK IFRS. You are encouraged to evaluate each of the adjustments reflected in the Group’s presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures and whether you consider each to be appropriate. In addition, each of the Non-IFRS Measures may be defined differently from the definitions of corresponding or similar terms under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. The Group’s Non-IFRS Measures have important limitations as analytical tools. Some limitations of the Non-IFRS Measures include: - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on the Group’s debt; - they do not reflect any cash income and certain other taxes that the Group may be required to pay; - they are not adjusted for all cash income or expense items that are reflected in the Group’s statements of cash flows; - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters the Group considers not to be indicative of its ongoing operations; and - in respect of Adjusted EBITDA, Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA and the other Non-IFRS Measures that reflect such measures, they reflect certain adjustments for anticipated cost savings, synergies and other estimates that may not be realised, whether in part or at all. Furthermore, you should carefully consider the risks and limitations of the Non-IFRS Measures, as they are based in part on assumptions made by the Group’s management regarding the future impact of actions that have not yet been, and which may not in fact be, implemented. For example, there is a risk that the synergies we seek to achieve may not be realised in the anticipated time frame or at all and that the magnitude of cost savings may be significantly less than expected. Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations, including in relation to the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on the Group’s UK IFRS results and using these Non-IFRS Measures only in a supplemental manner to evaluate the Group’s performance. Our primary Non-IFRS Measures are defined as follows:

Subsubsection Title: Pro forma net senior secured debt
Subsubsection Text: _Pro forma net senior secured debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s pro forma indebtedness in_ respect of the Senior Secured Notes, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Facilities, net of the Group’s cash and cash equivalents as at December 31, 2023, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. See “Capitalisation.” Pro forma net senior secured debt assumes that 100% of holders of targeted Existing Senior Secured Notes tender in the Richmond Tender Offer. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes will remain outstanding following the Transactions. To the extent that fewer eligible holders participate in the Richmond Tender Offer (or such Existing Senior Secured Notes are not accepted by us), pro forma net senior secured debt is not expected to change because we intend to hold the New Financing Proceeds (in cash or cash equivalents) on balance sheet until applied to repay such Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. Our presentation and calculation of the ratio of Pro forma net senior secured debt to Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA may be different from the calculation of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not indicative of our level of adherence to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements.”_

Subsubsection Text: _Pro forma interest expense represents the interest expense on our pro forma net debt after giving pro forma_ effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. Pro forma interest expense (i) excludes charges related to allocated debt issuance costs; (ii) excludes finance costs associated with leases (including, for the avoidance of doubt, leases in connection with the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions); (iii) excludes finance costs associated with liabilities relating to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction; and (iv) includes interest expense associated with the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes and the Senior Facilities. Pro forma interest expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to describe what our interest expense would have actually been had the above-mentioned transactions occurred at the beginning of the year ended December 31, 2023, nor does it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial condition at any future date.

Subsubsection Text: participate in the Richmond Tender Offer (or such Existing Senior Secured Notes are not accepted by us), pro forma net debt is not expected to change because we intend to hold the New Financing Proceeds (in cash or cash equivalents) on balance sheet until applied to repay such Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. Our presentation and calculation of the ratio of Pro forma net debt to Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA may be different from the calculation of Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not indicative of our level of adherence to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the xix ----- Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

This information has been provided for informational purposes only and should not xx ----- be considered indicative of actual results that would have been achieved had the as adjusted for transactions been completed on the dates indicated and do not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: Certain numerical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial data presented in millions or thousands, certain operating data, percentages describing market share and penetration rates, have been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data included in this Offering Memorandum may vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in the sections entitled “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”_ are calculated using the numerical data in the consolidated financial information of the Senior Notes Issuer or the tabular presentation of other data (subject to rounding) contained in this Offering Memorandum, as applicable, and not using the numerical data in the narrative description thereof. Figures shown as totals in some tables and elsewhere may not be exact arithmetic aggregations of the figures that precede them. xxi -----

Section Title: NOTICE TO BELGIAN INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum relates to a private placement of the Senior Secured Notes and does not constitute an offer to the public in Belgium to subscribe for or acquire the Senior Secured Notes. The Senior Secured Notes may therefore not be distributed in Belgium by way of an offer of securities to the public, pursuant to the EU Prospectus Regulation or the Belgian Law of 11 July 2018 on the public offering of investment instruments and the admission of investment instruments to trading on a regulated market, as amended, except if the Senior Secured Notes are offered solely to qualified investors within the meaning of the EU Prospectus Regulation and/or on the basis of any other exemption as referred to in Article 1, paragraph 4 of the EU Prospectus Regulation. This offering is conducted exclusively under applicable private placement exemptions and therefore it has not been and will not be notified to, and this Offering Memorandum or any other offering material relating to the Senior Secured Notes has not been and will not be approved by, the Belgian Financial Services and Markets Authority (Autorité des services et marchés financiers/Autoriteit voor financiële diensten en markten). The Offering, and any materials relating to the Offering, may not be advertised to, the Senior Secured Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to, and neither this Offering Memorandum nor any other information circular, brochure or similar document may be distributed, directly or indirectly, to, and the Senior Secured Notes should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available in Belgium to, any person qualifying as a consumer (consommateur/consument) within the meaning of the Belgian code of economic law (Code de droit _économique/Wetboek van economisch recht), as amended._ xi -----

Section Title: FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum includes “forward-looking statements,” within the meaning of the U.S. securities laws and certain other jurisdictions, based on current expectations and projections about future events, including statements under headings “Presentation of Industry and Market Data,” “Summary,” “Risk Factors,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Industry Overview,” “Business” and other sections. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, including those identified under the “Risk Factors” section in this Offering Memorandum. These include, but are not limited to: - competitive pressures and the actions of competitors in our industry; - risks relating to health and safety, sourcing, food safety and customer expectations for both food and non-food products; - risks related to the economic situation in the United Kingdom and other local, regional, national and global trends; - risks related to our reputation and brand; - changing consumer preferences and integrating them into our product selection; - risks related to the oil and gas industry affecting the demand for fuel; - risks related to climate change and the relevant regulations; - the impact on our business of unforeseen catastrophic events, such as war, terrorist attacks, civil unrest, disruptive geopolitical events, epidemics, pandemics or natural disasters; - cost inflation and fluctuations in the availability and price of food ingredients and products, commodities and packaging material, as well as in the price of electricity and fuel and labour, transportation and manufacturing costs; - inability to implement our business strategy or maintain and develop our omni-channel offer; - competitive pressures in retail industries; - the efficiency of our supply chain; - our reliance on third-party suppliers and partners to comply with obligations; - increased transportation costs or disruption to transportation services; - possibility to enter into transactions with related parties in the ordinary course of business or otherwise; - inability to keep pace with new technological developments; - risks in relation to our online presence; - disruptions in the IT infrastructure that we use; - open-source software restrictions on our ability to exploit our proprietary software and IT systems; - effective function of technology-based systems; - loss as a result of operational risk; xxxi ----- - impact of social media on our reputation; - increased expenses pursuant to commercial leases; - interference with our operations due to disruptions in our workforce or suppliers’ workforce or labour disputes; - failure to attract and retain qualified colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other changes to wage regulations; - the risk of claims by third parties on, or our failure or inability to protect, our intellectual property rights; - robbery, shop crime and fraud in our stores; - the seasonal or cyclical nature of certain of our sales and working capital requirements; - exposure to payments risks, system failures and security breaches; - risks related to the realisation of synergies and integration of acquired businesses; - our exposure to anti-competitive practices; - our dependence on the services of key executives; - increased criminal sophistication; - risks related to providing pharmacy services; - changes in results of our pharmacy business; - risks related to providing optometry services; - other risks relating to legal and regulatory issues; - other risks relating to financial, reporting and other matters; - risks relating to our acquisitions; - risks relating to our capital structure and the Senior Secured Notes; and - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum. All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this Offering Memorandum, including, without limitation, statements regarding the Group’s future financial position, risks and uncertainties related to the Group’s business, strategy, capital expenditures and the Group’s plans and objectives for future operations, may be deemed to be forward-looking statements. These forward- looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, including those identified under the “Risk Factors” section in this Offering Memorandum. Words such as “believe,” “expect,” “anticipate,” “may,” “assume,” “plan,” “intend,” “will,” “should,” “estimate,” “risk,” “target,” “objectives,” “outlook,” “probably,” “project,” “seek” and similar expressions or the negatives of these expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Although the Group believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, the Group can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to be correct. Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: We instructed CBRE Limited (“CBRE”) to value our property portfolio (the “CBRE Report”) as of December 31, 2023 (the “Valuation Date”). The CBRE Report was issued on April 12, 2024 and provides us with a valuation of the Group’s freehold and long leasehold assets, including our supermarkets, PFS, Food to Go (also referred to as Foodservice elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum) sites, industrial properties, office properties, investment properties, development and landbank sites and Distribution Centre – Held for Sale. The CBRE Report does not include de minimis non-operational parcels of lands or stores, short leaseholds, long leaseholds with no value (in each case, as assessed by the Group), or a parcel of land at Oldbury which is pending a potential planning appeal for refusal for residential development. The CBRE Report is intended to be a guide of the likely valuation of our property portfolio based on a number of assumptions including Special Assumptions (as defined below): - _Supermarket Portfolio: Market Value on the Special Assumption that each Property is let to Asda Stores Limited at CBRE’s opinion of rental value on a full repairing and insuring basis (“FRI”) for a term of 25 years commencing at the Valuation Date, with annual upward only rent reviews linked to the consumer price index (“CPI”) with a cap and collar of 1% to 4% per annum. - _Industrial Portfolio: Market Value on the Special Assumption of that each Property is let to Asda Stores Limited at CBRE’s opinion of rental value on a FRI basis for a term of 20 years, commencing at the Valuation Date, with five yearly upward only rent reviews to the higher of open market rental value or CPI subject to, a cap and collar of 2% to 4% per annum (compounded annually). - _Offices Portfolio: Market Value on the Special Assumption that each Property is let to Asda Stores Limited, at CBRE’s opinion of rental value, on an FRI basis for a term of 15 years, commencing at the Valuation Date, with five yearly upward only rent reviews linked to CPI, with a cap and collar of 1% to 3% per annum (compounded annually). - _Food to Go Portfolio (the Food to Go Portfolio comprises drive through or drive to sites occupied and _operated by a Starbucks franchisee): Market Value on the Special Assumption that each Property is let_ to Egspresso Limited in accordance with the terms of the Template Lease provided to CBRE by the Group, on an FRI basis, and at the current rent payable under licence for each of the sites as confirmed to CBRE by the Group. The Template Lease is for a term of 20 years, assumed to commence at the Valuation Date, with three yearly upward only rent reviews linked to the retail prices index with a cap and collar of 1% to 3%, compounded annually. For the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios, CBRE’s opinion of Market Value is subject to the Special Assumptions outlined above and makes no allowance for tenant incentives such as rent-free period or capital contributions. It is assumed that a purchaser has no liability with respect to capital expenditure or repair costs and that Asda Stores Limited (Egspresso Limited for Food to Go Portfolio) is responsible for outgoings including the payment of business rates and service charges but not the payment of head rents associated with long leasehold interests (where applicable). xxxvii ----- Note for the above where a lease to Asda Stores Limited (Egspresso Limited for Food to Go Portfolio) is assumed to be in place, the valuations are based on CBRE’s view of the perception of investors to the covenant strength of Asda Stores Limited (Egspresso Limited for Food to Go Portfolio), as at the valuation date. Any change in the covenant strength of Asda Stores Limited (Egspresso Limited for Food to Go Portfolio) could have material impact on the valuation reported. The Market Value of the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios, subject to the Special Assumptions referenced above, will result in valuations which differ from the Market Value of the Properties as at the valuation date. Should any different special assumption be adopted with respect to the lease, including details such as tenant covenant, rent, lease length, rent review provisions, repairing provisions (amongst other lease terms) this will also result in a difference in the valuation. - _Petrol Filling Station Portfolio: Market Value. The Petrol Filling Stations have been valued using the trading/profits methodology. - _Investment Properties: Market Value. - _Development and Land Properties: Market Value based on available information provided by the Group. - _Wigan DC: Property Held for Sale: Market Value. The CBRE Report has been undertaken in compliance with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (the “RICS”) Valuation Global Standards (the “Red Book”). The CBRE Report is informed by information provided by the Group.

Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: According to the CBRE Report, the aggregate of the individual property Market Values on the assumptions and Special Assumptions set out above comprised of 402 supermarket properties, 3 industrial properties, 2 office properties, 359 PFS properties 73 investment properties, 37 development land and landbank properties and 1 distribution centre – held for sale, as of December 31, 2023. The Properties were valued individually, and no account has been taken of any discount or premium that may be negotiated in the market if all or part of the portfolio was to be marketed simultaneously, either in lots or as a whole. The aggregate supermarket portfolio value is substantially higher than average annual investment transaction volumes in the supermarket sector. The portfolio value could only be realised over an extended period of time in order to avoid saturating the investment market. The valuation in the CBRE Report could be significantly higher than the proceeds achievable in an actual sale of the properties in the portfolio. The following table sets forth the opinion of Market Value on the assumptions and Special Assumptions set out above attributed to our properties by portfolio (such properties, the “Market Value SA Properties”), in each case as of December 31, 2023.
