Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: The CBRE Report has been prepared on the basis of the use of the relevant Properties, as supermarkets, industrial, offices, Food to Go Sites, petrol filling stations, investment properties when the CBRE Report was prepared. The values do not reflect any alternative use, intensification or development of use of these properties. The CBRE xxxix ----- Report determines the value of the relevant properties in their current use under the terms and assumptions set out below. In order to provide each opinion of value, certain trading data was provided to CBRE by the Group, where available for standalone PFSs within the PFS portfolio. No trading data has been provided for supermarkets or petrol stations connected to supermarkets. CBRE has relied on floor areas of the relevant properties as provided by Asda. The CBRE Report has been produced on a desktop basis only without inspection and it is acknowledged that this is a limitation which could impact the accuracy of the valuations reported. See “—Terms and Assumptions,” “—Methodology” and “—Limitations of _Valuations” for further assumptions providing the basis of the CBRE Report._

Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: The CBRE Report contains an overview of the relevant market prepared by CBRE. _Supermarket Portfolio_ For the year ended December 31, 2023, CBRE Prime Benchmark Supermarket Yields were 175 bps higher than in June 2022, representing the highest CBRE Benchmark Yield for the sector since 2009. The change in the CBRE Prime Benchmark Yield occurred between June 2022 and December 2022, and there was no change in 2023. Some categories of supermarket investment did however experience yield expansion in the second half of 2023, primarily those assets subject to over-rent and/or with secondary property characteristics. The CBRE Prime Benchmark Yield does not encompass all categories of supermarket investment but provides a high-level indication of the impact of market change in this period. Investment yields for supermarket investments may have changed by a greater or lesser degree than the CBRE Prime Benchmark Yield. The drivers of yield expansion during this period were: - Geo-political risk; - Negative Economic Outlook, cautious investor outlook, “Mini-Budget”; - Persistent inflationary pressure; - Rising Interest Rates leading to higher cost of capital; - Selective investor demand with an increased focus on risk and store fundamentals; and - Increased sensitivity to over-rent and income risk. Transaction volumes in 2023 were higher than £2.0 billion, above the five-year average, primarily driven by three large portfolio transactions. This demonstrated liquidity in the sector but did not result in yield contraction due to the ongoing price sensitivity outlined above.

Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: The valuation of all properties was based on their current use. CBRE made various assumptions as to tenure, letting, taxation, town planning, and the condition and repair of buildings and sites (including ground and groundwater contamination). If any of the information or assumptions on which the valuations are based are subsequently found to be incorrect, the valuation may also be incorrect and should be reconsidered. Where possible assumptions were checked against the high-level information made available by the Group. The valuation assumed that all properties included had the benefit of freehold or leasehold titles, free from restrictions that would have impacted the value. The valuation assumes that the long leasehold interests contain no restrictions that would prevent the sale of the relevant properties to a purchaser in the investment market. xl ----- The investment properties are generally situated adjacent to Asda supermarkets. The valuation assumes that either a separate sale of the investment property could be achieved through the creation of a new title, separate from the retail supermarket or that alternatively the investment property could be sold with the supermarket in the same transaction. In particular, in preparation of the CBRE Report, CBRE assumed each property to be the authorised use under planning legislation and in accordance with the use registered with the relevant regulatory agency. During the course of their engagement, CBRE did not perform site inspections, environmental audit, tests of services and amenities, investigations or tests as to the condition of the properties. CBRE did not make planning or permitting enquiries and did not examine deeds, leases or other documents relating to the title to our properties. The CBRE Report was produced based on certain assumptions, including, but not limited to, the assumptions that (i) our properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental law and are free from, environmental issues such as contamination, deleterious materials, flooding, ground conditions, invasive or protected plants or species and the properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental law, (ii) there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, all properties are free from defect, in good repair and condition and well maintained and in marketable condition, compliant with all building, accessibility and fire safety regulations and there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, (iii) properties possess a good and marketable freehold title free from any onerous restrictions or conditions, and all title, tenure, lettings, planning, taxation, statutory and local authority requirements are complied with, (iv) all properties benefit from full access and egress rights together with sufficient parking and loading facilities and are connected to all main services, (v) the floor areas supplied by Asda comply with the RICS Code of Measuring Practice (vi) no capital expenditure is required in respect of the properties and (vii) that the properties all have valid energy performance certificates compliant with the relevant regulations in each jurisdiction of the United Kingdom.

Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: All properties were valued in accordance with the Red Book and on the basis of Market Value, Market Value subject to Special Assumptions (as outlined above) or “Investment Value (Worth)” as set out above. The RICS Valuation—Global Standards contains mandatory rules, best practice guidance and related commentary for all members undertaking asset valuations. These valuation standards define Market Value as “the estimated amount for which an asset or liability should exchange on the valuation date between a willing buyer and a willing seller in an arm’s length transaction after proper marketing and where the parties had each acted knowledgeably, prudently, and without compulsion.” As required by the mandatory rules of the RICS, CBRE has confirmed to us that they do not have a material conflict of interest when preparing the CBRE Report, and that they adhere to the rules of conduct, as set out by the RICS. CBRE determined the Market Value subject to the Special Assumptions outlined above for the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios by applying a yield to their assumed rental income. The Market Value of the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios, subject to the Special Assumptions referenced above, will result in valuations which differ from the Market Value of the Properties as at the valuation date. Should a different special assumption be adopted with respect to the lease, including details such as tenant covenant, rent, lease length, rent review provisions, repairing provisions (amongst other lease terms) this will result in a difference in the valuation. For the Supermarket, Industrial and Office Portfolio and Food to Go Portfolios, the Market Value at the valuation date would be lower than the Market Value subject to the Special Assumptions referenced above. This is because the Market Value would disregard the lease referenced by CBRE in their Special Assumptions. CBRE determined the Market Value for the Petrol Filling Station Portfolio utilising the trading/profits methodology. Rental values were prepared on the basis of methods adopted by CBRE as appropriate in assessing the Market Value (subject to Special Assumptions where relevant) and are not necessarily appropriate for other purposes, nor do they necessarily accord with the definition of Market Rent in the Red Book, which is as follows: “The estimated amount for which an interest in real property should be leased on the valuation date between a willing lessor and a willing lessee on appropriate lease terms in an arm’s length transaction, after proper marketing and where the parties had each acted knowledgeably, prudently and without compulsion.” xli ----- Investment Value (or Worth) is defined in International Valuation Standards as “The value of an asset to a particular owner or prospective owner for individual investment or operational objectives.”

Section Title: VALUATION REPORT
Subsubsection Text: As used in this “Valuation Report” section, “Market Value” means the estimated amount for which an asset or liability should exchange on the valuation date between a willing buyer and a willing seller in an arm’s length transaction, after proper marketing and where the parties had each acted knowledgeably, prudently and without compulsion; “Properties” means properties owned by the Group; “Special Assumption” means an assumption that either assumes facts that differ from the actual facts existing at the valuation date or that would not be made by a typical market participant in a transaction on the valuation date; and “Investment Value (or Worth)” means the value of an asset to a particular owner or prospective owner for individual investment or operational objectives. xlii -----

Subsubsection Text: _This Offering Memorandum refers to the CBRE Report with respect to certain of the real estate portfolio owned by Asda. Valuation (including those used in the CBRE Report) are prepared on the basis of various assumptions, estimates and projections. See “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters—We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party valuation report of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete.” Moreover, the number of supermarkets, PFS, Food to Go sites, industrial properties, office properties, investment properties, development and landbank sites and Distribution Centre – Held for Sale, as described in this section and derived from the CBRE Report may differ from the number of stores listed by category in “Business—Our Store Formats.” These differences are primarily due to the fact that the CBRE Report only considers freehold and long leasehold properties and included land and non-trading sites. In contrast, the figures presented in “Business—Our Store Formats” represent ASDA’s active trading footprint across the various categories and therefore includes all leasehold properties and contains certain categorization differences._

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Till Roll data on a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We operate a significant store estate of over 1,200 large stores and convenience sites that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We are also now a major player in the UK convenience market, having added 472 convenience sites (including petrol filling stations) to our portfolio, as well as 124 stand-alone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites), following the Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition. These acquisitions have given us significant foothold in the fast-growing convenience market which, alongside our existing fuel portfolio, makes us the second-largest independent fuel owner-operator in the United Kingdom. The graph below compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers based on Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. _(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Till Roll.)_ We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and 1 ----- during the COVID-19 pandemic, followed only by a slight contraction as the pandemic eased. Since, the UK grocery retail market has experienced consistent growth, achieving a record-high size of £144.0 billion in sales for the 52week period ended December 24, 2023, according to Kantar Worldpanel, despite facing high inflation and global geopolitical tensions in 2022 and 2023. See also “Industry.” One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to offering high quality products with low prices to our customers and our wholly-owned supplier, International Procurement and Logistics Ltd (“IPL”), which enables us to take a vertically-integrated approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers, our growing presence in the convenience and foodservice market, our popular customer loyalty programme Asda Rewards, and our team of flexible and engaged colleagues. We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our revenue was £25.6 billion (including fuel), with 16.5% of sales made online, our net cash flow from operating activities was £1,245.8 million, our profit for the year was £194.5 million, and our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was £1,264 million. Excluding the results of the EG UK Business, which was acquired on October 31, 2023, and the results of the Arthur Business, which was consolidated from May 31, 2023, the chart below presents the breakdown of our 2023 revenue by product category (food, general merchandise, clothing and petrol), and channel (stores and online (including George.com)). _(Source: Asda information. Year ended December 31, 2023. Note: excluding approximately £588 million from the Arthur Acquisition, £411 million from the EG UK Acquisition and £199 million of other revenue from Asda Mobile sales, financial services sales, shipping and wrapping revenue, pharmacy revenue and, until the EG UK Acquisition, Asda On The Move.)_ Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditure KPI) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. For more information on our differentiated operating model, see “—Key Strengths—We benefit from a differentiated operating model.”_ Between 2021 and 2023, our average profit margin (defined as profit for the year divided by revenue) was 4.3%, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2% (including fuel), our cumulative cash flows from 2 ----- operating activities totalled £3,340.6 million, cumulative free cash flow was approximately £2,097 million and our average cash conversion was 68%. See “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial _Data—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_ We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our significant freehold real estate asset portfolio, which also can provide a potential source of liquidity. See “Valuation Report.” In 2023, through the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent Transaction, we have been able to, and in the future may continue to, selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities. See “—Lease Agreements.” We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. We have made more than £300 million annualized price investment since 2022 across over 1,200 lines. Within the UK value market, we have strong market shares across core grocery products (13.1%), beers, wines and spirits (12.8%), impulse grocery (12.1%), household and pet (12.1%), frozen (11.4%) and total grocery (11.4%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our category market shares range from 9.6% to 13.1% (except health and beauty)(in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal Asda data, our prices are approximately 2.5% to 6.1% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on the average of the first eight weeks in 2024, based on total goods price gap percentage). We believe our prices continue to compete with those of discounters such as Lidl and Aldi. In January 2024, we launched a new price matching programme where we have price matched Aldi and Lidl on approximately 300 comparable grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products. Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food and non-food products to customers as an accessible “one-stop shop” experience that is supported and enhanced by our strong online offer and expansion into the convenience market under the Asda Express banner. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers at our brick-and-mortar stores and through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our customers. The COVID-19 pandemic increased use of and engagement with our online platforms. In the first half of 2021, there were approximately 8.6 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with order growth from approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020) to an average of more than 773,000 weekly orders in 2021 (based on the average weekly orders for the first 26 weeks of 2021) and a peak of more than 850,000 orders during the third lockdown (based on the seven days to January 15, 2021). Online engagement has fallen from the peaks experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic, but we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). We also offer at-home delivery and customers are able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 Asda Click & Collect sites. Our business model integrates our store-based and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders. 3 ----- Our online grocery business is profitable within one of the world’s most developed online grocery markets. According to Kantar Worldpanel, as of January 21, 2024, we operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), growing our market share in a market that is 5.5% larger on a one-year basis (comparing Total Grocery Absolute Online Sales from the 52 weeks ended January 22, 2023 to the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024). Our online business is already of significant scale; the chart below shows the growth of our online sales, including a breakdown of online grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented. _(Source: Asda information.)_ According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the third-largest online clothing, footwear and accessories retailer in the United Kingdom by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and we held 8.5% of the total UK online clothing, footwear and accessories market by volume for the 24 weeks ended January 7, 2024. Combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £3.6 billion in 2023 (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 16.2% between 2018 and 2023. Additionally, our ‘toyou’ service allows customers to conveniently collect and return orders from George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 112 brands and processed more than 4.4 million parcels in the year ended December 31, 2023. We also have a strong presence in the convenience market with significant opportunity for additional expansion in this fast-growing sector. In October 2022, we took our first notable step into the convenience market after acquiring 132 sites including 129 convenience sites attached to forecourts from the Co-op (the “Co-op sites,” and such business, the “Arthur Business”) and three development sites as part of the Arthur Acquisition. We agreed to divest 13 of the Co-op sites following the recommendation of the CMA after an Initial Enforcement Order stemming from its review of the acquisition. The disposals of these sites completed across December 2023 to January 2024 for proceeds of £25.2 million. Each Co-op site included a grocery retail store between 1,500 and 3,000 square feet of space and an attached petrol filling station driving footfall. In October 2023, we acquired the majority of EG Group’s business in the United Kingdom for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion (including transaction fees). The deal represented a major step in our convenience proposition, adding 356 well-invested PFSs to our convenience portfolio, 161 of which are stand-alone and 195 of which are co-located with foodservice concessions, as well as 124 stand-alone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites). In foodservice, we acquired franchises for some of the United Kingdom’s best loved outlets, including Greggs, Subway, Burger King and Sbarro, as well as our own proprietary brand, Leon. Certain of our acquired sites also continue to benefit from an additional KFC and Starbucks non-Group branded offerings operated by third parties. Through this acquisition, we accessed another high-growth sector, foodservice, tapping into a new market which is highly complementary to Asda’s current offering. Each of the acquired sites are community-focused and strategically located at the heart of residential areas with a diversified footprint across the United Kingdom, and represent broader retail destinations with ancillary services such as parcel delivery, car wash and last mile food delivery, with opportunity to expand further. The acquired sites also present a significant 4 ----- opportunity for further synergies across Asda’s business through higher volumes, buying synergies and cost savings through operational leverage. In September 2023, we began the conversion of the Co-op sites from Co-op branding to our Asda Express banner, implementing Asda pricing across fuel and grocery upon conversion. We completed the conversion of the remaining convenience sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in March 2024. Total capex investment to convert the stores to Asda Express was approximately £17 million. We believe we will be able to bring Asda’s great value to even more customers across the United Kingdom by reaching new communities and shoppers with this smaller store format. In the converted Co-op sites, our Asda Express prices were an average of 6.1% cheaper than their corresponding prices under Co-op ownership. We also have further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in 2023 and a strong pipeline of approximately 40 sites that have been identified for potential opening in 2024. Going forward, our focus will be on the continued integration of the Co-op sites and EG UK Business into the Asda Group and delivering synergies. Currently, with our team of approximately 150,000 flexible and engaged colleagues, with around 98,000 fulltime employees, serving approximately 16.8 million customer trips each week (based on the average of weeks 37 to 40 of 2023), we are committed to and deeply invested in the UK food supply chain. Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base skewing slightly towards value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers who are attracted by our strategy to offer high quality products at low prices and with strong market shares in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. For more information about our customer mix, see “—Our Customers,” and for more information about the geographic distribution of our stores, see “—Our Store Formats.” Second, we believe we are well-positioned geographically, with a strong regional footprint across the United Kingdom. Our store footprint is strongest in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Our large and diverse store estate offers customers a variety of differentiated shopping formats. We operate 30 supercentres, 396 superstores, 153 supermarkets, 30 Asda Living stores, 499 convenience sites (including our petrol filling stations) and 124 stand-alone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites). For more information on our stores, see “—Our Store Formats.” We continue to benefit from certain support provided by Walmart through the Transitional Agreements, primarily in relation to the continued use of its IT platform. We have set up a dedicated team to facilitate the transition of our IT environment away from the Walmart ecosystem and onto a stand-alone IT solution, which we refer to as Project Future. We believe Project Future presents significant opportunities in terms of our efficiency, data capabilities, customer experience and competitive edge and are targeting complete separation from Walmart by the end of 2024. See “—Our Technology and Information Systems,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions— Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: We are a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance
Subsubsection Text: _We operate in a large, historically stable, resilient and growing industry with favourable macroeconomic tailwinds_ We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market, which has demonstrated resilient performance underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household spend on food and beverages. For example, UK GDP growth has shown stable development over the years. Although the United Kingdom’s GDP declined by 10.4% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP rebounded in 2021, returned to pre-COVID-19 levels in 2022 and amounted to approximately £2.0 trillion in 2023, according to Fitch Solutions, with an average expected GDP growth of approximately 0.4% from 2023 to 2025. 5 ----- The UK grocery retail market is also characterised by favourable demographic characteristics, including a growing population. According to ONS, the UK population is projected to grow from 67 million in 2021 to over 73 million by 2036, which is expected to result in an overall increase in the consumer base for groceries. In addition to its historical stability, the UK grocery retail market is also resilient. In 2023, grocery retail was the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom – valued at £200.5 billion on a Retail Value RSP (as defined herein) basis, according to Euromonitor. Groceries are a necessary and stable consumer expenditure, which generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets that involve more discretionary spending. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during and following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic: between 2009 and 2016, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 2.2% and between 2016 and 2023, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 3.1%, with a growth CAGR of 4.6% during the COVID-19 pandemic from 2019 and 2020. Additionally, during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, according to ONS, the percentage of average weekly household spend on food and non-alcoholic drinks remained fairly consistent at approximately 11.0%, demonstrating the market’s resilience during periods of macroeconomic difficulty, and this percentage spiked to 14.4% in 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic, reflecting an increase in at-home consumption during the pandemic. This percentage has remained relatively flat in the intervening years, ranging between 10.5% and 11.8% from 2007 to 2022. In recent years, as the COVID-19 global pandemic was waning, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sparked an energy crisis which further accelerated growing inflation and cost of living pressures. However, according to Kantar Worldpanel, the UK grocery market, comprised of grocers (and excluding non-grocers), has grown by 8.7% over the past three years (on a Till Roll basis for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, compared to the 52 weeks ended January 24, 2021). _We are the United Kingdom’s third-largest grocer, holding sizeable market share_ According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom, with 13.7% of market share and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (based on Till Roll data over 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024). For the year ended December 31, 2023, our revenue was £21.9 billion (excluding fuel). We have a network of over 1,200 large stores and convenience sites throughout the United Kingdom, with a particular focus on superstores, supermarkets, online formats and convenience. We are also the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom by value (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel), and have grown our market share over many years, maintaining this share in a much-enlarged market as customers turned to online shopping throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, we believe that we are well-positioned as a large and established business with a clear set of peers. We also believe that our multi-format, omni-channel offer positions us well to compete effectively and to continue growing our market share. Following the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, which gave us a significant foothold in the convenience and foodservice markets, our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2023 were £25,619.9 million and £1,078 million, respectively, compared to £24,477.8 million and £867 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2022. We believe that we also hold a leading position in the UK foodservice market. We cater to a broad target demographic, which we believe provides us a long-term competitive advantage. In contrast to discounters, we provide a broad range of branded and own-brand offers, while also having a more developed and established online platform. _We believe we have faced the greatest impacts of discounters on our market_ The adverse impact of discounters (primarily Aldi and Lidl) on the traditional grocers in recent years has been significant but, while we believe that discounters will continue to put pressure on the market, we believe that we and other traditional grocers have already faced the greatest impacts of this competition in the markets in which we operate and, if anything, that the discounters pose a greater challenge to other traditional grocers, who we believe are more geographically exposed to the areas where discounters are likely to focus in the near-term. As compared to our traditional grocer peers, our geographical concentration is in the North of England, Scotland and Wales, as evidenced by our number two market shares in those regions. The discounters have already 6 ----- penetrated these areas and we expect the discounters to continue to shift the focus of their expansion to the South of England, the East of England and London, where we operate fewer sites as compared to the Midlands, the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Furthermore, the catchment areas of 76.7% of our stores already contain both major discounters, Aldi and Lidl, which is a higher percentage than any of our traditional grocer competitors (the boundary used is a 10-minute drive-time radius around each point, which is consistent regardless of location type or size of store, but excludes convenience stores, and stores are only included in the count where there is both Aldi and Lidl stores present within the drive-time boundary). Therefore, we believe that our current performance already factors in the adverse impact of discounters to a large extent. Moreover, according to Kantar Worldpanel, we have stemmed the losses to the discounters in recent months, and we have reduced switching losses to the discounters to a two-year record low for the 4 weeks ended February 18, 2024. Together, Lidl and Aldi account for 17.5% of the market, with Aldi’s share at 9.8% and Lidl at 7.6% in each case on the basis of Till Roll data and according to Kantar Worldpanel for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024. However, the growth experienced by the discounters has begun to fall sharply, with Aldi posting growth behind the market for the four weeks ended January 21, 2024, and Lidl’s growth decreasing over 50% for the same period compared to the four weeks ended January 22, 2023. We also believe we can reduce losses to the discounters through our value proposition, including our opening price point range, Just Essentials. In January 2024, we also launched a new price matching programme where we have price matched Aldi and Lidl on 287 comparable grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products. _We have demonstrated resilience through downturns_ Just as our market has proven resilient in times of economic difficulty and uncertainty, our business has also proven resilient during recent economic and market downturns, including during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as through the rise of discounters in the UK grocery retail market in more recent years, particularly during 2014 to 2016. During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, we continued to perform well, achieving an average like-for-like sales (excluding fuel) growth rate of 6.1% for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2008 and 2009. Our EBITDA margins have also remained stable, ranging from 4.7% to 4.9% between 2007 and 2023. Despite the significant social and economic shifts driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, our business experienced strong overall performance, particularly in our online and supermarket formats. Overall, our food business performed consistently throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, despite an initial increase in sales due to panic buying and customers stocking-up on key staples at the outset of each of the first three lockdown periods. Following an initial decline at the beginning of the first lockdown, our general merchandise business also generally performed well throughout these lockdown periods, due to increasing purchases of homeware products. While our clothing business was initially negatively impacted during the early stage of the first UK lockdown period, we experienced improved performance in this business in line with an overall improvement of the general economy and a rebound in consumer confidence. Recently, geopolitical tensions and ongoing inflation above historical norms and the Bank of England’s target have led to uncertainty in the market and for our consumers. However, we have remained highly resilient in the face of these challenges and have kept focused on supporting customers and colleagues with cost-of-living pressures, whilst continuing to deliver strong financial results. During times of economic stress, we believe our value proposition is particularly appealing to customers and can drive sales: we benefited from increased sales generating revenue (excluding fuel) of £21.9 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to £20.4 billion for the year ended December 31, 2021. As the current high inflationary environment persists, we are focused on initiatives to support our customers in the cost-of-living crisis and protect market share by investing in price and quality, which we believe can drive growth. For example, in 2022, we also launched our new grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials by Asda that expands the range of its predecessor, Asda Smart Price, from approximately 160 to 272 products with new branding and reformulations for taste and quality. In the same year, we also rolled out a “Dropped and Locked” price campaign, where we locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items to give customers certainty around their shopping costs during the year, as well as our loyalty rewards programme, Asda Rewards, as an indirect cost-saving scheme for customers to earn cash back on their shopping. 7 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: We benefit from a differentiated operating model, including a diversified proposition with unique multi-format and multi-channel offering
Subsubsection Text: _We have well-developed own-brands_ We believe that our own-brand offers have been a key strength of our business and continue to offer growth opportunities. We have an extensive own-brand product range in our food business, with approximately 7,800 own-brand SKUs. Our approach to range development and innovation enables us to identify and meet changing customer needs and has resulted in the creation of many award-winning products; we launched approximately 950 lines in 2021, 1,547 new lines in 2022 and 1,597 new lines in 2023, and approximately 3,858 lines were reformulated in 2023. As a result of the EG UK Acquisition, we also acquired Leon, our own proprietary foodservice brand. In addition to our diverse and extensive product offer with our own-brand range, we have also been able to drive growth through service and price positioning. We leverage our IPL sourcing model to deliver value, especially in our produce, cooked meats and wine segments. In particular, the introduction and development of the opening price point range, Just Essentials, has been key to helping customers with the cost-of-living pressures in 2023 after the “Dropped and Locked” price campaigns in 2022, where we locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items to give customers certainty around their shopping costs during that year. We also offer own-brands through George, see “—The George Clothing _and George Home offers are generally profitable and well-established.” We are driven by our commitment to delivering low prices to our customers_ We believe our commitment to delivering low prices to our customers is a competitive advantage as we aim to lead on price while staying competitive on assortment and quality. We believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal Asda data, our prices are approximately 2.5% to 6.1% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on average for the first eight weeks in 2024, based on total goods price gap percentage). Following the implementation of our Aldi and Lidl price matching programme, which runs alongside our established customer value propositions, including Just Essentials, Asda Smart Price, our price locking campaigns, Fab 5 and Asda Rewards, we believe our prices can compete with those of discounters. Our low prices are supported by rigorous cost control and a commitment to affordability, which enables us to control expenses so that we can pass cost savings on to our customers. _Loyal customer base through our reward loyalty programme, Asda Rewards_ In 2022, we launched our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards. The app-based scheme enables customers to earn cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store. The programme also provides the opportunity to leverage data insights which enables us to better target investment in the customer proposition. Asda Rewards total users and penetration among customers has grown quickly, with over 7.5 million new users joining over the last 12 months and a total of 1.6 million members who have registered for Blue Light. The number of total active customers reached 4.9 million as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 30-day period, and the programme has earned around £300 million revenue in 2023. 8 ----- The following graph shows the increasing sales penetration, or the number of sales linked to customers using Asda Rewards since its inception, which reached 50.6% in the week of Christmas in 2023: By the end of 2023, we saw approximately 47% of sales linked to Asda Rewards. We have found that after joining Asda Rewards, members spend more than non-members within every segment and are more likely to become repeat customers. In particular, we believe that members spend more than 10% after joining the programme (measured through tokenised payment cards) and for our high value customers, we believe that this equates to an incremental addition of approximately £11 per week. By driving sales volume, the loyalty scheme has been incrementally profitable since shortly after its launch, and the Retail Media segment has achieved £103.1 million profit. The following graph shows the average sales by quarter of Asda Rewards members versus non-members. _We operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, which is profitable_ The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one of the highest rates of the population using the internet. There has been a significant shift in the grocery retail market away from brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing as demographic trends, greater mobile and device usage, improved service proposition and technological advances in applications and customer interfaces have driven 9 ----- increasing penetration rates in the online grocery retail market. We believe we are poised to take advantage of these favourable consumer trends, as we have already established ourselves in the rapidly growing UK online grocery retail market and our store and warehouse footprint is strategically positioned across attractive geographic areas to service the growing demand for groceries online. According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended January 21, 2024. Having responded quickly to the increase in demand for online shopping during the COVID-19 pandemic, we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). As a result of our strong performance in the online market, combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com rapidly increased from previous years to a total of £3.6 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023 (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales) as compared to £3.3 billion for the year ended December 31, 2022 (of which £2.9 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales). According to Kantar Worldpanel, we hold an 8.5% share of the UK online clothing, footwear and accessories market (in terms of volume of units sold on a 24-week basis as of January 7, 2024). We believe there is greater scope for our online profitability to improve further. We expect that the demand for online groceries will continue to be strong as customers increasingly adopt online shopping as a more permanent and preferred way to purchase groceries. _The George Clothing and George Home offers are generally profitable and well-established_ We launched our clothing offer, George, in 1990 and it is the third-largest clothing footwear and accessories retailer in the United Kingdom by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and is the leading UK childrenswear retailer with 18.7% market share by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024, in each case according to Kantar Worldpanel. Despite challenges to this product category overall, our online clothing sales have increased from £379.3 million for the year to December 31, 2021 to £423.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, with 82% of all sales made via mobile devices in 2023. We believe this demonstrates our strength in the online segment, which is a key part of our operating model. Additionally, we have expanded the George branded offer to include general merchandise, including through collaborations with strategic partners. We have extended product ranges with partners who specialise in certain categories, have a strong affinity fit with our existing customers and bring complementary expertise and reputation, such as in homeware with Stacey Solomon and Claire’s in jewellery and accessories. The George Home brand generated approximately £747.7 million in sales and contributed approximately 50.0% of our total general merchandising sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Sales by the George Home brand grew at a CAGR of approximately 3% between the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2023. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories generally have higher margins than our food product categories.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: We benefit from a well invested and vertically integrated model and are supported by a significant asset base
Subsubsection Text: _We benefit from vertically integrated procurement through IPL_ We believe that we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via our captive sourcing arm, IPL, which enables us to take a vertically integrated approach to procurement. We believe that IPL provides us with valuable sourcing differentiation as compared to our competitors. IPL is one of the largest importers of produce in the United Kingdom and, while IPL is a group company and exclusively serves Asda, it is also our largest supplier. The aim of our vertically integrated procurement model is to consolidate import activity for key products and reduce our overall costs. In 2023, we purchased £1,724 million of our products through IPL. The foundation of IPL’s cost-price advantage is that it eliminates the “middleman” who typically serves as the intermediary in the supply chain, thereby giving us greater control of costs, quality and supply of a diverse range of products. We have an extensive IPL footprint across the United Kingdom, with nine processing facilities across the country and more than 3,793 colleagues as of the year ended December 31, 2023. Our IPL product mix is diversified according to our needs, with a mix of 56% fruit and vegetables, 28% protein, 7% plants and flowers, 6% beverages and 3% grocery in 2023. Additionally, we have been able to build upon and benefit from our supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity and make progress in our sustainability agenda. For example, through IPL we are supporting industry projects on water stewardship in our produce supply chain. 10 ----- We also believe that IPL has provided greater stability and allowed us greater control over our supply chain now that the United Kingdom has left the European Union’s single market and customs union. IPL’s EU supply chain ensures IPL takes control of the transport direct from its suppliers’ sites. This allows IPL to appoint experts in haulage and freight clearance, removing delays at the various border control points and ensuring the most efficient supply chain. IPL’s logistics team are based in Spain, which is the top EU exporting country into the United Kingdom for fresh produce. This has ensured IPL quickly understands any impacts to supply chains, such as localised disruption by the farming fraternity, allowing IPL to take actions to protect the supply chains. _We are supported by a significant asset portfolio_ We are supported by a well-invested and geographically diversified store estate and benefit from a total real estate portfolio of £8.5 billion, which is comprised of freehold and long leasehold assets, and includes £756 million of certain properties owned by the Group but pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under the Ground Rent Facility. As of December 31, 2023, 77% of our asset portfolio was comprised of freehold or long leaseholds, based upon attributable EBITDAR per property (less central allocations), with certain adjustments made to align the calculation methodology across the Group’s properties following the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition. Of this 77%, 12% is attributable to certain properties that are pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under the Ground Rent Facility. Our valuable real estate portfolio also provides a potential source of liquidity and underpins our strong ongoing cash flow generation. On August 10, 2023, we completed the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions with Realty Income, which resulted in proceeds of £646 million that were used to finance a portion of the EG UK Acquisition. On December 12, 2023, we also completed the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction with a number of investors, which resulted in proceeds of £400 million that were used to repay a bridge loan that was used to finance a portion of the EG UK Acquisition. In the future we may continue to selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities. See “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—2023 Sale and Leaseback Facility” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Ground Rent Transactions – Ground Rent Facility.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: We have strong exposure to the resilient convenience and PFS channel with upside through synergies
Subsubsection Text: In December 2022, we opened our first two convenience sites under the Asda Express banner. We also have further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in early 2024 and a strong pipeline of approximately 30 sites that have been identified for potential opening in 2024. The Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition gave us a strong presence in the fast-growing convenience market, having added 472 convenience sites and petrol filling stations to our portfolio. The Arthur Acquisition comprised 116 convenience stores with PFSs attached and the EG UK Acquisition comprised 356 PFSs (including two that have since been shut) with convenience stores and 124 standalone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites). These acquisitions accelerated our growth in the convenience sector and strategic ambition to bring our value heritage as a consumer champion to even more customers. We completed the conversion of all the sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in March 2024. See also “— _Business Strategy—Location.” We believe our recent acquisitions will drive our results by delivering additional net_ working capital and EBITDA synergies as we integrate buying for the wider convenience network into Asda and seek to drive higher volumes and growth as a result of price investment in the fuel and grocery offering. We also expect synergies to arise from range optimisation, monetisation of customer data, our increased scale, in-store marketing income, improvement in fuel card terms and operational efficiencies. See “Summary Historical Consolidated _Financial Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_ According to Euromonitor, in 2023, the UK convenience market was approximately £44 billion and the UK foodservice market was approximately £67 billion, and the UK convenience market has grown at a faster rate than the UK grocery retail market relative to 2015. Our exposure to these highly attractive and profitable convenience and foodservice markets is underpinned by favourable structural factors including (i) the rise of shopping locally, (ii) the evolution of shopper missions, (ii) the shift of our offering to a broader format of retail destinations, and (iv) our shift into the foodservice and consumption market. 11 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: We have achieved a successful financial profile
Subsubsection Text: We have achieved a successful financial profile that is underpinned by strong profit margins, Adjusted EBITDA margins, cash flows from operating activities, Free Cash Flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditure KPI) and Cash Conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. Between the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2023, our average profit margin (defined as profit for the year divided by revenue) was 4.3%, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2% (including fuel), our cash flows from operating activities totalled £3,340.6 million, cumulative free cash flow was approximately £2,097 million and our average cash conversion was 68%. This strong financial performance is driven by our commitment to deliver low prices to our clients, diverse product offer, strong own-brand grocery offer, expanded convenience and foodservice offerings and well-established George-branded product categories. Our Adjusted EBITDA margins have benefitted from our cost transformation programmes, which have generated SG&A cost savings without compromising the low prices we offer our customers. We are a structurally negative working capital business driven by growth in payables, and the beneficial payment terms to suppliers versus payments received by consumers instantly on purchase. We delivered a strong net working capital performance in the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, with our active working capital management, resulting in increased working capital inflows in those two years. Furthermore, we have pursued a disciplined approach to our capital expenditure over time, with the aim of maintaining and improving our real estate platform rather than opening new sites.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: We have a highly experienced and execution focused management team
Subsubsection Text: We are led by an experienced, entrepreneurial management team that is committed to continuing our strong track record of growth, with a focus on product quality, delivering low prices to our customers and exceptional customer service. Together with Michael Gleeson, the Group’s chief financial officer, our executive committee provides strong, dynamic and deep, leadership. We also benefit from the long-standing experience, market expertise, business relationships and industry know-how of our shareholder, Mohsin Issa, who is leading the management team on an interim basis. As we continue to expand our footprint and achieve our business goals, we plan to take advantage of opportunities to further enhance and supplement our management talent, both from inside our organisation as well as with external candidates. We have made key investments into our digital marketing team and expect to onboard a new chief digital officer in the third quarter of 2024. Our search for a permanent chief executive officer is robust and ongoing.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and a significant asset backing, as further described below.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our proposition strategy is about creating more reasons to shop with us than anywhere else and providing an offering that meets all of our customers’ needs under one roof. Demonstrating the strength in our offering across the store, we recently won four awards at the 2023 annual Grocer Gold Awards, including the Grocer 33 Price award for the 26th consecutive year, the ‘Own Label Range of the Year’ award for our Just Essentials product range, the ‘Consumer Initiative of the Year’ award for our Kids Eat for £1 Cafe Meals scheme and ‘Online Supermarket of the Year.’ We believe we are well established as the lowest-price full-selection retailer in the United Kingdom, and we lead the traditional grocers in terms of lowest price. Moving forward, we intend to reduce the complexity of the customer shopping experience so that we can reflect that benefit to customers’ prices where it matters most in our value proposition. We aim to simplify our value proposition to maintain price leadership, further improve quality perception and continue to improve customer experience in-store and online. We also strive to create a more hassle-free customer experience in-store with our digital transformation. For example, we have broadened our Scan&Go services that allows customers to use a handset or the Scan&Go mobile app to scan and bag items as they shop and utilise a dedicated checkout area for quick and easy payment. We have also transformed our approach to rewarding customer loyalty through the launch of Asda Rewards in 2022, our innovative, app-based loyalty scheme that gives customers Asda pounds, not points. Customers earn cash back on their shopping, with regularly updated missions and star products enabling extra savings. Since 2022, more than 5 million of our customers enrolled in Asda Rewards and as of December 31, 2023, Asda Rewards resulted in a total of £383 million customer savings since it was first trialled. Following this initial success, we plan to look into different ways to offer even further value to our customers, “gamefy” the application and to monetise and utilise the data it provides. We believe that this approach will allow us to grow our customer analytics platform to bring better, faster and deeper customer insights to our investment decisions and to improve the overall customer experience by personalising our offer. Through Asda Rewards, we are also able to roll out seasonal offerings such as our Christmas Saver Cashpot that enabled customers save up their cash pot earnings in preparation for the festive period, with approximately 1.7 million members saving approximately £50 million into their 2023 Christmas Cashpots. We offered saving incentives where customers who transferred savings earned from their Asda Rewards cash pot into their Christmas Saver Cashpot received additional cash bonuses based upon the amount transferred. With improved availability and seasonal offerings, we continue to earn our place in customers’ minds as the retailer for key celebrations throughout the year. We believe that such rewards incentives will further drive customer loyalty and retention. In non-food, we have begun trialling a number of initiatives across clothing and general merchandise in our “lab stores.” We use the lab-store as a platform to test new technologies, concepts and ideas and assess what works for customers and colleagues. For example, we tested a “shop within a shop” concept with our Big Asda Toyshop, which had its own merchandising and look and feel, in eight stores in 2022. Following strong sales, we have rolled it out in an additional 121 stores. For Halloween in 2023, we trialled a new approach to the store entrance, creating an inviting and festive shopping environment. Through these and other concepts, we have overhauled the in-store shopping experience, radically rethinking our use of space, lighting and merchandising and are looking at how to replicate with new themes and categories on a regular basis across the portfolio. We also aim to grow Asda as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of relevant branded products and services, while also building upon our existing capabilities, such as logistics and our customer-facing ‘toyou’ proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of appealing “one-stop-shop” store destinations for more customer missions. We believe these partnerships will not only provide additional income through rent and revenue share models but will also create a positive effect on our overall business.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our goal under our product strategy is to make desirable products affordable. We aim to modernise our brand and deliver the best value to our customers, helping them fulfil their money saving goals without needing to compromise on quality. 13 ----- We began our product transformation in 2022 with the overhaul of our opening price point range, Just Essentials by Asda. This line is a key part of our strategy to make desirable products that are affordable. In 2023, we also locked in the price of over 500 popular products until the end of the summer to give customers certainty around their budgets. We delivered three key price drops in 2023, lowering the prices on over 800 high volume lines, including in October 2023 where we lowered prices by an average of 14% on many of our popular products. We will look to continue dropping prices where possible and aim to pass price drops straight onto customers where we can. As inflation is starting to ease in certain areas, we are working with our suppliers and IPL to ensure our customers feel the benefit of those reductions. As part of this brand reset, we are also focused on our mid-tier value and range offerings, investing throughout our own brand offering to drive customers to reappraise us on quality. We launched our new scratch cooking and meal solutions ranges and have introduced new own-label meal solutions brands, including Health Menu, Take-Out Club, the Indian-inspired Bom Bahia and pan-Asian-inspired House of Yum ranges, and Bistro, a selection of hearty pub-style favourites. These ranges are designed to compete directly with the likes of M&S Gastropub and takeaway brands, a key opportunity as customers switch to at-home spending amidst cost-of-living pressures. We launched ambitious quality and taste match campaigns during 2023 to demonstrate our confidence in the quality and value of our products, including Harrod’s blind taste test products and M&S Taste Match campaign across a range of popular household items. In the M&S Taste Match campaign, hundreds of our products were voted “as tasty” or “tastier than” their M&S equivalents, but at a lower cost, in a blind taste testing conducted by Cambridge Market Research. Foodservice and chilled categories also represent an avenue for growth and are important in moving the dial on customers’ quality perception. A strong proposition in these categories is essential for fulfilling our ambition of becoming a key market player in the convenience market. In non-food, we launched ‘Exclusively at George’ in May 2023, which was dubbed the first-ever supermarket elevated fashion collection. It put a spotlight on high-quality fabrics, with a focus on both quality and style. Following the success of ‘Exclusively at George,’ we introduced the Studio Edit, which will be a permanent premium arm of the George range, with a focus on wardrobe staples, premiere fabrics and finishing touches typically found in more expensive pieces. Continuing in the elevated lifestyle space, we partnered with TV presenter and influencer Stacey Solomon to create the homeware range, ‘At Home with Stacey Solomon Exclusively for George Home’ in August 2023. We believe these lines showcase our ability to deliver high quality, highly desired products across a broad range of categories to meet our customers’ every day needs.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: As part of our location strategy, we seek to be accessible however and whenever we are needed. We believe that customers seeing Asda in new locations and new formats will help us broaden our customer base. In 2022, we made significant progress in our location strategic priority area, increasing our expansion into the convenience sector. Our core focus in our location strategy is on the successful integration of the recent Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition, which together added 472 convenience sites and petrol filling stations and 124 standalone foodservice sites to our portfolio. In September 2023, we began the conversion of the Co-op sites from Co-op branding to our Asda Express banner, implementing Asda pricing across fuel and grocery upon conversion. We completed the conversion of the remaining convenience sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in March 2024. We believe we will be able to bring Asda’s great value to even more customers across the United Kingdom by reaching new communities and shoppers with this smaller store format. In the converted Co-op sites, our Asda Express prices were an average of 6.1% cheaper than their corresponding prices under Co-op ownership. We also have further organic Asda Express openings planned to bolster our location strategy. Going forward, our focus will be on the continued integration of the Co-op sites and EG UK Business into the Asda Group and delivering synergies. Beyond our expansion into the convenience market, we plan to continue to drive growth and market share gains in the online channel through the expansion of our online grocery channel’s capacity to meet increased consumer demand. We continue to seek to optimise our online grocery operating model and further develop our already profitable economic model through the ongoing assessment of our online product range and promotions, further monetisation of our e-commerce assets, as well as other initiatives. In addition to growing our core online grocery 14 ----- business, we are targeting further growth by expanding the reach of our online platform and expanding our delivery services. We expect to provide customers with greater and more convenient access to our product range by accelerating our last-mile delivery capabilities via partnerships.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The goal of our experience strategy is to make shopping with us easy and enjoyable. We are focused on operational excellence, testing scalable operational innovation for end-to-end service improvement. We are currently looking at changes to further improve availability in store, improve stock flow and drive effective labour management. For example, we are trialling artificial intelligence (“AI”) cameras to identify gaps in product availability and optimise stock management in store. We believe this is an example of how AI could significantly help improve the customer experience and optimise our colleagues’ time to focus on delivering high quality service. We are also striving towards a best-in-class shopping experience that gives customers the range they desire in an environment that’s easy to navigate. Our current store design had not been updated for many years, so our near-term strategy includes modernising our stores to facilitate a better customer journey. In order to ensure our colleagues are equipped to offer a best-in-class customer experience, we are also investing in colleague hours in-store via a combination of additional temporary colleagues in stores and opportunities for existing colleagues to work over-time if they wish to. Increasing the numbers of hours being worked in store means that more colleagues are on hand to serve customers across the busy and peak periods (such as Christmas). Alongside value and choice, we believe that service is a key quality signifier for customers and impacts where they choose to shop. To help further this strategy, we also hired David Hills as our new Chief Customer Officer in September 2023, who brings a wealth of retail and grocery-sector experience to our business and will play a pivotal role in providing our shoppers a hassle-free and pleasurable experience when shopping at Asda.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Commitment to ESG targets and building a sustainable business for the long term
Subsubsection Text: Part of our strategy is to ensure our Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) commitments are fully integrated into our wider business transformation plans. We believe the sales opportunity driven by eco-active shoppers, or shoppers who are highly concerned about the environment and are actively taking actions to reduce their waste, is expected to reach approximately £2 billion across the market by the year 2027. We believe ESG is a key decision enabler for customers in deciding where to shop and that setting the right ESG plan is beneficial for our customers, colleagues and investors. Our ESG strategy is focused on four pillars: healthy and sustainable choices (providing our customers with a product mix that is healthier and with a lower environmental impact), energy and climate change mitigation (reducing our greenhouse gas emissions), nature positive (sourcing and farming which respects and restores) and waste (reducing food, product and packaging waste). In August 2023, we published our third ESG report (based on 2022 data), which provided an annual update on the progress we had made towards supporting these pillars and meeting our environmental targets and in October 2023, we received our first external assessment of our ESG strategy, with an entity score of 54 points and an overall rating of 3 (on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the strongest) by the financial services ratings’ agency Sustainable Fitch. Sustainable Fitch positively assessed our human and labour rights policies, gender balanced workforce and well-defined management systems, as well as our actions to increase the share of non-high fat, salt and sugar own-brand products and improve food nutrition labelling. Obtaining this rating is part of our ongoing commitment to transparently reporting on our efforts to achieve our ESG targets. For example, we have continued to reduce our operational carbon footprint, with emissions down 8% from 2021 to 2022 and 40% from 2015 to 2022, and we believe we are well on the way to achieving our commitment to reduce emissions 50% by 2025 and reaching net zero emissions by 2040. We have committed to setting a near-term science-based carbon reduction target, including a specific Forests, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) target. These targets have been submitted to the Science-Based Targets Initiative (“SBTi”) for validation. The proposed targets were submitted before the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition so reflect our footprint prior to these acquisitions. In terms of waste reduction, over 90% of our own brand packaging was recyclable in 2022, and we donated over 2,000 tonnes of surplus food through our charity partnerships, both reducing waste and supporting those in need during challenging times. We increased the proportion of our own-label packaging that can be recycled at the kerbside to 88% (with a further 4.7% recyclable in store) and introduced the Refill Price Guarantee on our in-store refill zones, 15 ----- guaranteeing that unpackaged products are cheaper than their packaged equivalents. We reused or repurposed 86% of our operational waste and sent zero operational waste to landfill in 2022. We believe we have made significant progress towards our ESG goals but that there is still much to do, and we will continue working to build a sustainable business for the long term.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our primary strategy is designed to provide great value for money and to bring brighter living within everyone’s reach. Our strategy is centred around four primary pillars which guide our business priorities and planning: proposition, product, location and experience. These pillars are underpinned by our commitment to running an efficient operating model, driving the business through improved data and systems and an ESG programme that builds a sustainable business for the long term. Through our strategy, we seek to maintain and extend our advantage in offering value for money by ensuring that our prices are competitive and reassuring shoppers on quality. We aim to provide a consistent, trusted experience, incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere through the creation of attractive store propositions and partnerships that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while increasing the number of self-serve opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth where customers care, expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience. We believe that our strategy provides a clear path to achieve our ambition of becoming the second-largest grocer in the United Kingdom by market share. 12 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. We have built our business on listening to our diverse range of customers, offering what they need at the best value and bringing innovation to the UK market. We were founded in 1965 through the merger of the Asquith family grocery business with the Associated Dairies company in Yorkshire. Our name is derived from this historic merger, combining “Asquith” and “Dairies” to form “Asda.” Founded in the North of England, we have a rich history, heritage and culture. The Asquith family has deep ties to the grocery business, W.R. Asquith having run a butcher’s shop in Knottingley, West Yorkshire, which eventually expanded to seven shops. W.R. Asquith’s sons, Peter and Fred, went on to create the United Kingdom’s first self-service supermarket in Castleford, introducing food discounting to the UK grocery market, and eventually co-founded Asda. In parallel to the growth of the Asquith family business, a group of West Riding dairy farmers joined forces, eventually becoming Associated Dairies & Farm Stores Limited led by Arthur Stockdale. Arthur’s son, Sir Noel Stockdale, went on to co-found Asda with Peter and Fred Asquith. In 1965, we acquired GEM, a major U.S. discount retailer operating in the United Kingdom. With the addition of general merchandise to the former GEM stores, we introduced the superstore to the UK market, a landmark event in the development of UK retailing. To complement this offer, Peter Asquith also introduced the first discounted petrol filling station. By 1970, we operated over 30 stores and were poised to expand beyond our original home in the North of England. Throughout the 1970s, we grew our presence in the South of England, opening stores in Newport, Plymouth and Gosport. In 1977, we launched our “Asda Price” TV adverts, featuring the “pocket tap” which came to be the official sign language for Asda. By the end of the 1970s, we were operating over 80 stores and opened our 100[th] store in 1981. Throughout the 1980s, we focused on expanding our distribution capabilities, opening seven new distribution centres strategically located throughout the United Kingdom by 1985. In 1987, our flagship Watford store opened, another landmark in UK retailing, and featured the longest-ever checkout bank at the time, with 45 checkouts. In 1988, we opened our headquarters in Leeds, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher overseeing the opening ceremonies. In 1989, George Davies was asked to produce a line of clothing for us that was high-quality, high-value and had its own identity: the pioneering George brand was born. In the 1990s, we developed the Asda Way of Working, an innovative framework for a new organisational structure that focuses on our stores and promotes colleague involvement, which set the stage for the Asda culture of today. In 1996, we opened our first Asda Pharmacy location in Harrogate, North Yorkshire and launched our “Tickled Pink” campaign to raise money for the fight against breast cancer, a partnership that continues to this day. In 1998, we began our online retail operations with a dedicated depot in Croydon. In 1999, we joined the Walmart family, becoming part of the world’s largest retailer. Throughout the early 2000s, we continued to grow and innovate, expanding our online and Click & Collect offers, opening our first Asda Living store and our first Eco Store, winning awards for the value we offer customers as well as for the positive environment we create for colleagues, launching our Free From and Extra Special offers, launching stand-alone PFSs as well as Asda Opticians. In 2015, we celebrated our 50[th] birthday and George’s 25[th] birthday. Asda has continued to innovate, including the United Kingdom’s first parcel tower, which allows customers to collect online orders in less than 60 seconds, and voice-activated shopping through Google Home. 16 ----- In October 2020, the Issa Brothers and TDR Capital reached an agreement with Walmart to acquire a majority stake in Asda, with Walmart retaining an equity interest in the business. Following regulatory approval, the deal closed in February 2021 and our new owners were able to take operational control in June 2021.
