In October 2022, we took our first significant step into the convenience market and acquired 116 convenience sites from the Co-operative Group (“Co-op”) as part of the Arthur Acquisition, expanding our community-focused reach of retail destinations and petrol filling station driving footfall in strategic locations at the heart of residential areas. On October 31, 2023, we greatly expanded our footprint in the convenience market and completed the purchase of the majority of the EG UK business for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion (including transaction fees), adding a total of 480 sites to our portfolio (consisting of 356 petrol filling stations, two of which have since closed, and 124 foodservice sites) through the EG UK Acquisition. In March 2024, we completed the conversion of the acquired Co-op sites and EG UK Business sites to Asda Express. We look forward to exciting prospects in this new market, including the expansion of the Asda Express convenience format to new locations. Our values are rooted in service to our customers, respect for the individual, striving for excellence and acting with integrity. We pursue our values with the support of our colleagues, culture and technology.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement originally provided for (i) the Original Facility A, (ii) the Original Facility B, (iii) the Original Revolving Facility and (iv) a further revolving credit facility in principal amount of £190,000,000 which was voluntarily cancelled by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in full on September 16, 2021. In connection with the EG UK Acquisition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into an additional revolving facility 1 in principal amount of £117,272,727 (the “Additional Revolving Facility 1”) and an additional revolving facility 2 in principal amount of £50,000,000 (the “Additional Revolving Facility 2”, and together with Additional Revolving Facility 1, the “Additional Revolving Facilities”), which increased the Original Revolving Facility by a principal amount of £167,272,727. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer further entered into the Private Placement Facility. It is contemplated that on or around the Issue Date, (i) the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby and (ii) the Senior Facilities Agreement will be amended and restated via an amendment and restatement agreement to amend the terms thereof and constitute the Senior Facilities as at the Issue Date. On or around the Issue Date, we will use the gross proceeds from the New Financing and cash on hand to (i) partially repurchase the Existing Senior Secured Notes, (ii) prepay and cancel Original Facility B in full (the “Facility B Refinancing”) and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. In addition, New Facility A will also be utilised on or around the Issue Date and the proceeds of such utilisation will be applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards financing part of the outstanding amounts under the Original Facility A, thereby effecting a maturity extension of the commitments of consenting lenders (the “Facility A Maturity Extension”). Likewise, the New Revolving Facility will also be established on or around the Issue Date and it is expected that the commitments under the Original Revolving Facility will be cancelled, thereby effecting a maturity extension of the commitments of consenting lenders (the “Revolving Facility Maturity Extension”). In this Offering Memorandum, we refer to the following as the “Transactions”: (i) the New Financing and the use of proceeds therefrom, including the making and consummation of the Richmond Tender Offer, (ii) the establishment of New Facility A and New Revolving Facility and use of proceeds therefrom, (iii) the Facility A Maturity Extension, the Revolving Facility Maturity Extension and the Facility B Refinancing, (iv) the payment of fees and expenses related to the Transactions, and (v) to the extent not used to repurchase and cancel Existing Senior Secured Notes in connection with the Richmond Tender Offer, prepay and cancel the Original Facility B in full and pay the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions, the holding of the New Financing Proceeds on balance sheet (in cash or cash equivalents) and the application thereof to repay any Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, as applicable, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to 17 ----- the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which were not targeted under the Richmond Tender Offer, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, will not be included in the repayment described in clause (v) above and therefore will remain outstanding following the Transactions.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we have launched an offer to purchase for cash our outstanding Existing Senior Secured Notes held pursuant to Regulation S under the Securities Act (the “Richmond Tender Offer”) up to a certain maximum acceptance amount, expected to be set not to exceed (x) the sum of (i) the aggregate net proceeds from the New Financing and (ii) £415 million less (y) the sum of (i) the aggregate amount required for the prepayment and cancellation of the Original Facility B in full and (ii) the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions. Pursuant to the terms of the Richmond Tender Offer, we will not accept any tenders with respect to Existing Senior Secured Notes held pursuant to Rule 144A under the Securities Act. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which were not targeted in the Richmond Tender Offer, will remain outstanding following the Transactions. The Richmond Tender Offer is being made upon terms and subject to the conditions set out in the separate tender offer memorandum dated April 26, 2024 (the “Tender Offer Memorandum”). The Richmond Tender Offer is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions, including, but not limited to, the consummation of the New Financing, on terms satisfactory to the Issuer in its sole discretion. We cannot assure you that the Richmond Tender Offer will be consummated in accordance with its terms, or at all, or that any of the Existing Senior Secured Notes will be tendered and purchased in the Richmond Tender Offer. The Offering is not conditioned upon the consummation of the Richmond Tender Offer. The maximum amount of Existing Senior Secured Notes and the maximum amount of each series of Existing Senior Secured Notes accepted in the Richmond Tender Offer will be determined by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in its sole and absolute discretion, subject to the terms of the Richmond Tender Offer. This Offering Memorandum does not relate to the Richmond Tender Offer, which is only made upon the terms and subject to the conditions set out in the Tender Offer Memorandum, and is only made to certain eligible holders of Existing Senior Secured Notes holding book-entry interests in the Regulation S global note.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a public limited company incorporated and existing under the laws of England and Wales. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is resident in the United Kingdom for tax purposes. Since the date of its incorporation, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s activities have related only to acting as an investment and financing holding company. The registered name of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Bellis Acquisition Company plc and it was incorporated on September 3, 2020 under registration number 12855280 and re-registered as a public limited company on December 18, 2020 for the purpose of consummating the LBO Acquisition Transactions. Its registered office and its principal place of business is Asda House, Great Wilson Street, Leeds, England, LS11 5AD, United Kingdom.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger of their UK-based Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP’s EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was established, which the Issa Brothers now lead as co-CEOs. The business, globally headquartered in Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery & merchandise and foodservice offer. The Issa Brothers were honoured as Commanders of the Order of the British Empire by Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II in her Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution to business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom. In July 2023, Zuber Issa received an Honorary Fellowship from the University of Central Lancashire. TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over €15.0 billion of committed capital across four European buyout funds. Founded in 2002, TDR Capital LLP has been 18 ----- creating value by applying a high-impact approach to investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven value-based and operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and operating professionals from its single office in London. TDR’s strong returns have been driven by combining ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital preservation. TDR Capital LLP takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional support. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, TDR has invested in 25 portfolio companies across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors. Walmart Inc. is a people-led, technology-powered omni-channel retailer dedicated to helping people around the world save money and live better – anytime and anywhere – by providing the opportunity to shop in retail stores and through eCommerce, and to access our other service offerings. Each week, Walmart serves over 240 million customers who visit approximately 10,500 stores and numerous eCommerce websites under 19 countries. Walmart is engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S., Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China, India and Mexico.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On October 31, 2023, Project America Bidco Ltd, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer, completed its acquisition of Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited, comprising the majority of EG Group’s UK business (the “EG UK Business”). The EG UK Business is a fuel, grocery and foodservice retailer operating throughout the United Kingdom and was acquired for an enterprise value £2.07 billion on a cash-free, debt-free basis. The final proceeds at the point of acquisition were £2.1 billion (including transaction fees) and comprised: - £401 million of equity from the Group’s shareholders in the form of a subordinated shareholder loan; - the Private Placement Facility; - £646 million of proceeds from a sale and leaseback transaction of 24 stores completed in August 2023, with a further store that completed in November 2023 (the “2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions”); - a bridge loan of £290 million (the “America Bridge Loan”); and - £88 million of cash on balance sheet. The America Bridge Loan was refinanced and the cash on balance sheet was replenished via a ground rent property transaction on 55 of Asda’s freehold and long leasehold property sites, which completed in December 2023 with proceeds of £400 million (the “2023 **Ground Rent Transaction”). The remaining proceeds from the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction were retained as cash on balance sheet, in part repaying cash utilised to fund the EG UK Acquisition and to settle transaction fees. For more detail on the Private Placement Facility, the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Facility and the Ground Rent Transaction, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The shareholders are involved in active discussions regarding Zuber Issa ceasing to continue as a shareholder of the Group in which he holds his participation through his 50% ownership in Able Holdings Limited and consequent withdrawal from his directorships in the Asda business. Upon the completion of a transaction whereby Zuber Issa would no longer be a shareholder of the Group, it is expected that he would resign from his directorships in all Bellis and Asda entities. The discussions remain ongoing and there can be no assurance that a definitive agreement will ultimately be entered into or that any such transaction will take place.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: _The unaudited preliminary financial results presented below are derived from the Group’s unaudited management accounts. This information has not been audited or reviewed, nor have any procedures been performed_ 19 ----- _by the Group’s independent auditors with respect thereto, and it has not been prepared with a view towards compliance with UK adopted International Accounting Standards. Accordingly, you should not place undue reliance on it, and no opinion or any other form of assurance is provided with respect thereto. The Group’s unaudited preliminary financial results are based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to change, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of the Group’s financial or operational results for the three-month period ended March 31, 2024. Although the Group believes the management estimates and unaudited preliminary financial information and the assumptions on which they are based to be reasonable, the Group’s actual results as of and for the three-month period ended March 31, 2024 to be published in the coming months may vary from the information contained below and such variations could be material._ Based on preliminary management accounts, we estimate that our revenue (excluding fuel) for the threemonth period ended March 31, 2024 was £5,305 million (of which we estimate £5,109 million was attributable to the standalone Asda business (excluding acquisitions), £65 million was attributable to sales from the Arthur Business and £131 million was attributable to sales from the EG UK Business), an increase of £210 million, or 4%, compared to £5,095 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 (of which £5,012 million was attributable to the standalone Asda business (excluding acquisitions) and £83 million was attributable to sales from the Arthur Business, which were not consolidated into the Group results until May 30, 2023 when the CMA lifted its Initial Enforcement Order in connection with the Arthur Acquisition). Asda standalone sales excluding fuel have increased by 1.9% yearover-year, with like-for-like growth of 0.5%. This overall increase was driven in part by investments made into our proposition, including as a result of the Aldi and Lidl Price Match programme, Fab 5 and mega deals driving improvements in price perception. We also benefited from non-food sales, which grew faster than the Asda group as a whole and faster than the market. The grocery market continues to be very competitive and overall our sales growth, excluding fuel, was slower than the market in the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, partly reflecting slower than market growth in our inflation. For the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, we estimate that our Adjusted EBITDA was £254 million, an increase of £48 million, or 23%, from £206 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. For the three month-period ended March 31, 2024, we estimate that £7 million of Adjusted EBITDA was attributable to the Arthur Business, £35 million of Adjusted EBITDA was attributable to the EG UK Business and £ (17) million was attributable to the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. For the three-month period ended March 31, 2023, £16 million of Adjusted EBITDA was attributable to the Arthur Business. This overall increase was supported by improved year-over-year trading margins and disciplined cost control, with Adjusted EBITDA margins (excluding fuel) increasing by 0.70 percentage points year-over-year to 4.8% in the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, from 4.1% in the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. Fuel margins were slightly lower in the period in the standalone Asda business, as well as in the EG UK Business and the Arthur Business, as cost prices rose significantly while retail prices did not increase as quickly. We believe this overall growth in the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA is mainly driven by recovering gross margin, including a strong performance in our clothing line and our ability to control costs, which highlights the resilience of our business model. We believe in continued investment in price, particularly as inflation softens, which could boost consumers discretionary spending. We expect utility costs to begin to decline year-on-year from April 2024. We continue to integrate the EG UK Business and the Arthur Business and expect to crystallise synergies. We closed the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, with cash balance of approximately £1 billion with a strong underlying Cash Conversion. Our Adjusted Net Cash Flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA minus capex (excluding Project Future capex) plus/minus change in net working capital minus Project Future costs (including Future capex) minus net financing costs plus proceeds from disposals minus other and debt repayment plus cashflows Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition) was negative £32 million in the three-month period ended March 31, 2024 as compared to negative £157 million in the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. Ongoing positive momentum on the net working capital with improving payment terms, particularly on fuel and on inventory management further helped improve our cash generation. 20 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY CORPORATE AND FINANCING STRUCTURE
Subsubsection Text: _The following chart illustrates the Group’s expected simplified corporate structure and principal indebtedness on the Issue Date after giving effect to the Transactions. For a summary of the debt obligations referred to in this chart, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes.”_ (1) Funds managed by TDR Capital LLP beneficially own 50.0% of the ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo Limited (“Topco”) through a holding company, Optima Group S.à r.l., and Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE each beneficially own 25.0% of the ordinary shares of each of Topco and Property Newco indirectly through their holding company, Able Holdings Limited. For additional information regarding our ultimate shareholders, see “Principal Shareholders.” (2) On the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, Walmart, through its wholly owned subsidiary Global Pinnacle Corporation, made a £500 million rollover equity investment in senior shares and a special participation share issued by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (“Topco 2”), which constituted a portion of the £1,280 million LBO Equity Contribution that was used to pay the LBO Purchase Consideration for the LBO Acquisition. The rollover equity investment was made on a cashless roll-over basis. 21 ----- (3) On February 24, 2021, the Senior Notes Issuer issued £500.0 million aggregate principal amount of senior notes due February 16, 2027. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, £500.0 million Existing Senior Notes remain outstanding. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Existing Senior Notes.”_ (4) On February 24, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer issued £2,250.0 million aggregate principal amount of senior secured notes due February 16, 2026. On November 5, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer issued £500,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 4.500% senior secured notes due 2026. £2,250 million in aggregate principal amount of Existing Senior Secured Notes will be repaid with the New Financing Proceeds. See “Use of Proceeds.” After giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, in an amount equal to £500.0 million, will remain outstanding. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Existing Senior Secured _Notes.”_ (5) The Senior Facilities Agreement, after giving effect to the Transactions provides for committed facilities of up to £1,750 million (equivalent), which comprises up to £73,725,000 Original Facility A (to the extent not repaid in full, with a minimum amount of £9,775,000 of commitments under Original Facility A expected to remain outstanding on or around the Issue Date), a minimum of £92,250,000 New Facility A (with a possible additional commitment of £63,725,000 under Original Facility A which could be extended under New Facility A on or shortly after the Issue Date), the €1,050,000,000 Facility B (EUR) and the £683,903,176 Private Placement Facility, as well as at least £747,722,727 New Revolving Facility (with a possible incremental commitment of £45,000,000 under the New Revolving Facility which could be made available on or shortly after the Issue Date). The borrowers under the Senior Facilities Agreement are the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and (in respect of the New Revolving Facility only) Asda Stores Limited and the Senior Facilities are guaranteed by the Guarantors. New Facility A will be utilised on or around the Issue Date and the proceeds of such utilisation will be applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards financing part of the outstanding amounts under the Original Facility A on a cashless basis. Facility B (EUR) will be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer towards financing any the outstanding amounts under the Original Facility B or repurchasing or redeeming the Existing Senior Secured Notes. Subject to certain limitations, other subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, may become borrowers under the Senior Facilities Agreement in the future. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement” and “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.” Subject to compliance with the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Senior_ Secured Notes Indenture, the New Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, the commitments made available under the Senior Facilities Agreement may be increased in the future. The New Revolving Facility is expected to remain undrawn on the Issue Date. (6) Represents the £1,750 million in aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes. On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be general senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors and will be secured by the Initial Collateral as set forth under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security.” Within 30 days, the Senior Secured Notes will also be secured by the Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral. Within 180 days, the Senior Secured Notes will also be secured by the Post-Closing Real Estate Collateral. The Guarantors also guarantee the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Existing Senior Secured Notes on a pari passu and equal and ratable basis with the Senior Secured Notes (and on a senior basis to the Existing Senior Notes). The Shared Security also secures the Senior Notes Issuer’s obligations under the Existing Senior Notes on a second-priority basis. Additionally, the Collateral (including the Shared Security) secures the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Existing Senior Secured Notes on an equal and ratable basis with the Senior Secured Notes (and, with respect to the Shared Security, on a senior basis to the Existing Senior Notes). The Collateral (including the Shared Security) may also secure certain hedging obligations and (in the event that the Term Loan Facilities (as defined herein) are repaid in full) certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred and secured on the Collateral on a super senior basis. In the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the holders of any hedging obligations and other indebtedness that is permitted to be secured on a super priority basis have been repaid in full. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor _Agreement.” As of December 31, 2023, based on Asda’s allocation of properties for accounting purposes (which has not been verified by an_ assessment of the registered proprietor of each of the properties) and subject to matters disclosed in the section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Valuation Report,” the Guarantors hold sites representing over 99% of the value of the Market Value SA Properties (consisting of Asda supermarkets (excluding supermarkets pledged in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction), Food to Go sites, industrial properties and office properties), 90% of the value of the Market Value Properties (consisting of PFSs, investment properties, development and landbank sites and a Distribution Centre – Held for Sale site) and 0% of the properties leased in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. Asda believes such percentage allocation would not materially vary based on verification of the registered proprietor of each of the properties. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Guarantors represented 98% of the Group’s consolidated revenue. Each Notes Guarantee will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, including the Agreed Security Principles, and certain contractual and legal limitations. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Certain Insolvency Considerations _and Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.” By virtue of these limitations, a_ Guarantor’s obligation under its Notes Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Senior Secured Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Notes Guarantee. The gross proceeds from the Offering are expected to be £1,750 million, which the Senior Secured Notes Issuer intends to use, together with the borrowings under Facility B (EUR) and cash on hand to (i) partially repurchase the Existing Senior Secured Notes, (ii) prepay and cancel Original Facility B in full and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” 22 -----

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: 2026 ............................................................... % 2027 ............................................................... % 2028, and thereafter ....................................... 100.000% Tender offers ..........................................................** In connection with certain tender offers for the Senior Secured Notes, including in connection with an offer to repurchase the Senior Secured Notes upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the outstanding Senior Secured Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Senior Secured Notes in the tender offer and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, purchases all of the Senior Secured Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, all of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be deemed to have consented to such tender or other offer and, accordingly, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Senior Secured Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Senior Secured Notes. 27 ----- Additional Amounts ...............................................** All payments made by or on behalf of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or any Guarantor in respect of the Senior Secured Notes or any Notes Guarantee, as applicable, will be made free and clear of and without withholding or deduction for, or on account of, any taxes, except to the extent required by law. If any deduction or withholding for, or on account of, any taxes imposed or levied by or on behalf of a Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined herein) is required by law to be made from any payments under the Senior Secured Notes or the Notes Guarantees, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or the Guarantors will, subject to certain exceptions, pay additional amounts so that the net amount received by each holder in respect of such payments after such withholding or deduction (including any deduction or withholding from such additional amounts) is not less than the amounts which would have been received by such holder in the absence of such withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes.”_ Tax redemption ......................................................** If certain changes in the law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction become effective that would impose withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or any Guarantor is required to pay additional amounts, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem the Senior Secured Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, together with accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date fixed for redemption and all additional amounts, if any. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Redemption for _Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control ..................................................** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be required to make an offer to repurchase all outstanding Senior Secured Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof. Certain Covenants ..................................................** The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will, among other things, restrict the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries, to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; 28 ----- - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - impair the security interests created for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes; and - consummate certain Sale and Leaseback Transactions, Ground Rent Transactions or Qualified Securitisation Financings (in each case, as defined under “Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Certain Definitions.”_ Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Senior Secured Notes obtain and maintain an investment-grade rating. Each of the covenants in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ Transfer Restrictions .............................................** The Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Senior Secured Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Notice to Investors.” The Group has not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Senior Secured Notes under the securities laws in any jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer). Original Issue Discount ..........................................** The Senior Secured Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, U.S. holders (as defined under “Certain Tax _Considerations—Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations”) of the Senior Secured Notes generally will_ be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, such U.S. holders generally will include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States _Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.”_ No Established Market for the Senior Secured** The Senior Secured Notes will be new securities for which Notes ........................................................................** there is currently no established trading market. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Senior Secured Notes. Listing ......................................................................** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited to list the Senior Secured Notes on the Official List of the Exchange and to admit the Senior Secured Notes for trading on the Exchange. 29 ----- Governing Law .......................................................** The Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by the applicable law of the jurisdiction in which the relevant collateral is located. Senior Secured Notes Trustee ...............................** Deutsche Trustee Company Limited. Security Agent ........................................................** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Paying Agent and Transfer Agent ........................** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Registrar .................................................................** Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. Ranking of the Senior Secured Notes ...................** The Senior Secured Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, secured as set forth under “— _Security”;_ - rank _pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future Indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including the Senior Facilities and the Existing Senior Secured Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s Guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes; - be general senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, secured as set forth under “— _Security”;_ 23 ----- - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation (including obligations to trade creditors) of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its Subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness only, including liabilities in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction and secured lease liabilities; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the Subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that are not Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors and liabilities in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction and lease liabilities. Notes Guarantees ...................................................** On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by each of the Guarantors. Asda believes such percentage allocation would not materially vary based on verification of the registered proprietor of each of the properties. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Guarantors represented 98% of the Group’s consolidated revenue. Ranking of the Notes Guarantees .........................** The Notes Guarantee of each Guarantor will: - be a general senior obligation of the applicable Guarantor, secured as set forth under “—Security”; - rank _pari passu in right of payment with any existing or future Indebtedness of the applicable Guarantor that is not subordinated in right of payment to the applicable Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s obligations under the Senior Facilities and the Existing Senior Secured Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing or future Indebtedness of the applicable Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the applicable Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the applicable Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes Guarantee, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness or obligation only, including liabilities in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction and secured lease liabilities; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the Subsidiaries of the applicable Guarantor that are not Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors and liabilities in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction and lease liabilities. 25 ----- The Notes Guarantees will be subject to the Agreed Security Principles and the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Notes Guarantees may be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security—Enforcement_ _of_ _Security”_ and _“Description_ _of_ _Certain_ _Financing_ _Arrangements— Intercreditor Agreement.”_ Security ...................................................................** On the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by first-priority security interests over (a) the issued share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (b) any material intercompany receivables owing to the Senior Notes Issuer by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (c) the material intra-group receivables owing to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (d) the material bank accounts located in England and Wales of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and (e) a floating charge over all or substantially all of the assets (other than customarily excluded assets) of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, as and when created. Within 30 days of the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by first-priority interests over each Guarantor’s (a) material bank accounts, (b) the issued share capital of such Guarantors, (c) material intercompany receivables owned to such Guarantors by other member of the Group, (d) a floating charge over all or substantially all of the assets (other than customarily excluded assets) of each of the Guarantors and also secured by interests over (a) the shares held in Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited by Project America Bidco Limited and (b) any material receivables owed to it by Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited or its Subsidiaries from time to time, in each case on a third party limited recourse basis. Within 180 days of the Issue Date, subject to Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by first-priority interests over the Material Real Property (by way of mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security). The security interests securing the Senior Secured Notes may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of _the Senior Secured Notes—Release of Liens.”_ Use of Proceeds .......................................................** The gross proceeds from the Offering, are expected to be £1,750 million, which the Senior Secured Notes Issuer intends to use, together with the borrowings under Facility B (EUR) and cash on hand to (i) partially repurchase the Existing Senior Secured Notes, (ii) prepay and cancel Original Facility B in full and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions, as set out in “Use of Proceeds.” 26 ----- Optional Redemption .............................................** Prior to     , 2026, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Senior Secured Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus a “make-whole” premium. Subsubsection Text: In assessing the performance of our business, we consider a variety of alternative performance measures and financial measures. Such indicators are either purely operational in nature, include financial information not derived from our accounting system and may include VAT which is collected by us at the cash registers or online checkout but turned over to the competent tax authorities. For certain 2021 financial information, we present an annualised figure. The actual financial results of the Group do not include a full year of trading in the year ended December 31, 2021, as the Senior Notes Issuer acquired the trading group Asda Group Limited part way through the year on February 16, 2021. As a result, actual results for the year ended December 31, 2021 for the Senior Notes Issuer consolidated group do not constitute a full comparative period. In 2021, non-underlying items relate to transaction costs relating to LBO Acquisition, Project Future costs, gain on bargain purchase and a sale-and-leaseback gain. (3) Like-for-like sales growth is a measure of annual growth of sales calculated as current year comparable sales excluding fuel (excluding VAT) versus prior year comparable sales. Current year comparable sales includes all revenue except fuel sales, sales generated from stores in the first twelve complete calendar months following opening, sales generated from stores that have permanently closed, sales generated from stores that have been temporarily closed for more than two consecutive calendar months within the previous twelve full calendar months, financial services commissions, ‘toyou.’ Sales are net of Asda Rewards earned and other discounts. SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: (A) The asset write-off adjustment relates to the non-cash write off of all tangible fixed assets with value written off in the normal course of business, usually as a result of store or depot remodelling activities. 36 ----- (B) The elimination of IFRS 16 impact adjustment deducts from EBITDA rental payments made during the period and accounts for all leases as if they were classified as operating leases under IAS 17 prior to the entry into force of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019. (C) Prior year ATM rates adjustment reflects the removal of income that has been included in EBITDA following a change in the assessment of business rates for automated teller machines (“ATMs”). (D) The restructuring adjustments comprise one off provisions relating to (i) facilities management restructuring, in-store bakery proposition restructuring, management and back office restructure and closure of Heston & Dartford depots totalling £30.6 million in 2021, (ii) facilities management restructuring and retail admin colleague restructuring totalling £4.7 million in 2022 and (iii) Night-to-twilight shift re-organisation, head office colleague restructure, livings and post office closures totalling £17.4 million in 2023. (E) Tax saving pass through adjustment reflects the pass through to Walmart of tax deductions relating to adjustments to the carrying value of the loan from Asda Stores Limited to the ASDA Group Pension Scheme which was part of the financing of the ASDA Group Pension Scheme buy-in. These tax deductions were passed through to Walmart under the terms of the LBO Transaction. (F) The legal settlement in 2023 relates to a net credit received as a result of settling historical legal cases. This credit recognized is net of amounts which were passed through to Walmart under the terms of the original LBO Acquisition. (G) The Group acquired Arthur Foodstores Ltd, a carve-out of 132 convenience sites from the Co-operative Group as part of the Arthur Acquisition, in October 2022. The Arthur Acquisition was subject to an Initial Enforcement Order by the CMA and it therefore was deemed that the Group did not have control according to the principles defined in IFRS 10 Consolidated Financial Statements in order to consolidate the results into the Group in the year ended December 31, 2022. With respect to the year ended December 31, 2022, the Group includes actual Adjusted EBITDA related to the trading performance of the Arthur Business since the closing of the transaction on October 30, 2022 as if the trading performance of the Arthur Business had been consolidated from October 30, 2022 in Adjusted EBITDA without giving effect to any annualization. With respect to the year ended December 31, 2023, results for the Arthur Acquisition have been included in the Group’s consolidated results from May 30, 2023 when the Initial Enforcement Order was lifted by the CMA. An adjustment has been made to Adjusted EBITDA for the year-ended December 31, 2023 to give effect to Adjusted EBITDA of the Arthur Business from January 1, 2023 through May 30, 2023 as if the trading performance of the Arthur Business had been consolidated from January 1, 2023. No further adjustment has been made to reflect the annualisation of the impact of 13 sites that were disposed in December 2023 and January 2024, as required as remedies to the CMA’s investigation into the Arthur Acquisition; see below adjustment (T) in relation to the year ended December 31, 2023. (H) Prior to the LBO Acquisition, ASDA Stores Limited provided retirement benefits for eligible employees through two defined benefit plans in the UK, including one funded, the ASDA Group Pension Scheme (the “Scheme”). On July 9, 2021, the trustees of the Scheme completed a full buy-out of the Scheme. To the extent that the Scheme was unable to make repayments of principal amounts outstanding on the buy-in loan out of Scheme assets, ASDA Stores Limited was obliged to make a contribution to the Scheme to the value of the shortfall. The pension buyout loss reflects the difference between the net carrying amount of Scheme assets and liabilities and the recoverable amount of the buy-in loan at the date of buyout, after accounting for a net actuarial loss of £13.9 million. For more details see note 20 to the 2021 Financial Statements. (I) The ARO provision release adjustment removes the accounting gain recorded in EBITDA relating to the release of an asset retirement provision as a result of remeasuring the asset retirement obligation liability due to changes in the discount rate. (J) At completion of the Arthur Acquisition in October 2022, Asda entered into an Outsourcing and Interim Franchise Agreement (“OIFA”) with Co-op. Under the terms of the OIFA, Co-op provided outsourced management services for the Arthur Business sites. These services included providing the workforce to operate the sites, area management teams, the supply and fulfilment of grocery inventory and IT services. These services were provided during the period of the CMA review and up until the stores were handover to Asda management and re-branded as Asda Express. Under the terms of the OIFA, Arthur paid a management fee to Co-op based on a percentage of revenue. Other advisor and integration fees adjustment relate to the non-recurring payments made under the OIFA arrangements, non-recurring third-party advisor fees to support the independent management team and other non-recurring third-party advisor fees incurred by the Group. (K) In 2021, the one-off acquisition costs incurred relating to the LBO Acquisition relate to third party advisor fees and stamp duty paid in relation to the acquisition in the prior period of the entire issued share capital of Asda Group Limited. In 2022, the one-off acquisition costs incurred relating to the Arthur Acquisition relate to third party advisor fees in relation to the acquisition in the prior period of the entire issued share capital of Arthur Foodstores Limited. In 2023, the one-off acquisition costs incurred relating to the EG UK Acquisition relate to third party advisor fees in relation to the acquisition in the prior period of the entire issued share capital of Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited. (L) The one-off separation costs adjustment removes the incremental costs incurred to support the separation from Walmart. These costs include IT related and non-IT related costs. Since the LBO Acquisition, the Group has embarked on a programme, Project Future, to separate its IT systems from its previous owner Walmart. The separation programme is one-off and non-recurring in nature, and will transition the Group to a standalone IT infrastructure using software as a service from digital partners. (M) All share-based payment liabilities issued prior to the LBO Acquisition were settled during the year ended December 31, 2021. The share option programmes allowed Group employees to acquire shares of the former ultimate parent company of Asda Group Limited – Walmart Inc. These awards were granted by a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Group. The fair value of options granted was initially measured at grant date and spread over the period during which the employees became unconditionally entitled to payment. The charge was recognised as an employee expense, with a corresponding increase in liabilities. The fair value of the share options was measured based on an option valuation model, taking into account the terms and conditions upon which the instruments were granted. The liability was re-measured at each balance sheet date and at settlement date and any changes in fair value were recognised in the consolidated income statement during the vesting period. These share-based payment transactions were accounted for as cash-settled. 37 ----- (N) Options in Walmart shares have historically been awarded to employees of the Group; these share option awards were accounted for within EBITDA as cash settled equity awards. Share award schemes were all existing options in Walmart shares and were settled in 2021, the corresponding charges have since fallen away and, as a result, are added back for the year ended December 31, 2021 (£17.5 million). Since then, the Group has, however, enhanced other colleague incentive programmes. The estimated annual incremental cost of these enhanced incentive programmes was estimated to be £16 million in 2021. Therefore, a charge of £16.0 million has been included for year ended December 31 2021. In subsequent periods, this incremental investment in colleague incentive programmes is considered to be an underlying cost of the business and therefore, no adjustments are made in the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023. (O) The ground rent charge relates to payments in connection with servicing the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. (P) The Starbucks rental income adjustment reflects the recognition of rental income from the Starbucks freehold properties acquired as part of the EG UK Acquisition. This adjustment represents rental income for two months since closing of the transaction recognized on a straight-line basis. (Q) In connection with the EG UK Acquisition, the Group entered into a number of arrangements with EG Finco Limited, including the TSA and an integration support arrangement. These arrangements were all negotiated concurrently with the acquisition of Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited, they are interdependent with the terms of the acquisition, and were negotiated as a single transaction. Under the TSA, a subsidiary of EG Finco Limited will provide Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited and its subsidiaries with IT and other centralized services for an initial term of two years. During this initial term, these services are provided at £nil cost to the Group, subject to certain limited exceptions. In addition, EG Finco Limited has also agreed for a period of two years to reimburse the Group for certain centralized costs which transferred as part of the transaction perimeter and are required to support the acquired business. This arrangement is not considered to be part of the business combination under IFRS 3R and therefore, £27.3 million of the consideration transferred to EG Finco Limited has been allocated to the TSA arrangement based on the fair value of the services provided subsidiaries of EG Finco Limited and the estimated costs to be recharged by the Group to EG Finco Limited. This has been recognised within prepayments and will be recognized within operating expenses in the consolidated income statement over the initial two-year term of the TSA. The TSA prepayment unwind adjustment reflects an adjustment for the amortization of the prepayment recognized in EBITDA since closing of the transaction. (R) Under the integration support arrangement, the Group and EG Finco Limited entered into an agreement whereby EG Finco Limited would support the costs associated with the integration of the acquisition by the Group for a fixed amount of £11.3 million over two years with the payments made quarterly. The full amount has been recorded as an adjustment to the purchase consideration and recognized within Other Debtors at closing in the consolidated balance sheet. The integration payment reflects the recording of this payment within EBITDA on a straight-line basis. (S) In 2022, management shares in the immediate parent company of the Group, Bellis Midco 4 Limited, were issued to eligible members of senior management employed by the Group as part of a Management Incentive Plan (“MIP”) in exchange for proceeds determined by an independent calculation of fair value at the issue date. The MIP add-back reflects adjustment to add back the related share-based payment charge under IFRS 2 for the year ended December 31, 2023. (T) The adjustment for the Arthur Acquisition impact of CMA disposals relates to the annualisation of the impact of 13 sites that were disposed in December 2023 and January 2024, as required as remedies to the CMA’s investigation into the Arthur Acquisition. (U) Represents the targeted synergies from the Arthur Acquisition that are expected to be delivered within two years of completion. These synergies are related to the anticipated benefits of increased volume and margin benefits which we believe we can achieve through our value leadership, scale, supplier relationships and operational efficiencies. (V) Represents the adjustment to annualise LTM EBITDA for the acquisition of America. The EG UK Acquisition closed on October 31, 2023 and the results of the EG UK Business were consolidated into our results from that date. This adjustment reflects £164 million of EBITDA attributed to the EG UK Business from January 1, 2023 to October 31, 2023, which represents the actual performance of the acquired perimeter for that period. (W) Represents the targeted synergies resulting for the EG UK Acquisition expected to be delivered within two years of completion A large portion of the synergies are expected to flow into gross profit as sales grow and buying benefits materialise. These synergies are comprised of (i) £44 million related to fuel, £24 million related to grocery and merchandise and £1 million related to foodservice. We expect the Fuel synergies to stem from price investments and an uplift in EG volumes, fuel cost price reductions, fuel card commercial terms improvements, joint buying benefits and merchant cost savings. We expect grocery and retail synergies to come from price investments and an uplift in EG volumes, range optimisations, in-store marketing income, other monetisation of customer data, best cost price switching and buying benefits. We expect foodservice synergies to come from an enhanced foodservice proposition, our in-store foodservice outlets at our grocery sites and the introduction of new foodservice sites leveraging our vacant tenancy portfolio. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We may from time to time pursue acquisitions, which may prove more costly than anticipated and may not generate anticipated synergies and which may have an adverse impact on our business, as could our failure to successfully integrate such businesses following acquisition. Our business could also be negatively impacted by merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by supranational and national laws and regulations.”_ (X) Sale and leaseback rent store assets annualisation adjustments relate to the annualisation of rent costs and servicing costs associated with the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions as if the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions had completed on January 1, 2023. (Y) Ground rent annualisation adjustments relate to the annualisation of rent costs and servicing costs associated with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction as if the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement was in place on January 1, 2023. 38 ----- (4) Free Cash Flow is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditure KPI. The following table sets forth a reconciliation of Free Cash Flow to Adjusted EBITDA.

Subsubsection Text: (A) Movement in Net Working Capital for the year ended December 31, 2022 and year ended December 31, 2023 represents the sum of the movements in trade and other receivables, inventories, trade and other payables, and provisions as disclosed in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows. (8) _Pro forma net debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s pro forma indebtedness in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities and the guarantees relating to the Existing Senior Notes, net of the Group’s cash and cash equivalents as at December 31, 2023, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. See “Capitalisation.” Pro forma net debt assumes that 100% of holders of targeted Existing Senior Secured Notes tender in the Richmond Tender Offer. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which were not targeted in the Richmond Tender Offer, will remain outstanding following the Transactions. To the extent that fewer eligible holders participate in the Richmond Tender Offer (or such Existing Senior Secured Notes are not accepted by us), pro forma net debt is not expected to change because we intend to hold the New Financing Proceeds (in cash or cash equivalents) on balance sheet until applied to repay such Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior 39 ----- Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. Our presentation and calculation of the ratio of Pro forma net debt to Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA may be different from the calculation of Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not indicative of our level of adherence to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes,” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” (9) _Pro forma net senior secured debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s pro forma indebtedness in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, and the Senior Facilities, net of the Group’s cash and cash equivalents as at December 31, 2023, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements.”_ (10) _Pro forma interest expense represents the interest expense on our pro forma net debt after giving pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. Pro forma interest expense (i) excludes charges related to allocated debt issuance costs; (ii) excludes finance costs associated with leases (including, for the avoidance of doubt, leases in connection with the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions), (iii) excludes finance costs associated with liabilities relating to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction and (iv) includes interest expense associated with the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes and the Senior Facilities. Pro forma interest expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to describe what our interest expense would have actually been had the above-mentioned transactions occurred at the beginning of the year ended December 31, 2023, nor does it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. 40 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: _The historical consolidated financial information and other financial data of the Group as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 have been extracted from the audited consolidated financial statements of the Group included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum or from the Group’s accounting records. We also present in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited financial information adjusted to give pro forma effect to the Transactions (“As Adjusted Financial Information”). See “—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators” and “Capitalisation.” The As Adjusted Financial Information included in this Offering Memorandum has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards. The assumptions underlying the As Adjusted Financial Information have not been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. The As Adjusted Financial Information has been provided for informational purposes only. Results indicated by certain of these measures may not be realised, and funds depicted by certain of these measures may not be available for management’s discretionary use if such results are not realised. Further, the As Adjusted Financial Information does not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or our cash position or financial position as at any future date. The actual results may differ significantly from those reflected in the unaudited pro forma financial information for a number of reasons, including, but not limited to, differences in assumptions used to prepare the As Adjusted Financial Information. Results of operations for prior periods or years are not necessarily indicative of the result to be expected for any future period. Prospective investors should bear in mind that the performance indicators and ratios that we report herein, such as the EBITDA Measures, Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion, movement in working capital, Underlying Cash Flow From Operations, capital expenditure, Capital Expenditure KPI and certain other measures are not financial measures defined in accordance with UK IFRS and, as such, may be calculated by other companies using different methodologies and having different results. Therefore, these performance indicators and ratios are not directly comparable to similar figures and ratios reported by other companies. The following tables also contain financial measures and ratios that are not presented in accordance with UK IFRS. For the definitions and analytical limitations of these Non-IFRS Measures, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” You should read the information summarised below in conjunction with the information contained in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the consolidated financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Risks Relating to Our General Operations We operate in a highly competitive industry and our business, financial condition and results operations, as well as the strength of our brand, may be materially adversely affected by actions of our competitors and our failure to respond to competitive pressures.
Subsubsection Text: In the highly competitive grocery retail industry, success depends on satisfying changing customer needs more effectively than the competition. Failure to meet consumer demands is a competitive disadvantage and we may therefore be exposed to a loss of market share. There can be no assurance that we can continue to successfully compete with existing competitors or new market entrants. Our competition generally includes international and domestic brick-and-mortar retailers (including, generalist grocers, supermarket chains, discount retailers, grocery specialists and convenience stores), some of which also operate omni-channel businesses such as Amazon, as well as online pure players, such as Ocado. In recent years, the historically stable grocery retail market in the United Kingdom has undergone a structural shift towards discounters, such as Aldi and Lidl, convenience formats and online retailers, to the detriment of traditional supermarkets and hypermarkets. We generally compete for, among other things, customers, market share, employees, digital prominence, products and services and in other important aspects of the business with many other local, regional, national and global omni-channel retailers, wholesale operators and retail intermediaries. Our competitors generally compete with us on the basis of, among other things, price, quality, selection, availability, services offered to customers, location, store hours, in-store amenities, shopping convenience, brand reputation, overall shopping experience, attractiveness and ease of use of our online platforms, cost and delivery speed of merchandise purchased through our digital platforms or through our omni-channel integration of our physical and digital operations. In executing our strategy, we may face a variety of competitive challenges, including, among others: - potential emergence of new competitors, including foreign and domestic retailers entering our markets, or consolidation, strengthening or expanded offerings of existing operators, as has been the case in recent years with the emergence of discounters (for more information, see “Industry” and “Business—Key _Strengths”);_ - potential creation by competitors of new store formats, additional convenience grocery retail store offerings, in-store or online services, delivery and pick-up options, loyalty and reward schemes or online platforms that customers may prefer; - the risk of our competitors successfully adopting our business model in their own stores; - competitive pressure on product pricing from core competitors, as well as increasing competition from discounters and online retailers; 41 ----- - the risk of our competitors providing better service, quality, value or availability of products; and - the risk of our competitors better utilising customer data to provide personalised and efficient services, including better loyalty and reward schemes and preferred pricing for loyalty and reward schemes’ members. The performance of our competitors and changes in their pricing, promotions, product mix or other business strategies, and our response (or failure to respond) to such competitive pressures, may lead to lower sales revenue, higher operating expenses and/or lower profit margins and may require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. There can be no assurance that, with evolving customer preferences, our customers will not shift towards competitors with a different business model. Even in geographies, channels and formats where we have a strong retail presence, we face the risk that new retail market entrants may attempt to gain market share through pricing pressure. For example, the UK grocery retail market has seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) that compete through differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand products. We experience downward pricing pressure, and if we are unable to maintain our competitive position, we could experience additional downward pressure on prices, lower demand for our products, reduced retail margins, the inability to take advantage of new business opportunities and the loss of market share, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. In recent years, and in particular during the COVID-19 pandemic, the demand for online shopping services has increased substantially and many of our competitors have expanded their online offerings. If our competitors are able to offer faster or cheaper deliveries, and/or more convenient delivery options, we could lose current or potential customers, our brand and reputation could suffer, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. To remain competitive, we must continue to develop and enhance our online offering and the information systems that support our online activities, as well as continue to optimise our logistics and distribution capabilities. This may require the acquisition of equipment and software and the development, either internally or through third-parties of new proprietary software and logistics and distribution solutions. In addition, any impairment of or disruption to our supply chain or delivery fleet could result in a disruption in the delivery of our products to our online customers, which could harm our brand and could generate additional costs. Furthermore, the online grocery industry in the United Kingdom may not sustain or improve upon current levels of demand, and we may fail to develop our online retail proposition to successfully appeal to a broader customer base and sustain current growth rates. If we are unable to effectively compete with our online competitors or if we fail to retain and attract online customers, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, we may fail to successfully compete with the growing convenience retail market, despite our growing presence is such market. If we are unable to successfully expand our operations into the convenience retail market and the convenience retail market continues to grow, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to manage risks relating to health and safety, sourcing, food safety and customer expectations for both food and non-food products and in our stores and premises, which increases the risk of injury or loss of life, reputational damage, and decreased customer confidence.
Subsubsection Text: Food and product safety and food hygiene and traceability (including in respect of product origins, freshness and conditions of preservation through the supply chain) are top priorities for us: the actual safety of the food and other products and services we offer, as well as the public’s perception of that safety, are essential to our business, brand and reputation. Any event, such as a significant product recall or negative press reaction to statements made or actions taken could damage our brand or reputation or cause customers to lose confidence in the safety and quality of the products we sell. We are also subject to a number of food safety and hygiene regulations. See “Business— _Regulation—Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer Protection.” Failures to comply with these_ regulations could result in a number of adverse consequences, including fines, loss of licences, costs of compliance or certification requirements. We may not be able to ensure that our customers always enjoy safe, quality products. We sell food for human consumption, which subjects us to safety risks such as contamination (including the presence of an undeclared 42 ----- allergen, a foreign object, substance, unintentional microbe or chemical, other agent or residue or the introduction of a genetically modified organism, and other types of contamination caused by the presence of pests that are inherent to the product in question or present where such product may be stored), spoilage, mislabelling, expired products and product tampering, all of which could lead to product withdrawals or recalls or destruction of inventory and could result in bad publicity, temporary store or warehouse closures and substantial costs in connection with compliance or remediation. There is also a risk that products may not be sourced in a responsible or sustainable way. We may also be impacted by any assertion that our products have caused illness or injury, whether true or false, proven or unproven. We could also be subject to claims or lawsuits relating to an actual or alleged illness or injury stemming from product contamination, spoilage, mislabelling, expired products, product tampering or any other incidents that compromise the safety and quality of our products. From time to time we also recall products. Risks to the health of our customers can also arise from our branded and own label suppliers, some of whom are third parties who operate outside of our direct control, in relation to the ingredients, foods and products we sell in our stores. For example, we rely on suppliers, some of whom are third parties who operate outside of our control, for ingredients, foods and products we sell in our stores. Our use of third-party suppliers increases the risk that any of the aforementioned types of incidents could be caused by factors outside of our control and that multiple locations could be affected. In addition, food or product safety-related risks may also occur under any one of our own-brand labels and we may be impacted by negative publicity regarding any assertion that our food or other products have resulted in illness or injury. Our customers expect that we will provide them with a large selection of safe, high-quality products. Our colleagues are critical to maintaining our customer and supplier relationships and ultimately protecting our reputation as a business. If we are unable to control and guarantee the quality of the products we sell, especially our own-brand products and in-store services, our brand and reputation may be negatively impacted. We rely upon electrical power to operate all our facilities across our distribution network. To attain maximum performance, these types of facilities must often operate on a continuous basis and at the appropriate pre-set temperatures. As a result, any shortage or interruption in power supply may result in food spoilage and any extended power supply shortages or interruptions could result in perishable food losses, each of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Actual recent increases and potential future increases in wholesale energy prices may result in an increase in our costs incurred to maintain adequate and constant power supply at our facilities. Cold chain requirements, setting out the temperatures at which our ingredients and products must be stored and transported, are established both by law and by us to help guarantee the safety of our food products. Our cold chain must be maintained from the moment the ingredients arrive at, or are frozen by, our suppliers, through transportation and ultimately to the time of sale in our stores or delivery to our customers. In the past, the United Kingdom has experienced shortages of CO2 due to the temporary shutdown of fertilizer manufacturing facilities of which CO2 is a by-product and is an important component of our cold chain. CO2 is also used in the preparation of some of the foods and beverages we produce or we otherwise buy from suppliers, for sale in our stores and in the refrigeration technologies of some of the sites we acquired. A failure in our cold chain could lead to food spoilage, risks to the health of our customers, fines and other penalties and damage to our brand and reputation, each of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Consumers are increasingly focused on the traceability of food products to assist them in deciding what to purchase. In January 2013, incidents of horse meat in parts of the European food supply chain mislabelled as beef were identified, negatively impacting retailers and producers throughout Europe, including Asda, and led to additional standards, such as BRC standards on traceability, food fraud and food defence. While we conduct quality practices and procedures, it may be difficult to detect contamination, spoilage, mislabelling, product tampering or any other incidents that compromise the safety and quality of our products, particularly fraudulent or malicious activity. Adverse publicity about these types of problems, whether valid or not, may discourage customers from buying our products or may affect our brand and reputation. Our actual or perceived sale of unsafe food products could result in product liability claims, a loss of customer confidence, product recalls and legal claims, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
