A significant lawsuit, widespread product recall or other events leading to the loss of customer confidence in the safety and quality of our products could damage our brand and reputation and negatively impact our sales, profitability and prospects for growth. Further, if a product recall is required in circumstances where the financial consequences are not covered by the relevant supplier or our insurance, it may have a material adverse effect on our financial performance. Although we maintain product liability insurance, we cannot be certain that our coverage will 43 ----- be adequate for liabilities actually incurred or that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms, or at all. Even if future product liability claims against us are unsuccessful, these claims could be costly and time-consuming and may divert our management’s time and resources from operating our business and may harm our brand and reputation. We also face additional risks from product defects in relation to the sale of our non-food products, including, for example, the risks of battery explosions, appliance malfunction or toys or other items that prove to be dangerous. If products we purchase from our suppliers are damaged or defective, we may not be able to return products to these suppliers and obtain refunds on our purchase price or obtain indemnification from them for any damages caused. Our brand and reputation could be damaged by the marketing of such dangerous or defective products, especially in case of serious defects, such as products containing harmful substances, causing death, physical harm or other health problems. In addition, there is a risk that compliance lapses by us or by our suppliers could occur, which could lead to investigation by agencies responsible for customer product safety. In all such cases, especially if there is a prolonged impact on product quality, our brand and reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially adversely affected. Certain risks are inherent in the operation of foodservice, serve-over and self-serve counters and our brand and reputation could be damaged to the extent the quality of these facilities fall below our established standards. For example, if particular temperatures and environments are not properly maintained, food safety could be compromised and dangerous bacteria, such as Escherichia coli or Listeria monocytogenes could develop, which could cause harm to our customers and ultimately impact our reputation. Additionally, these facilities are also subject to public tampering and contamination, over which we have limited control. Even if our products are not affected by contamination or other incidents that compromise their safety and quality, we are subject to risks affecting the food industry generally, including risks posed by widespread contamination, widespread diseases (such as H1N1, SARS, MERS, BSE, COVID and avian influenza) and evolving nutritional and health-related concerns. Regulatory authorities may limit the supply of certain types of food products in response to public health concerns, and customers may perceive certain products to be unsafe or unhealthy, which could require us or our suppliers to find alternative ingredients or products that may not be available at commercially reasonable prices or within acceptable time constraints. In addition, such governmental regulations may require us to identify replacement products for our customers or, alternatively, to discontinue certain offerings or limit the range of product offerings. We may be unable to find substitutes that are as appealing to our customers, or such substitutes may not be widely available or may be available only at increased costs. Such substitutions or limitations could also reduce demand for our products. Each of the factors above may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “—Any events that negatively impact the reputation of, or value _associated with, our brands could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business is dependent on the economic situation in the United Kingdom and we are exposed to local, regional, national and global economic, political, social and other trends that could materially adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: General economic conditions in the United Kingdom and globally may adversely affect our financial performance. Higher interest rates, fluctuating petroleum product prices (including crude oil, natural gas, gasoline, and diesel fuel), higher costs for raw materials as well as electricity and other energy, weakness in the housing market, inflation, deflation, increased costs of essential services, higher levels of unemployment, decreases in disposable income, reduced access to customer credit, higher customer debt levels, changes in customer spending and shopping patterns, fluctuations in currency exchange rates, higher tax rates, imposition of new taxes or other changes in tax laws, state-implemented austerity measures, other regulatory changes, the imposition of tariffs or other measures that create barriers to or increase the costs associated with international trade, overall economic slowdown or recession and other UK or global economic factors could materially adversely affect customer demand for the products we sell, cause us to change the mix of products we sell to one with a lower average gross margin, cause a slowdown in discretionary purchases of goods, adversely affect our revenue and result in slower inventory turnover and greater markdowns of inventory, or otherwise materially adversely affect our operations and results of operations and could result in impairment charges to intangible assets, goodwill or other non-current assets. 44 ----- In addition to the economic factors listed above, any other economic factors or circumstances resulting in higher transportation, labour, insurance costs, fuel, energy or commodity prices, inflation, and other economic factors could increase our cost of sales and operating, selling, general and administrative expenses and otherwise materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, following the easing of COVID-19 lockdown measures across the United Kingdom in the first half of 2021, the increase in economic activity has led to increased pressure across global supply chains, including in relation to labour shortages within the food manufacturing supply chain (including shortages of heavy goods vehicle (“HGV”) drivers), which have resulted in wage inflation; a lack of container capacity within global shipping, which has resulted in an increase in global shipping rates; increases in wholesale energy prices; shortages of certain raw materials (including CO2) and increases in commodity prices, which have resulted in input price inflation within the supply chain. Unfavourable economic conditions or economic, social or political uncertainty globally or in the United Kingdom could significantly adversely affect our revenue, growth and profitability and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or ability to implement our strategy. As a UK business, we are particularly affected by the economic, political and social conditions prevailing from time to time in the United Kingdom. We cannot assure you that we will be able to sustain our current profit levels if adverse economic, political and social events or circumstances occur in the United Kingdom. See also “—The _occurrence of catastrophic events, such as war, terrorist attacks, civil unrest, disruptive geopolitical events, epidemics, pandemics and natural disasters, could materially adversely affect our and our suppliers’ (including other third parties on which we rely) business, financial condition and results of operations.” Recent increases in rates of_ inflation and house prices in the United Kingdom, forecasted further increases in such inflation rates and house prices and central banks’ responses to those increases, as well as other changes in economic conditions could impact consumer spending, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or ability to implement our strategy. Economic downturns create increased pressure on margins for all retailers, including us, and a significant economic downturn in the United Kingdom, or the impact of the current cost living crisis, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Inflationary or deflationary pressures on the products we sell could also impact our net sales and earnings, and during financial years 2022 and 2023, we experienced levels of inflation that are higher than we have experienced in recent years. If the cost of goods changes as a result of inflation, we may be unable to adjust our retail prices accordingly, which could adversely impact our sales or earnings. While we actively seek to manage our selling prices and production costs, volumes, inventories and working capital, future changes in economic conditions in the United Kingdom could result in short-term and long-term decreases in consumer confidence and demand, increases in selling prices and production costs or the volatility of raw material prices, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our suppliers and their respective businesses, whether in the United Kingdom or abroad, may also be adversely affected by the same, similar or other economic, political and social factors that affect our operations, which could result in an increase in the cost to us of the goods we sell to our customers or, in more extreme cases, in certain suppliers not producing certain goods in the volume typically available to us for sale or at all. For example and as a result of Brexit, we are faced with higher risks with regards to getting our products into the 18 stores we operate in Northern Ireland. See “Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters—We are subject to regulations relating to the _implementation of the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union.”_ In addition, our business is affected by unstable economic and political conditions and geopolitical conflicts, such as the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine and escalating conflict in the Middle East (including tensions in the Red Sea and between Israel and Iran). Whilst we are unable to forecast the long-term impact that this war will have, according to the Bank of England, inflationary pressures intensified sharply following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The Bank of England indicated that this has led to a material deterioration in the outlook for the world and UK growth and has exacerbated the combination of adverse supply shocks that the United Kingdom and other countries continue to face. The war in Ukraine and related sanctions have pushed up the cost of oil and other key commodities. Moreover, this war could lead to additional market and other disruptions, including significant volatility in commodity prices and supply of energy resources, instability in financial markets, volatility in foreign exchange rates and interest rates, supply chain, labour and logistics interruptions, an increased risk of food availability and integrity, as well as food fraud issues, increased wholesale prices, political and social instability, changes in consumer or purchaser preferences as well as increase in cyberattacks and espionage. These factors have resulted in an increase 45 ----- in our transportation costs for distribution, utility costs for our stores and costs to purchase products from our suppliers and may make it more difficult to maintain our low prices or may result in decreased footfall at our stores or decreased traffic for our online business. As a result of the war in Ukraine, Europe is experiencing an energy crisis. For example, Russia’s closure of the Nord Stream pipeline in September 2022 has threatened a large percentage of the European Union’s natural gas supplies, which has led to energy price increases and could lead to shortages on the global energy market. Whilst some costs such as energy prices may ultimately abate, there remains considerable uncertainty and the potential for price volatility as a result of the war in Ukraine and conflict in the Middle East (including as a result of tensions in the Red Sea) which is likely to continue to impact consumer confidence and commodity prices. Inflationary pressures arising from the ongoing war in Ukraine and energy crisis have contributed to a rise in the cost of living and a reduction in disposal income for consumers. Our revenue and profitability are influenced by customer discretionary spending, which is influenced by the cyclical nature of the general economy, levels of unemployment, population demographics, inflationary/deflationary cycles, real disposable income, VAT increases, interest rates, the availability of customer credit and customer perception of overall economic conditions and their own economic prospects, all of which are factors beyond our control. We are actively monitoring the war in Ukraine as well as the ongoing and increasing inflationary pressures on consumer sentiment and spending and assessing its impact on our business. We expect these factors to adversely impact the financial performance of the wider grocery market as well as our performance whilst these conditions persist. We are unable to predict the nature and extent of inflationary pressures on our customers’ shopping habits and the environment in which we and our suppliers operate. The extent and duration of Russia’s war in Ukraine, sanctions and resulting market disruptions could be significant and could potentially have substantial impact on the global economy and our business for an unknown period of time. During periods of adverse economic, political and social conditions, we may also have difficulty accessing financial markets, which could make it more difficult, more expensive or impossible to obtain funding for additional investments to expand our business and operations or for refinancing, such that we may be unable to meet our debt service obligations, including on the Senior Secured Notes, or other financial obligations as they become due. Any prolonged adverse economic, political or social environment could make it difficult for us, as well as for our customers and suppliers, to maintain current revenue and profitability levels and could materially limit our growth. In the past, challenging market conditions have resulted in greater volatility and, in some cases, reduced liquidity, widening of credit spreads and a lack of price transparency in credit markets. Each of the factors above may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any events that negatively impact the reputation of, or value associated with, our brands could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our brand and reputation constitute a significant part of our value proposition. Our success has been founded in part on our ability to develop our brand as a leading UK retailer of quality, competitively priced grocery, clothing and general merchandise. Maintaining the reputation of and value associated with our brand is central to the success of our business. This can be an especially difficult task for retailers, particularly in light of the development of social media for advertising, including influencer marketing and brand partnerships with other third parties across the various platforms in recent years, which has led to a sharp increase in reputational risks. Any event, such as a significant product recall or negative press reaction to statements made or actions taken, or the failure to make certain statements or take certain actions, by us or our senior management (or on our behalf by advertising partners), that could damage our brand or reputation or cause customers to lose confidence in the safety and quality of the products we sell could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our principal brand names and trademarks (such as the Asda logo) are key assets of our business. See “Business—Our Intellectual Property.” We rely upon a combination of copyright and trademark laws to establish and protect our intellectual property rights but cannot be certain that the actions we have taken or will take in the future will be adequate to prevent material violation of our proprietary rights. There can be no assurance that litigation will not be necessary to enforce our trademark or proprietary rights or to defend ourselves against claimed infringement of the rights of third parties. Adverse publicity, legal action or other factors could lead to substantial erosion in the value of our brand, which could lead to decreased customer demand and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “Risks Related to Legal and Regulatory Matters—From time to 46 ----- _time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.”_ The brand names of our own-brand products also represent an important asset of our business. Certain of these own-brand items are manufactured and/or packaged by third parties, and while our policies set out quality control standards, we do not control these third parties or their quality control, employment, ethics or other business practices. If we are unable to control and guarantee the quality of our own-brand products, our reputation may be damaged, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Maintaining broad market acceptance of our own-brand items depends on many factors, including pricing, costs, quality and customer perception, and we may not achieve or maintain expected sales for our own-brand label items. See also “Risks Related to Legal and Regulatory Matters—We rely on certain suppliers and partners, some of _which are third parties, and any failure by these suppliers and partners to comply with obligations could have a materially adverse impact on our brand, reputation, business, results of operations and financial condition and our agreements with these suppliers and partners may be subject to adjustments that could increase our expenses.”_ In light of the stringent employment, health and safety, environmental and other regulations to which we are subject and the scrutiny we face from, among others, regulators, other national or local authorities, non-governmental organisations and other stakeholders, a violation, or allegations of a violation of such laws or regulations, or a failure to achieve particular standards by any of our suppliers or manufacturers we purchase goods from, could lead to unfavourable publicity and a decline in demand for our products, or require us to incur additional costs or to make changes to our supply chain and other business arrangements to ensure compliance. Any such events concerning us or any of the manufacturers or suppliers that supply products to us could substantially erode the reputation of, or value associated with, our brands and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial conditions and results of operations. Likewise, any failure to meet workplace health and safety or other legal standards and any death, injury or illness to customers, colleagues, contractors, suppliers or third parties may lead to a loss of trust and confidence in us, as well as litigation and/or financial or other penalties being imposed.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Sales of our products are subject to changing customer preferences and trends and we may be unable to successfully or timely respond to these changing customer preferences.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our business depends on the continued appeal of the range of products and services we offer, as well as our ability to provide an appealing omni-channel offering that draws new and returning customers. Given the varied backgrounds and tastes of our customer base, we must offer a sufficient range of products to satisfy a broad spectrum of preferences. Demand for our food products is affected by customer tastes and preferences, which are impacted by, among other things, social trends, health concerns, ethical considerations and culinary trends. Further to a review on customer and product trends, customers are increasingly focused on health and wellness, including avoiding foods with certain ingredients such as trans fats, gluten, sugar, sodium, processed wheat, animal products or other product attributes and prefer foods which fit in to their image of a healthy lifestyle. Customers have also shown increasing preference for vegan and organic products, ethically sourced products, environmentally-friendly product packaging and products that support local business. The review suggests that other food trends include foods that can be cooked with just an oven, on-the-go eating, comfort food with global influences, gourmet fast food and indulgent hybrid snack combinations. We must adapt and develop products to address these trends and preferences in a timely manner in order to remain competitive. Further, our customers increasingly expect a seamless omni-channel experience and when making a decision to purchase products from us, want to be able to have access to greater amounts of information than ever before, including on traceability, environmental sustainability and nutritional value. Likewise, our clothing, home product lines and general merchandise offer are subject to changing customer tastes in apparel and decor which are also impacted by sustainability considerations. Customers also increasingly expect to be able to interact with us in a variety of ways, such as through mobile application purchases, which require investments in technology and human resources. Customers also increasingly desire convenience and accessibility, requiring further investments to expand our footprint in the convenience market, including under our Asda Express banner. In addition, in this current economic environment, customers continue to experience cost pressures on their household budgets as they face a real wage decline, increasing the importance of value or lower margin food and non-food offerings. However, consumer patterns, which have increasingly been tending towards eating and working at home due to inflationary pressures and the increase in working from home in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic in the last three years, may reverse and an increasing number of employees may return to working from the office or an increase in dining out once 47 ----- inflationary pressures subside, which in turn may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. If we do not identify or effectively respond to customer trends and preferences in a timely manner, or if we fail to meet our customers’ expectations, it could negatively affect our relationship with our customers, our reputation, the perception of our value proposition, demand for our products and services, our market share and the growth of our business, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. It is difficult to quickly, consistently and successfully predict the products and services our customers will be interested in and respond to changes in their shopping patterns. Responding to shifts in customer preferences and expectations also can entail significant costs. The success of our business depends on how accurately and quickly we predict customer demand, availability of merchandise, the related impact on the demand for existing products and the competitive environment. Price transparency, assortment of products, customer experience, convenience and the speed, ease and cost of delivery or collection options are of primary and increasing importance to customers, particularly as a result of the growth of digital tools and social media that inform customers. Further, if we misjudge demand for certain products, particularly for our non-food products, we may build up excess inventory for those products, which could result in a decrease in their sales price and inefficient working capital management which, if material, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Conservation measures, technological advances and negative shift in market perception towards the oil and gas industry could reduce demand for fuel.
Subsubsection Text: As a retailer of petroleum-based fuel that increased its market presence following the EG UK Acquisition, we may be unable to adapt to fast-paced developments regarding climate change and the impact of petroleum-based fuel on the environment, which may alter consumer sentiments and lead to the increased use of alternative fuels. Increasing attention to climate change, fuel conservation measures, alternative fuel requirements, incentives to conserve energy or use alternative energy sources (such as electric vehicles and biofuels), increasing consumer demand for alternatives to oil and natural gas, and technological advances in fuel economy and energy generation devices may result in increased costs, reduced demand for our fuel and reduced revenues. Global efforts to respond to the challenges of climate change may also have an impact on the demand for the price of oil and gas moving forward, as countries increasingly shift toward alternative energy sources, which may in turn impact our revenues in the long term if we are unable to achieve or maintain a sufficiently low break-even price. In particular, the automobile industry has focused heavily on reduced fuel consumption, a trend that will likely continue with improvements to alternative fuels such as electricity, hydrogen or compressed natural gas. If customers and the automobile industry continue to embrace electric and hybrid vehicles and alternative fuels, this could have an adverse impact on our growing fuel business, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. For example, in October 2022, the European Union adopted legislation requiring a 55% CO2 emission reduction for new cars and 50% for new vans by 2030 compared to 2021 levels and for a 100% CO2 emission cut by 2035, effectively prohibiting the sale of new combustion engine cars. Should similar legislation be enacted in the United Kingdom, this could accelerate the transition of the economy away from the use of fossil fuels towards lower-or-zero-carbon emissions alternatives, which could decrease demand for, and in turn the prices of, the fuel we sell, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation. In addition, institutional lenders may, of their own accord, elect not to provide or place additional restrictions on funding for fuel-linked companies based on climate change related concerns, which could affect our access to capital for potential growth projects and other financing requirements.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business and the markets in which we operate may be adversely impacted by climate change, adverse weather conditions, the carbon transition and climate change regulation.
Subsubsection Text: Climate change, including the impact of global warming, subjects our businesses to a broad range of risks at several different levels. Our operations are subject to physical risks across all regions of operation, which include an increase in sea level and changes in weather conditions, such as rapid changes in precipitation and extreme weather events. For example, global shipping may be disrupted as a result of extreme weather patterns. 48 ----- Food production systems require a diverse range of plants, animals, bacteria and fungi, both for the direct supply of food and to sustain the underlying ecosystem processes that make agriculture possible – from water supply to soil fertility enhancement, pollination and natural pest control. Changing global weather patterns in the geographies of food production systems may negatively impact or destroy the ecosystems where products grow, in turn affecting such products’ availability and/or quality. In addition, water resources are vital to food production systems and the scarcity of such resources may have an adverse impact on agricultural production and yields. See “Business—Our _Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies—Our Environmental, Social and Governance Goals—Our ESG Priority Areas—Energy and Climate Mitigation.” Other climate-related issues such as adverse_ weather conditions may have a significant impact on our operations, property, supply chain (particularly in our fresh food offering) and our ability to maintain availability on our shelves. We also face transitional risks related to climate change. Developments related to climate change may expedite a transition away from the use of carbon-intensive sources for energy generation and products derived from certain fossil fuels, which could have a material and adverse effect on us if we are not able to demonstrate that our products align with a low-carbon transition or we are not able to meet our carbon transition targets. As a retailer, we recognise that we have a responsibility to minimise the adverse impact that our business activities have on the environment. Failure to do this may result not only in adverse environmental impacts, but also financial penalties and long-term damage to our reputation. As the global climate crisis becomes more critical, there is a risk that we will fail to address climate-related impacts on our business in reputational, operational and financial terms and may not meet stakeholder expectations. In addition, we are subject to legislation and regulation regarding climate change and the emission of greenhouse gases including with respect to our supply chain, and compliance with related rules could be difficult and costly. We could incur increased energy, environmental and other costs and capital expenditures to comply with existing or new greenhouse gas emission laws and regulations. Failure to comply with any such laws and regulations could result in penalties as well as adverse consequences to our reputation and image among our customers and stakeholders. The realisation of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The occurrence of major failures or catastrophic events, such as war, terrorist attacks, civil unrest, disruptive geopolitical events, epidemics, pandemics, natural disasters and technology disruptions, could materially adversely affect our and our suppliers’ (including other third parties on which we rely) business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The occurrence of one or more natural disasters, such as floods, fires, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, tropical storms, tornadoes, cyclones and typhoons; weather and climate conditions, such as winter and summer storms, heatwaves, severe cold weather and droughts, whether as a result of climate change or otherwise; geo-political events; public health situations, such as epidemics, pandemics and other contagious outbreaks, such as the global coronavirus pandemic; and catastrophic events, such as war, civil unrest, terrorist attacks or other acts of violence, including active shooter situations, knife attacks, technology disruptions (including cyber-attacks), as well as protests, strikes and boycotts could materially adversely affect our and our suppliers’ (including other third parties on which we rely) business, financial condition and results of operations. Such events could result in closure of, physical damage to, or the complete loss of, one or more of our and our suppliers’ (including other third parties on which we rely) properties, limitations on operating hours, workforce shortages, the inability of customers and colleagues to reach or have transportation to our stores and facilities, the evacuation of the population from areas in which our stores and facilities are located, the unavailability of our online platforms or our delivery and Click & Collect services, changes in customer purchasing patterns and in disposable income, disruptions to supply and logistics chain, reduced availability of products in our stores, disruptions to utilities for our stores and facilities, increased freight costs and wholesale energy prices, shortage of raw materials and disruptions to our communications network. Responding to such events and their effects may require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. In particular, COVID-19 had a significant impact on our operations, including by, among other things, requiring us to manage customer numbers at our premises, reduce the operation of certain stores depending on the guidelines or orders of the relevant government, invest in protective and other safety equipment, accelerate the 49 ----- deployment of automated check-outs, increase our capacity for home delivery and Click & Collect purchase options, build up our inventory of consumer staples and undertake a transition to a remote work environment for our corporate offices in response to new regulatory requirements. Whilst many of these measures are no longer necessary, we have retained a few, such as automated check-out services for our customers and the ability for certain of our colleagues to adopt a hybrid work routine. A renewed COVID-19 outbreak or any other future pandemic, could result in disruptions to our supply chain, divert management’s attention, adversely affect the price of, availability of and demand for certain food products or limit the total number of customers that may be in the store at any one time. Any of the foregoing impacts of COVID-19 or any other future pandemic could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The scope and duration of any such impacts cannot be predicted because of the unprecedented nature of COVID-19 or similar events. We risk exposure to losses incurred as a result of damage to, or destruction of, our and our suppliers’ (including other third parties on which we rely) stores and facilities, loss or spoilage of inventory and business and service interruption caused by such events. These events and their impact could otherwise disrupt and materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See “—Risks Relating to Legal and _Regulatory Matters—We may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance and could be exposed to significant financial risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate.” Furthermore, we cannot provide any assurance_ that we would be able to successfully recover our costs, in full or in part, should we experience an event of the types described above or other business continuity problem. Each of the factors above may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are vulnerable to cost inflation and fluctuations in the availability and price of food ingredients and products, commodities and packing material, as well as to fluctuations in the price of electricity and fuel and labour, transportation and manufacturing costs.
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are influenced by market prices for certain essential food ingredients and products, commodities, packing materials, gas, electricity and fuel, as well as other raw materials and energy-related costs and labour, transportation and manufacturing costs. Increases in prices or scarcity of any of these ingredients, commodities, products or materials required for our business could materially increase our costs and disrupt our operations. Food cost inflation, particularly during periods of rapid inflation, could reduce our operating margins as it may reduce the demand for our products. In addition, there may be a lag between the occurrence of the price increase and the time at which we are able to increase the price of our products and pass them on to our customers. Volatility in the price and availability of raw materials can result from a wide variety of factors beyond our control, including poor harvests, shortages or interruptions, weather conditions, disease, political instability and changes in climate, among many other factors. Events such as Brexit, COVID-19 lockdowns, the war in Ukraine or the threat of political or social unrest (or the perceived threat thereof) have had or may have a material adverse impact on commodity, product or material prices, the availability of food ingredients and products, and labour, transportation and manufacturing costs. See “— _Our business is dependent on the economic situation in the United Kingdom and we are exposed to local, regional, national and global economic, political, social and other trends that could materially adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ Notwithstanding our hedging policies, we cannot fully eliminate the risks of price movements or risks associated with the availability of food products and ingredients. For example, we are currently experiencing industry-wide retail price inflation arising from labour shortages, the war in Ukraine, increases in the cost of key commodities, freight inflation, the shortage of heavy goods vehicle drivers and increases in wholesale energy prices, which may cause our suppliers to raise their prices, which could materially increase our costs and negatively impact our business. Whilst it is not possible to predict the long-term impact of the war in Ukraine, it has resulted in significant volatility in the price of energy and price and availability of agricultural and other commodities in the short-term (such as wheat, for example), as well as volatility in the market price of commodities. Our ability to pass along increased costs through price increases to our customers depends upon competitive conditions in our industry and pricing regulations and may not be compatible with our business ethos and strategy. If we are unable to pass such cost increases on to our customers or if the higher cost of the products offered results in decreased demand for our products, our business, results of operations and financial condition, as well as our brand, may be materially adversely affected. Food purchases account for a significant portion of our cost of goods sold. The prices of ingredients that we and our suppliers purchase are subject to volatility. Such fluctuations are attributable to, among other things, global commodity prices (which may be because of such commodity’s availability), currency exchange rates, and fiscal 50 ----- policy support for agriculture. The invasion of Ukraine by Russia in 2022, for example, led to significant rises in the price and availability of key ingredients, such as sunflower oil. The increase in inflation globally and the United Kingdom since 2022 has also increased our costs of acquiring ingredients, products, and the volatility of prices, and this inflation impact continues. See also “—Our business is dependent on the economic situation in the United _Kingdom and we are exposed to local, regional, national and global economic, political, social and other trends that could materially adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.” Our operations are_ dependent on a number of key supplier relationships, including our relationship with our wholly-owned subsidiary, IPL. As a result, we may be impacted by inbound cost inflation earlier than our competitors. We may not be able to preserve our profit margin during periods of increased food inflation without suffering reduced revenue, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Increases in prices or scarcity of ingredients or packaging materials required for our products could increase our costs and disrupt our operations. In addition, our ability to pass along increased costs through price increases to our customers depends upon competitive conditions in our industry and pricing regulations. If we are unable to pass such cost increases on to our customers or the higher cost of the products offered results in decreased demand for our products, our profitability, business, financial condition and results of operations may be adversely affected. In addition, fuel prices have remained high with the potential to increase the operating costs of our sites, which require large quantities of energy to regulate store & warehouse temperatures, in particular cold chain storage facilities that ensure the integrity of our products prior to sale, as well as fuel required for our vehicle fleet, which we cannot guarantee will not increase in the future. Energy costs, impacted by reduced Russian supply due to the ongoing war in Ukraine, have reduced and stabilised but remain higher than at any time since June 2021, and the risk of supply disruption and price volatility has increased due to tensions in the Middle East and Red Sea shipping routes. Increases in energy costs, whether driven by increased demand, decreased or disrupted supply or an anticipation of any such events will increase the costs of operating our stores. In addition, while shipping costs had previously fallen, these have more than doubled since the end of 2023 due to maritime traffic in the Red Sea. This has increased import prices in the short term with longer shipping times causing a reduction of supplies of intermediate inputs and consumer goods and the outlook for shipping costs remains uncertain. Increases in energy costs, whether driven by increased demand, decreased or disrupted supply or an anticipation of any such events will increase the costs of operating our stores. Fluctuations in the price of fuel products may also negatively affect the business of our petrol stations. Any increase in the prices at which we purchase our fuel inventory or our costs in partnering with third parties could adversely affect the margins on the fuel and non-fuel products and services we sell at our forecourts, and we may not be able to raise our prices due to economic conditions, competition, regulation, contractual terms or other factors. Fuel prices have been high in recent years and have fluctuated as a result of various factors, many of which are beyond our control, such as global and regional supply and demand, geopolitical and economic uncertainty, including the Russia-Ukraine war which has threatened supply lines and resulted in embargoes of certain supply sources, and the most recent escalation of the conflict in the Middle East (including tensions in the Red Sea), as well as pricing and availability of competing alternative fuel technologies. In addition, our fuel margins have increased materially in the past few years, and there is a risk that the margins may revert back to previous levels in the future. Changing fuel prices and the inability to project future prices can from time to time impact our business. For example, changing fuel prices affect the market value of our fuel inventories and expose us to significant fluctuations in the recorded value of our inventory and the related costs of goods sold, thus reducing our profit margins. In particular, when fuel cost prices increase, whether as a result of governmental intervention or global oil market conditions, we may not always be able to pass such increases onto our customers, which may reduce our fuel margins. Fluctuations in fuel cost prices may be exacerbated in the future, for example, as a result of environmental legislation or regulation or we may face pressure from consumers and governments to not increase our fuel retail prices. As such, there can be no assurance that the price of fuel will remain stable or that we will be able to pass any price increases onto our consumers, in a timely manner or at all, resulting in higher expenses, lower margins and other material adverse effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to implement our business strategy or to successfully maintain and develop our omni-channel offer and, along with the increasing complexity of our business and costs associated with our business strategy,

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: this may reduce demand for our products and services and materially adversely impact our relationships with our customers, market share, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.
Subsubsection Text: Our future performance is dependent on our ability to identify and develop business opportunities and to successfully execute our business strategy and adapt our value proposition to relevant customer trends. See “Business—Key Strengths” and “Business—Business Strategy.” Failure to properly deploy capital and other resources to further our strategy may negatively affect our planned initiatives. Any misjudgements, flaws or inadequacies in our execution could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The retail business continues to rapidly evolve, and consumers increasingly embrace online shopping, convenience and accessibility. As a result, the portion of total customer expenditures with retailers occurring through online platforms is increasing and the pace of this increase could accelerate. Accordingly, an important part of our business strategy involves offering a seamless omni-channel customer experience by integrating innovative online and mobile application-based solutions. Our ability to adapt our online offer and, in particular, to develop online sales depends on a number of factors, including our ability to successfully market our websites and social media, our ability to identify additional key partnerships for the expansion of our online channels, the capability of our existing distribution network to accommodate our growing online operations and the ability to successfully leverage our expanding online operations. However, we cannot assure you that our online operations will continue to grow. Expansion into the convenience and foodservice market is also a key part of our strategy. However, this expansion into convenience and foodservice may not be successful. It may require substantial additional capital expenditures, and we may not be able to compete with well-established competitors. In addition, integrating innovative omni-channel options into the retail store experience is critical for us to maintain our market position. Omni-channel retailing continues to evolve, our customers are increasingly more likely to shop across multiple channels that work in tandem, and we must keep pace with changing customer expectations and new developments. The portion of total consumer purchases occurring online and through mobile applications, as well as smaller store convenience formats, has continued to increase. The pace of this increase could further accelerate in the future. Our business has evolved from an in-store experience to interaction with customers across numerous channels, including in-store, online, mobile and social media, among others. We are making investments in our websites, mobile applications and new store formats. If we are unable to make, improve, or develop relevant customer-facing technology in a timely manner, or adapt our store estate or logistic network to keep up with the growth of our online and convenience sectors, our ability to compete and our results of operations could be adversely affected. Our strategy also relies on identifying, developing and/or adopting key technology solutions that allow us to integrate innovative online shopping processes into our operations. We may not be able to secure the requisite technology to implement our strategy, either due to cost or intellectual property rights of third parties. We may also fail to integrate new digital tools into our systems which could reduce their effectiveness. Our strategy, which includes investments in online channels, technology, store remodels and other customer-focused initiatives, may not adequately or effectively allow us to grow our business, maintain or grow our overall market position or otherwise offset the impact of the growth of our business. The success of our strategy will depend in large measure on our ability to continue building and delivering a seamless omni-channel shopping experience for our customers. Failure to successfully execute this strategy may adversely affect our market position and financial performance. In addition, increased online sales, including increasing online grocery sales, could result in a reduction in the amount of traffic in our stores, which would, in turn, reduce the opportunities for cross-store sales of merchandise that such traffic creates and could reduce our sales within our stores and materially adversely affect our financial performance. Given the various risks to which we are exposed and the uncertainties inherent in our business, we cannot guarantee the successful execution of our business strategy. Additionally, the implementation of our strategy may put operational strain on our business and consume management time and focus to the detriment of our existing business operations. If we do not meet our strategic objectives or achieve the results initially expected, we may be unable to recover our investment, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Furthermore, the cost of certain online and technology investments, including any operating losses incurred, could adversely impact our financial performance in the short-term and failure to realise the benefits of these investments may adversely impact our financial performance over the longer term. 52 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Competitive pressures in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high, which may impact our ability to compete successfully against existing or future competitors.
Subsubsection Text: The apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are each highly competitive and the marketplace is highly fragmented as many different retailers compete for market share by utilising a variety of store and on-line formats and merchandising strategies. The George Clothing and George Home brands compete on the basis of, among other things, the location of our stores; website, mobile applications and their respective design; the breadth, quality, style price and availability of our merchandise; and the level of customer service offered. In particular, the George Clothing brand faces competition from other low-cost and fast fashion retailers that have recently made significant price investments in their merchandise offerings and target some of the same categories of customers as the George Clothing brand. We expect competition to increase in the future. There are no significant economic barriers for others to enter our apparel, footwear and homeware retail sectors and our existing competitors are constantly adjusting their pricing, business strategies and promotional activity (particularly during holiday periods) in response to changing market conditions or their own financial condition. Additionally, the substantial sales growth in online apparel, footwear and homeware retail within the last decade has encouraged the entry of many new competitors, new business models and an increase in competition from established companies looking for ways to create successful online shopping alternatives. The internet and other technologies also facilitate comparison shopping in our apparel, footwear and homeware retail segments. Our digital channel competes against numerous websites, mobile applications and catalogues, which may have a greater volume of circulation and web traffic or more effective marketing through online media and social networking sites. We offer an omni-channel shopping experience for our customers and use social media and mobile applications as a way to interact with them to enhance their shopping experiences. Omni-channel retailing is constantly evolving, and we must keep pace with changing customer expectations and new developments by our competitors. There is no assurance that we will be able to continue to successfully maintain or expand our digital sales channels and respond to shifting consumer traffic patterns and digital buying trends. Our inability to adequately respond to these risks and uncertainties or successfully maintain and expand our digital business could have an adverse impact on our results of operations. We may not be able to continue to compete successfully against existing or future competitors. Intense pressures from our competitors, our inability to adapt effectively and quickly to a changing competitive landscape or a failure to effectively execute our model to retain and win customers in our targeted customer categories, could reduce demand for our merchandise, decrease our inventory turnover, cause us to take greater markdowns and negatively affect our sales and margins.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The efficiency of our supply chain is critical to our business and operations. Significant disruptions in our production and/or distribution, particularly for perishable goods, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to risks associated with delivery of products to our customers through our hub and spoke logistics model and our delivery fleet, which operates predominantly by road, but also indirectly through third parties’ deliveries by deep-sea freight and air. We operate with tailored logistics structures concentrated in a relatively small number of distribution facilities to supply and deliver our products. There is a risk that any of these facilities may be materially adversely affected by extraordinary events, such as a fire or an explosion. In some such cases, insurance is subject to limitations and therefore may not cover all of our losses. See “Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory _Matters—We may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance and could be exposed to significant financial risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate.” Any increases in the cost of transportation, including as a_ result of increased fuel prices or environmental regulations or initiatives that mandate more costly methods of transport, could significantly increase our cost of doing business. The efficiency and functioning of our supply chain without disruptions or delays is essential, especially for our fresh food products. Changes in our logistics structures, including as a result of impacts to our facilities, labour disruptions, fleet problems, natural events, technical disruptions, malfeasance or accidents, could lead to a temporary or extended disruption of our operations, disrupt product availability and inventory management and have a negative impact on our brand, reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, the invasion of Ukraine by Russia, increases in freight costs through increased fuel prices and surcharges and increases in oil prices, delays in manufacturing and transportation due to congestions at ports of loading and ports of entry (such as freight disruptions arising from port-of-entry limitations or restrictions in the United Kingdom during late 2021 and 2022, resulting from 53 ----- supply chain disruptions triggered by COVID-19 and compounded by port congestion and border control restrictions attributed to Brexit and most recently), as a result of the escalation of the conflict in the Middle East (including tensions in the Red Sea, and their impact on global shipping routes), quality control issues, a supplier’s financial distress, natural disasters or health crises, regulatory actions or ethical sourcing issues, trade sanctions or other external factors over which we have no control, could interrupt product supply and, if not effectively managed and remedied, have had or may have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, disruption as a result of major incidents or external events can have a number of impacts, for example increased freight costs and wholesale energy prices and shortage of raw materials. Any disruption to our supply chain or suppliers can impact our future. There is no assurance that such pressures will not increase in the future which could materially increase our costs and impact our business. Sourcing and supply chain challenges could also be exacerbated through climate change as adverse weather conditions increasingly disrupt our ability to source, transport and deliver goods whilst also impacting our customers’ ability to access our stores. Furthermore, the growth of our business is subject to limitations on the capacity of our current supply chain network and our ability to expand that network to meet our changing needs. Our failure to grow our supply chain network in line with the growth of our business could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. In addition, should we lose our supply chain finance providers, our ability to pay our suppliers on time may be impaired and our relationships with suppliers might suffer as a result, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See “Risks Relating to Our _Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes—We may be unable to access the short-term and long-term funding required to meet business needs.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on certain suppliers and partners, some of which are third parties, and any failure by these suppliers and partners to comply with obligations could have a materially adverse impact on our brand, reputation, business, results of operations and financial condition and our agreements with these suppliers and partners may be subject to adjustments that could increase our expenses.
Subsubsection Text: We have active business relations with more than 5,900 suppliers as of December 31, 2023, including in relation to our own-brand products. See “Business—Our Suppliers and Logistics.” In addition to IPL, we are also dependent on certain third-party suppliers for our products, which exposes us to risks that such suppliers may fail to meet timelines, provide us with sufficient inventory or comply with our specifications. If a delay or interruption of delivery were to occur either temporarily or permanently for any reason, we may not be able to meet customer demand, which may result in fewer sales and may harm our brand. For example, there is an increased risk within the import business due to tensions in the Red Sea, and their impact on global shipping routes. In addition, the recent constraints on global freight and cargo capacity as well as the ongoing shortages of qualified HGV drivers may in turn reduce, and in certain instances has reduced, the traditional range of products available to our customers. Further, as we require our suppliers to meet certain specifications and standards to ensure the quality of our products, the use of third-party suppliers increases the demands on our quality control personnel. If the products provided by our suppliers do not meet the relevant quality standards, our reputation may be materially adversely affected. In addition, we depend on certain of our suppliers for certain of our successful popular own-brand products which contribute to store traffic and sales. Any disruption of delivery of these key high-volume products may have a material adverse effect on our sales. Further, the associated reputational risks are heightened in the context of suppliers who supply and/or manufacture our own-brand products. See also “—Any events that negatively impact the reputation of, or value associated with, _our brands could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ There can be no guarantee that we will not be required to make changes to our supplier base, and at any point may be required to contract with other suppliers on less favourable terms and/or at a greater cost. While we have long-term relationships with many of our suppliers, and alternate suppliers are generally available, we do not have long-term contracts with all of our suppliers. As a result, certain of our suppliers could increase their prices or fail to deliver sufficient quantities to us in a timely fashion or at all. There is also a risk that suppliers will consolidate, giving us fewer choices and creating pricing pressure. Any deterioration in our relationships with our suppliers, the imposition of stricter conditions by suppliers (especially with respect to stringent payment terms or as a result of the willingness of credit insurers to reduce the exposure of our suppliers) or the non-renewal of our key supply agreements may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. If we experience a need to replace an existing supplier, there can be no assurance that additional suppliers will be available when required on terms acceptable to us. In addition, even if we were able to find new suppliers on acceptable terms, we may encounter 54 ----- delays in production and added costs as a result of the time it would take to train such suppliers in our methods, products, quality control standards, employment, health and safety standards. Our operations are dependent on a number of key supplier relationships, including IPL. While IPL is wholly-owned by Asda, any interruption to IPL’s operations could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, we are dependent on suppliers of the machinery used within our hub and spoke facilities for their continued supply and maintenance. We are also dependent on other third parties, including landlords and distributors, and other suppliers. If any such suppliers ceased operations or was temporarily unable to supply its respective services, this could materially adversely affect our operations or financial condition until an alternative supplier is found, and there could be no guarantee that any alternative supplier would be as satisfactory as the existing arrangements. Any adverse changes to our relationships with these suppliers and third parties or in a reduction in availability or level of service offered by these suppliers and third-party providers could restrict our ability to conduct our business and thereby adversely impact our financial condition and prospects. Our relationship with suppliers based in foreign markets presents certain risks. For example, if such suppliers are non-compliant with labour laws on manufacturing and the values listed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the ILO’s Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, we could be subject to action from international trade unions with whom we have no day-to-day relationship. There is also a risk that our suppliers may not comply with relevant anti-corruption laws, health and safety laws, environmental laws or other laws and regulations, which could result in reputational damage to Asda’s brand, loss of consumer trust or human rights or anti-corruption law investigations of Asda. In addition to non-compliance with international or domestic labour, health and safety laws or environmental laws, we face a variety of risks generally associated with sourcing products from suppliers in foreign markets, including, among others, political instability; increased security requirements applicable to foreign goods; the imposition of taxes, duties, other charges and restrictions on imports; currency and exchange rate risks; risks related to environmental matters or other issues in the foreign countries or factories in which our products are manufactured; delays in shipping; and increased costs of transportation. Any of these risks, in isolation or in combination, could materially adversely affect our reputation, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Increased transportation costs or disruption to transportation services could materially adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Cost-effective transportation of our products is an important element of our cost structure. We depend on the use of refrigerated trailers for the shipping of certain of our products from our suppliers’ facilities to our distribution centres, from our distribution centres to our stores and from our stores and distribution centres to our customers. Asda drivers deliver goods to stores and customers using a fleet of leased tractors, trailers and vans, as well as occasional spot-hire or third-party hauliers. See “Business—Our Suppliers and Logistics.” Transportation costs have historically fluctuated significantly over time, in particular in connection with oil prices, and increases in transportation costs could result in reduced profits. For example, more recently we have experienced increases in global shipping rates resulting from increased demand for container-based shipping and increases in the cost of fuel for our HGV fleet resulting from increases in the global price of oil, which, especially if protracted, could materially increase our costs and adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, climate change related taxes and levies are a large portion of the energy related costs required to maintain the cold chain. These climate change related taxes have been increasing in recent years and are expected to increase in the future. We are subject to regulations governing the number of hours and days that drivers can work consecutively, and as a result, we may not have enough drivers available to work during periods of very high demand or adverse weather conditions. Additionally, we face competition from other retailers and businesses in hiring and retaining drivers and couriers for our delivery services and distribution network. Moreover, delivery service is also a field with inherent high attrition rate and job mobility. We have been facing sustained freight inflation, plus a shortage of heavy goods vehicle drivers across the United Kingdom. In addition, the reduction in the number of EU nationals working in the United Kingdom following Brexit has led to shortages of staff at national food suppliers and in the food supply chain, as well as a shortage of drivers in the logistics sector. As a result, we may not be able to hire a sufficient number of drivers to meet our demand, which may result in us paying increased labour costs in order to attract new drivers or retain existing ones. Continued labour shortages or increased labour costs could materially adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, climate change related taxes and levies are a large portion of the energy related costs required to maintain the cold chain. These climate change related taxes have been increasing in recent years and are expected to increase in the future. Any increases in the cost of labour or 55 ----- transportation, including as a result of increased fuel prices or environmental regulations or initiatives that mandate more costly methods of transport, could significantly increase our cost of doing business. An impairment or loss of one or more distribution centres due to accidents, fires, technical disruptions, sabotage or other events, or an impairment or disruption in IPL’s or other suppliers’ service, including significant price increases, could result in a temporary disruption in the delivery of products to our stores and additional costs. Although we believe that we would be able to find an alternative distribution centre or an alternative operator, if necessary, we may be unable to find alternative providers in a timely fashion, on reasonable terms, or at all. We also require last-mile transport for our delivery services, which is one of the most expensive parts of the transportation process. Changes in these agreements governing the relationships with these providers could also result in reduced profits. Any increases in the cost of transportation, and any disruption to our transportation and logistics systems, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may enter into transactions with related parties in the ordinary course of business or otherwise.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, following disclosure in line with internal governance policies, we have entered and may enter into arm’s length transactions with affiliates that may be considered related party transactions. For example, we have in the past and may in the future, enter into transactions with EG Group, which is also owned by our shareholders. Following the EG UK Acquisition, many of our transactions with the EG Group business that had been considered “affiliate transactions” ceased to be affiliate transactions by virtue of the fact that we now own the EG UK Business and such business forms part of the Group. However, there can be no assurance that we will not enter into future transaction with EG Group or other related parties. We disclose all material related party transactions in our financial statements and have implemented certain policies and procedures whereby certain employees and committees screen each of the material transactions for any possible affiliations between us and companies controlled by us or our shareholders. See note 30 (“Related parties”) to the 2023 Financial Statements appearing herein for further disclosure on our related party transactions. See also “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.” In addition, we maintain robust internal governance procedures whereby we screen every agreement we enter into to determine if it is an affiliate transaction by cross-checking the party to our list of affiliates. In the event a counterparty is an affiliate, we work closely with our controllership and corporate governance teams to ensure that transactions are conducted at arm’s length. Although our corporate governance guidelines require that we engage in any related party transactions on an arm’s length basis, there can be no assurance that the terms of any such transactions will be as favourable to us as would be the case had they not been with related parties. The appearance of conflicts, even if such conflicts do not materialise, might adversely affect the public’s perception of us, as well as our relationship with other companies and our ability to enter into new relationships in the future, including with competitors of such related parties, which could harm our business and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to keep pace with new technological developments in the online grocery business.
Subsubsection Text: Consumer expectations regarding the use of digital tools and omni-channel shopping are rapidly evolving, with customers seeking to prioritise retailers that offer technological solutions that reduce shopping and checkout times. One of our objectives is to use digital tools to enhance the in-store experience from product selection to checkout and further develop the omni-channel retail experience we offer our customers. We rely in part on third parties for development of and access to such new technologies and tools. We expect that new services and technologies will continue to emerge. These new services and technologies may be superior to, or render obsolete, the technologies that we currently use. Incorporating new technologies into our products and services may require substantial expenditures and take considerable time, and ultimately may not be successful. In addition, our ability to adopt new services and develop new technologies may be inhibited by industry-wide standards, new laws and regulations, or third parties’ intellectual property rights. Our success will depend on our ability to develop new technologies and adapt to new technological changes and evolving industry standards.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face certain risks in relation to our online presence, which is a rapidly evolving part of our operations, including as regards data privacy, security breaches, hacking and vandalism. These cyber-attacks or data breaches materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our online channels are currently supported by a number of legacy technology platforms, all of which will be replaced in 2024 with new systems as part of Project Future. Further, we have successfully converted seven depots as 56 ----- of March 31, 2024 as part of our new Warehouse Management system “Manhattan” (with two more in progress) and have implemented our new store till systems across many stores. These online channels, which are increasingly important to our business and continue to grow in complexity and scope, and the systems on which they run, are regularly subject to cyberattacks. Those attacks involve attempts to gain unauthorised access to our websites and mobile applications to obtain and misuse customers’ information, including payment information. Such attacks, if successful, in addition to potential data misuse, may also create denials of service or otherwise disable, degrade or sabotage one or more of our online platforms, which may significantly disrupt our customers’ shopping experience. If we are unable to maintain the security of our digital platforms and keep them operating within acceptable parameters, we could suffer sanction, loss of sales, reductions in transactions, reputational damage and deterioration of our competitive position and incur liability for any damage to customers or others whose personal or confidential information is unlawfully obtained and misused, any of which events could have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations and impede the execution of our strategy or the growth of our business. Any of these risks could be amplified if we are unable to smoothly transition onto our new IT system as part of Project Future. The UK online grocery industry is still developing and rapidly evolving. Our online grocery operations must, therefore, be considered in light of the risks and difficulties we encounter operating in an industry that is still evolving. These risks and difficulties include: - managing rapid growth in personnel and operations; - developing sufficient management and technology capability in a rapidly evolving industry; - managing and further developing a complex business system; - capital expenditures associated with the development of our online operations and support functions; - risks surrounding online payments; - further development to our infrastructure and technology solutions; - maintaining our profit margins if consumer preferences shift overall to prefer online sales over brickand-mortar store sales; and - accurately predicting future capacity requirements and ability to maintain or grow market share. Furthermore, we may be affected by an increase in governmental regulation of the internet and/or online retail. The application or modification of existing laws or regulations, or adoption of new laws and regulations governing the internet and online retail operations could materially adversely affect the manner in which we currently conduct our online business. The legislative framework governing the internet remains largely unsettled, even in areas where there has been some legislative action. In addition, the growth and development of the market for online retail may lead to more stringent customer protection laws that may impose additional burdens on us, all of which may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and prospects. We may be subject to privacy or data protection failures, including in respect of the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of EUWA (the “UK GDPR”). We collect, process and utilise personal data from customers, business contacts, colleagues and other third-parties, marketing initiatives and the large number of credit and debit transactions we process, and the failure to adequately maintain and protect such information, or failure to comply with applicable data protection laws, including by providing adequate privacy notices to our online users, ensuring lawful use of the data, fulfilling rights requests and maintaining consents, could increase the risk of data loss or misuse or other data breaches and could have a material adverse effect on our brand, reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. See also “—We collect and process _personal data in our daily business, and the leakage of such data may violate law and could materially adversely affect our business.”_ We rely on third-party service providers to process customer payments made using debit cards and credit cards.
