Our online operations depend heavily upon the secure transmission of confidential information over public networks, including the use of cashless payments. The use and handling of this personal information is regulated by 57 ----- evolving and increasingly demanding laws and regulations at the sub-national, national and international level, as well as by certain third-party contracts. The legal and regulatory frameworks governing the use and handling of personal information are relatively new and are still evolving. If we or any of our third-party service providers fail to store, transmit and purge customer information in a secure or otherwise compliant manner, if our security and information systems are compromised as a result of data corruption or loss, a cyberattack or a network security incident, or if our colleagues or certain third-parties fail to comply with data protection laws and regulations (and, as a result, information about our customers or colleagues is obtained by unauthorised persons and/or used inappropriately), we could be subject to liabilities and penalties, damage to our reputation, litigation or government enforcement actions, substantial costs and a loss of customer confidence, all of which may significantly adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely extensively on information systems to process transactions, summarise results and manage our business. These systems are interdependent and disruptions in the IT infrastructure that we use could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on an extensive array of information systems (including servers, networks, applications, websites and databases) that are essential to the operation and management of our activities. The development, implementation and continuous and uninterrupted performance of our hardware, network, applications, website and other systems, including those which may be provided by third parties, are important factors in our delivery of products and services to our customers. We are dependent on our technical infrastructure and computer applications for all aspects of the day-to-day management of our business, including purchasing, sourcing, distribution, online sales, customer delivery, data exploitation, invoicing, cash collection, reporting and consolidation, as well as electronic data exchange and access to internal information, all of which provide necessary information upon which management makes its business decisions. Our performance depends on accurate, timely information and numerical data from key software applications to aid day-to-day business and decision-making processes. We are exposed to operational risks, such as the breakdown or failure of equipment, interruption of power supplies or processes, fires, floods or other natural disasters, acts of sabotage or vandalism, and industrial accidents. We rely on our information technology systems for communication among our suppliers, stores, distribution centres and headquarters and for our online sales. We may be adversely affected if our controls fail to detect or contain operational risks. If we do not allocate and effectively manage the resources necessary to build and sustain the proper technology infrastructure and to maintain the related automated and manual control processes, we could be subject to adverse effects, including billing and collection errors, business disruptions and damages related to security breaches. Any disruption caused by failings in our information technology infrastructure or underlying equipment or of communication networks could delay or otherwise impact our day-to-day business and decision-making processes and negatively impact our performance. Failure of our IT infrastructure or key IT systems could lead to loss of earnings, regulatory fines, limit our ability to operate effectively and have a negative impact on our reputation. We currently rely on Walmart for a material portion of our technology services and will continue to depend on Walmart to maintain and develop IT systems for our use during the term of the TSA. If we are unable to transition from the Walmart IT system onto a suitable replacement system, it could result in a material disruption to our business. See also “Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions—Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in _significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives” and “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart.” We are undergoing a_ separation programme, Project Future, to transition the Group to a standalone, leading edge IT infrastructure which will enable it to improve operating efficiencies, make better use of data, improve its experience for customers and colleagues, and enable the business to be more agile in responding to customers’ needs. There is a high degree of complexity in connection with the implementation of the IR system and we may not be able to successfully transition these systems to our standalone operations in a timely manner, or at all, or may have underestimated the costs required to do so. There can be no assurance that there will not be errors, delays, payroll transition issues, or other related issues resulting from the transition to a standalone company and adjustments to associated business processes or that we will be able to fix any error or issue. We also depend on other third parties to maintain and develop our IT systems. If such providers were to terminate their agreements with us or stop providing services to us for any reason, or if such providers were to 58 ----- considerably raise the price of their services, our business would be materially and adversely affected. Some of these providers are small companies and their long-term financial viability cannot be assured. We cannot guarantee you that we will be able to find and retain alternative providers or acquire the rights to intellectual property important to our operations if our current or future providers become financially unstable. To the extent any of these systems, technologies or programmes do not function properly and we cannot find and retain a suitable IT provider to help remedy the fault, we may experience material adverse effects on our business that require substantial additional investments to remedy, or which we may not be able to remedy at all. The performance of the IT systems that we use depends on, among other things, our ability to effectively safeguard such IT systems and related equipment against damage or compromise from interruptions to telecommunication services, data breaches, hacking and phishing attempts and the introduction of malware and computer viruses. Delays or interruptions in the delivery of our products could result from unknown data, software or hardware defects, insufficient capacity or the failure of our website hosting, mobile applications and telecommunications vendors to provide continuous and uninterrupted service. Any significant breakdown of plant or equipment, accidents, such as a serious flood, fire and other natural disasters, or other significant disruption to the operations of our primary sites for all of our computer and communications systems could significantly affect our ability to manage our information technology systems. Our equipment and technology systems also require ongoing maintenance, refinement, updating and may also require replacement with more advanced equipment or systems in the future. If we are unable to maintain more advanced equipment or systems in the future or upgrade our IT system regularly, we may experience difficulties with the adoption of new technology and systems into our existing operations. Furthermore, disruptions to operations or interruptions in operations involving such systems may occur in the future. Any material disruption or slowdown of our equipment or technology systems, including those caused by our failure to successfully upgrade our equipment or systems, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We cannot assure protection against unauthorised attempts to access the IT systems that we use, including malicious third-party applications that may interfere with or exploit security flaws in our products and services. We rely on encryption and authentication technology to provide the security necessary to effect the secure transmission of information from our customers, such as credit or debit card numbers (although as part of our Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards (“PCI-DSS”) compliance we do not store this data but use third-party payment providers). At the same time, we increasingly rely on cloud computing and other technologies that result in third parties holding significant amounts of Asda and customer information on our behalf. We cannot guarantee absolute protection against unauthorised attempts to access our or these third parties’ IT systems, including third party applications that may interfere with or exploit security flaws in our or these third parties’ products and services. Viruses, worms and other malicious software programmes could, among other things, jeopardise the security of information stored in a user’s computer or in our or these third parties’ computer systems, affect the availability of our or these third parties’ computer systems or attempt to change the internet experience of users by interfering with our ability to connect with users. In addition, in the past, we have also experienced system intrusion attempts through non-cyber means, including through fraudulent phone calls. We have seen an increase over the past several years in the frequency and sophistication of attempts to compromise the security of the types of IT and other systems we use. If any compromise in our security measures, or those of the third parties we rely on (including our suppliers) were to occur and our, or their, efforts to combat such a breach are unsuccessful, our reputation may be harmed leading to a material adverse effect on our financial condition and prospects. Any failure of such IT systems due to a technical issue or a cyberattack, and any failure of our IT systems’ support teams to mitigate such IT system failures, could have a material adverse effect on our business operations and assets. For example, any such failure could impact on the availability of electronic point of sale (EPOS) systems and therefore limit our ability to complete sales. Moreover, a failure that causes our websites to become unavailable could materially adversely affect online product viewing opportunities and sales. If any compromise in our security measures were to occur and our efforts to combat such a breach were unsuccessful, our operations would be interrupted and our reputation could be harmed, leading to a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. 59 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our use of open-source software may restrict our ability to exploit our proprietary software and IT systems and exposes us to certain risks.
Subsubsection Text: Our key proprietary software and critical IT systems incorporate significant elements of “open source” software, our use of which is subject to the terms of applicable licences. Open-source software is typically licensed for use at no initial charge on terms which allow modification and distribution of the software by the licensee. However, licence terms may impose on the user compliance requirements and obligations to disclose modifications we have made to the software to third parties. Our ability to realise fully the commercial benefits of any such software may be restricted because: - Open-source licences may be drafted in legally ambiguous language and may result in unanticipated consequences or obligations regarding our software; - due to the requirements to licence modified software, our competitors or licensees may have access to information which may help them to develop competitive products; - open-source software is available to the public for anyone to access and utilise, including our competitors; and - it may be difficult for us to identify accurately the developers of the open-source code (who may be licensors of the software) and whether the licensed software infringes third party intellectual property rights. Furthermore, to the extent we use open-source software we face certain more general risks which apply to any organisation making use of such software. Our use of GNU General Public Licence (“GPL”) software could subject certain portions of our proprietary software to GPL requirements, including an obligation on us to disclose that software to third parties and to permit them to use the software free of charge. Finally, open-source licences typically present onerous compliance requirements and failure to observe these may result in litigation or the loss of the right to use the software which may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and future prospects. Although we are not aware that we have breached any of these compliance requirements, and to our knowledge no third party has claimed that software owned by us should be made available on an open-source basis, any of the risks or restrictions relating to open-source software mentioned above could have an adverse impact on our financial condition and future prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If the technology-based systems that give our customers the ability to shop with us in stores and online do not function effectively, our results of operations, as well as our ability to grow our omni-channel business, could be materially adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Increasingly, customers are using computers, tablets, and smart phones to shop with us and with our competitors and to do comparison shopping. We use our websites, social media, online advertising, and email campaigns to interact with our customers and as a means to enhance their shopping experience. As a part of our omni-channel strategy, we offer home delivery and pickup options under which many products available for purchase online can be picked up in-store by the customer via our Click & Collect offer and our Scan&Go service that allows customers to use a handset or the Scan&Go mobile app to scan and bag items as they shop and utilise a dedicated checkout area for quick and easy payment, in each case providing additional customer traffic at such stores. In 2022, we also implemented a new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards, which is an app-based system whereby customers earn cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store and online, and earn additional discounts on certain products. Omni-channel retailing is a rapidly evolving part of the UK retail grocery industry. We must anticipate and meet our customers’ changing expectations while adjusting for technology investments and developments in our competitors’ operations through focusing on the building and delivery of a seamless shopping experience across all channels. Any failure on our part to provide attractive, user-friendly secure digital platforms that offer a wide assortment of merchandise at competitive prices and with low-cost and rapid delivery options and that continually meet the changing expectations of online shoppers and developments in online and digital platform merchandising and related technology could place us at a competitive disadvantage, result in the loss of online and other sales, harm 60 ----- our reputation with customers, have a material adverse impact on the growth of our online business and have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may suffer a loss as a result of operational risk, including human error, ineffective or inadequate designed processes, failure of IT or other systems, improper conduct by colleagues and third parties, failures by suppliers and third-party providers and criminal activity including fraud, theft and cybercrime.
Subsubsection Text: Any failure to maintain the security of the information relating to our business, customers, and colleagues, whether as a result of cybersecurity attacks on our information systems or otherwise, could damage our reputation, result in litigation or other legal actions against us, cause us to incur substantial additional costs, and materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In the ordinary course of our business, we are exposed to the risk of theft or misappropriation of funds and products and to the risk of fraud and corruption in our stores and warehouses, as well as human error. For example, from time to time, products may be misappropriated during transportation, or we may experience a misappropriation of funds or goods in our stores or at other levels of our business. We cannot assure that incidences of inventory loss and theft will not increase further in the future, that insurance will cover such losses adequately or that the measures we are taking against such theft will effectively decrease inventory shrinkage. In addition to increasing security costs to combat inventory theft, the occurrence of such risks may have a material adverse impact on our results of operations and reputation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Use of social media may adversely impact our reputation or subject us to fines or other penalties.
Subsubsection Text: There has been a marked increase in the use of social media platforms and similar devices, including blogs, social media websites and other forms of internet-based communications which allow individual access to a broad audience of customers and other interested persons. Consumers value readily available information concerning retailers, manufacturers and their goods and services and often act on such information without further investigation, authentication and without regard to its accuracy. The availability of information on social media platforms and devices is virtually immediate as is its impact. Social media platforms and devices immediately publish the content their subscribers and participants post, often without filters or checks on accuracy of the content posted. The opportunity for dissemination of information, including inaccurate information, is virtually limitless. Information concerning or affecting us may be posted on such platforms and devices at any time. Information posted may be inaccurate and adverse to us, and it may harm our business. The harm may be immediate without affording us an opportunity for redress or correction. Such platforms also could be used for the dissemination of trade secret information or compromise of other valuable company assets, any of which could harm our business. We also use social media platforms as marketing tools. For example, we maintain TikTok, Instagram, Facebook and Twitter accounts. In addition, we may from time-to-time partner with celebrities, influencers and other third parties across various social media platforms, but there can be no assurance that these campaigns will be successful or that their values align with Asda’s values and therefore our association with such parties may negatively affect or harm our reputation. Furthermore, other social media users with whom we do not have partnerships or control over may use their accounts and following based on these social media platforms to criticise Asda with subjective or false, or without basis, which may in turn adversely impact our reputation. See also “—Any events that negatively _impact the reputation of, or value associated with, our brands could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ As laws and regulations rapidly evolve to govern the use of these platforms and devices, the failure by us, our colleagues or third parties acting at our direction to abide by applicable laws and regulations in the use of these platforms and devices could adversely impact our business or subject us to fines or other penalties.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rent certain of our properties pursuant to commercial leases that may be subject to adjustments that could increase expenses and have a materially adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Certain of our stores and warehouses are leased pursuant to commercial leases for fixed terms consistent with market practice. Such leases usually provide for regular rent reviews, at which time our rental costs may increase in line with certain indices or in line with the open market rent. Our ability to maintain our existing rental rates during 61 ----- renewals or to renew any expired lease on favourable terms will depend on many factors which are not within our control, such as applicable real estate laws and regulations, payments for utilities, local taxes or assessments, conditions in the local real estate market, competition for desirable properties and our relationships with current and prospective landlords. If rent reviews were to increase at higher rates than currently anticipated or if we were unable to renew any expired leases on commercially favourable terms, our financial performance could be adversely impacted. Further, we may be unable to extend expiring lease agreements at all or may have no or limited ability to close certain store locations that do not meet our financial targets or are no longer consistent with our brands’ positioning. These changes in the size of our store network can have a significant impact on our revenues and expenses from one period to the next, which affect the comparability of our results during these periods. Our ability to enter into leases to open new retail locations depends on the availability of locations that meet our criteria for traffic, square footage, lease economics, demographics and other factors. In addition, the market for suitable retail locations is highly competitive. Some of our competitors may have the ability to negotiate more favourable commercial lease terms than we can. The above risks are also applicable to (i) the leases of the Warehouse Assets pursuant to the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions, (ii) the leases of the SLB Properties pursuant to the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and (iii) the leases of the CGR Properties pursuant to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. Any breach that we commit under our lease agreements and do not remedy in line with the relevant forfeiture provisions may lead to forfeiture of the relevant lease by the landlord, subject to our ability to seek relief from forfeiture (except in respect of lease agreements for stores located in Scotland where no such relief process applies) from the courts (any such relief being at the discretion of the courts). Forfeiture of the leases would result in the loss of our right to occupy the property and may entail material interruption to the business and operations of the Group. In addition, a breach of any Ground Lease may entitle the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction to accelerate the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement and enforce security over all properties secured under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction resulting in the loss of ownership of the freehold and long leases properties comprising the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. If we are unable to renew our lease agreements as they expire or if any of our existing lease agreements are terminated for any reason and we are unable to secure other favourable locations on acceptable terms, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “Risks Relating to _Financial, Reporting, and Other Matters—We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party valuation report of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”_ The Group’s leases of the Warehouse Assets and SLB Properties and the Ground Leases are leases for terms of at least 25 years. If the Group needs to exit a lease of a Warehouse Assets or SLB Property, it will need to assign or underlet the lease and must meet the criteria set out in the relevant leases to effect a disposition. In a depressed market or if there is no demand for a property, the Group may not be able to exit that property in a cost-efficient manner, or at all. In terms of the Ground Leases, the tenant is not permitted to assign so in order to exit the property the tenant may seek to underlet the property (subject to the restrictions contained in the Ground Leases); the implication of this is that on such an underletting the tenant remains liable for any non-performance of the tenant covenants in the relevant lease by the undertenant.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A significant disruption in our workforce or the workforce of our suppliers or a failure to extend, renew or renegotiate trade union agreements could lead to labour disputes that might interfere with our operations or otherwise could materially adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we employed 148,771 colleagues, with 98,284 full-time employees. 126,541 of these colleagues worked in our store network and 13,139 worked in our distribution network. From time to time, we may experience labour disputes and we can never rule out the possibility of work stoppages. We are also exposed to similar risks involving the workforce of our third-party suppliers, including all of our distribution centre operators. In particular, a labour stoppage or other interruption at one of our suppliers or distribution centres would impact our ability to supply our stores or online orders and could have a pronounced effect on our operations as a result. As we do not directly control our suppliers, we have limited information on labour relations between our suppliers and their workforces. 62 ----- In addition, some of our colleagues are members of trade unions and are parties to collective bargaining agreements, which contain provisions covering issues such as working hours and compensation. See “Business—Our _Colleagues.” We may not be able to extend existing agreements, renew them on their current terms or, negotiate such_ agreements in a favourable and timely manner or without work stoppages, strikes or similar industrial actions, any of which may have a material adverse effect on our business. If we seek to reduce colleague benefits, or otherwise are unable to maintain satisfactory colleague and labour relations, the results could include work stoppages, strikes or other industrial action or labour difficulties (including higher labour costs), any of which could materially adversely affect our operations. As a result, any deterioration in our relationships with our colleagues, unions and other colleague representatives could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, we experienced a 48-hour industrial strike at our Gosport superstore starting on February 10, 2024 and at our Wisbech superstore starting on March 29, 2024 and we expect there to be a similar strike at our Lowestoft superstore starting on May 10, 2024. These strikes are initiated by the General, Municipal, Boilermakers’ and Allied Trade Union (the “GMB”), following negotiations over work-culture concerns. GMB members have begun preparing industrial action ballots at our Brighton Marina and Brighton Hollingbury stores. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have not received the notice outlining any of these industrial strikes’ dates. We have been and, in the future, may again be subject to additional industrial action ballots at different stores, and negotiations with trade unions cannot ensure the avoidance of strikes or work stoppages. From time to time, disagreements and other disputes may emerge with our workforce and/or their representatives and we are presently engaged in ordinary course litigation regarding dismissals, overtime work and other routine disputes or actions. See “Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation.” We cannot assure you that a future labour disturbance, work stoppage, or failure to attract and retain operative personnel at any of our stores, depots or our suppliers’ facilities in the United Kingdom or elsewhere would not have a material adverse effect on such store’s or facility’s operations and, potentially, on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our failure to attract and retain qualified colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other changes to wage regulations could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are reliant on our staff for the management, operation, creation, maintenance, repair and upgrading of our business, operations and systems. Our ability to recruit or adequately replace, retain and motivate suitably qualified and experienced staff is important for our ongoing success. It may in the future become more difficult for us to recruit or retain such members of staff with the relevant skillset, retain key colleagues, or adapt colleague skillsets to align with transformation activities, which could lead to a negative impact on operational performance, a delay in separation transformation and ultimately impact our external reputation. Moreover, the UK labour market may become more competitive. An inability to recruit and retain sufficient personnel of the right calibre or the incurring of significant costs in order to do so may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and future prospects. Furthermore, our automated warehouses and delivery trucks still require intensive labour. Colleague benefits (which include wages, National Insurance contributions and other payments) currently represent one of our most significant cost items, accounting for a substantial portion of our total expenses. Consequently, our commercial success depends in part on our ability to manage our labour costs and control their impact on our margins. We may in the future be forced to raise our wages due to changes in market conditions, new labour laws and regulations, collective bargaining with our recognised trade unions or general wage increases across the industry or in any particular region in which we operate. For example, in April 2023, we voluntarily increased our rate for hourly-paid store colleagues to £11.00 an hour and further increased this in July 2023 to £11.11 an hour. For stores inside the M25 and around Greater London, our rate for hourly-paid store colleagues increased to £12.28 an hour. The national minimum wage is due to increase to £11.44 an hour in April 2024, and we plan to give our colleagues an interim increase, with those inside the M25 and around Greater London receiving £12.61 an hour. In July 2024, we are proposing a further increase in pay to 120,000 of our colleagues which will increase the basic pay for retail workers to £12.04 an hour, with those at stores inside the M25 and around Greater London receiving £13.21 an hour. Overall, this is an 8.4% increase in pay from £11.11 in July 2023 to the proposed £12.04 in July 2024. Additionally, we compete with other producers for dependable employees. The supply of such employees is limited and competition to hire and retain them may result in higher labour costs, for example as a result of higher wages implemented in response to inflationary pressure and cost of living increases. Furthermore, a number of our 63 ----- employees are subject to national minimum wage requirements. Given the high proportion of our colleagues who are paid hourly, future increases or changes to the National Minimum Wage legislation, the National Living Wage or other hourly wage legislation or regulations could have an impact on our future financial success. As of April 2023, the National Living Wage increased from £9.50 per hour as of April 2022 to £10.42 per hour. The National Living Wage will increase in increments with a target to be set by the UK government of reaching £11.44 by April 2024. We must comply with such legislation. Any failure to comply could result in criminal prosecution with any party found to be guilty of deliberate non-compliance being subject to disqualification as a company director for up to 15 years. From time to time, we are subject to legal proceedings in connection with the wages we pay. See “Business—Legal _Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation.” If legislation is enacted that has the effect of raising national minimum wage_ requirements, requires additional mandatory employee benefits or affects our ability to hire or dismiss employees, we could face substantially higher labour costs. Increases in labour costs could adversely affect our profitability if we are not able to pass them on to our customers. As national minimum hourly wage rates increase, we may be required to increase not only the wage rates of our hourly paid colleagues but also the wages of our salaried managers as an increase in hourly rates inevitably erodes the pay gap between hourly paid and first line managers. This makes it more challenging to incentivise our most talented colleagues to progress into management positions. It also makes it difficult to retain our talented managers. Although difficult to predict with certainty, these higher salaried costs could have a material adverse effect on our profitability. While we cannot be certain how this will affect our business, an increase in the minimum wage rate paid to certain workers will increase our labour costs which may adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition. Our ability to meet our management labour needs, while controlling wage and labour-related costs, is subject to numerous external factors, including the availability of and competition for qualified persons in the local markets in which we are located, unemployment levels within those markets, prevailing pay rates, changing demographics, and changes in employment and labour laws. Such laws related to hours, wages, job classification and benefits could significantly increase operating costs. If we fail to maintain our competitive position on pay and benefits, the quality of our workforce could decline, causing our customer service to suffer, while increasing wages for our colleagues could cause our profit margins to decrease. If we are unable to hire, retain, and train colleagues capable of meeting our business needs and expectations, our business and brand image may be impaired. Any failure to meet our staffing needs or any material increase in turnover rates may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and prospects. Furthermore, we are required to pay social security, National Insurance contributions, pension contributions and other similar charges for our colleagues. These may increase over time or the laws and regulations setting forth any exonerations or other exemptions from payment of such charges from which we currently benefit may change, increasing our liabilities. We maintain a defined contribution pension plan that covers current and former colleagues pursuant to which the employer, employee or both make contributions on a regular basis to such plans. See “Management’s Discussion _and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations— Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In.” Any of the foregoing may affect our profitability and may have a material_ adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. If we are not able to pass on such higher costs to our customers, these higher labour costs could materially adversely affect our profitability.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our intellectual property rights may be infringed or challenged. Intellectual property claims by third parties or our failure or inability to protect our intellectual property rights could diminish the value of our brand and weaken our competitive position.
Subsubsection Text: We own or use a variety of trade names, logos, domain names, service marks and trademarks in our business and rely on trademark and copyright laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions to protect our intellectual proprietary rights. We may not have adequate protections for our intellectual property rights or may be accused of infringing intellectual property rights of third parties. We cannot be certain that third parties will not infringe, misappropriate or terminate these rights. With the exception of the George brand, we own nearly all the intellectual property rights over the trademarks, trade signs and copyrights that we use. We also own some of the intellectual property rights over the software and technologies that we use. However, such use may be challenged by 64 ----- third parties. If we are unable to protect and maintain our own intellectual property rights or our use of the intellectual property rights owned by others, or we are unable to renew our intellectual property rights when they expire, the value of our brands could be diminished, and our competitive position could weaken. We may not be able to discover or determine the extent of any unauthorised use of our proprietary rights. Third parties that licence our proprietary rights may also take actions that diminish the value of our proprietary rights or reputation. The protection of our intellectual property may require the expenditure of financial and managerial resources. Moreover, the steps we take to protect our intellectual property may not adequately protect our rights or prevent third parties from infringing or misappropriating our proprietary rights. We also cannot be certain that others will not independently develop or otherwise acquire equivalent or superior technology or other intellectual property rights. In addition, our products, services, websites or acts conducted in the ordinary course of our business may violate, or be perceived to violate, intellectual property rights of third parties (in particular, copyrights, trademarks, design rights, patents and software) and we may be subject to infringement claims. We may also be involved in claims raised by third parties against our suppliers. For example, we may be involved in claims regarding products or services supplied by our suppliers that are perceived as infringing intellectual property rights of third parties. Third parties may assert intellectual property claims against us as we expand our business to include new services and continue to develop our online channel. We may also face claims from our suppliers if they consider that their intellectual property rights are being misused, especially where those suppliers have a strong brand image and reputation. Our defence of any claim, regardless of its merit, could be expensive and time consuming, and could divert management resources. Successful infringement claims against us could result in significant monetary liability and prevent us from selling some of our products and/or services. In addition, the resolution of claims may require us to abandon the sale or provision of the litigious product or service, redesign our own private-label products or acquire licence rights from third parties, which could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Robbery, shop crime and fraud in our stores may adversely affect us.
Subsubsection Text: We, like other grocers, have increasingly become the target of robberies, burglaries and theft across our stores. We have witnessed the rate of such crimes increase (in volume and frequency) recently, which may be linked to the continuing cost of living crisis in the United Kingdom. We and are our personnel are exposed to safety threats such as theft, assault or destruction of property. Higher crime rates throughout the United Kingdom could negatively our sales and operations. Despite our efforts to reduce our exposure to such crimes, for instance through security guards or security cameras on our sites, we expect to continue to be exposed to such crimes and new forms of crime. There can be no assurance that our current or future efforts to counteract crimes will be effective or that the cost of such efforts will not increase. In addition, we have been the target of other forms of crime such as, fraud and embezzlement by our colleagues. Any crime we become victim of may give rise to litigation and related costs, including reputational costs and the costs linked to the diversion of the attention from our management team from day-to-day operations of our business. A single significant incident of fraud, or increases in the overall level of fraud, may be sufficient to result in significant reputational damage to us or could lead to the imposition of regulatory sanctions. Our inability to control and reduce robberies, whether intentional or not, burglaries, fraud, embezzlement or other forms of crime in a cost-effective manner could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Certain activities of our business are seasonal or cyclical in nature, and our revenue, working capital requirements and results of operations may vary from quarter to quarter as a result.
Subsubsection Text: Our sales, profits, working capital requirements and cash flows within any given year have historically been affected by seasonal fluctuations. For example, sales volumes have historically been higher in the run-up to the Christmas and Easter holidays and historically lower in February. In addition, sales of certain of our products have historically been higher during the summer tourist season. These seasonal influences have a direct impact on our earnings, and fluctuations in our inventory or store closings during these peak periods could affect our working capital requirements. If seasonal fluctuations are greater than anticipated, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our quarterly results of operations may also fluctuate significantly as a result of other factors, including the timing of new store openings, temporary or definitive closings 65 ----- or disposals, and the revenue contributed by new stores or the loss of revenue from closed or sold stores. For these reasons, sequential quarterly comparisons may not be a good indication of our performance or how we may perform in the future. For a further discussion of the impact of seasonality on our business, see “Management’s Discussion _and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations— Seasonality of Our Results of Operations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to payments risks, including processing risks, increases in transaction fees, actions taken by third parties that could disrupt our operations, failure by us or third parties on whom we rely to fully comply with rules and standards governing payment processing, and system failures and security breaches.
Subsubsection Text: We are reliant on electronic payment methods. We accept payments using credit and debit cards, gift cards, contactless, PayPal, Android Pay and Apple Pay. As we offer new payment options to customers, we and our customers may be increasingly exposed to fraud (although fraud is not currently a significant concern). For existing and future payment options we offer our customers, we may become subject to additional regulations and compliance requirements (including obligations to implement enhanced authentication processes that could result in significant costs and reduce the ease of use of our payments products). We pay interchange and other fees for these card payments, which may increase over time and raise operating costs and lower margins. Interchange fees on Visa and MasterCard are regulated and are therefore currently subject to an effective minimum amount, which is beyond our control. Interchange fees on American Express payments are negotiated with American Express on an arm’s-length basis. We rely on third parties to provide payment processing services, and it could disrupt our operations if these companies become unwilling or unable to provide these services. We are also subject to payment card association operating rules, certification requirements, PCI-DSS and rules governing electronic funds transfers, which could change or be reinterpreted, making them difficult or impossible to comply with. If we fail to comply with these rules or requirements, we may be subject to fines and/or higher transaction fees and, in extreme cases, may lose our ability to accept payments from customers, process electronic funds transfers or facilitate other types of online payments. See also “—We rely extensively on information systems to process transactions, summarise results and manage our _business. These systems are interdependent and disruptions in the IT infrastructure that we use could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.”_ Any failure of our payment processing systems, whether caused by a systems failure or otherwise, will adversely affect our income in the short-term and may result in us losing customers which may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and prospects. In addition, there can be no assurance that advances in computer capabilities, new discoveries in the field of cryptography, or other events or developments will not result in a compromise or breach of the processes we use to protect customer transaction data. If any such compromise or breach were to occur, it could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. In certain circumstances, our contract with our payment card acquirer and American Express generally require us to adhere to payment card network rules which could make us liable to payment card issuers and others if information in connection with payment cards and payment card transactions that we process is compromised. In such cases, resulting liabilities could be substantial.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may from time to time pursue acquisitions, which may prove more costly than anticipated and may not generate anticipated synergies and which may have an adverse impact on our business, as could our failure to successfully integrate such businesses following acquisition. Our business could also be negatively impacted by merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by supranational and national laws and regulations.
Subsubsection Text: We have in the past acquired and may in the future from time to time acquire other companies or businesses. Pursuing future acquisitions depends on, among other things, identifying suitable acquisition or investment opportunities and successfully completing those transactions. Acquisitions involve numerous risks, any of which could harm our business, including difficulties in integrating the technologies, operations, existing contracts and personnel of an acquired company; difficulties in supporting and transitioning vendors, if any, of an acquired company; diversion of financial and management resources from existing operations or alternative acquisition opportunities; failure to realise the anticipated benefits or synergies of a transaction; failure to identify all of the problems, liabilities or other shortcomings or challenges of an acquired company or technology, including issues related to intellectual property, regulatory compliance practices, revenue recognition or other accounting practices or colleague or customer issues; risks of entering new markets in which we have limited or no experience; potential loss of key colleagues, customers 66 ----- and suppliers from either our current business or an acquired company’s business; inability to generate sufficient revenue to offset acquisition costs; additional costs associated with funding the acquisition; and possible write-offs or impairment charges relating to acquired businesses. Furthermore, acquisitions of businesses outside of our markets may present additional challenges due to cultural and linguistic differences and the difficulties presented by integrating and managing a business that is geographically more remote. Our ability to integrate and manage acquired businesses effectively and to handle any future growth will depend upon a number of factors, and failure to manage growth effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “— _Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions—We may not be able to successfully integrate the businesses we have recently acquired into our business.”_ In addition, the growth of our business to date, and our future growth, has placed and is expected to continue to place significant demands on our management and operational and financial infrastructure. Managing growth has in the past and will in the future continue to require significant expenditure and allocation of management resources, as well as an expansion in headcount. If we fail to achieve the necessary level of efficiency as we continue to grow, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “—We _depend on the services of our senior management team, and our business and growth strategy could be materially adversely impacted if we were to lose a significant number of members of our senior management and were unable to replace them with executives of equal experience and capabilities.”_ Acquisitions may also increase our indebtedness, both through debt incurred to finance the acquisition and existing indebtedness of the acquired company, which could make it more difficult to incur additional indebtedness. Any increase in indebtedness in connection with an acquisition may have a material adverse effect on us. See “— _Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes—We may incur additional debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Senior Secured Notes, and impact our ability to operate our businesses.”_ Moreover, merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by national laws and regulations could negatively impact our business if such laws and regulations prevent us from expanding our growth through the consummation of mergers or acquisitions in certain categories or oblige us to divest certain stores or activities that may have an impact on our market shares in some geographical areas. For example, in order to address competitive concerns raised by the Competition and Markets Authority (“CMA”), we agreed to divest 13 sites in connection with the Arthur Acquisition. At the same time, if smaller players in our markets are able to consolidate, this could increase the competitive pressure on our business due to an increase in such competitors’ economies of scale and a reduction in their operating costs. Moreover, our competitors might acquire smaller players in our markets, further strengthening their position in the market. These events could cause our business, financial condition and results of operations to be materially and adversely affected. See “—We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices.
Subsubsection Text: Part of our overall strategy is to be a leader in our business sectors. We may be accused of anti-competitive practices based on our conduct and taking into account our market position. Any such claims could materially adversely affect our reputation, potentially result in legal proceedings that could have an impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations and require us to divest assets. Such claims could also impair our ability to conduct acquisitions accretive to our business. For example, in 2023, we were part of a CMA fuel pricing market study which resulted in a fine to Asda related to the delayed provision of information. Before certain potential future acquisitions can be consummated, we may also be required to seek approvals and consents from regulatory agencies or there may be applicable waiting periods that will need to expire. We may be unable to obtain such regulatory approvals or consents, or, in order to obtain them, we may be required to dispose of assets or take other actions that could have the effect of reducing our return on potential future acquisitions. For example, in order to address competitive concerns raised by the CMA, we agreed to divest 13 sites in connection with the Arthur Acquisition. Even if regulatory authorities do not require disposals or other actions, the regulatory approval process may have the effect of delaying our ability to implement potential future acquisitions. See also “—We are subject to extensive, increasingly _stringent and frequently changing laws and regulations and increased scrutiny from regulators and enforcement authorities, including in relation to advertising, food and product safety, health and safety matters and the environment, and both compliance and non-compliance therewith could impose substantial liabilities and costs and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ 67 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A loss of key personnel or of our ability to attract and retain experienced members of management, qualified employees and other key personnel could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on our senior management as one of our major competitive strengths. Our success depends, in part, upon the continued services of our senior management team to operate our business and execute our strategies. Our senior management’s knowledge of the market, our businesses and our company represent a key strength of our business model. The success of our business strategy and our future growth also depend on our ability to attract, train, retain and motivate skilled colleagues, managerial, sales, administration, development and operating personnel. There can be no assurance that any members of our senior management team will continue to be employed by us or that we will be able to attract and retain qualified personnel in the future. For example, as disclosed in “Recent Developments,” our shareholders are also involved in active discussions regarding Zuber Issa ceasing to continue as a shareholder of the Group. We also currently do not have a Chief Executive Officer, which could have an adverse impact on our business and divert other management attention. The loss of a significant number of members of our senior management team who are in critical roles, the failure to attract additional key personnel, or the failure to find a suitable Chief Executive Officer in a timely fashion could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. This could also result in additional duties for the remaining members of senior management, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Increased criminal sophistication to facilitate human trafficking and modern slavery may lead to our business operations being infiltrated and abused more often for the illegal purpose of exploiting vulnerable individuals.
Subsubsection Text: Because of our dependency on cross-continental goods transport and the type of operations such as food packaging manufacturing that are well-documented targets for exploitation schemes by criminals, there is a risk that criminals will continue to attempt to conduct their exploitative schemes undetected within our supply chain or business operations. We have dealt with occasional incidents of modern slavery and human trafficking in recent years, and we believe that these criminal acts in general across any business sector in the United Kingdom will continue to exist and may increase. If we are unable to identify, act and remediate third party criminal acts quickly then, despite not having acted illegally ourselves, there is a significant risk of negative publicity.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians
Subsubsection Title: Certain risks are inherent in providing pharmacy services, our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us and may cause us reputational harm.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we operate 247 pharmacies and, as a result, we are exposed to risks inherent in the packaging, dispensing, distribution and disposal of pharmaceuticals and other healthcare products, such as risks of liability for products which cause harm to customers, as well as increased regulatory risks and related costs and reputational risks. We cannot guarantee that the coverage limits under our insurance programmes will be adequate to protect us against future claims, or that we will be able to maintain this insurance on acceptable terms in the future, or at all. Our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows may be materially adversely affected if in the future our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate or unavailable, or there is an increase in the liability for which we self-insure, or we suffer harm to our reputation as a result of an error or omission. We are subject to numerous government regulations. Each of our in-store pharmacies must be registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council (or the Pharmaceutical Society of Northern Ireland in Northern Ireland). Additionally, before a registered pharmacy can dispense prescriptions under the National Health Service, it must be included in the pharmaceutical list relating to a Health and Wellbeing Board Area, maintained by NHS England, NHS Scotland or NHS Wales and maintained by the Family Practitioner Services in Northern Ireland. In addition, pharmacies dispensing controlled substances are required to maintain records of sale and supply and report incidents to the NHS. If we fail to comply with existing or future laws and regulations, we could be in breach of professional standards and/or NHS terms of service, which could lead to a hierarchy of penalties up to and including the loss of such pharmacy’s registration. Each pharmacy therefore has a responsible pharmacist to ensure it operates in a safe and legal manner and corporate-wide this responsibility is shared by the Superintendent Pharmacist. Application of laws and regulations could subject our current practices to allegations of impropriety or illegality or could require us to make changes to our operations. In addition, we cannot predict the impact of future 68 ----- legislation and regulatory changes on our pharmacy business or assure that we will be able to obtain or maintain the regulatory approvals required to operate our business.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians
Subsubsection Title: Changes in results of our pharmacy business could materially adversely affect overall results.
Subsubsection Text: A majority of our retail pharmacy revenue is generated by filling prescriptions for which we receive payment from the NHS. We also generate revenue through providing NHS services, private services and the sale of over-the-counter medicines that can only be sold from a registered pharmacy by a pharmacist or a person acting under the supervision of a pharmacist. Our retail pharmacy operations are subject to numerous risks, including: changes in availability, pricing, and safety profiles of prescription drugs that we purchase and sell, changes in NHS reimbursement for prescription drugs; a reduction in the pharmacy global sum leading to reduced retained purchase margins available for pharmacy in England; a reduction in dispensing activity payments; the introduction of new NHS services; and a move away from reimbursement for dispensing prescription drugs; increased competition from other retail pharmacy operations, including online; overall economic conditions; and changes in the regulatory environment for the retail pharmacy industry and the pharmaceutical industry, and other changes in laws, rules and regulations that affect our retail pharmacy business. If the supply of certain pharmaceuticals provided by one or more of our vendors were to be disrupted for any reason, we would in turn have to seek a new supplier for such pharmaceuticals, with related risks of shortages or delays in our own pharmacy operations. Any such disruption could cause reputational damage and result in a number of our pharmacy customers transferring their prescriptions to other pharmacies. One or a combination of such factors may adversely affect the volumes of prescriptions we dispense, our cost of sales associated with our retail pharmacy operations, and the revenue and gross margin of those operations or result in the loss of cross-store selling opportunities and, in turn, affect our overall revenue, other results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians
Subsubsection Title: Certain risks are inherent in providing optometry services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we operate Opticians in 157 stores and in all four nations of the United Kingdom. We also have an online site supplying powered contact lenses under the “general direction” of a registered optometrist, suitably qualified dispensing optician or medical practitioner. The majority of our revenue is from the sale of spectacles and eye examinations. We are regulated by the General Optical Council (“GOC”). To operate in the United Kingdom and use the title “Opticians” we have to be registered as a Body Corporate with the GOC and therefore are subject to the GOC Business Standards as well as the Opticians Act 1989. It is a requirement of the GOC that any Body Corporates which do not have GOC registrants as the majority of their Board, must have a Responsible Officer (Superintendent Optometrist) in position. All Optometrists and Opticians also have to be registered with the GOC to be able to practice and they are subject to the GOC Professional Standards as well as the Opticians Act 1989. Breaches to the GOC standards could lead to warnings, fines, sanctions on practice up to being removed from the GOC register either as a business or individual and unable to practice. All of our optical departments also hold a contract with the NHS Integrated Care Boards or Health Board to be able to provide NHS services. Breaches of the terms within such contracts can lead to penalties, including up to revoking such contract and stopping us providing NHS services. These penalties can occur at the store level, regional level or national level. Since 78% of our eye examinations were funded by the NHS in 2023, any penalties or stoppage in NHS services would have a material adverse impact on our business. Our Optometrists in all four nations also have to be registered on an NHS performer’s listing to be able to provide NHS eye examinations. In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, some of our stores also conduct additional NHS services which are commissioned at a local level, which requires such stores to abide by additional NHS standard contracts with local service level agreements. In Wales, Optometrists also need to have Wales Eye Care Services (WECS) accreditation and completed Wales General Ophthalmic Services (WGOS) training to be registered as a performer on the NHS performers list. 69 ----- Changes in the regulatory environment for the optical industry and other changes in laws, rules, NHS contract terms and regulations may also have an effect on our operating and commercial model. The provision of professional eye care services entails an inherent risk of professional malpractice and other similar claims. We may become subject to professional malpractice regulatory or NHS actions or claims under various theories relating to the professional services provided by our departments. This could also lead to a public relations and/or reputational risk both at the local and national level. We may not be able to continue to obtain adequate liability insurance at reasonable rates, in which event, the cost could require us to exit this offering, as insurance is a regulatory requirement for both a Body Corporate and individual registrants. Furthermore, our insurance may not be adequate to cover claims asserted against us, thus, potentially decreasing our future cash position. If the glazing supply provided by our main Optical vendor was to be disrupted for any reason, our Optical operations could be severely affected until at least such time as we could transfer to a new glazing manufacturer. Any such disruption could cause reputational damage and result in a number of our Optical customers transferring their purchases to other Opticians. This may adversely affect the volumes of glasses we dispense, our cost of sales associated with our Optical operations, and the revenue and gross margin of those operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.
Subsubsection Text: We may be subject to legal and regulatory enquiries or investigations, both civil and criminal, that could divert management time and resources and result in fines, taxes, sanctions, variation or revocation of permissions and authorisations, as well as reputational damage. For example, from time to time, we and/or our management are involved in litigation, tax audits, claims and other proceedings related to the conduct of our business, including, but not limited to, claims from our current and former employees, claims of intellectual property infringement, claims from customers (such as for injuries at our premises), claims asserting unfair competition and unfair business practices by third parties and environmental, health and safety claims (including, for example, related to the presence of asbestos in any of our properties). We could face a wide variety of employee claims, including general discrimination, privacy, labour and employment and disability claims. For example, Asda Stores Limited has been served with approximately 52,923 employment tribunal claims (the “Equal Value Claims”) that began in 2008 and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester (the “Employment Tribunal”) in the United Kingdom on behalf of current and former Asda store employees, and further claims may be asserted in the future. There are also 8,147 claims filed in the High Court which are stayed pending the outcome of the Equal Value Claims. The claimants allege that the work performed by employees in Asda’s retail stores is of equal value in terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of employees working in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities, and that the difference in pay between these job positions disparately impacts women because more women work in retail stores while more men work in warehouses and distribution facilities, and that the pay difference is not objectively justified. The claimants are requesting differential back pay based on higher wage rates in the warehouse and distribution facilities and higher wage rates on a prospective basis. In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could compare their positions in Asda’s retail stores with those of employees in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities. On March 26, 2021, the Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision, that the work of hourly-paid workers in distribution centres and the work of hourly-paid workers in stores can be compared. The litigation is currently in the equal value stage when the Employment Tribunal Claimants are proceeding in the next phase of their claims. That phase will determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal value to the work performed by employees in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities. The equal value hearing is scheduled to take place from September 9, 2024 to December 13, 2024 at the Manchester Employment Tribunal. At present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed and cannot reasonably estimate any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no assurance as to the 70 ----- scope and outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows. See “Business—Legal _Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation.”_ Any claims could result in litigation against us and could also result in regulatory proceedings being brought against us by various governmental agencies. Often these cases raise complex factual, accounting and legal issues, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time and legal expenses. Litigation and claims and regulatory proceedings against us or our management could result in unexpected expenses and liability and could also materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Even if we were successful in defending such proceedings, we could still suffer from the distraction of management resources to such proceedings, incur certain expenses and possibly face harm to our reputation from case-related publicity. The involvement in litigation and arbitration proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to extensive, increasingly stringent and frequently changing laws and regulations and increased scrutiny from regulators and enforcement authorities, including in relation to advertising, food and product safety, health and safety matters and the environment, and both compliance and non-compliance therewith could impose substantial liabilities and costs and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of our business, our operations and properties are subject to increasingly stringent laws and regulations relating to, among other things, labour, competition, imports and exports, advertising, customer protection, alcohol and tobacco licencing, supplier relations, planning approvals for the opening of new stores, business operations, product safety, intermediation in customer credit and insurance, information technology, store safety and accessibility and health, safety and environment. Moreover, some of our businesses are subject to specific regulations, compliance with each of which can be complex and costly or can result in significant cash outflows. These include compliance with marketing laws and regulations, compliance with pharmaceutical laws and regulations, compliance with optometry laws and regulations, compliance with e-commerce laws and regulations and compliance with real estate laws and regulations. Additionally, we are subject to, among other things: telecommunications regulation, both directly and indirectly; regulations that govern our relationships with our suppliers, limiting our operational flexibility; and labour and employment laws that regulate the human resources implications of any proposals to restructure our business, our colleagues’ working conditions, maximum working hours and, in certain jurisdictions, the ability to have stores open 24 hours a day or work on Sundays. We may be subject to audits and/or inquiries into our labour law practices by competent authorities and enforcement costs and penalties can be significant. Any claims could result in litigation against the Group and could also result in regulatory or legal proceedings and fines being brought against the Group. For example, in 2023, the CMA fined Asda £60,000 in connection with a market-wide fuel pricing market study. Often these cases raise complex factual, accounting and legal issues, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time, legal expenses and exposure to financial penalty. In addition, the CMA introduced the Green Claims Code, and in 2022, launched investigations into George and other non-Asda apparel brands for eco-friendly and sustainability claims made about their fashion products, including clothing, footwear, and accessories. For more information see “Business— _Regulation—Competition and Markets Authority—Green Claims Code,” and “Business—Legal Proceedings— Environmental Claims Matter.”_ We are also subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice (“GSCOP”), a statute governing the largest UK food retailers which requires these retailers to treat their suppliers fairly, lawfully and in good faith. The proposed fines for breaching the legislation may be up to 1% of the breaching retailer’s turnover. Even if no fines are assessed, a finding of breach by the Groceries Code Adjudicator responsible for enforcing the GSCOP may cause negative publicity and damage our image, reputation or brand, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, we are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation (Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the “Controlled Land Order”), which is legislation administered by the CMA and designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by their competitors for grocery retailing in the future. Prior to the LBO Acquisition, we purchased our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary, which sold the electricity back into Asda. These electricity purchases are regulated by the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (“OFGEM”), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity markets in Great Britain. Since 71 ----- March 2021, we have purchased our electricity on a retail basis facilitated through a third-party agent. Therefore, since the regulations relating to wholesale electricity purchases do not apply to the retail purchases made since March 2021, we have navigated the process of revoking the electricity supply license with the help of a consultancy firm. This process has confirmed that we have met of our obligations and we have no liabilities outstanding. In addition, we are subject to regulation by the Office of Communications (“OFCOM”), an independent regulator and competition authority for the UK communications industries, which regulates selling practices for mobile telecommunication services and changes to mobile termination rates, among other things. The FCA is responsible for the regulation of insurance and customer credit-related activities in the United Kingdom. Firms carrying on such activities in the United Kingdom must generally be authorised by the FCA with appropriate permissions, and FCA authorised firms are subject to ongoing regulation and supervision by the FCA. In connection with distributing the Asda Money suite of white-labelled financial services products, Asda Stores Limited is authorised by the FCA with limited permission to carry out credit broking, and both Asda Stores Limited and Asda Financial Services Limited are registered with the FCA as introducer appointed representatives of a number of third-party insurance and credit product providers. Any failures in or inadequate controls around the customer introduction process for those regulated financial services products, or any technical deficiencies in the arrangements with such third-party insurance and credit product providers, could in principle result in regulatory investigations and related costs and penalties, as well as reputational damage. Additionally, as a retailer and manufacturer of food products for human consumption, we are subject to stringent production, packing, health, quality, labelling and distribution standards. Each of our stores and our suppliers’ facilities may be subject to licencing, reporting requirements and official quality controls by numerous governmental authorities. Difficulties in obtaining or failure to obtain the necessary licences or approvals could delay or prevent the development or operation of a given retail location or distribution centre. Our stores and our distribution centres are subject to regular inspection by authorities for compliance with hygiene regulations applicable to the sale, storage and manufacturing of foodstuffs and the traceability of genetically modified organisms, meats and other raw materials. Should any non-compliance with such regulations be discovered during an inspection, authorities may temporarily shut down the store, distribution centre or facility concerned and/or result in prosecution and the imposition of a fine for such non-compliance which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
