Further, we are subject to various environmental and health and safety requirements, including those governing discharges to water and air, waste disposal, the clean-up of contaminated sites, product content and labelling and worker health and safety. We could incur substantial costs, including clean-up obligations, fines, penalties and other criminal and civil sanctions, and third-party claims for personal injury or property damage, as a result of violations of our liabilities under these requirements. For example, we own and operate service stations, which include significant storage of petrol, liquified natural gas or other hazardous materials, and many of our sites store fuel for use in backup generators and, as a result, we are subject to a variety of legislation governing the use, management, storage and disposal of hazardous substances, wastes and other regulated materials, such as petroleum and petroleum products, and any environmental impacts from current or historical operations at such locations. Our operations and facilities also require permits and authorisations under environmental, health and safety requirements, which are subject to renewal, modification and rescission by issuing authorities. We also may be required to incur substantial capital or other costs to comply with such requirements or those that are promulgated in the future. In addition, we could be sued for health problems caused by the use of tobacco products. In fact, various health related legal actions, proceedings and claims arising out of the sale, distribution, manufacturing, development, advertising and marketing of cigarettes have been brought against vendors of tobacco products in the United States. If this trend progressed to the United Kingdom, any unfavourable verdict against us in a health-related suit could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. From time to time, we may be notified of or otherwise become aware of additional laws and regulations that governmental organisations or others may claim should be applicable to our business. Compliance with future requirements could result in substantial costs to us. Failure to comply with any such laws or regulations could subject us to sanctions which could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or results of operations. Future changes in such laws and regulations could also have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or results of operations. The laws and regulations to which we are subject frequently change, which may materially impact our business operations, and our failure to comply with such laws can result in significant fines and other penalties. See 72 ----- also “Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We are subject to regulations relating to the implementation of the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union.”_ As a general matter, legal requirements are subject to interpretation, and we are unable to predict the ultimate cost of compliance with these requirements or their effect on our operations. Failure to define clear roles and responsibilities or to regularly communicate with and train our colleagues may result in non-compliance with applicable laws and regulations. As is the case for other retailers of our size, we may from time to time be subject to inquiries or investigations from regulatory bodies by local authorities, competition authorities or financial regulators, in the ordinary course of our business. Such authorities may take the view that we have not conducted or are not conducting our business fully in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and, consequently, we may be required to make significant expenditures to defend against allegations of wrongdoing or modify our business practices to comply with differing interpretations of existing laws and regulations or with future laws and regulations, which may increase our costs and materially limit our ability to operate our business. For a further discussion of the material regulatory regimes with which we must comply, see “Business— _Regulation.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to regulations relating to the implementation of the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union.
Subsubsection Text: Since January 1, 2021, the United Kingdom has been trading as an independent country outside of the European Union following the UK electorate voting in favour of leaving the European Union (commonly referred to as “Brexit”) in June 2016 and the conclusion of a new trading agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom which was entered into in December 2020. This means that new regulations are in place governing the import and export of goods between the United Kingdom and the European Union from this date which places a greater cost and administrative burden on us. For example, from April 30, 2024, physical, documentary and identity checks at the border are scheduled to be required for medium-risk animal products, plants and plant products, such as chilled and frozen meat, fish, cheese, eggs, dairy products and certain cut flowers and seeds, imported to United Kingdom from the European Union. There are also additional regulations in place governing tariffs for products of non-EU origin when they are exported across the border from the United Kingdom to the European Union which also can place a greater cost and administrative burden on us. The UK government may implement additional regulations governing trade movement into and out of the United Kingdom which could have a negative impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We are a UK business. The Brexit administration requirements could mean that the United Kingdom will suffer as a result of losing commercially favourable access to the EU single market, or specific countries in the European Union, further resulting in a negative impact on the general and economic conditions in the United Kingdom and the European Union which could in turn have a negative impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, since we operate 18 stores in Northern Ireland, Brexit has had an additional impact on our business, results of operation and prospects due to new bureaucratic hurdles and the implementation of the Northern Ireland Retail Movement Scheme on October 1, 2023, which established a new framework for the movement of retail goods from Great Britain to Northern Ireland. Future changes may occur in regulations that we are required to comply with as well as amendments to treaties governing but not limited to tax, duties and tariffs, which could adversely impact our operations and require us to modify our financial and supply arrangements.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We collect and process personal data in our daily business, and the leakage of such data may violate law and could materially adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to regulations regarding the use of personal data. In the ordinary course of our business, we collect, process and in some cases store certain personal financial and other information about our customers and colleagues (some of which may be sensitive, such as information about customers’ dietary preferences or restrictions), marketing initiatives and the large number of credit and debit transactions we process. For example, we use our Asda Rewards loyalty programme to leverage data insights about our customers for targeted investment in our business. We also process sensitive information about our colleagues, including their bank details, union membership and health status. We must therefore comply with strict data protection, privacy and security laws and regulatory guidance. In order for our business to function successfully, we must process personal data, including credit and debit card information in an adequately secure manner. In addition, our online operations depend heavily upon the secure transmission of confidential information over public networks, including the use of cashless payments. We rely on 73 ----- third-party service providers to process customer payments made using debit cards and credit cards. See also “Risks _Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We are exposed to payments risks, including processing risks, increases in transaction fees, actions taken by third parties that could disrupt our operations, failure by us or third parties on whom we rely to fully comply with rules and standards governing payment processing, and system failures and security breaches.”_ The use and handling of this personal information is regulated by evolving and increasingly demanding laws and regulations at the national and international levels, as well as by certain third-party contracts. The legal and regulatory frameworks governing the use and handling of personal information are relatively new in our markets and are still evolving. Any failure or perceived failure by us or any of our third-party service providers to comply with our policies or with any other privacy related laws, regulations, industry self-regulatory principles, industry standards or codes of conduct, regulatory guidance, orders to which we may be subject or other legal obligations could materially adversely affect our reputation and brands and may result in claims, fines (including by card merchants), civil or criminal proceedings or actions against us by governmental entities or others. For example, we are subject to the UK GDPR which became applicable on January 31, 2020. The UK GDPR is almost identical to the EU GDPR, which strengthens existing rights, provides for new rights and gives customers and colleagues increased control over their personal data, including the requirement for data collectors to process and use personal information solely for the reasons for which they were collected. Laws, such as the UK GDPR, restrict our ability to collect and use personal information relating to individuals including the use of that information for marketing purposes. We rely on our own colleagues to maintain our databases and seek to ensure that procedures are in place to ensure compliance (including that we maintain proper privacy notices). Non-compliance with the UK GDPR could result in a possible fine of up to either £17.5 million or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover for the preceding financial year, whichever is higher, for the most serious infringements. See also “Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our _General Operations—We may suffer a loss as a result of operational risk, including human error, ineffective or inadequate designed processes, failure of IT or other systems, improper conduct by colleagues and third parties, failures by suppliers and third-party providers and criminal activity including fraud, theft and cybercrime.”_ Moreover, even if we are compliant with such laws and requirements, we may not be able to prevent security breaches involving customer transaction data. If we or any of our third-party service providers fail to transmit customer information in a secure manner, if our security and information systems are compromised as a result of data corruption or loss, a cyberattack or a network security incident, or if our colleagues or certain third-parties fail to comply with data protection laws and regulations (and, as a result, information about our customers and colleagues is obtained by unauthorised persons or used inappropriately), we may be subject to the aforementioned consequences, all of which may significantly adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Laws and regulations relating to privacy, data protection, customer protection and the digital advertising business are evolving and subject to potentially different interpretations in different jurisdictions. Changes in these laws and regulations or their interpretations may force us to incur substantial costs or require us to change our business practices and may present challenges to our ability to collect customer data and promote our sites, product offerings and services through electronic communication.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance and could be exposed to significant financial risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate.
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to risks that are inherent to our business operations and currently maintain insurance we believe is customary for businesses of our size and type and in the markets in which we operate. For a description of our material insurance policies, see “Business—Insurance.” Given the number of locations and settings in which our colleagues provide services and the range of activities our colleagues engage in, we may not always be able to foresee accurately all activities and situations in order to ensure that they are fully covered by the terms of our insurance policies and, as a result, we may not be covered by insurance in specific instances. While we seek to maintain appropriate levels of insurance, not all risks are insured or insurable. As a result, we cannot guarantee our insurance programmes will be adequate to cover future claims or operating losses incurred as a result of accidents resulting from fires, explosions, water damage, theft, political unrest, natural events causing damage to our property (buildings, furniture, equipment, merchandise or computer systems) or following a business interruption at our premises, nor that we will be able to maintain our insurance programmes on acceptable terms in the future. 74 ----- We typically renew our insurance on an annual basis. In connection with this renewal process, our insurance costs may increase following the occurrence of several events resulting in substantial claims for damages, in response to any negative development in our claims history or due to material price increases in the insurance market in general. The occurrence of several events resulting in substantial claims for damages in a calendar year may have a material adverse effect on our insurance premiums. Furthermore, given a recent change in our credit ratings, our providers required that we offer additional financial security for a portion of the deductible amounts payable by us under our policies, which has increased the overall costs of carrying insurance. If we are not able to maintain our current insurance coverage or do so at a reasonable cost or if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate or unavailable in the future, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially adversely affected. Our insurance coverage may not cover all risks, and there are some risks that may only be covered to a limited extent due to limits in our insurance policies. For instance, we may incur losses that cannot be insured against or that we believe are not economically reasonable to insure. Unanticipated changes in the actuarial assumptions and management estimates underlying our reserves for such losses could result in significantly higher expense than anticipated, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians—Certain _risks are inherent in providing optometry services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against_ us”_ and “Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians— _Certain risks are inherent in providing pharmacy services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims against us and may cause us reputational harm.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We may be adversely impacted by environmental, social and governance matters, including if we are unable to meet goals and commitments that we establish in relation to such matters.
Subsubsection Text: In recent years, there has been an increased focus from investors, governmental and nongovernmental entities, and the public on environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) matters, including greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy, packaging and waste, practices related to sustainable supply chain, energy and water use, diversity, equity and inclusion, human rights and social commitment. A variety of organisations evaluate, and measure the performance of, companies on such ESG matters, and the results of these assessments are widely publicised. For example, many investment funds focus on positive ESG business practices and sustainability scores when making investments and may consider a company’s ESG or sustainability scores as a reputational or other factor in making an investment decision. If our ESG practices do not meet investor, customer, or employee expectations, which continue to evolve, our brand, reputation, and customer and employee retention may be negatively impacted. The execution of our ESG strategies to achieve goals, commitments, and targets are subject to risks and uncertainties, many of which may be outside of our control and prove to be more costly than we anticipate. These risks and uncertainties include our ability to achieve our goals, commitments, and targets within the currently projected costs and the expected timeframes; unforeseen operational and technological difficulties; the outcome of research efforts and future technology developments; and the success of our collaborations with third parties. It is possible that stakeholders may not be satisfied with our ESG reporting, our ESG practices or our speed of adoption. We could also incur additional costs and devote additional resources to monitor, report and implement various ESG practices. Any failure, or perceived failure, to achieve our ESG goals, commitments, and targets could damage our reputation and customer, investor and other stakeholder relationships, and may even result in regulatory enforcement action. Such conditions could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See “Business— _Our Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: The international scope of the George Clothing business may subject us to additional legislative, judicial, accounting, legal, regulatory, tax, political and economic risks and conditions specific to the countries or regions in which we sell and deliver products, which could materially adversely affect our business or financial performance.
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our UK operations, George Clothing products are available for sale internationally through a third-party supplier. Our future results of operations from international sales of the George Clothing products could be negatively affected by a variety of factors, most of which are beyond our control. These factors include stability of the third-party supplier, political conditions, including political instability, local and global economic conditions, legal and regulatory constraints (such as direct marketing, regulation of product and service offerings including regulatory restrictions (such as foreign ownership restrictions) on online and retail operations in international markets), restrictive 75 ----- governmental actions (such as trade protection measures), local product safety and environmental laws, tax rates, laws and regulations, local labour laws, anti-money laundering laws and regulations, trade policies, currency regulations, laws and regulations regarding customer and data protection, and other matters in any of the countries or regions in which we operate, now or in the future. Additionally, following the Separation, pursuant to the TMA, Walmart has granted us a licence to continue to use the George brand within the United Kingdom (for sale, marketing and distribution purposes on an exclusive basis) and outside the United Kingdom in certain specified countries in Europe (on a non-exclusive basis) granted us a licence to use the George brand (on a non-exclusive basis) in certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such specified European countries in substantially the same way and to the same extent as the brand was used by Asda immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement, as specified in, and subject to the terms of, the TMA, in each case on and subject to the terms of the TMA. The TMA restricts Asda from using the George brand (and other Licensed IP (as defined in “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional _Agreements with Walmart—Trade Mark Agreement”)) following the LBO Acquisition Completion Date other than in_ accordance with the licences granted under the TMA contains certain covenants and undertakings from Asda Stores Limited, including as regards Asda’s use of the George brand (and other Licensed IP); see “Certain Relationships and _Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart—Trade Mark Agreement.” As referred to in_ “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart—Trademark _Agreement,” Walmart has a right to terminate the TMA under certain circumstances, including for material breach of_ the TMA by Asda or repeated non-material breaches of the TMA by Asda. Asda has also indemnified the Walmart Group for losses arising out of Asda’s use of the Licensed IP (including the George brand) in material breach of the TMA. Violating the TMA with Walmart could lead to Walmart exercising its right to terminate the TMA and the licence to Asda of the George brand, and Asda therefore ceasing to have the right to use the George brand, as well as to potential claims by Walmart against Asda for breach of the TMA. See also “Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—Our intellectual property rights may be infringed or challenged. Intellectual property claims by third parties or our failure or inability to protect our intellectual property rights could diminish the value of our brand and weaken our competitive position.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to the risk of violations of anti-corruption laws, sanctions or other similar regulations.
Subsubsection Text: We must comply with certain anti-corruption laws or other similar regulations. We operate in certain parts of the world that lack a developed legal system or have experienced widespread corruption. Under some circumstances, strict compliance with anti-corruption laws may conflict with local customs and practices. Our internal policies mandate compliance with these laws, but we cannot ensure that our internal control policies and procedures will always protect us from acts committed by our associated persons. Violations of such laws can result in civil penalties, including fines, denial of export privileges, injunctions, interdicts, asset seizures, debarment from government contracts, termination of existing contracts, revocations or restrictions of licences, criminal fines or imprisonment. In addition, such violations could also negatively impact our reputation and consequently, our ability to retain existing customers and attract new customers. On the other hand, any such violation by our competitors, if undetected, could give them an unfair competitive advantage. The consequences that we may suffer due to the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: Changes in tax rates or laws, tax liabilities or tax accounting rules could affect future results.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to complex tax laws in the United Kingdom and have historically been subject to international tax laws in connection with international sales of the George Clothing and George Home products. Changes in (or changes in interpretations of) tax treaties, tax laws or regulations or tax authority guidance could materially adversely affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments, possibly with a retroactive effect. Our effective tax rate and tax liability will be affected by a number of factors in addition to our results of operations, accounting standards and changes in accounting standards, and future changes in the law. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations or our effective tax rate and have a negative effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, in the United Kingdom, if the tax authority concluded that VAT was chargeable on a particular supply on which we did not charge VAT to customers, we would be liable to account for such VAT. The occurrence of any of 76 ----- the foregoing tax risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In the jurisdictions in which we operate, governments might centrally adjust the value of business rates in the property market. For instance, in the United Kingdom, the government adjusts the value of business rates to reflect changes in the property market approximately every five years. The most recent revaluation came into effect in England, Scotland and Wales on April 1, 2023 (based on rateable values from April 1, 2021). At revaluation, all properties are given a new rateable value which, depending on the underlying movement in the value of the property, can have an adverse impact on the tax liability due on the property. Adjustments to business rates could result in increased costs and consequently could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Further, legislation has been enacted or is currently under consideration in a number of jurisdictions to adopt and implement Pillar Two of the base erosion and profit shifting (“BEPS”) project initiated by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (“OECD”), which is designed to introduce a global minimum tax rate of 15% for certain multinational groups. In December 2021 and March 2022, the OECD published model rules and related commentary to support member jurisdictions of the G20/OECD Inclusive Framework on BEPS (including the United Kingdom) to implement the Pillar Two framework. For example, the United Kingdom government has legislated to implement the Pillar Two income inclusion rule by introducing a “domestic top-up tax” and a “multinational top-up tax” for certain large multinational and UK groups for accounting periods beginning on or after December 31, 2023. The legislation applies to certain multinational and UK groups with annual group revenue exceeding €750 million. Broadly, the “domestic top-up tax” may be assessed inter alia on UK located qualifying entities of a qualifying group where the effective tax rate (“ETR”) of all UK members of the relevant group is less than 15%. Further, the “multinational top-up tax” may be assessed inter alia on a UK responsible member (typically, the ultimate parent, or where the ultimate parent is not in a territory which has implemented Pillar 2, the most senior group member in such a territory) of a qualifying multinational group where members have an ETR of less than 15% (as determined under the applicable rules) to the extent that a qualifying domestic top-up tax has not otherwise been collected. Based on initial analysis undertaken by the Group, the Pillar Two transitional safe harbour is expected to apply for each relevant territory and an election will be made such that no top-up tax charge is expected to arise in respect of the accounting period ended December 31, 2024. If this were not to be the case, and the ETR of the Pillar Two group members were to be at any point less than 15%, it is possible that Pillar Two top-up taxes could be assessed on the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and/or other members of the Group. Further changes related to Pillar Two are expected to be implemented in the United Kingdom and in other jurisdictions in which we do business. The timing and ultimate impact of any such changes on our tax obligations remains uncertain and will continue to be monitored by the Group.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: Tax disputes, tax audits and adverse decisions rendered by tax authorities may expose us to substantial tax liabilities which could materially impact our business and reputation.
Subsubsection Text: Tax authorities, such as HMRC, periodically examine our activities. We often rely on generally available interpretations of applicable tax laws and regulations, including interpretations made by the relevant tax authorities and courts of law. Although we believe that we have adequately assessed and accounted for our potential tax liabilities, and that our tax estimates are reasonable, there cannot be certainty that the relevant tax authorities are in agreement with our interpretation of these laws, nor, as the case may be, that such tax authorities or courts will not depart from their prior rulings or stated practice. In such instances, there may be, and there are currently, historical tax questions on which tax authorities have taken different views or from which disputes have arisen or may arise, which if unfavourably determined may require us to pay settlement amounts, assessment amounts, interest, fees or penalties, which may adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: The audit reports of Ernst & Young LLP and KPMG LLP included in this Offering Memorandum include statements purporting to limit the persons that may rely on such reports and the opinions contained therein.
Subsubsection Text: The audit reports of Ernst & Young LLP for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022 and the audit report of KPMG LLP for the year ended December 31, 2023, which are included in this Offering Memorandum, include a statement, in accordance with guidance issued by The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and 77 ----- Wales, that Ernst & Young LLP and KPMG LLP do not assume responsibility to anyone (including holders of Senior Secured Notes) other than the Senior Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer’s members as a body, for its audit work, audit reports or opinions it has formed. Each of Ernst & Young LLP and KPMG LLP has undertaken its audit work, in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006, to state to the Senior Notes Issuer’s members those matters that it is required to state to them in an auditor’s report and for no other purpose. Investors in the Senior Secured Notes should understand that these statements are intended to disclaim any liability to parties (such as purchasers of the Senior Secured Notes) other than to the Senior Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries with respect to those reports. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the Securities Act, or in a report filed under the U.S. Exchange Act. If a U.S. court (or any other court) were to give effect to the limitation above, the recourse that investors in the Senior Secured Notes may have against the independent auditors based on their reports or the consolidated financial statements to which they relate could be limited. The extent to which auditors have responsibility or liability to third parties is unclear under the laws of many jurisdictions, including the United Kingdom, and the legal effect of these statements in the audit reports is untested in the context of an offering of securities. The inclusion of the language referred to above, however, may limit the ability of holders of the Senior Secured Notes to bring any action against our auditors for damages arising out of an investment in the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: Limitation of Valuations – Property valuations are inherently subjective and uncertain and are based on assumptions which may prove to be inaccurate. We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party valuation report of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete.
Subsubsection Text: Property valuations are inherently subjective and uncertain and are based on assumptions which may prove to be inaccurate. We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party valuation report of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete. As a result, the valuation report presents the external valuer’s best estimate of the value of the Group’s properties subject to the assumptions and Special Assumptions set out above. This Offering Memorandum refers to the CBRE Report with respect to certain of the real estate portfolio owned by Asda. Valuation of property and property-related assets is inherently subjective and uncertain, in part because all property valuations are made on the basis of information and assumptions which may not prove to be accurate, and in part because of the individual nature of each property. Property valuations are complex, involve the use of data which is not publicly available and involve a degree of subjective professional judgement by the valuers. In valuing properties, the valuers are required to make certain key assumptions in respect of matters including, but not limited to, the existence of willing buyers, title to the property, condition of structure and services, deleterious materials, environmental matters, legal matters, statutory and regulatory requirements and planning, estimated market rental values, market-based yields, expected future rental revenues from the property, where relevant potential future trading performance, and other factors. In respect of properties which may require development, redevelopment or refurbishment, the development considered achievable, assumed timescale, the assumed future development cost and an appropriate finance rate and profit rate and/or discount rate are also used to determine the property value together with market evidence and recent comparable properties where appropriate. The adoption of different assumptions would be likely to produce different valuation results. The assumptions made may prove to be inaccurate or not borne out by future events and could negatively affect the valuation of the properties. The CBRE Report was furthermore produced on a desktop basis and without visual inspection of Asda’s properties. Where properties have not been inspected, the valuer will not carry out the usual range of enquiries performed during a full inspection of properties and will make the appropriate assumptions based on the information provided or available that, without a full inspection, cannot be verified. The instructing parties have acknowledged and accepted the heightened and inherent uncertainty and risks relying upon a valuation prepared on a desktop basis. The CBRE Report is thus based on information provided by management and certain assumptions, including, but not limited to, the assumptions that (i) our properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental law and are free from, environmental issues such as contamination, deleterious materials, flooding, ground conditions, invasive or protected plants or species and the properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed 78 ----- environmental law, (ii) there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, all properties are free from defect, in good repair and condition and well maintained and in marketable condition, compliant with all building, accessibility and fire safety regulations and there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, (iii) properties possess a good and marketable freehold title free from any onerous restrictions or conditions, and all title, tenure, lettings, planning, taxation, statutory and local authority requirements are complied with, (iv) all properties benefit from full access and egress rights together with sufficient parking and loading facilities and are connected to all main services, (v) the floor areas supplied by Asda comply with the RICS Code of Measuring Practice (vi) no capital expenditure is required in respect of the properties and (vii) that the properties all have valid energy performance certificates compliant with the relevant regulations in each jurisdiction of the United Kingdom. In particular, CBRE has assumed each property to be the authorised use under planning legislation and in accordance with the use registered with the relevant regulatory agency. During the course of their engagement, CBRE did not perform site inspections, environmental audit, tests of services and amenities, investigations or tests as to the condition of the properties. CBRE did not make planning or permitting enquiries and did not examine deeds, leases or other documents relating to the title to our properties. The valuation assumed that the properties were in a reasonable state of condition without material capital expenditure required. The CBRE Report was prepared as at the valuation date of December 31, 2023 and is not as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. CBRE has not been requested to update or revise any of the information contained in the CBRE Report as of any later date or the date of this Offering Memorandum, is not under any obligation to do so and nor will it be asked to do so prior to the issuance of the Senior Secured Notes or at any later date. Accordingly, the information included in the CBRE Report may not reflect the current physical, economic, competitive, market or other conditions with respect to the Group properties. Your attention is drawn to the fact that in respect of the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios, the CBRE Report was additionally prepared upon the Special Assumption that the properties were let up on leases of 15 – 25 years rather than their current status of being held with vacant possession. The Special Assumptions are defined by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) Valuation – Global Standards (2022) as “an assumption that either assumes facts that differ from the actual facts existing at the valuation date or that would not be made by a typical market participant in a transaction on the valuation date.” We cannot assure you that the assumptions or projections used, estimates made or procedures followed in the CBRE Report are correct, accurate or complete. CBRE provided its valuation of the relevant properties as of at the valuation date of December 31, 2023 and it does not take into account subsequent events. Accordingly, the information included in the CBRE Report may not reflect the current physical, economic, competitive, market or other conditions with respect to the property portfolio. CBRE have accepted no responsibility to any third party for the whole or any part of the contents of the CBRE Report. Other appraisers may reach a different valuation of Asda’s property portfolio. Moreover, the values determined in the CBRE Report could be significantly higher than the amount that would be obtained from the actual sale of the properties included in the Group Portfolio, especially in a distressed or liquidation scenario, if a sale of the Properties is not subject to the assumptions or Special Assumptions in the CBRE Report, sale of a number of properties in a portfolio, in the event of a downturn in the local, regional or national real estate market. Accordingly, the CBRE Report should not be considered a representation of the actual present or future value of Asda’s property portfolio. The realisable value of the applicable property portfolio at any given time will depend on various factors, including: - macroeconomic conditions in the United Kingdom, the European Union and elsewhere; - an economic downturn; - potential changes to the competitive landscape for grocery retail; - capital expenditure requirements; - changes in occupier and investor demand; - supply and demand generally affecting pricing; - adaptability or obsolescence; 79 ----- - regulation (e.g., minimum energy efficiency standards); - changes in consumer behaviour and shopping habits, either organic or as a result of any other event listed above or elsewhere under these “Risk Factors”; and - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, we anticipate that the value of Asda’s property portfolio will change over time, and it may change materially. After the issuance of the Senior Secured Notes, neither third parties nor we will provide holders of the Senior Secured Notes with a revised CBRE Report and we expressly disclaim any duty to update such CBRE Report under any circumstance.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: The unaudited financial data and forward-looking statements included in this Offering Memorandum need to be carefully considered and may materially differ from actual results.
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum incorporates data for the three months ended March 31, 2024, that are derived from preliminary financial results and estimates contained in our unaudited management accounts, which have not been and will not be audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards and are subject to change. The data for three months ended March 31, 2024, presented in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the three-months ended March 31, 2024, and is based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and risks. As such, you should not place reliance on them when making an investment decision. We have included data for the three months ended March 31, 2024 in order to provide information about our recent performance but this information should be treated with a higher level of caution for reasons including but not limited to the fact that management accounts are not prepared with the same level of rigor and are not subject to the same level of management review and scrutiny as interim or year-end financial information. In addition, we provide information about for the three months ended March 31, 2024, in accordance with the Group’s accounting policies, which may differ materially from U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and/or UK IFRS, in accordance with which we have prepared the Financial Statements and certain other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum. Furthermore, management accounts may not provide for closing procedures that are as detailed as those conducted at period or year end. Additionally, management accounts may be subject to cut-off errors and misallocation of items between months.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: We may not have the ability to meet our additional financial and other reporting requirements or implement effective systems of internal control and other standards, which may adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our internal controls over financial reporting are intended to ensure we maintain accurate records, promote the accurate and timely reporting of our financial information, maintain adequate control over our assets, ensure the independence of our auditors and detect unauthorised acquisition, use or disposition of our assets. Effective internal and disclosure controls are necessary for us to provide reliable financial reports and to operate successfully as a business. Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal controls. Any system of controls, however well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable, and not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the system are met. In addition, the design of any control system is based in part upon certain assumptions about the likelihood of future events. Because of these and other inherent limitations of control systems, there can be no assurance that any design will succeed in achieving its stated goals under all potential future conditions, regardless of how remote. If our internal controls do not keep pace with the size and sophistication of our businesses and the applicable financial reporting framework, or we fail to successfully integrate the businesses we acquired as part of the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, we may not be able to implement and maintain adequate internal controls. If we fail to implement and maintain effective internal controls, it could result in material misstatements in our financial statements or failure to meet our reporting obligations in a timely manner, which may cause a loss of confidence in our reported financial information which could increase our operating costs and materially impair our ability to operate our business. See also “—Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions—We may not be _able to successfully integrate the businesses we have recently acquired or will in the future acquire into our business.”_ 80 ----- Moreover, we may acquire companies or assets which we determine to be complementary to our current business. Such acquired companies or assets may have insufficient systems of internal control, or otherwise have defects which we do not discover until we begin to integrate these systems of internal control with ours. We cannot assure you that we will be successful in integrating these systems of internal control with ours, or that such a task will be within our initial expectations in terms of costs, resources and time expended.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Financial, Reporting and Other Matters
Subsubsection Title: Our non-current assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, may not be fully realisable and are subject to periodic testing for impairment, and we may incur significant impairment charges as a result.
Subsubsection Text: Our non-current assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, are subject to periodic testing for impairment. We have recorded a significant amount of goodwill. Total goodwill, which represents the difference between the consideration paid plus any non-controlling interest and the acquisition date fair value of identifiable net assets, was £1,182.2 million as of December 31, 2023, or 6% of our consolidated total assets. Within total goodwill, the Arthur Acquisition resulted in goodwill of £290.5 million, of which £30.4 million has since been allocated to assets held for sale, and the EG UK Acquisition resulted in goodwill of £922.1 million. The value of any goodwill recorded on our financial statements may not be fully realisable upon sale of all or part of the business or any other liquidity event. Goodwill is recorded on the date of acquisition and, in accordance with UK IFRS, is tested for impairment annually and whenever there is any indication of impairment. Impairment may result from, among other things, deterioration in our performance, a decline in expected future cash flows, adverse market conditions, adverse changes in applicable laws and regulations, any changes in the key assumptions used for internal calculations of values in use and a variety of other factors. The amount of any impairment must be expensed immediately as a charge to our income statement. We can give no assurance that we will not record any goodwill impairments in the future. Any future impairment of goodwill may result in material reductions of our income and equity under UK IFRS.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives.
Subsubsection Text: The separation from Walmart is a complex transaction that requires significant management attention and poses a number of risks including, but not limited to, system cutovers and those related to the implementation of our new IT infrastructure independent from Walmart. Prior to the LBO Acquisition, the Asda Group was historically part of the operations of Walmart, which provided us with operational, financial, and other support, and certain of our accounting and information technology systems were incorporated in Walmart’s larger operations. As a result of the LBO Acquisition, we became a standalone company and, accordingly, we have had to develop and implement the systems and infrastructure necessary to support our current and future business. On the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, Asda Stores Limited and Walmart entered into the TSA, under which Walmart undertakes to provide certain information technology services to Asda on a transitional basis (the “Transitional Services”). The Transitional Services include continuity of IT and communication services and provide support and facilitate our ability to operate on a standalone basis. Under the TSA, each relevant Transitional Service is to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) the migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of Asda from Walmart, and (ii) the termination of the TSA by Walmart or Asda Stores Limited under certain circumstances as described under “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements _with Walmart—Transitional Services Agreement.” If Walmart terminates the TSA in accordance with its terms or is_ unable or unwilling to provide the Transitional Services as agreed, we may not be able to replace these services at an acceptable price and in a timely manner, or at all. The Transitional Services include certain IT services which are provided pursuant to third-party vendor contracts. These services will require the vendor consent to extend the term of the underlying agreement past the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, and thereafter will have to be renegotiated with the IT vendor. 81 ----- The complexity of our new IT system and of its implementation means that we may not be able to successfully transition the systems to our standalone operations under Project Future. See “Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We rely extensively on information systems to process transactions, summarise results and manage our business. These systems are interdependent and disruptions in the IT infrastructure that we use could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.” Any failure to transition successfully within the terms of the applicable Transitional Agreement(s) may_ cause us to incur substantial expenses in addition to the anticipated separation costs and would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. At the LBO Completion Date, Walmart and the LBO Seller also entered into several other transitional agreements with various entities within the Asda Group alongside the TSA. The Transitional Agreements include a TMA which includes licences of the George, Scan & Go, Smart Price and Rollback trademarks, certain domain names, including George.com, as well as certain other Walmart-owned trade mark rights used by a member of the Asda Group between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart” for a description of the Transitional Agreements that are still_ in place. In the event any of our service relationships and agreements with Walmart are terminated, we may find it difficult to find a suitable alternative supplier of such services in a timely fashion or at all. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to successfully integrate the businesses we have recently acquired into our business.
Subsubsection Text: We may not be able to successfully integrate our recent acquisitions, namely the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, There is the risk that the integration of these acquisitions could result in significant added complexity and management distraction, as well as difficulty related to, among other things, the integration of certain operating and IT systems, including point of sale systems and inventory processing systems, the loss of customers or key employees, the disruption of our respective ongoing businesses or possible inconsistencies in standards, procedures and policies. Delays or issues could lead to additional cost which impacts profitability. Furthermore, certain acquired contracts may have terms and conditions that are weaker than our standard contracts, and we may not be able to integrate or update them as quickly as we would like or without incurring significant fees. In addition, we may not have, or be able to retain or hire, employees with the appropriate skill sets for the tasks associated with our integration plans, particularly in the expected time frame in which we require them, and could experience employee departures and early retirement due to relevant business changes, all of which could adversely affect the success of the integration plans. In particular, the loss of key managers or other experienced and knowledgeable local employees, may result in the loss of knowledge and continuity for the relevant business. The integration process for our acquisitions, if implemented ineffectively, would restrict the realisation of the full expected benefits, including cost savings and synergies. Failure to meet the challenges involved in integrating these businesses into our existing business and to realise the anticipated benefits therefrom could cause an interruption of, or a loss of momentum in, our activities and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation. In order to fully integrate the financial accounting systems of our acquired businesses, we will also have to complete the implementation of our own standalone IT system. Prior to the completion of Project Future, the businesses acquired from the Arthur Acquisition are being migrated onto the IT systems of EG Group. Both the Arthur Business and the EG UK Business will remain on the IT systems of EG Group for a transitional period, after which, they will have to be transitioned onto our new system. This has required, and will continue to require, additional capital investments by us, and may require incremental resources and system configurations that could increase our operating costs in future periods, as we continue in our ongoing efforts to adjust our control environment to the standards of a business of our size and scale. See also “—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating _to Our General Operations—We may from time to time pursue acquisitions, which may prove more costly than anticipated and may not generate anticipated synergies and which may have an adverse impact on our business, as could our failure to successfully integrate such businesses following acquisition. Our business could also be negatively impacted by merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by supranational and national laws and regulations.”_ In connection with these acquisitions, we may also face risks related to unforeseen legal or regulatory issues as we expand our fuel and convenience operations, difficulty in consolidating facilities and infrastructure, and a diversion of management’s attention from our day-to-day business as a result of the need to deal with the foregoing disruptions and integration matters. 82 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to achieve some or all of the returns, synergies, cost savings or other benefits that we expect to realise from our recent acquisitions or group initiatives.
Subsubsection Text: We cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully realise the expected benefits from the EG UK Acquisition or the Arthur Acquisition or the group initiatives that we have taken, or expect to take, aimed at realizing synergies, operational efficiencies or cost savings, or that the costs to realise these benefits will not be higher than anticipated. A variety of risks could cause us not to realise some or all of the expected benefits. These risks include, among others, unexpected costs associated with operating our business, inability to eliminate duplicative back-office overhead or redundant selling and general and administrative functions and an inability to avoid labour disruptions in connection with any integration of the foregoing. Our ability to successfully manage organisational changes is important for our future business success. In particular, our reputation and results of operations could be harmed if colleague morale, engagement, or productivity decline as a result of organisational or other changes. Moreover, our implementation of these initiatives may disrupt our operations and performance, and our estimated cost savings from these initiatives are based on several assumptions that may prove to be inaccurate and, as a result, we cannot assure you that we will realise these cost savings. If, for any reason, the benefits we realise are less than our estimates, or our improvement initiatives adversely affect our operations or cost more or take longer to implement than we project, or if our assumptions prove inaccurate, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially adversely affected. These actions may not provide the expected benefits, or could take longer to achieve than expected, and could lead to disruption of our operations, loss of or inability to recruit key personnel, decline in colleague productivity, weakening of internal standards, controls or procedures, and impairment of key customer and supplier relationships. In addition, cost saving and operational efficiencies may not be able to be sustained due to changes in customer needs, changes in regulations, availability and cost of materials or other cost variables. Our anticipated cost saving and benefits from the EG UK Acquisition and Arthur Acquisition are based upon assumptions about our ability to implement cost saving measures in a timely fashion within certain cost parameters and implement net cost savings which are in excess of inflationary cost increases. Our ability to achieve planned cost saving and benefits of these acquisitions is dependent upon a significant number of assumptions, some of which may be beyond our control, including the development of the markets for our products and services, political, legal, fiscal, market and economic conditions including but not limited to cost price inflation through our supply chain, regulatory developments, and tariff and wage increases. If one or more of our underlying assumptions regarding these measures proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realise fully or at all, or realise in the anticipated timeframe, the expected benefits from our cost saving and operational measures. We also undertake a number of group initiatives aimed at realizing synergies, operational efficiencies or cost savings. There can be no assurance that our acquisitions or any of these initiatives will be as successful or accretive as initially expected or meet our strategic goals. For example, we may fail to realise expected operational efficiencies or cost savings. There is also a risk that the synergies that we seek to achieve may not be realised within the time frame we currently anticipate, or at all, and that the magnitude of cost savings or operational efficiencies may be less than expected or the costs of achieving these synergies may be higher than expected. Our anticipated synergies are based on a number of assumptions, which are subject to uncertainties and contingencies that are outside of our control.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to enforce claims relating to a breach of the warranties or pursuant to certain indemnification obligations that Asda Holdings UK Limited has provided and undertaken under the LBO Acquisition Agreement and related transaction documents.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the LBO Acquisition, Asda Holdings UK Limited (the “LBO Seller”), has given certain customary warranties and undertaken certain customary indemnification obligations in the LBO Acquisition Agreement and related transaction documentation related to the Asda Group. Nonetheless, the LBO Purchaser may not be able to enforce any claims against the LBO Seller relating to breaches of these warranties or in respect of such indemnification obligations. Moreover, even if the LBO Purchaser is able to eventually recover any losses resulting from a breach of these warranties or in respect of such obligations, the Purchaser, and therefore indirectly we, may temporarily be required to bear these losses ourselves. 83 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Our leverage and debt service obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operation or prospects.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had total third-party debt of £4,500 million (equivalent) comprising Original Facility A, New Facility A, Facility B (EUR), the Private Placement Facility, the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes and the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes. See “Capitalisation.” We are highly leveraged and that leverage could be sustained at this level or higher for the foreseeable future. The level of indebtedness that we hold, and will continue to hold, could, among other things: - limit our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future working capital, capital expenditures, business opportunities and other corporate requirements; - reduce our flexibility to respond to, and pose additional risks for us in the face of, general adverse economic and industry conditions; - reduce the portion of our Underlying Cash Flow From Operations that will be available for uses other than servicing our debt, such as funding working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures or other general corporate purposes; - restrict us from pursuing strategic acquisitions or exploiting certain business opportunities; - limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; - place us at a disadvantage compared to our competitors that are not as highly leveraged; - negatively impact credit terms with our creditors; and - limit our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing. Any of these, or other, consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our debt obligations, including our obligations under the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: We may incur additional debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Senior Secured Notes, and impact our ability to operate our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: The agreements governing our debt limit our ability to incur additional indebtedness, but do not prohibit us from doing so. The terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture permit us (and, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will permit us) to incur additional debt, including in respect of committed borrowings of at least £747,722,727 million under the New Revolving Facility. Some of this debt could rank pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes, be structurally senior to the Senior Secured Notes or be secured on assets which do not form part of the Collateral for the Senior Secured Notes. Additional debt could also mature prior to the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, under the terms of the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, we are permitted, and under the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, we will be permitted, subject to certain conditions (including the refinancing of the term loan indebtedness outstanding as of the Issue Date under the Senior Facilities Agreement in full), to incur new debt that has super senior priority status over the Senior Secured Notes in respect of the proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral and certain distressed disposals. If new debt is added to the Group’s existing debt levels, the related risks that we currently face would increase. Furthermore, if we are able to designate some of our Restricted Subsidiaries under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture as Unrestricted Subsidiaries, those Unrestricted Subsidiaries would be permitted to borrow beyond the limitations specified in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and engage in other activities in which Restricted Subsidiaries may not engage. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes.” In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture do not, and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will not, 84 ----- prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness as defined under each of these documents, including short-term working capital facilities, which are permitted to be secured by security interests in the Collateral (including on a super senior basis, subject to the refinancing or repayment of the Term Loan Facilities in full and certain other conditions). If we are ever unable to service our debt, it would likely have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects and our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a holding company dependent upon cash flow from subsidiaries to meet its obligations on the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating activities of its own and no business operations, and its primary assets relate to its shares in Acquisition 2 and its primary liabilities relate to inter-group balances with the Senior Notes Issuer, commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the issuance of the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the guarantees of the Existing Senior Notes and the Transactions. We expect our operating subsidiaries to provide us with funds to meet our obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes through a combination of dividends and payments in respect of intercompany loans. Our subsidiaries’ obligations under intercompany loans will be junior obligations and will be subordinated in right of payment to all of the Group’s existing and future senior and senior subordinated indebtedness, including obligations under, or guarantees of obligations under, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes. If our subsidiaries do not distribute cash sufficient to make scheduled payments on the Senior Secured Notes, we will not have any other source of funds that will allow us to make payments to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, various agreements governing the Group’s debt may restrict and, in some cases may actually prohibit, the ability of these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax laws may also subject such payments to further taxation and applicable corporate law may limit the amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prohibit such payments. In particular, our subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends to us may be limited to the amount of distributable reserves available to them. Finally, our subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes have no obligation to make payments with respect to any of the Senior Secured Notes. The inability to transfer cash among entities within their respective consolidated groups may mean that, even though the entities, in aggregate, may have sufficient resources to meet their obligations, they may not be permitted to make the necessary transfers from one entity in their consolidated group to another entity in their consolidated group in order to make payments to the entity owing the obligations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Senior Secured Notes under which the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically and under which the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee.
Subsubsection Text: Under various circumstances, the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes will be released automatically, including: - in connection with any sale or other disposition of Collateral (other than the Security Interest in respect of the Issuer Share Collateral) to (a) a Person that is not the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or a Restricted Subsidiary (but excluding any transaction subject to “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants—Merger and Consolidation”), if such sale or other disposition does not violate the covenant_ described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Sales of _Assets and Subsidiary Stock” or is otherwise permitted in accordance with the Senior Secured Notes_ Indenture or (b) subject to certain exceptions, any Restricted Subsidiary; - in the case of a Guarantor that is released from its Notes Guarantee pursuant to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the release of the property and assets, and capital stock, of such Guarantor; - upon becoming a member of the Regulated Group, the release of the property and other assets, and capital stock, of such member of the Regulated Group, and upon the borrower under an intercompany 85 ----- loan becoming a member of the Regulated Group, the release of any Security Interest in any receivables under such intercompany loan; - in case of a Restricted Subsidiary that is not a Significant Subsidiary following the release of its Lien granted in favour of the Senior Facilities Agreement (see “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement—Guarantees and Security”), so long as no Event of Default_ has occurred and is continuing, the release of the property and assets, and capital stock, of such Restricted Subsidiary; provided that there is no other Indebtedness secured by a Lien on the assets of such Restricted Subsidiary that would result in the requirement for the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees to be secured on such property, assets or capital stock pursuant to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (including as described under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement—Required _Consents—Provisions Following an IPO”);_ - as allowed under the amendments and waivers provisions of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - upon payment in full of principal, interest and all other obligations on the Senior Secured Notes or upon legal defeasance, covenant defeasance or satisfaction and discharge of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, as provided thereunder; - if we designate any Restricted Subsidiary to be an Unrestricted Subsidiary in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the release of the property and assets, and capital stock, of such Unrestricted Subsidiary; - upon the occurrence of a Suspension Event as described under “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status”;_ - in connection with a Permitted Reorganisation; - as otherwise permitted in accordance with the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; or - in the case of any Proceeds Loan, or any other material intercompany receivables owed by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Restricted Subsidiaries to the Senior Notes Issuer, upon its contribution to the equity of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its Restricted Subsidiaries following the Issue Date. In addition, under various circumstances, the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically, including: - upon a sale or other disposition (including by way of consolidation or merger) of the capital stock of the relevant Guarantor (whether by direct sale or sale of a holding company) or the sale or disposition of all or substantially all the assets of the Guarantor (other than to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or a Restricted Subsidiary) otherwise permitted by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - upon the designation of the Guarantor as an Unrestricted Subsidiary in accordance with the Indentures; - upon becoming a member of the Regulated Group; - upon payment in full of principal, interest and all other obligations on the Senior Secured Notes or upon legal defeasance, covenant defeasance or satisfaction and discharge of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, as provided thereunder; - with respect to a Guarantor that is not a Significant Subsidiary, so long as no Event of Default has occurred and is continuing, to the extent that such Guarantor (i) is unconditionally released and discharged from its liability with respect to the Senior Credit Facilities and (ii) does not guarantee any Syndicated Term Facility or any other Credit Facility that provides for aggregate lending commitments in excess of £50.0 million at the relevant date of determination or Public Debt; 86 ----- - pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (including as described under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement—Required _Consents—Provisions Following an IPO”);_ - as allowed under the amendments and waivers provisions of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - as allowed under the additional guarantees covenants of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - as a result of a transaction permitted by “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants— _Merger and_ _Consolidation—The Guarantors”; or_ - in connection with a Permitted Reorganisation. In addition, the Notes Guarantees and Security Interests will be subject to release upon a distressed disposal as contemplated under the Intercreditor Agreement. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Senior Secured Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities and preference shares (if any) of the Group’s non-guarantor subsidiaries.
Subsubsection Text: Generally, claims of creditors of a non-guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors, and claims of preference shareholders (if any) of the subsidiary, will have priority with respect to the assets and earnings of the subsidiary over the claims of creditors of its parent entity, including claims by holders of the Senior Secured Notes under the Notes Guarantees. For example, the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (the “CGR Lender”) is a priority creditor in respect of Asda Propco Limited (being the borrower under the Group Rent Transaction, which a non-Guarantor subsidiary). In the event of any foreclosure, dissolution, winding-up, liquidation, reorganisation, administration or other bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding of any of the Group’s non-guarantor subsidiaries, holders of their indebtedness and their trade creditors will generally be entitled to payment of their claims from the assets of those subsidiaries before any assets are made available for distribution to the parent entities of such non-guarantor subsidiaries. As such, the Senior Secured Notes and each Notes Guarantee will each be structurally subordinated to the creditors (including trade creditors) and preference shareholders (if any) of the Group’s non-guarantor subsidiaries. In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will not require subsidiaries that become a member of the Regulated Group to guarantee the Senior Secured Notes under any circumstances and any Notes Guarantee will be automatically released upon the relevant Guarantor becoming a member of the Regulated Group.
