As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the Guarantors collectively accounted for 98% of the Asda Group’s consolidated revenues and, as of December 31, 2023, based on Asda’s allocation of properties for accounting purposes (which has not been verified by an assessment of the registered proprietor of each of the properties) and subject to matters disclosed in the section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Valuation Report”, the Guarantors hold sites representing over 99% of the value of the Market Value SA Properties (consisting of Asda supermarkets (excluding supermarkets pledged in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction), Food to Go sites, industrial properties and office properties), 90% of the value of the Market Value Properties (consisting of PFSs, investment properties, development and landbank sites and a Distribution Centre – Held for Sale site) and 0% of the properties leased in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, subsidiaries that are not Guarantors had no third-party debt outstanding. In addition, our audited consolidated financial statements include both Guarantor and non-guarantor subsidiaries and, as such, may be of limited use in assessing the financial position of the Guarantors.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Your rights in the Collateral may be adversely affected by the failure to perfect security interests in the relevant assets.
Subsubsection Text: Under certain applicable law, a security interest in certain tangible and intangible assets can only be properly perfected, and its priority retained, through certain actions undertaken by the secured party and/or the grantor of the security. The security interests in the Collateral may not be perfected with respect to the claims of the Senior Secured Notes if we, or the Security Agent, fail or are unable to take the actions required to perfect any of these security interests. The Security Agent has no obligation to perfect any of these liens or any security interest. In addition, certain applicable law requires that certain property and rights acquired after the grant of a general security interest, such as 87 ----- real property, equipment subject to a certificate and certain proceeds, can only be perfected at or promptly following the time such property and rights are acquired and identified. Absent perfection, the Security Agent, on behalf of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes may have difficulty enforcing or may be entirely unable to enforce rights in the Collateral in competition with third parties, including a trustee in bankruptcy and other creditors, including those who claim a security interest in the same assets. The Senior Secured Notes Trustee and the Security Agent have no obligation to monitor the acquisition of additional property or rights that constitute collateral or perfection of any security interest and will not be expected to do so. There can be no assurance that we will inform the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or the Security Agent of the future acquisition of property and rights that constitute collateral, and that necessary action will be taken to properly perfect the security interest in such after-acquired collateral.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Certain of the Collateral will not be granted until after the Issue Date.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes will be secured on the Issue Date by the Initial Collateral and will not initially benefit from any security interest in the Post-Closing Collateral as described in “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Security.” Within 30 days of the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by first priority_ interests over the Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral and within 180 days of the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by first priority interests over the Material Real Property, in each case subject to the Agreed Security Principles and as described in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security.” There can be no assurance that the Group will be successful in procuring the Post-Closing Collateral within the time period specified, if at all, and the failure to do so could result in an “event of default” under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: It may be difficult to realise the value of the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Collateral will be subject, in each case, to any and all exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens and other imperfections permitted under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement and accepted by other creditors that have the benefit of security interests in the Collateral from time to time, whether on or after the date the Senior Secured Notes are first issued. The existence of any such exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens and other imperfections could adversely affect the value of the Collateral, as well as the ability of the Security Agent to realise or foreclose on such Collateral. Furthermore, the ranking of security interests can be affected by a variety of factors, including, among others, the timely satisfaction of perfection requirements, statutory liens or characterisation under the laws of certain jurisdictions. Enforcement of the Security Interests by the Security Agent will be subject to practical problems generally associated with the realisation of security interests in collateral. For example, under English law, the enforcement of share pledges, whether by means of a sale or an appropriation, is subject to certain specific requirements. The share pledges will be enforced by the Security Agent. The Intercreditor Agreement regulates the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to instruct the Security Agent to take enforcement action. Initially, the Security Agent will not be required to take enforcement action unless instructed to do so by an Instructing Group with a sufficient majority. The Security Agent may also need to obtain the consent of a third party to enforce a security interest. The Group cannot assure you that the Security Agent will be able to obtain any such consents when required to facilitate a sale of, or appropriate or otherwise foreclose on, the Collateral. For example, any change in the direct or indirect control of Asda Stores Limited will require the approval of the FCA. Accordingly, the Security Agent may not have the ability to sell or foreclose upon Collateral assets the sale of which would result in any such change of control. In any such case, the value of the Collateral, may significantly decrease.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not control certain decisions regarding the Collateral, and the sale of particular assets could reduce the pool of assets securing the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Security Documents will, subject to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, allow the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and other security providers to remain in possession of, retain control over, freely operate, and collect, invest and dispose of any income from the Collateral. So long as no acceleration event under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture is occurring or would result therefrom, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Guarantors, may, among other things, without any consent 88 ----- by the Security Agent, conduct ordinary course activities with respect to the Collateral, such as selling, factoring or otherwise disposing of Collateral and making ordinary course cash payments, including repayments of indebtedness. Any of these activities could reduce the value of the Collateral and consequently the amounts payable to holders of the Senior Secured Notes from the proceeds of any sale of the Collateral in the case of an enforcement.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The security interests over the Collateral will be granted to the Senior Secured Notes Trustee and the Security Agent, respectively rather than directly to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The security interests over the Collateral that will secure, amongst other obligations, the Group’s obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and the obligations of the Guarantors under the Notes Guarantees will not be granted directly to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes but will be granted only in favour of the Senior Secured Notes Trustee and the Security Agent, respectively. The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will provide (along with the Intercreditor Agreement) that only the Security Agent has the right to enforce the Security Interests in the Collateral. As a consequence, holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not have direct security interests and will not be entitled to take enforcement action in respect of the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes, except through the Senior Secured Notes Trustee, who will (subject to the provisions of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture) provide instructions to the Security Agent in respect of the Collateral.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Each Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit its validity and enforceability.
Subsubsection Text: Each Notes Guarantee will provide the holders of the Senior Secured Notes with a direct claim against the relevant Guarantor. In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and certain other security providers will secure the payment of the Senior Secured Notes by granting security under the relevant Security Documents. However, each security interest granted under a Security Document will be limited in scope to the value of the relevant assets expressed to be subject to that security interest, and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will provide that each Notes Guarantee will be limited to the maximum amount that can be guaranteed by the relevant Guarantor, without rendering the relevant Notes Guarantee or security interest (as applicable) voidable or otherwise ineffective under English or other applicable law, and enforcement of each Notes Guarantee or Security Document (as applicable) would be subject to certain generally available defences. These laws and defences include those that relate to corporate benefit, fraudulent conveyance or transfer, voidable preference, financial assistance, corporate purpose, capital maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defences affecting the rights of creditors generally. See “Certain Insolvency Considerations and _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the _Security Interests.”_ Although laws differ among various jurisdictions, in general, under fraudulent conveyance and other laws, guarantees and security interests can be challenged (by the bankruptcy receiver or trustee, in case of bankruptcy of the relevant Guarantor, or by any of the creditors of such Guarantor outside bankruptcy), and a court could declare unenforceable against third parties (including the beneficiaries thereof) and/or void, any legal act performed by a Guarantor (including, without limitation, the granting by it of the Notes Guarantees or the security interests granted under the Security Documents) and, if payment had already been made under a Notes Guarantee or enforcement proceeds applied under a Security Document, require that the recipient (and possibly, subsequent transferees thereof) return the payment to the relevant Guarantor, if the court found, inter alia, that: - the amount paid or payable under the relevant Notes Guarantee or the enforcement proceeds under the relevant Security Document was in excess of the maximum amount permitted under applicable law; - the relevant Notes Guarantee or security interest under a Security Document was incurred with actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud creditors or shareholders of the Guarantor or, in certain jurisdictions, even when the recipient was simply aware that the Guarantor was insolvent when it granted the relevant Notes Guarantee or security interest; - the Guarantor did not receive fair consideration or reasonably equivalent value for granting the relevant Notes Guarantee/security interests and the Guarantor was: (i) insolvent or rendered insolvent because of the relevant Notes Guarantee/security interest; (ii) undercapitalised or became undercapitalised because of the relevant Notes Guarantee/Security Document; or (iii) intended to incur, or believed that it would incur, indebtedness beyond its ability to pay at maturity; and/or 89 ----- - the relevant Notes Guarantees/Security Documents were held to exceed the corporate objects of the Guarantor or not to be in the best interests or for the corporate benefit of the Guarantor. We cannot assure you which standard a court would apply in determining whether a Guarantor or a party granting the security interests was insolvent at the relevant time or that, regardless of the method of the valuation, a court would not determine that a Guarantor or such party was insolvent on that date, or that a court would not determine, regardless of whether or not a Guarantor or such party was insolvent on the date its Notes Guarantee was issued or its security interests were granted, that payments to holders of the Senior Secured Notes constituted unfair or voidable preferences, fraudulent transfers or voidable conveyances on other grounds.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking.
Subsubsection Text: The Collateral for the Senior Secured Notes may be granted by means of supplemental debentures to, and confirmation agreements of, existing security agreements or by means of further layers of security documents. As such, in certain circumstances, the Collateral may be second-ranking and only be deemed and treated as security interests ranking pari passu with the security interests securing the Senior Facilities pursuant to the application of the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement. If the Intercreditor Agreement or the relevant provisions thereof were avoided or held to be unenforceable for any reason, holders of the Senior Secured Notes would not benefit from such first-priority treatment and be subordinated, with respect to such security interests, to senior security interests over the same Collateral securing the Senior Facilities.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Currency exchange rates may have an impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to foreign currency translation and transaction effects because the Group’s business is based in the United Kingdom and the Group prepares its consolidated financial statements in pounds sterling; however, we have a significant amount of euro-denominated debt, including Facility B (EUR), and may incur further euro-denominated debt in the future. Our results of operations may be affected by both the transaction effects and the translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations. We are and will continue to be required to pay principal and interest payments in a currency outside of our functional currency, exposing us to unrealised and realised gains and losses due to foreign exchange depending on fluctuations in exchange rates. In addition, fluctuations in the euro-sterling currency exchange rate could have a substantial effect on our financial statements due to related gains or losses resulting from the conversion into sterling of euro-denominated liabilities. Although we may use currency swaps to hedge against the effect of changes in the euro-sterling rate and some purchases in US Dollars are managed using forward contracts, there can be no assurance that hedging or such forward contracts will be available on commercially reasonable terms and, even if such arrangements are available, they may not completely insulate us from currency exchange risks. In addition, hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements. The Group is currently contemplating additional cross-currency swaps as well as interest rate swaps in respect of the unhedged portion of our ongoing EUR exposure and floating rate exposure respectively under the Senior Facilities Agreement. From time to time we also enter into additional currency swap transactions in order to manage any operational currency exposures. We may, but are under no obligation to, enter into additional foreign exchange interest rate swaps or cross currency swaps as well as interest rate swaps in order to hedge our ongoing EUR exposure and floating rate exposure respectively under the Senior Facilities Agreement. However, there can be no assurance that such hedging will eliminate the potentially material adverse effect of such fluctuations. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations— _Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview—Foreign Currency Risk.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Our variable interest rate debt may be impacted by applicable regulation and may bear interest that could rise significantly, thereby increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.
Subsubsection Text: The debt the Group has incurred, and may incur in the future, under the Senior Facilities Agreement bears interest at variable rates, and we are exposed to the risk of fluctuations in interest rates. In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will permit us to incur substantial additional indebtedness, which may bear a floating rate of interest. 90 ----- These interest rates could rise significantly in the future, increasing our interest expense associated with these obligations, reducing cash flow available to fund working capital, capital expenditures or other general corporate purposes and hindering our ability to make payments on the Senior Secured Notes. Although we may enter into and maintain certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these rates, there can be no assurance that hedging will be available on commercially reasonable terms or that it will continue to be available on such terms in the future. Hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements. In addition, any elimination of any applicable benchmark, or changes in the manner of administration of such benchmark, could require an adjustment to the terms and conditions of our floating rate debt. Any such consequence could have a material adverse effect on the value of and return on any such floating rate debt. If any applicable benchmark was discontinued or otherwise unavailable, the rate of interest on our floating rate debt will be determined for the relevant period by the fallback provisions applicable to such debt. Any such change, as well as manipulative practices or the cessation thereof, may result in a sudden or prolonged increase in a reported benchmark rate, which could have an adverse impact on the Group’s ability to service debt that bears interest at floating rates of interest.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The insolvency laws of England and Wales and other jurisdictions may not be as favourable to you as the U.S. bankruptcy laws and may preclude holders of the Senior Secured Notes from recovering payments due on the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer are incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, the Guarantors are incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, and certain other security providers may be, incorporated under the laws of Jersey. In addition, the Security Documents will be governed by the laws of England and Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland, and the rights under the Security Documents will thus be subject to the laws of such jurisdictions. In the event of a bankruptcy, insolvency or similar event, proceedings could be initiated in England and Wales or another relevant jurisdiction. Such multi-jurisdictional proceedings may be complex and more costly for creditors and otherwise may result in greater uncertainty and delay regarding the enforcement of your rights. Holders’ rights under the Senior Secured Notes, the Notes Guarantees, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Security Documents, as applicable, will be subject to the insolvency, property and administrative laws of several jurisdictions and there can be no assurance that you will be able to effectively enforce your rights in such complex, multiple bankruptcy, insolvency or similar proceedings. In addition, the bankruptcy, insolvency, property, administrative and other laws of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s, the Guarantors’ and the other security providers’ jurisdictions of organisation or incorporation may be materially different from, or in conflict with, each other and those of the United States, including in the areas of rights of creditors, priority of governmental and other creditors, ability to obtain post-petition interest and duration of the proceeding. The application of these laws, or any conflict among them, could call into question whether any particular jurisdiction’s law should apply, adversely affect your ability to enforce your rights under the Senior Secured Notes, the Notes Guarantees, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Security Documents, as applicable, in those jurisdictions or limit any amounts that you may receive. Further, certain orders, proceedings or appointments entered, undertaken or effected with respect to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer or the Guarantors (including pursuant to a scheme of arrangement or a restructuring plan under the Companies Act 2006) that may adversely affect Holders’ rights under the Senior Secured Notes, the Notes Guarantees, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Security Documents may not result in any default or event of default occurring under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. See “Certain Insolvency Considerations and _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of _the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests” with respect to certain of the jurisdictions mentioned above._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Group may not have the ability to raise the funds necessary to finance an offer to repurchase the Senior Secured Notes upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control as required by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture.
Subsubsection Text: Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a “change of control,” the Senior Secured Notes Issuer would be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Senior Secured Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of purchase. A change of control may also result in an event of default under, acceleration of, or an obligation to mandatorily prepay amounts outstanding under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and other indebtedness. A change of control may also lead to an obligation to mandatorily prepay all 91 ----- amounts under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (where “change of control” means Asda Group Limited ceases to control the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction holding structure, or there is a change in the ownership of the wider Group that results in ownership by a person who does not satisfy the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction lenders’ “know your customer” or similar identification procedures). If a change of control were to occur, we cannot assure you that the Group would have sufficient funds available at such time, or that it would have sufficient funds to provide to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer to pay the purchase price of the outstanding Senior Secured Notes or repay or prepay the Ground Rent Facility, Senior Facilities, the Existing Senior Secured Notes or the Existing Senior Notes or that the restrictions in the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement or the Group’s other existing contractual obligations would allow us to make such required repurchases, repayments or prepayments. The repurchase of the Senior Secured Notes pursuant to such an offer could cause a default under such indebtedness, even if the change of control itself does not. The ability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer to receive cash from its subsidiaries to allow it to pay cash to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes following the occurrence of a change of control, may be limited by the Group’s then existing financial resources. In addition, we expect that we would require third-party financing to make an offer to repurchase the Senior Secured Notes upon a change of control. We cannot assure you that we would be able to obtain such financing. Any failure by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer to offer to purchase the Senior Secured Notes would constitute a default under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a default under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and certain other indebtedness. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of Control.” In addition, a change of control could constitute a default under the Group’s other indebtedness and the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (but only in the latter case if the acquiring entity does not satisfy the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction lenders’ “know your customer” or similar identification procedures). Additionally, an enforcement of the share pledge over the Senior Secured Notes Issuer could constitute a “change of control” under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. Future indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its subsidiaries may also contain prohibitions of certain events that would constitute a change of control or require such indebtedness to be repurchased or repaid upon a change of control.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: In certain circumstances, a Change of Control Offer will not be required to be made.
Subsubsection Text: The change of control provisions contained in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganisation, restructuring, merger or other similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a “Change of Control” as defined in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. Except as described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change _of Control,” the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will not contain provisions that would require the Senior Secured_ Notes Issuer to offer to repurchase or redeem the Senior Secured Notes in the event of a reorganisation, restructuring, merger, recapitalisation or similar transaction. The definition of “Change of Control” in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will include a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries, taken as a whole, to any person. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “substantially all,” there is no precise established definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of “substantially all” of the assets of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a change of control has occurred and whether the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: There may not be an active trading market for the Senior Secured Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Senior Secured Notes may be limited.
Subsubsection Text: The Group cannot assure you as to: - the liquidity of any market in the Senior Secured Notes; - your ability to sell your Senior Secured Notes; or - the prices at which you would be able to sell your Senior Secured Notes. 92 ----- Future trading prices for the Senior Secured Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things, prevailing interest rates, the Group’s operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the market for non-investment grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Senior Secured Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Senior Secured Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to disruptions that may cause volatility in prices. The trading market for the Senior Secured Notes may attract different investors and this may affect the extent to which the Senior Secured Notes may trade. It is possible that the market for the Senior Secured Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such disruption may have a negative effect on you, as a holder of the Senior Secured Notes, regardless of the Group’s prospects and financial performance. As a result, there is no assurance that there will be an active trading market for the Senior Secured Notes. If no active trading market develops, you may not be able to resell your holding of the Senior Secured Notes at a fair value, if at all. Although an application will be made for the Senior Secured Notes to be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, the Group cannot assure you that the Senior Secured Notes will become or remain listed. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Senior Secured Notes as a result of the admission to trading on the Official List of the Exchange, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting (whether or not for an alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the Senior Secured Notes as applicable, from the Exchange may have a material effect on a holder’s ability to resell the Senior Secured Notes, as applicable, in the secondary market. The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will allow us to issue additional notes in the future which could exacerbate the impact of a lack of sufficient liquidity of the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes will be denominated and payable in pound sterling. If investors in the Senior Secured Notes measure their investment returns by reference to a currency other than sterling, such investment in the Senior Secured Notes will entail foreign exchange-related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the values of the pound sterling relative to the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments because of economic, political and other factors over which the Group has no control. Depreciation of the pound sterling against the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their investments could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Senior Secured Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to investors when the return on such Senior Secured Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which the investors measure the return on their investments. Investments in the Senior Secured Notes denominated in a currency other than U.S. dollars by U.S. investors may also have important tax consequences as a result of foreign exchange gains or losses, if any. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal _Income Tax Considerations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Senior Secured Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. The Senior Secured Notes will be considered to be issued with OID if the stated principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes exceeds their issue price (as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes) by an amount equal to or more than a statutorily defined de minimis amount. In such event, investors in the Senior Secured Notes subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in their gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, such investors generally will include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States _Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: You may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations.
Subsubsection Text: Each of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer and the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries are organised outside the United States, and the Group’s business is conducted entirely outside the United States. The directors, managers and/or executive officers of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer and the Guarantors are non-residents of the United States. Although the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United 93 ----- States on these directors, managers and executive officers. In addition, as all of the assets of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer and the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries and those of their directors, managers and executive officers are located outside of the United States, you may be unable to enforce judgments obtained in the U.S. courts against them. Moreover, actions of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Notes Issuer and the Guarantors may not be subject to the provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States. The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards, rendered in civil and commercial matters with England and Wales. There is, therefore, doubt as to the enforceability in England and Wales of U.S. securities laws in an action to enforce a U.S. judgment in such jurisdictions. In addition, the enforcement in England and Wales of any judgment obtained in a U.S. court, whether or not predicated solely upon U.S. federal securities laws, will be subject to certain conditions. There is also doubt that a court in England and Wales and Jersey would have the requisite power or authority to grant remedies sought in an original action brought in such jurisdictions on the basis of U.S. Securities laws violations. For further information see “Service of Process and Enforcement of Judgments.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Senior Secured Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed in this Offering Memorandum and other factors that may affect the value of the Senior Secured Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Senior Secured Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of the Group’s financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Certain covenants will be suspended upon the occurrence of a change in the Group’s ratings.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes receive both a rating of Baa3 or better by Moody’s and a rating of BBB- or better from Standard & Poor’s (or, in each case, the equivalent rating by Fitch if either Moody’s or Standard & Poor’s has no rating for the Senior Secured Notes) and no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, then beginning that day the provisions of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture described in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status” will not apply to the Senior_ Secured Notes. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the rating assigned by any such rating agency to the Senior Secured Notes should subsequently decline to below such ratings, the foregoing covenants will be reinstituted as of and from the date of such rating decline. If these covenants were to be suspended, the Group would be able to incur additional debt or make payments, including dividends or investments, which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, during the period in which the covenants are suspended, there will be no restrictions on our ability to designate any of our subsidiaries as unrestricted subsidiaries. There can be no assurance that the Senior Secured Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating will be maintained.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The lender under the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement may call an event of default if the notes issued pursuant to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction cease to have a rating.
Subsubsection Text: The Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement provides that if the notes issued pursuant to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction cease to have a rating, then this triggers an event of default. This would permit the lender under the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement to accelerate the facility and enforce security.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: We may choose to provide further cash to our subsidiary Asda Propco Limited in certain circumstances in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction.
Subsubsection Text: On June 30, in each calendar year beginning on June 30, 2029, certain trigger events may require Asda Propco Limited to deposit cash (from subordinated debt, equity injection or free cash in the general account of Asda Propco Limited) as additional collateral for the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction or to substitute applicable superstores. The amount of cash required to be deposited depends on the percentage of stores operated on properties that are subject 94 ----- to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (“Portfolio Stores”) that are affected stores. Whether a store is an affected superstore is dependent on the sales performance of that superstore relative to all of the superstores we own. It ranges from (if the affected Portfolio Stores represent less than 15% of such rent for all Portfolio Stores) 12 months of rent for all affected Portfolio Stores for the year to June 30 (“Allocated Rent”) to double the Allocated Rent (if affected Portfolio Stores represent 50% or more of portfolio Allocated Rent). If an event of default occurs under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction, the lenders thereunder may enforce over the relevant properties and therefore we would no longer own those properties. If an event of default arises under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction, the lenders thereunder may accelerate the loan and enforce their mortgages over the properties subject to the transaction, or over the shares in Asda Propco Limited (which owns the freehold or long leasehold interest in all of the relevant properties). Events of default are included for the insolvency of the tenant under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (i.e., Asda Stores Limited), and for persistent non-payment under or material breach of the CGR Ground Leases. In the case of the latter, such an event of default will not arise unless either (i) in respect of a CGR Ground Lease in England & Wales, a notice of intended forfeiture under s.146 Law of Property Act 1925 has been served on the tenant and the tenant has not complied with such notice, or (ii) in respect of a CGR Ground Lease in Scotland, an irritancy warning notice has been served on the tenant, and Asda Propco Limited has not substituted the affected property. It is proposed that the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement will be amended to reflect the distinction between forfeiture and irritancy in English and Scottish leases, respectively.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: We have certain liabilities under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction where the lenders’ recourse is not limited to the value of the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction properties.
Subsubsection Text: Asda Group Limited has entered into a tax deed of covenant with Asda Propco Limited and the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction for the purposes of managing certain group level tax compliance obligations in respect of the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. The tax deed of covenant also contains a tax indemnity given by Asda Group Limited to Asda Propco Limited to cover the imposition of unexpected tax liabilities arising in connection with the Asda Group. For example, the tax deed of covenant contains an indemnity covering the imposition of any secondary liability taxes or the imposition of any de-grouping charge. Asda Group Limited has provided an indemnity in favour of the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction for any increased costs it incurs itself, and for any liability for increased costs incurred by noteholders in each case in the event the transaction is characterised as a securitisation under UK Securitisation Regulation Rules or EU Securitisation Regulation Rules. In addition, Asda Group Limited undertakes to take such actions as are within its control to comply with UK Securitisation Regulation Rules and EU Securitisation Regulation Rules, and to procure that Asda Propco Limited and any relevant affiliate does likewise.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The transfer of the Senior Secured Notes is restricted, which may adversely affect their liquidity and the price at which they may be sold.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been registered under, and the Group is not obliged to register the Senior Secured Notes or the Notes Guarantees under, the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from, or a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and any other applicable laws. See “Notice to Investors.” The Group has not agreed to or otherwise undertaken to register any of the Senior Secured Notes or the Notes Guarantees, and do not have any intention to do so.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Senior Secured Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: Unless and until the Senior Secured Notes are in definitive registered form, or definitive registered notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests (which may occur only in very limited circumstances), owners of book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of the Senior Secured Notes. The common depositary (or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the global notes. Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the global notes representing the Senior Secured Notes will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, these 95 ----- payments will be credited to participants’ accounts that hold book-entry interests in the global notes representing the Senior Secured Notes and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, we will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, owners of book-entry interests in the Senior Secured Notes must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and if such owners are not a participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which their interest is owned, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Senior Secured Notes under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. Unlike the holders of the Senior Secured Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have any direct rights to act upon any solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Senior Secured Notes. Instead, owners of book-entry interests will be permitted to act only to the extent they have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if applicable, from a participant. There can be no assurance that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable an owner of a book entry interest to vote on any matters or on a timely basis. Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, unless and until the definitive registered Senior Secured Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, owners of book-entry interests will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. We can make no assurances that the procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The interests of the group’s principal shareholders may conflict with your interests.
Subsubsection Text: The interests of the Group’s principal shareholders, in certain circumstances, may conflict with your interests as holders of the Senior Secured Notes. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, all of the outstanding shares of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer are held by the Senior Notes Issuer, which is 50% indirectly owned by Mohsin and Zuber Issa and 50% indirectly owned by funds managed by TDR Capital LLP. See “Principal Shareholders.” As a result, the principal shareholders have, and will continue to have, directly or indirectly, the power to, among other things, affect the Group’s legal and capital structure and its day-to-day operations, as well as the ability to elect and change its management and to approve any other changes to its operations. Our shareholders may make strategic decisions with regards to their ownership of the Group that may not be aligned with the interests of holders of the Senior Secured Notes. For instance, they may seek to acquire further ownership interests or dispose their existing ownership interests in the Group. Our principal shareholders may also have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings or other transactions that, in their judgment, will enhance their equity investments, although such transactions might involve risks to you as a holder of Senior Secured Notes. For example, these shareholders could vote to cause us to incur additional indebtedness, sell certain material assets or pay dividends, in each case, so long as the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement so permit. The incurrence of additional indebtedness could increase the Group’s debt service obligations, the payment of dividends would reduce the Group’s ability to meet its debt service obligations or fund working capital, capital expenditures or general corporate purposes and the sale of certain assets would reduce the Group’s ability to generate revenue, each of which could adversely affect holders of the Senior Secured Notes. Such transactions may not be in the best interests of the Group or the holders or the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, TDR Capital is in the business of making investments in companies and may, from time to time, acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with us. TDR Capital may also pursue acquisitions that may be complementary with our business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be available to us. So long as our shareholders continue to indirectly own a significant amount of the outstanding shares of our common stock, even if such amount is less than 50%, our shareholders will continue to be able to strongly influence or effectively control our decisions. In addition, our principal shareholders own EG Group, which operates in the fuel and convenience retail industry in jurisdictions including the United Kingdom, and may, in the future, own businesses that directly compete with ours or do business with us. This may give rise to a conflict of interest for such directors in circumstances where the interests of EG Group are not aligned with the Group’s interests. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions.”_ 96 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: We will be subject to significant restrictive debt covenants, which limit our operating and financial flexibility.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will contain covenants which impose significant operating and financial restrictions on us. These agreements limit our ability to, among other things: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock; - make certain restricted payments and investments; - transfer or sell assets or enter into sale and leaseback transactions; - enter into transactions with affiliates; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions of minority interests; - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments to us; - take certain actions that would impair the Security Interests granted for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes; - incur or enter into certain sale and leaseback transactions, ground rent transactions and qualified securitizations involving real property; and - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets. These covenants could limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue acquisitions and other business activities that may be in our interest. In addition, we are subject to the affirmative and negative covenants contained in the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, which, in the case of the negative covenants, are substantially in line with those applicable to the Senior Secured Notes (other than certain additional covenants applicable to the Senior Facilities Agreement customary for facilities of that nature and certain covenants applicable to the Private Placement Facility that are more restrictive than included in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture). See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement—Covenants.” Asda Propco Limited is also subject to certain affirmative and negative covenants in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (which are transaction-specific and broadly based on the Loan Market Association Single Currency Term Facility Agreement for Real Estate Finance Multiproperty Investment Transactions). A breach of any of those covenants could result in an event of default under those debt documents, which could lead to an event of default and acceleration under our other debt instruments that contain cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions, including the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture. If our creditors accelerate the payment of amounts owing to them under such other debt instruments, we cannot assure you that our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay in full those amounts, to satisfy all our other liabilities and the liabilities of our subsidiaries which would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Senior Secured Notes, in full or in part. In addition, if we are unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could proceed against any security interests granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to access the short-term and long-term funding required to meet business needs.
Subsubsection Text: The availability and ability to access appropriate levels of funding and liquidity on financial terms acceptable to us is critical for continued business operations. Our Treasury function seeks to ensure that we continue to have access to sufficient funding by, amongst other things, monitoring rolling forecasts of our cash flows, which includes our ability to service our debt obligations. We have sought to manage our liquidity through entry into short-term financing arrangements with a number of third-party financial institutions, including arrangements to allow a number of our suppliers to participate in supply chain finance (“SCF”) arrangements with such financial institutions. Such 97 ----- arrangements reduce pressure on supplier payment terms, allowing payments in respect of supplier invoices on longer payment terms and correspondingly increasing short-term liquidity. However, as these SCF facilities are uncommitted and the level of funding financial institutions provide pursuant to them is discretionary, there is a risk that these facilities will not be sufficient to meet our liquidity needs. A decision by one or more of these third-party financial institutions to reduce the amount of funding available pursuant to such SCF facilities or fully withdraw the access to such SCF facilities, or a disruption to one or more of the financial institutions providing such facilities, could adversely affect our cash flows and liquidity. The withdrawal of such facilities could lead to a review of payment terms by suppliers, with a significant reduction in payment terms to suppliers risking a working capital outflow. If these programmes or underlying supplier terms do not continue and we are unable to secure alternative programmes, our cash and working capital may be negatively affected and we may have to increase our long-term borrowings for short- and long-term liquidity requirements. For a description of our supply chain finance arrangements, see “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Supply Chain Facilities.”_ We are also subject to the risk that our capital structure may not be sufficient to support the growth of our business and maintain our existing credit rating. Our capital structure consists of debt obligations (including the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Senior Notes) and equity (issued share capital, share premium and reserves). Part of our capital risk management strategy is to monitor a broad range of financial metrics and manage compliance with financial covenants relating to our debt obligations. There is a risk that we are unable to access to financial markets to obtain appropriate sources and levels of funding at economic rates or debt funding is removed due to noncompliance with lending agreements and related covenants.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt, fund working capital, rental and lease payments and sustain our operations. Our ability to generate or raise sufficient cash depends on many factors beyond our control.
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, we expect to issue a significant amount of debt and will have significant debt service obligations, including under the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes and the Senior Facilities. Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on and to refinance our debt, and to fund working capital, rental and lease payments and capital expenditures, will depend on our future operating performance and ability to generate sufficient cash. This depends, to some extent, on the success of our business strategy and on general economic, financial, competitive, market, legislative, regulatory and other factors discussed in these “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, as well as other factors, many of which are beyond our control. This also depends on our cash flow cycle, which experiences seasonal fluctuations. Levels of customer traffic at our stores are affected by the weather and travel patterns, among other factors, which could also have a negative impact on our cash position and impact our ability to make payments on and to refinance our debt and to fund working capital and capital expenditures. If our interest or lease payment dates coincide with periods of significant cash outflow, we may have insufficient cash to pay our obligations as they come due. We cannot assure you that the currently anticipated cost savings, revenue growth and operating improvements will be realised, that cash flows from operations will be sufficient, or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us on satisfactory terms or in an amount sufficient to enable us to refinance all or a portion of our debt, pay our debts when due, or to fund our other liquidity needs. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, on or before maturity. 98 ----- We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In particular, our ability to restructure or refinance our debt will depend in part on our financial condition at such time as well as on many factors outside of our control, including then-prevailing conditions in the international credit and capital markets. In such event, we may not to be able to meet our debt repayment obligations. In addition, the terms of our debt limit, and any future debt may limit, our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. See _“—We will be subject to significant restrictive debt covenants, which limit our operating and _financial flexibility.” Any refinancing of our debt could be at higher interest rates and could require us to comply with_ more onerous covenants, which could further restrict our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects. There can be no assurance that any assets which we could be required to dispose of could be sold or that, if sold, the timing of such sale and the amount of proceeds realised from such sale would be acceptable. Furthermore, our inability to meet payment obligations under our existing debt could trigger various default provisions, accelerate a substantial portion (if not all) of our debt, and would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not control decisions regarding the Collateral in certain circumstances.
Subsubsection Text: Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees will be secured on a first-priority basis by the same Collateral securing the obligations under the Senior Facilities. In addition, under the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the Group is (or, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, will be) permitted to incur significant additional indebtedness and other obligations that may be secured by the same Collateral on a pari passu basis, including other credit facilities and certain hedging liabilities. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that a common Security Agent, who is also the security agent for the lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement and any additional debt secured by the Collateral permitted to be incurred by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement, will act only as provided for in the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement regulates the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to instruct the Security Agent to take enforcement action. Initially, the Security Agent will not be required to take enforcement action unless instructed to do so by an Instructing Group (as defined under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”) that comprises creditors holding more than 50% of the indebtedness under the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement, and indebtedness ranking pari passu with such indebtedness (the “Majority Senior Secured Creditors”) (in each case acting through their respective creditor representative). Additionally, the Senior Facilities Agreement allows (or, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, will allow) the Group to incur additional indebtedness secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes, which would further dilute the voting interest of holders of the Senior Secured Notes issued on the Issue Date. The lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement and creditors in respect of any indebtedness secured on a _pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes that we may incur in the future may have interests that are different_ from the interests of holders of the Senior Secured Notes and they may, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, elect to pursue their remedies under the Security Documents at a time when it would be disadvantageous for the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to do so. In addition, if the Security Agent sells Collateral comprising the shares of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or any of its holding companies or subsidiaries as a result of an enforcement action or other distressed disposal in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement, claims under the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees against, and the liens over any other assets of, such entities and any subsidiaries of such entity securing the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees may be released. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Release_ _of Liens.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Collateral may not be sufficient to secure the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by security interests in the Initial Collateral, within 30 days of the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by security interests in the Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral and, within 180 days of the Issue Date, 99 ----- the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by security interests in the Post-Closing Real Estate Collateral, in each case as described in this Offering Memorandum. The Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes will also secure the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and, with respect to the Shared Security, the Existing Senior Notes (on a second-priority basis). Such Collateral may also secure additional debt ranking pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes to the extent permitted to be incurred by the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement. The holders of Senior Secured Notes’ rights to the Collateral may therefore be diluted by any increase in the debt secured by such Collateral on a pari passu or senior basis or a reduction in the value of the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes. The value that holders of the Senior Secured Notes may receive upon enforcement of the Collateral will depend upon many factors, including, among others, the ability to sell this Collateral in an orderly sale, the condition of the economies in which our operations are located and the availability of buyers. The book value of the Collateral should not be relied on as a measure of realisable value for such assets. All or a portion of the Collateral may be illiquid and may have no readily ascertainable market value. Likewise, we cannot assure you that there will be a market for the sale of the Collateral, or, if such a market exists, that there will not be a substantial delay in its liquidation. In addition, the share pledges over the shares of an entity may be of no value if that entity is subject to an insolvency or bankruptcy proceeding. The Collateral is located in England and Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland, and the multi-jurisdictional nature of any foreclosure on the Collateral may limit its realisable value. For example, the bankruptcy, insolvency, administrative and other laws of the various jurisdictions may be materially different from, or conflict with, each other, including in the areas of rights of creditors, priority of government and other creditors, ability to obtain post-petition interest and duration of the proceedings. In addition, third parties may have rights over Material Real Property (including rights to acquire and pre-emption rights) exercisable in the event of transfer of such Material Real Property (including as a result of enforcement of security interests in such Collateral). In such cases, the enforcement of the security interests over, or transfer of, such Material Real Property may be significantly delayed, prevented in part or prevented entirely.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The granting of the security interests in connection with the issuance of the Senior Secured Notes or the incurrence of permitted debt in the future, may create or restart hardening periods, i.e., the periods of time following the granting of security interests during which such security interests may be challenged in accordance with the laws applicable in certain jurisdictions.
Subsubsection Text: The granting of security interests to secure the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees following the Issue Date may create hardening periods for such security interests in certain jurisdictions. The granting of shared security interests to secure future indebtedness permitted to be secured on the Collateral may restart or reopen such hardening periods in particular, as the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will permit the release and retaking of security granted in favour of the Senior Secured Notes in certain circumstances, including in connection with the incurrence of future indebtedness and a Permitted Reorganisation. Please see “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Security.”_ The applicable hardening period for these new security interests can run from the moment each new security interest has been granted or perfected. At each time, if the security interest granted or recreated were to be enforced before the end of the respective hardening period applicable in such jurisdiction, it may be declared void or ineffective and/or it may not be possible to enforce it. Please see “Certain Insolvency Considerations and _Limitations on Validity _and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: If the New Revolving Facility is designated as super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, creditors under the New Revolving Facility and counterparties to certain hedging obligations and future indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a super senior basis under the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement are entitled to be repaid with proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in priority to the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Intercreditor Agreement includes provisions governing the sharing of proceeds from enforcement of the Collateral. Such enforcement proceeds are required to be turned over to the Security Agent after certain events, including the acceleration of the Senior Secured Notes. The Security Agent is required to apply turned-over amounts and other recoveries by the Security Agent from enforcement actions toward discharging the super senior obligations (including, among others, (following the designation of the New Revolving Facility as super senior liabilities in 100 ----- accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture) those under the New Revolving Facility, certain hedging obligations and supply chain financings that may, pursuant to the terms of the Indentures, be secured on a super senior basis (the “Super Senior Liabilities”) under certain circumstances, including the refinancing in full of the Term Loan Facilities) in priority to applying any such amounts toward discharging the Senior Secured Notes. As such, in the event of a foreclosure of the Collateral, holders of the Senior Secured Notes may not benefit from such recoveries if the then-outstanding claims under such Super Senior Liabilities are greater than the proceeds recovered. Any proceeds remaining from an enforcement sale of Collateral will, after all obligations under such Super Senior Liabilities have been discharged, be applied pro rata in repayment of the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities (other than the New Revolving Facility where a designation of the New Revolving Facility as super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement has occurred) and any other obligations secured by the Collateral which are permitted to rank pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes. Furthermore, claims of other secured creditors that are secured by assets that do not also secure the Senior Secured Notes will have priority with respect to such assets over the claims of holders of the Senior Secured Notes. As such, the claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be effectively subordinated to the rights of such secured creditors to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness. 101 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: _An investment in the Senior Secured Notes involves a high degree of risk. In addition to the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum, you should carefully consider the following risk factors before purchasing the Senior Secured Notes. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only ones the Group faces. Additional risks and uncertainties of which the Group is not aware or that it currently believes are immaterial may also adversely affect the Group’s business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. If any of the possible events described below were to occur, the Group’s business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be materially and adversely affected. If that happens, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Senior Secured Notes, respectively, when due, and you could lose all or part of your investment. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The Group’s actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: USE OF PROCEEDS
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we have launched an offer to purchase for cash our outstanding Existing Senior Secured Notes held pursuant to Regulation S under the Securities Act (the “Richmond Tender Offer”) up to a certain maximum acceptance amount, expected to be set not to exceed (x) the sum of (i) the aggregate net proceeds from the New Financing and (ii) £415 million less (y) the sum of (i) the aggregate amount required for the prepayment and cancellation of the Original Facility B in full and (ii) the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions. Pursuant to the terms of the Richmond Tender Offer, we will not accept any tenders with respect to Existing Senior Secured Notes held pursuant to Rule 144A under the Securities Act. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which were not targeted in the Richmond Tender Offer, will remain outstanding following the Transactions. The Richmond Tender Offer is being made upon terms and subject to the conditions set out in the separate tender offer memorandum dated April 26, 2024 (the “Tender Offer Memorandum”). The Richmond Tender Offer is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions, including, but not limited to, the consummation of the New Financing, on terms satisfactory to the Issuer in its sole discretion. We cannot assure you that the Richmond Tender Offer will be consummated in accordance with its terms, or at all, or that any of the Existing Senior Secured Notes will be tendered and purchased in the Richmond Tender Offer. The Offering is not conditioned upon the consummation of the Richmond Tender Offer. The maximum amount of Existing Senior Secured Notes and the maximum amount of each series of Existing Senior Secured Notes accepted in the Richmond Tender Offer will be determined by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in its sole and absolute discretion, subject to the terms of the Richmond Tender Offer. This Offering Memorandum does not relate to the Richmond Tender Offer, which is only made upon the terms and subject to the conditions set out in the Tender Offer Memorandum, and is only made to certain eligible holders of Existing Senior Secured Notes holding book-entry interests in the Regulation S global note.

Section Title: USE OF PROCEEDS
Subsubsection Text: The following table illustrates the estimated sources and uses of funds in connection with the Transactions. The estimated fees and expenses related to the Transactions are shown in the table below as of the expected Issue Date.
