Actual amounts may vary from these estimated amounts due to several factors, including the gross proceeds derived from the Offering, the accrued and unpaid interest due in respect of the Existing Senior Secured Notes and Original Facility B, original issue discounts and the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. 102 ----- Any changes in these amounts may be reflected as an increase or decrease of cash on balance sheet used to fund the Transactions. This table should be read in conjunction with “Capitalisation.”

Section Title: USE OF PROCEEDS
USE OF PROCEEDS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Represents the £1,750 million (equivalent) aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes offered hereby. (2) Represents the £900 million (equivalent) aggregate principal amount of the indebtedness to be incurred under Facility B (EUR) that we expect to enter into on or around the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.” (3) Represents an assumption that 100% of the targeted Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes will be tendered and accepted as part of the Richmond Tender Offer at a purchase price of 98.75%. If less than 100% of such Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes are tendered and accepted, following the closing of the Offering, we intend to hold outstanding New Financing Proceeds that are not used to purchase tendered and accepted Existing Senior Secured Notes, prepay and cancel the Original Facility B in full and pay the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions on balance sheet (in cash or cash equivalents) until applied for the redemption of the outstanding Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were subject to the Richmond Tender Offer, but were untendered or unaccepted for repurchase, at stated maturity. (4) Represents an assumption that 100% of the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes will be tendered and accepted as part of the Richmond Tender Offer at a purchase price of 100.00%. If less than 100% of such Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes are tendered and accepted, following the closing of the Offering, we intend to hold outstanding New Financing Proceeds that are not used to purchase tendered and accepted Existing Senior Secured Notes, prepay and cancel the Original Facility B in full and pay the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions on balance sheet (in cash or cash equivalents) until applied for the redemption of the outstanding Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date. (5) Represents the aggregate principal amount of indebtedness expected to be prepaid under Original Facility B with the New Financing Proceeds, excluding estimated accrued and unpaid interest through the Issue Date, following which the Original Facility B will be repaid in full. (6) Represents estimated underwriting, financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction costs as well as professional fees in connection with the Transactions. Estimated fees and expenses exclude any applicable VAT and accrued and unpaid interest. These fees and expenses have been estimated as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, and the actual amount of transaction fees and expenses may differ from the estimated amount depending on several factors, including differences between our estimates of fees and expenses and the actual fees and expenses as of the Issue Date. 103 -----

Section Title: USE OF PROCEEDS
Subsubsection Text: The gross proceeds from the Offering are expected to be approximately £1,750 million (equivalent). On or about the Issue Date, we will use the gross proceeds from the New Financing and cash on hand to (i) partially repurchase the Existing Senior Secured Notes, (ii) prepay and cancel Original Facility B in full and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. In this Offering Memorandum, we refer to the following as the “Transactions”: (i) the New Financing and the use of proceeds therefrom, including the making and consummation of the Richmond Tender Offer, (ii) the establishment of New Facility A and New Revolving Facility and use of proceeds therefrom, (iii) the Facility A Maturity Extension, the Revolving Facility Maturity Extension and the Facility B Refinancing, (iv) the payment of fees and expenses related to the Transactions, and (v) to the extent not used to repurchase and cancel Existing Senior Secured Notes in connection with the Richmond Tender Offer, prepay and cancel the Original Facility B in full and pay the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions, the holding of the New Financing Proceeds on balance sheet (in cash or cash equivalents) and the application thereof to repay any Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, as applicable, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which were not targeted under the Richmond Tender Offer, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, will not be included in the repayment described in clause (v) above, and therefore will remain outstanding following the Transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Till Roll data on a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We operate a significant store estate of over 1,200 large stores and convenience sites that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We are also now a major player in the UK convenience market, having added 472 convenience sites (including petrol filling stations) to our portfolio, as well as 124 stand-alone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites), following the Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition. These acquisitions have given us significant foothold in the fast-growing convenience market which, alongside our existing fuel portfolio, makes us the second-largest independent fuel owner-operator in the United Kingdom. 108 ----- The graph below compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers based on Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. _(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Till Roll.)_ We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the COVID-19 pandemic, followed only by a slight contraction as the pandemic eased. Since, the UK grocery retail market has experienced consistent growth, achieving a record-high size of £144.0 billion in sales for the 52week period ended December 24, 2023, according to Kantar Worldpanel, despite facing high inflation and global geopolitical tensions in 2022 and 2023. See also “Industry.” One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is in turn centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to offering high quality products with low prices to our customers and our wholly-owned supplier, International Procurement and Logistics Ltd (“IPL”), which enables us to take a vertically-integrated approach to procurement and which we believe gives us a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and well-established George Clothing and George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers, our growing presence in the convenience and foodservice market, our popular customer loyalty programme Asda Rewards, and our team of flexible and engaged colleagues. We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our revenue was £25.6 billion (including fuel), with 16.5% of sales made online, our net cash flow from operating activities was £1,245.8 million, our profit for the year was £194.5 million, and our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was £1,264 million. 109 ----- Excluding the results of the EG UK Business, which was acquired on October 31, 2023, and the results of the Arthur Business, which was consolidated from May 31, 2023, the chart below presents the breakdown of our 2023 revenue by product category (food, general merchandise, clothing and petrol), and channel (stores and online (including George.com)). _(Source: Asda information. Year ended December 31, 2023. Note: excluding approximately £588 million from the Arthur Acquisition, £411 million from the EG UK Acquisition and £199 million of other revenue from Asda Mobile sales, financial services sales, shipping and wrapping revenue, pharmacy revenue and, until the EG UK Acquisition, Asda On The Move.)_ Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditure KPI) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. For more information on our differentiated operating model, see “—Key Strengths—We benefit from a differentiated operating model.”_ Between 2021 and 2023, our average profit margin (defined as profit for the year divided by revenue) was 4.3%, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2% (including fuel), our cumulative cash flows from operating activities totalled £3,340.6 million, cumulative free cash flow was approximately £2,097 million and our average cash conversion was 68%. See “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial _Data—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_ We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our significant freehold real estate asset portfolio, which also can provide a potential source of liquidity. See “Valuation Report.” In 2023, through the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent Transaction, we have been able to, and in the future may continue to, selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities. See “—Lease Agreements.” We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we maintain a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. We have made more than £300 million annualized price investment since 2022 across over 1,200 lines. Within the UK value market, we have strong market shares across core grocery products (13.1%), beers, wines and spirits (12.8%), impulse grocery (12.1%), household and pet (12.1%), frozen (11.4%) and total grocery (11.4%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). Our offer is strong across the full food basket: our category market shares range from 9.6% to 13.1% (except health and beauty)(in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal 110 ----- Asda data, our prices are approximately 2.5% to 6.1% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on the average of the first eight weeks in 2024, based on total goods price gap percentage). We believe our prices continue to compete with those of discounters such as Lidl and Aldi. In January 2024, we launched a new price matching programme where we have price matched Aldi and Lidl on approximately 300 comparable grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products. Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is supplemented by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food and non-food products to customers as an accessible “one-stop shop” experience that is supported and enhanced by our strong online offer and expansion into the convenience market under the Asda Express banner. We believe our omni-channel offer, through which we reach customers at our brick-and-mortar stores and through our significant online offering and on our app, appeals to our customers. The COVID-19 pandemic increased use of and engagement with our online platforms. In the first half of 2021, there were approximately 8.6 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with order growth from approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020) to an average of more than 773,000 weekly orders in 2021 (based on the average weekly orders for the first 26 weeks of 2021) and a peak of more than 850,000 orders during the third lockdown (based on the seven days to January 15, 2021). Online engagement has fallen from the peaks experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic, but we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). We also offer at-home delivery and customers are able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 Asda Click & Collect sites. Our business model integrates our store-based and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders. Our online grocery business is profitable within one of the world’s most developed online grocery markets. According to Kantar Worldpanel, as of January 21, 2024, we operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales), growing our market share in a market that is 5.5% larger on a one-year basis (comparing Total Grocery Absolute Online Sales from the 52 weeks ended January 22, 2023 to the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024). Our online business is already of significant scale; the chart below shows the growth of our online sales, including a breakdown of online grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented. _(Source: Asda information.)_ According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the third-largest online clothing, footwear and accessories retailer in the United Kingdom by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and we held 8.5% of the total UK online clothing, footwear and accessories market by volume for the 24 weeks ended January 7, 2024. Combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion (of which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £3.6 billion in 2023 (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR of 16.2% between 2018 and 2023. Additionally, our ‘toyou’ service allows customers to conveniently collect and 111 ----- return orders from George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 112 brands and processed more than 4.4 million parcels in the year ended December 31, 2023. We also have a strong presence in the convenience market with significant opportunity for additional expansion in this fast-growing sector. In October 2022, we took our first notable step into the convenience market after acquiring 132 sites including 129 convenience sites attached to forecourts from the Co-op (the “Co-op sites,” and such business, the “Arthur Business”) and three development sites as part of the Arthur Acquisition. We agreed to divest 13 of the Co-op sites following the recommendation of the CMA after an Initial Enforcement Order stemming from its review of the acquisition. The disposals of these sites completed across December 2023 to January 2024 for proceeds of £25.2 million. Each Co-op site included a grocery retail store between 1,500 and 3,000 square feet of space and an attached petrol filling station driving footfall. In October 2023, we acquired the majority of EG Group’s business in the United Kingdom for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion (including transaction fees). The deal represented a major step in our convenience proposition, adding 356 well-invested PFSs to our convenience portfolio, 161 of which are stand-alone and 195 of which are co-located with foodservice concessions, as well as 124 stand-alone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites). In foodservice, we acquired franchises for some of the United Kingdom’s best loved outlets, including Greggs, Subway, Burger King and Sbarro, as well as our own proprietary brand, Leon. Certain of our acquired sites also continue to benefit from an additional KFC and Starbucks non-Group branded offerings operated by third parties. Through this acquisition, we accessed another high-growth sector, foodservice, tapping into a new market which is highly complementary to Asda’s current offering. Each of the acquired sites are community-focused and strategically located at the heart of residential areas with a diversified footprint across the United Kingdom, and represent broader retail destinations with ancillary services such as parcel delivery, car wash and last mile food delivery, with opportunity to expand further. The acquired sites also present a significant opportunity for further synergies across Asda’s business through higher volumes, buying synergies and cost savings through operational leverage. In September 2023, we began the conversion of the Co-op sites from Co-op branding to our Asda Express banner, implementing Asda pricing across fuel and grocery upon conversion. We completed the conversion of the remaining convenience sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in March 2024. Total capex investment to convert the stores to Asda Express was approximately £17 million. We believe we will be able to bring Asda’s great value to even more customers across the United Kingdom by reaching new communities and shoppers with this smaller store format. In the converted Co-op sites, our Asda Express prices were an average of 6.1% cheaper than their corresponding prices under Co-op ownership. We also have further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in 2023 and a strong pipeline of approximately 40 sites that have been identified for potential opening in 2024. Going forward, our focus will be on the continued integration of the Co-op sites and EG UK Business into the Asda Group and delivering synergies. Currently, with our team of approximately 150,000 flexible and engaged colleagues, with around 98,000 fulltime employees, serving approximately 16.8 million customer trips each week (based on the average of weeks 37 to 40 of 2023), we are committed to and deeply invested in the UK food supply chain. Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the entire UK population, in terms of both customer demographics and geography, with our customer base skewing slightly towards value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers who are attracted by our strategy to offer high quality products at low prices and with strong market shares in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. For more information about our customer mix, see “—Our Customers,” and for more information about the geographic distribution of our stores, see “—Our Store Formats.” Second, we believe we are well-positioned geographically, with a strong regional footprint across the United Kingdom. Our store footprint is strongest in the North of England, Scotland and Wales. Our large and diverse store estate offers customers a variety of differentiated shopping formats. We operate 30 supercentres, 396 superstores, 153 supermarkets, 30 Asda Living stores, 499 convenience sites (including our petrol filling stations) and 124 stand-alone foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites). For more information on our stores, see “—Our Store Formats.” We continue to benefit from certain support provided by Walmart through the Transitional Agreements, primarily in relation to the continued use of its IT platform. We have set up a dedicated team to facilitate the transition of our IT environment away from the Walmart ecosystem and onto a stand-alone IT solution, which we refer to as Project Future. We believe Project Future presents significant opportunities in terms of our efficiency, data capabilities, customer experience and competitive edge and are targeting complete separation from Walmart by the 112 ----- end of 2024. See “—Our Technology and Information Systems,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions— Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are engaged in a single reportable operating segment of business: the retailing of food (including grocery and foodservice outlets), clothing, general merchandise, fuel and services in a single geographical segment, the United Kingdom and online. The majority of our revenue is generated by the sale of goods through retail outlets in the United Kingdom and through the Group’s online channels. The operations of all product areas of the business are subject to similar economic characteristics and are sold in a similar retail environment. The Group is not reliant on any individual major customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use certain financial key performance indicators (“KPIs”) to monitor the financial and operating performance of our business. For an overview of these KPIs, including definitions and reconciliations, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures” and “Summary Historical _Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the highly competitive UK grocery retail market, which we believe is undergoing a period of significant structural change, characterised by factors such as strong growth and aggressive pricing on the part of discounters (such as Lidl and Aldi) as well as the other traditional grocers, and a shift away from large brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing and convenience retail, all against the backdrop of the general political and economic uncertainty, including high inflation and the ongoing war in Ukraine, and any lingering impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, the latter of which has accelerated many of these trends. In a highly competitive environment during a time of economic uncertainty, there is a risk we are unable to navigate changes in market structure or consumer shopping trends leading to failure to enhance brand value, an inability to execute our strategic plan and we could be exposed to loss of market share. Across all of our market channels, we compete with grocery retailers and other operators for customers, employees, locations, products and other important aspects of our business. Our success depends on our ability to satisfy customer needs more effectively than the competition. In order to do so, we have adopted a strategy to differentiate ourselves from our competitors and compete effectively against them on range, quality, price, convenience of location and the overall shopping experience, among other things. We believe our market proposition is that we offer the greatest value in terms of the price and quality of our products. For example, through our M&S Taste Match campaign, hundreds of our products were voted “as tasty” or “tastier than” their M&S equivalents, while our recent Aldi and Lidl Price Match programme delivers a broad range of popular everyday products at discounter rates. Our market differentiation strategy focuses on optimising our product offerings, monitoring our mix of formats and store concepts, expanding into convenience formats, strengthening our brand identity and seeking out 113 ----- opportunities to increase omni-channel sales. Further, our strategy is based on what we believe to be a well-established own-brand grocery offering, our large and diverse store estate that caters to our customers’ different preferences and our deployment of digital tools and online platforms and innovation and a well-known and successful clothing and general merchandise brand, George. Competition may also affect the prices we charge for our products, which in turn impacts our revenue and margins, although this is usually experienced on a product-specific basis. For example, a competitor may cut its prices to attract footfall to its stores, which in turn may require us to respond with a similar price reduction. In January 2024, we announced a new price matching programme where we have price matched Aldi and Lidl on 287 comparable grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products. This Aldi and Lidl Price Match programme runs alongside our established customer value propositions, including Price Drop and Asda Rewards. We have also implemented various other strategic initiatives and investments in new product development, particularly low cost/high-quality options. For example, in May 2022, we launched a new grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials By Asda. The range replaced the existing budget offering, Asda Smart Price, expanding the range from approximately 160 to 272 products, with items reformulated and refreshed to offer optimum price and quality. Prices for most of our products are set on a national basis and, as a result of significant structural changes to the UK grocery market, there has been substantial pressure on profit and EBITDA margins across the industry, which has led market participants to engage in intense short-term promotional activity, particularly through multibuy offers, member pricing and selective price cuts. At the same time, we have also experienced an overall market trend of food and other input price inflation. For example, increases in the UK National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage, alongside voluntary wage increases to support workers in this high inflationary environment, have led to grocery market wage inflation. Moreover, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine led to significant pressures on the energy market, which further accelerated rising inflation. As a result, we and other grocers experienced input inflationary pressures relating to food prices, energy and fuel. Following the easing of COVID-19 lockdown measures across the United Kingdom in the first half of 2021, the increase in economic activity led to increased pressure across global supply chains, including in relation to labour shortages within the food manufacturing supply chain (including shortages of HGV drivers ), a lack of container capacity within global shipping, increases in wholesale energy prices, shortages of certain raw materials (including CO2); and increases in commodity prices which have resulted in input price inflation within the supply chain, and there is no assurance that such pressures will not further increase in the future. Sourcing and supply chain challenges could also be exacerbated through climate change and adverse weather conditions. We manage this input cost inflation in several ways, such as by using our bargaining power with suppliers, increasing or decreasing the prices of certain products to offset each other, through product re-engineering, for example by maintaining the same price point and altering the weight or recipe, but without compromising on quality and, in certain circumstances, passing through cost increases to consumers. In addition, we have also worked with suppliers to help alleviate the challenges arising from recent supply chain pressures. This has included using our own logistics network to support suppliers in the transportation of products from their manufacturing sites to our distribution centres, and amending ordering profiles to enable suppliers to better manage the efficiency of their production lines. These changes, however, have put pressure on our profit and EBITDA margins during the periods under review. Whilst the level input inflation as of the date of this Offering Memorandum has been reduced compared to 2022 and 2023, we expect input cost inflation to continue during the remainder of 2024. We also operate in the highly competitive UK clothing and footwear retail market through the George Clothing brand, which offers a wide variety of low cost, high-quality clothing and apparel for babies, children, men and women, including jewellery, footwear and hosiery selections. The George Clothing brand was the number three clothing, footwear and accessories retailer by volume of units sold in the United Kingdom for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel, with strong margins as compared to food categories and strong online growth in the past three years. However, we face competitive challenges in the clothing and footwear retail market, including from competitors that continue to invest in their online and in-store presence. Such competitors target some of George Clothing’s key customer categories. We will continue to face steep competition on the basis of, among other things, the location of our stores; our website and mobile applications, and their respective design; the breadth, quality, style, price and availability of our merchandise; and the level of customer service offered. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations— _Competitive pressures in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high.” For a further discussion of_ 114 ----- our competitive landscape, market share and consumer trends in the UK grocery retail business, see “Industry—UK _Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: General Economic Conditions in Our Geographic Markets
Subsubsection Text: Our core grocery retail business generated 84.2% of our total sales (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023. The grocery retail business is generally relatively insulated from swings in demand related to general economic conditions because consumer purchases of grocery and non-grocery staples tend to be less discretionary than purchases in other retail categories. Certain of our other non-grocery offerings, on the other hand, are more correlated to discretionary spending, and therefore, are more susceptible to changes in general economic conditions. Such offerings, including George Clothing and general merchandise, generated 15.8% of our total sales (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023. Notwithstanding the overall resilient nature of our core grocery retail business, consumer tastes and shopping practices are affected by specific economic conditions in the local markets in which we operate, as well as, to a lesser extent, global economic conditions. Such conditions include employment levels, inflation, GDP growth, average and minimum wage levels, real disposable income, currency exchange rates, consumer confidence and consumer willingness to spend. In addition, the outbreak and spread of COVID-19 resulted in national and local authorities mandating or recommending various restrictions and other measures throughout most of 2020 and the first half of 2021, including mandatory business restrictions and closures and social distancing, quarantine and lockdown measures. However, our grocery operations were classified as an essential business in all locations in which we operate and remained open to serve the needs of our customers. As a result, with many other stores closed and consumers often preferring to do as much shopping as they could in one place to minimise potential exposure to the virus, we experienced exceptionally strong sales during this time. These results were partially offset by other challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic, such as increased cleaning costs, supply chain delays, increased freight costs and wholesale energy prices and shortages of certain raw materials. While our operations have largely recovered from the impacts of COVID-19 and the worst of the outbreak is largely considered to be in the past, there could be additional outbreaks and there is a risk of continued disruption as a result of such outbreaks at locations within our supply chain, or other related disruption at suppliers. As the COVID-19 pandemic waned and related governmental measures were eased, the economy reopened and our results in 2022 and 2023 decreased from the highs experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, as the world emerged from the global pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sparked an energy crisis which further accelerated growing inflation and cost-of-living pressures have continued to create uncertainty for customers and businesses alike. When consumers are confident about current and future economic conditions, we believe our premium grocery offerings, some of which carry higher margins than core products, are more likely to attract shoppers and that customers with rising disposable incomes are more likely to make impulse purchases, which can be margin accretive and lift average basket sizes. Conversely, during an economic downturn, basket sizes may tend to decrease while frequency of trips increases as customers disposable income reduces and they carefully manage their spend within a more constrained household budget. Consumers may increasingly opt for cheaper alternatives, such as “discount” retailers, and we may record more purchases of our affordably-priced and attractive mid-tier and opening price point own-brand products relative to local and international third party branded goods. The high inflationary environment, however, can also drive revenue as a result of the price inflation of products, rather than solely relying on an increase in the volume of products sold. During times of economic stress, however, we believe our value proposition is also particularly appealing to customers and can further drive sales and volumes. As the current high inflationary environment persists, we are focused on initiatives to support our customers in the cost-of-living crisis and protect market share by investing in price and quality. For example, in April 2022, we launched our Dropped and Locked price campaign, which locked in the prices of a variety of products. As a result, prices on these products dropped by an average of 12% and locked until the end of 2022 to give customers certainty around their shopping in light of these cost-of-living pressures. While we expect the UK grocery market to remain resilient into 2024, we also expect customers to continue feeling the impact of cost pressures on their household budgets as they face a real wage decline, making it more important than ever that we continue to focus on providing our strong value offering in food and non-food to enable us to serve customers on any type of budget. Additionally, our expansion into the convenience market provides further opportunity as customers increasingly desire convenience and accessibility and represents progress towards our strategic objective to be accessible to customers. 115 ----- For a further discussion of the macroeconomic conditions in the UK grocery retail market and the trends affecting its growth, see “Industry.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition have had a key role in shaping our commercial strategy, and the implementation of these strategies and integration of these businesses will have an impact on our results of operations. We now have an active strategy to penetrate the convenience market, which will accelerate following the acquisition of 356 PFSs and 124 standalone foodservice sites through the EG UK Acquisition and 116 convenience sites as part of the Arthur Acquisition. Following the trial of Asda On the Move, where we offered Asda-branded products at sites owned by EG Group, we recently launched the Asda Express brand for our standalone Asda owned and operated convenience sites. These Asda Express convenience stores stock up to 3,000 branded and own-label products to suit a broad range of customer needs. In December 2022, we opened our first two organic Asda Express stores. We also have further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in 2023 (including five opened in the fourth quarter of 2023) and a strong pipeline of approximately 40 sites that have been identified for potential opening in 2024. The sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition have all been converted to the Asda Express branding. We believe that these store concepts will allow us to access the convenience market and are responsive to changes in our customers’ lifestyles. However, there can be no assurance that this venture into the convenience sector will be successful or profitable. The development of this convenience proposition will also require additional capital expenditures and may have a significant impact on our results of operations. We also anticipate £86 million of synergies stemming from incremental uplift to Asda’s margin from the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition. We expect to achieve these synergies from price investment in the fuel and grocery offering, which we believe will lead to in an increase in volumes and will in turn enable buying benefits across the Asda product portfolio. In addition, we expect synergies to arise from range optimisation, monetisation of customer data, our increased scale, in-store marketing income, improvement in fuel card terms and operational efficiencies. However, we cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully realise the expected synergies and benefits from the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition, or that the costs to realise these synergies and benefits will not be higher than anticipated. The integration of the EG UK Business and Arthur Business into the Group could also result in various challenges, including related to the integration of certain operating and IT systems, including point of sale systems and inventory processing systems, the loss of customers or key employees, diversion of management’s attention, the disruption of our respective ongoing businesses or possible inconsistencies in standards, procedures and policies. Furthermore, certain contracts may have terms and conditions that are weaker than our standard contracts, and we may not be able to integrate or update them as quickly as we would like or without incurring significant fees. In order to fully integrate the financial accounting systems of our acquired businesses, we will have to complete the implementation of our own standalone IT system. Prior to the completion of Project Future, the business acquired from the Arthur Acquisition is being migrated onto the IT systems of EG Group. Both the Arthur Business and the EG UK Business will remain on the IT systems of EG Group for a transitional period, after which, they will have to be transitioned onto our new system. If the TSA expires before we complete the implementation of Project Future or we are not able to successfully transfer onto our new IT platform, this could result in increased costs or a material disruption to the business. Project Future and the integration of the Arthur Business and EG UK Business have required, and will continue to require, additional capital investments by us, and may require incremental resources and system configurations that could increase our operating costs in future periods, as we continue in our ongoing efforts to maintain our control environment to the standards of a business of our size and scale.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Excluding purchases of goods sold, we have a largely fixed cost base in the short- to medium-term, which does not fluctuate with sales volumes. Instead, our costs generally increase from period to period based on the sensitivity of certain costs to inflation. We are able to control some costs to a certain degree, such as those related to marketing and labour (via short-term contracts as well as adjustments to the number of hours our colleagues work), but must maintain sufficient sales levels to absorb the increase in our expenses in order to maintain or improve our retail margins. We have also been able to reduce overall costs by leveraging our vertically integrated procurement 116 ----- arm, IPL, which is a wholly-owned supplier that serves us exclusively and provides us with a cost price advantage by eliminating the “middle man” in our supply chain and sources goods such as fresh fruit and vegetables, flowers, cooked meats and wines. However, even after taking such actions, certain expenses such as rent, the price of food ingredients, energy costs, energy taxes and other direct and indirect taxation are outside of our control. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We are vulnerable to cost inflation and fluctuations in the availability and price of food ingredients and products, commodities and packing material, as well as to fluctuations in the price of electricity and fuel and labour, transportation and manufacturing costs.”_ Labour costs represent a significant part of our cost structure. Whilst we can adjust the size of our workforce, where we have proposals to reduce our headcount, we have legal obligations to consult with colleague representatives (including trade unions) and engage other labour force actors before proposals can be implemented. The obligation to consult with colleague representatives may result in amendments to proposed reductions in headcount and therefore take time before we can implement such changes should they proceed. Additionally, we are subject to laws setting minimum wages. During the periods presented, the UK government increased the National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage and we agreed to further wage increases to support our colleagues and ease inflationary pressures, which had an impact on our cost structure and generally increased our costs, although this has been in part offset by cost saving and efficiency initiatives. For example, in April 2023, we voluntarily increased our rate for hourly paid store colleagues to £11.00 an hour and further increased this in July 2023 to £11.11 an hour. For stores inside the M25 and around Greater London, our rate for hourly paid store colleagues increased to £12.28 an hour. The national minimum wage is due to increase to £11.44 an hour in April 2024, and we plan to give our colleagues an interim increase, with those inside the M25 and around Greater London receiving £12.61 an hour. In July 2024, we are proposing a further increase in pay to 120,000 of our colleagues which will increase the basic pay for retail workers to £12.04 an hour, with those at stores inside the M25 and around Greater London receiving £13.21 an hour. Overall, this is an 8.4% increase in pay from £11.11 in July 2023 to the proposed £12.04 in July, 2024. Any further increase in wages, energy, maintenance or any other input in our cost structure which is not mitigated, can also affect our results of operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General _Operations—Our failure to attract and retain qualified colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other changes to wage regulations could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Investment in New Store Concepts and Channel and Product Innovation
Subsubsection Text: One of the drivers of our results of operations is our ability to maintain our traditional customer base and attract new customers through our ongoing investments in fulfilment capacity and development of our operations, including the evolution of our network of brick-and-mortar retail stores. Our retail store network is largely mature; however, we regularly evaluate the performance of our stores and have repositioned and remodelled stores under new store concepts to improve our customers’ experience and respond to their changing preferences. For example, we have refocused capital expenditure on remodelling our existing stores, in particular to realign store space and offerings to enhance our customer proposition and better respond to customers’ shopping behaviour. In October 2020, we opened our first “sustainability store” at our Middleton superstore location, which is a concept designed to encourage customers to reuse and refill their products, allowing customers to bring and fill their own containers with products such as coffee, rice, pasta and other goods, as well as offering second-hand clothing and increased recycling options. We have since opened three further refill sections in our stores in Toryglen, York and Milton Keynes. We are also further responding to shifting customer preferences, who increasingly desire fast and accessible products, through our roll-out of our Asda Express convenience stores. See “—Convenience and Integration Strategies.” In addition to new, standalone store concepts, we have also invested in new “shop within a shop” concepts with our Big Asda Toyshop, which has its own merchandising and look and feel. We first trialled this concept in eight stores in 2022 and following strong sales, we are aiming to roll it out in an additional 121 stores over the next year. We generally incur initial and ongoing capital expenditure and pre-opening costs with each new grocery retail store and store concept. We have also dedicated significant investment into the expansion of our online grocery channel, Asda Groceries, our Click & Collect and ‘toyou’ parcel collection and return services, and rapid delivery services through Uber Eats, Deliveroo and Just Eat to access new and existing customers who are increasingly shopping online, a trend that accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic. We intend to continue to target operating model improvements to our online channel supported by developments in our IT infrastructure and use data to help us better understand our 117 ----- customers. In August 2022, we rolled out our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards nationwide, following trials in a number of stores earlier in the year. Asda Rewards provides customers with Asda pounds instead of points for their loyalty through an app-based scheme. Customers earn cash back on their shopping, with regularly updated missions and star products enabling extra savings. Asda Rewards grew to almost five million active users by the end of 2023 (over the prior 30-day period) and continues to deliver strong incremental sales for the Group, while also providing valuable insight into the shopping patterns of our customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: The Online Grocery Market in the United Kingdom
Subsubsection Text: The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one of the highest rates of the population using the internet. We believe it will continue to grow in the mid-term, fuelled by consumers shifting to online channels and at-home consumption, which accelerated following the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe our growth has been, and we expect our growth to continue to be in the medium term. According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended January 21, 2024. The UK online grocery market is intensely competitive. We compete with traditional grocery retailers that are active in the online grocery retail market, including Tesco.com, Sainsburys.co.uk, Waitrose.com and Morrisons.com, as well as with new competitors in the online grocery market, including broad-reaching e-commerce companies such as Amazon, as well as pure online players like Ocado. In order to retain our competitiveness in the evolving UK online grocery market, we continue to develop innovative customer solutions, such as our Express Collection service which enables customers to place an order for collection within four hours while other grocers also explore rapid delivery offerings (e.g., Ocado Zoom, Sainsbury’s Chop Chop). Furthermore, we continue to invest in strategic partnerships that lead to innovation and that we believe will drive further increases in our market share, such as our partnerships with Uber Eats, Just Eat and Deliveroo which provide express and last-mile delivery options for convenience groceries. See “Business—Our Online Platform” and “Business—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners” for further detail. We believe these broad-ranging online options, and in particular our in-store picking model, has bolstered, and will continue to bolster, the performance of our online channel and our ability to adapt to shifting consumer demands.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Monetisation and Accounting Treatment of Real Estate Asset Portfolio
Subsubsection Text: We are supported by a significant freehold real estate backing from properties across the United Kingdom in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. As part of the financing for the EG UK Acquisition, we utilised a portion of our real estate portfolio and entered into the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. In the future, we may continue to selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities on attractive terms. Such transaction would have the effect of raising our interest expenses, which would depress net income. In accordance with IAS 16 (Property, Plant and Equipment), land and buildings are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Property, Plant and Equipment was recognised at fair value on February 16, 2021 at the time of the original LBO Acquisition in accordance with the requirements of IFRS 3 (Business Combinations) which for the purposes of IAS 16 represents cost. These assets have subsequently been stated at deemed cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Items under construction are valued at cost and not depreciated. Depreciation is charged from the date that the assets are available for use on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of each part of an item of property, plant and equipment. Land is not depreciated. When an item is disposed of or when no future economic benefits are expected to arise from its continued use, any gain or loss arising on the derecognition of the asset is included in the income statement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Expanding Partnerships and Taking Advantage of New Opportunities
Subsubsection Text: Creating a platform of partnerships has been key to reaching new customers and consistently delivering innovative customer propositions that draw shoppers to our stores, driving increased sales in our core grocery retail business. We have commercialised our capabilities and years of learning derived from our retail experience to partner with various service providers who can deliver access to, among other services, new convenience and delivery channels, where we believe there are significant opportunities to serve our customers in new and appealing ways. For example, in 2023, we launched our first Deliveroo HOP site at the new ‘Asda Express’ convenience store in Tottenham 118 ----- Hale. Deliveroo HOP is the delivery service’s newest innovation that gives customers a speedier service and better product availability with a model of ‘HOP’ whereby partners own and manage sites while integrating Deliveroo’s Hop technology and leveraging Deliveroo’s logistics network. Certain partnerships have also allowed us to focus on our omni-channel proposition or expand our non-core grocery offerings. For example, in August 2023, we announced an exclusive collaboration with TV presenter Stacey Solomon for a homeware range, exclusively at George Home, that expands our reach to customers in the homeware channel across bath, bed, dining, living and accessories. In April 2022, we also launched a ‘pet zone’ in selected stores to help consumers pick up everything from pet insurance to accessories. In November 2021, we partnered with baby brands such as Mamas & Papas, Graco and Ickle Bubba in selected stores to expand our baby product and accessory offerings. Additionally, we have developed partnerships with general merchandise retailers, that leverage their authority in certain categories and will attract customers to our stores. For example, we recently expanded our partnership with jewellery and accessories retailer, Claire’s Holdings LLC which will bring its hair, cosmetics, and fashion accessories. We also use partnerships to elevate our brand. For example, in December 2023, we launched a Christmas advertisement featuring guest Chief Quality Officer Michael Bublé, who is strongly associated with Christmas and cheer. The advertisement had very positive reception, and we believe this marketing campaign is an example of how we can drive customers to reappraise us on quality, whilst reassuring them on price, and modernising our brand. Partnerships across our various channels will continue to be an important focus for us as we continue looking for new ways to reach existing and new customers and to capitalise on our customers’ growing desire for convenient lifestyles, whereby individuals seek to accomplish multiple missions at once. See “Business—Our Tenants _and Strategic Partners” for further detail._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The comparability of the Group’s historical financial information is impacted by a number of factors. This section discusses key factors that the Group believes have had a material effect on the comparability of its results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on its results of operations and financial condition in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Seasonality of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our sales and cash flows are affected to a relatively limited extent by seasonal variations due to consumers’ shopping habits and, to a lesser extent, weather conditions. Family groups represent a significant proportion of our customer base. As a result, our revenue has historically been comparatively higher during the Christmas and Easter periods. In general, revenue shifts due to weather tend to be relatively short-term, with impacts occurring within a given month, rather than across a quarter or a longer period. From time to time, we may also experience reduced sales revenue if inclement or severe weather reduces in-store footfall and impulse purchases, without concomitant offset by online sales. At the same time, adverse weather conditions, such as snow or flooding, can increase customer demand for our online offerings, although they can also adversely affect our ability to deliver products to customers. In this case, however, increased demand for online offerings would not likely offset reduced sales revenue in stores resulting from inclement weather. In general, our fixed costs, including labour expenses (other than related to seasonal workers), real estate leases and SG&A expenses, are more evenly distributed over the year. Additionally, our procurement and sourcing activities are also generally more evenly spread throughout the year, except for a build-up in preparation for the Christmas season and to a lesser extent a build-up in preparation for Easter in April. While our financial calendar generally aligns with our operational profile, we experience calendar effects when, for example, the number of trading days or payroll periods in a given period varies from period to period or year to year or certain holidays fall in different periods from year to year. As a result of the foregoing, comparisons of consecutive interim periods may not be a good indication of our performance, and the calendar effects we experience may have an impact on year-on-year comparisons of interim periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: During the year ended December 31, 2019, the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme entered into an agreement for a bulk annuity insurance buy-in of the Asda Group Pension Scheme with Rothesay Life. The agreement was entered into with Rothesay Life, and insures the long-term benefits of approximately 12,300 members of the Asda Group Pension Scheme. The buy-in transaction, which was enabled by a one-off final contribution by Asda of £0.7 billion and a loan facility made available by the Asda Group Pension Scheme’s sponsor, Asda Stores Limited (see 119 ----- below), has taken place ahead of a full scheme-buy-out that was completed in July 2021. The transaction removed future Asda Group Pension Scheme liabilities from the Asda balance sheet, simplifying the business. The buy-out means Asda Group Pension Scheme members have received an individual annuity policy, issued by Rothesay Life, which will pay members’ pension benefits in full. At the time of the buy-in, it was agreed that certain of the assets of the Asda Group Pension Scheme did not meet the criteria for transfer to Rothesay Life pursuant to the buy-in transaction and were retained by the Asda Group Pension Scheme (the “Illiquid Assets”). The sponsor of the scheme, Asda Stores Limited, agreed to make a loan facility available to the trustees in an aggregate principal amount of £467.0 million in 2019 with the principal purpose of providing liquidity to the Asda Group Pension Scheme to allow the trustees to pay the premium in full under the buy-in policy with Rothesay Life, and also to provide prudent reserves that are available to fund the operation of the Asda Group Pension Scheme up to completion of the buy-out and eventual winding-up (the “Pension Scheme

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by a combination of factors. This section discusses key factors that we believe have had a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition in the future. While we believe that our results of operations and financial condition, and particularly the results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, have been primarily affected by the following key factors, these factors are not exhaustive, and the entirety of this Offering Memorandum should be reviewed, particularly the “Risk Factors” section. Additionally, although we believe that the underlying operating trends that have benefitted our business in recent years, as described further below, are relatively stable and will generally continue to drive relatively steady patterns of revenue and EBITDA metrics, it is difficult to predict future performance with any degree of certainty.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Expenses”). The loan facility was set up on arm’s-length terms, including in relation to interest. Since completion of
Subsubsection Text: We consolidate the results of operations of any acquired business in our financial statements from the acquisition date. The acquisition date is the date when the Group obtains control of the acquired business as defined by IFRS 10 Consolidated Financial Statements. Therefore, our historical financial periods are not directly comparable to one another. For example, following the closing date of the EG UK Acquisition on October 31, 2023, the results of EG UK were consolidated into our results. Following the closing of the Arthur Acquisition in October 2022, the CMA implemented an IEO and consequently, management concluded that the restrictions imposed by the IEO meant that the Group did not obtain control of the Arthur Business at the closing date. On May 30, 2023, after accepting our proposed remedies of disposing of 13 of the acquired sites, the CMA lifted the IEO and the results of the Arthur Business were consolidated into our results from that date. Our results in 2023 have been impacted by the revenues and expenses of the acquired business starting from the relevant date when we started consolidated the results of the applicable acquired business, whereas prior comparative periods do not include the results of the acquired business. 120 ----- Moreover, if we incur additional debt or enter into new financing arrangements in connection with any acquisition, our financial condition and results of operations will be impacted such instruments and may differ from the historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion. For example, on October 31, 2023, we completed the EG UK Acquisition, which was also funded, among others, with the proceeds of external indebtedness, including the Private Placement Facility and the America Bridge Loan, the latter of which was subsequently refinanced with the proceeds from the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. Accordingly, our financial condition and results of operations following the EG UK Acquisition were, and will be, impacted by debt interest costs and rental expenses and may differ from the historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion. In addition, all historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the Senior Notes Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries. However, the financial results of the Senior Notes Issuer do not include a full year of trading in the year ended December 31, 2021, as it acquired the trading group Asda Group Limited part way through the year on February 16, 2021. As a result, results for the year ended December 31, 2021 for the Senior Notes Issuer consolidated group do not constitute a full comparative period. In certain instances, to provide a more meaningful comparison, the results for the year ended December 31, 2021 down to the level of operating profit are presented on an annualised basis as if Asda Group Limited had been acquired by the Senior Notes Issuer on January 1, 2021. Such annualised results are derived from the financial statements of Bellis Finco plc for the period ended December 31, 2021 and the actual results of Asda Group Limited from January 1, 2021 to the date of acquisition of Asda Group by Bellis Finco plc on February, 14 2021. The table below provides a reconciliation from the audited Asda Group Limited Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2021 to annualised results for the Senior Notes Issuer.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Expenses”). The loan facility was set up on arm’s-length terms, including in relation to interest. Since completion of
Subsubsection Text: the buy-in transaction any proceeds realised in respect of the Illiquid Assets have been required to be applied by the trustees to fund interest and principal payments under the loan facility, to the extent such proceeds are not required to be retained to maintain prudent reserves with respect to the Pension Scheme Expenses. Pursuant to arrangements agreed in connection with the LBO Acquisition Agreement, payments received by Asda Stores Limited under the loan facility that are attributable to the Illiquid Assets are required to be paid to Walmart. Accordingly, the risk and reward of the performance of the Illiquid Assets was effectively transferred to Walmart. To the extent that realisations from the Illiquid Assets are insufficient to cover interest and principal payments owing to Asda Stores Limited under the loan facility, Asda Stores Limited is obliged under a separate agreement to provide sufficient funding to the Asda Group Pension Scheme to enable the trustees to fund such shortfall. As the amount of such funding provided by Asda Stores Limited to the Asda Group Pension Scheme would be applied to repay the loan facility owing to Asda Stores Limited, the combined effect of such transactions would have no net impact on Asda Stores Limited. Asda Stores Limited reached an agreement with the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme to make a cash contribution of £214.6 million to the Asda Group Pension Scheme on December 30, 2020. Such amount was applied to repay amounts due to Asda Stores Limited under the loan facility on the same day. On July 9, 2021, the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme completed the full buy-out of the Asda Group Pension Scheme with Rothesay Life. Following this transaction, from the date of the buy-out, Rothesay Life has become directly responsible for the Asda Group Pension Scheme liabilities and as such, the Asda Group Pension Scheme assets and Scheme liabilities (except for a pension liability of £0.5 million, which has continued to be accounted for as pension liabilities in line with the requirements of IAS 19 (Employee Benefits)) were derecognised in the Group balance sheet from July 9, 2021. From the date of the buy-out, the outstanding balance on the buy-in loan referred to above has been accounted for as a financial asset in line with the requirements of IFRS 9 (Financial _Instruments). Any differences between the fair value of the buy-in loan and the pension asset at the date of the buy-in_ has been accounted for as a loss or gain within the other comprehensive income statement or the income statement depending on their nature. We do not anticipate material amounts to be recognised in respect of these differences individually or in aggregate. The remaining liabilities with respect to the Asda Group Pension Scheme were settled in the year to December 31, 2023. The carrying value of liabilities associated the Asda Group Pension Scheme at December 31, 2023 is £nil, compared to £0.5 million in at December 31, 2022.

Subsubsection Text: Operating costs include costs, other than finance costs and tax. The largest components of operating costs are cost of goods sold (net of supplier rebates), employment costs, depreciation and amortisation, property costs including business rates, utilities, marketing costs, distribution costs, maintenance expenses, consumables, store suppliers, interchange fees and IT costs (including the costs of Project Future and charges under the TSA payable to Walmart). For the year ended December 31, 2021, operating costs also included income (of which the most significant is income from recycling of certain categories of waste) other than revenue, other income and finance income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Finance income consists of bank interest receivable and interest receivable on amounts owed from fellow subsidiary undertakings of the ultimate parent of the Group. Finance costs consist of external interest payable, interest on lease liabilities, interest payable on amounts owed to fellow subsidiary undertakings of the ultimate parent of the Group, asset retirement obligations discount unwind and net interest cost on the Asda Group’s defined benefit pension schemes. External interest payable includes interest on external debt issued by the Group during the current year and prior period, amortisation of fees incurred in relation to external debt and commitment fees and interest relating to the Original Revolving Facility.

Subsubsection Text: (1) Relates to third-party advisory fees incurred during the year in respect of the EG UK Acquisition. (2) Since the LBO Acquisition, the Group has embarked on a programme, Project Future, to separate its IT systems from its previous owner Walmart. The separation programme will transition the Group to a standalone, leading edge IT infrastructure which will enable it to improve operating efficiencies, make better use of data, improve its experience for customers and colleagues, and enable the business to be more agile in responding to customers’ needs. Amounts classified as non-underlying during the current year and prior year relate to costs incurred outside the normal course of business in respect of research spend, design and build costs relating to IT infrastructure and SAAS solutions which cannot be capitalised, consultancy costs incurred in relation to the management of the programme, run costs relating to standalone systems where equivalent legacy Walmart systems are still in use by the business, and costs of interim software solutions which do not meet the criteria of the Group’s policy to capitalise. Where legacy Walmart systems are still in use, the costs of these are included in charges relating to the TSA. The total IT spend included in underlying operating costs reflects management’s expectation of the level of annual spend required to operate the business on standalone IT systems in the normal course of business, which includes the charges incurred under the TSA and a proportion of Project Future costs.
