Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Revenue (including fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £25,616.9 million, an increase of £1,139.1 million, or 4.7%, compared to £24,477.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was due to growth in non-fuel sales, partly offset by an overall decline in fuel sales revenue, a result of the comparatively lower average selling price in 2023 compared to high and volatile prices in 2022. Revenue (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £21,898.4 million, an increase of £1,446.1 million, or 7.1%, compared to £20,452.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily a result of growing revenue across both food and non-food in the existing Asda business, whilst also reflecting the additional sales from the Arthur Business and the EG UK Business. The Group recorded particularly strong year on year growth in the first half of 2023, by comparison to the first half of 2022, as a result of the impact of weaker performance in the first half of 2022, following emergence from COVID-19 lockdowns and supply chain challenges. Sales in the second half of 2023 showed more modest growth, partly due to unseasonable weather in the summer and autumn, which impacted customer behaviour and created unpredictability, particularly in seasonal categories, which was partially offset by positive impacts following the launch of Asda Rewards in August 2022. Further commentary below provides detail on the performance of our key categories. _Food_ Food sales increased in the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to year ended December 31, 2022, including impact of sales from the acquired businesses. The Group has continued to invest in its food proposition in 2023, building on the success of the launch of the Just Essentials opening price point range in 2022. Value remains a key priority, including the aim to pass along the benefits of commodity price deflation where it has occurred and reflecting significant investment in our key supplier relationships. Nevertheless, sales performance in 2023 continues to reflect the pass through of the significant commodity price inflation which has occurred over the past two years. The Group has continued to invest in driving quality improvement across our own-brand mid-tier offering. Following refreshes to the Group’s produce, meat fish and poultry, and bakery in 2021 and 2022, the Group has overhauled its core chilled, meal solutions, and cooking ingredients ranges in 2023. These categories are key signifiers of quality and are central to the Group’s strategic priority to make desirable products affordable, giving customers a reason to reappraise Asda’s offering. The Group has also launched a selection of premium sub-brands, including two vegan-friendly ranges, Plant Based, a healthy, balanced selection of meat-free lines, and OMV!, an indulgent vegan range, as well as ranges to rival takeaway offerings and key competitor prepared food ranges. These include, our popular Bistro, Take Out and House of Yum ranges. The Group also launched some ambitious quality and taste match campaigns during the year, including an M&S quality match across a range of popular items. 127 ----- _Non-food_ Non-food sales grew slightly in the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to year ended December 31, 2022 on a like-for-like basis and were particularly strong in the first half of 2023, in both clothing and general merchandise. Across both clothing and general merchandise, the third quarter was particularly impacted by the unseasonal weather, but rebounded to like for like growth in the fourth quarter of 2023. _Online_ Online sales comprise Asda.com grocery sales and non-food sales through George.com. Online grocery is a key strength of the Group, where it held the number two grocery market share position throughout 2023, and online is a key element of Asda’s omnichannel retail offering, fostering strong customer loyalty and typically larger spend per basket. The proportion of sales made through online delivery and click and collect was slightly higher in 2023. _Fuel_ Fuel sales were £3,719 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, a decrease of 7.6% as compared to £4,026 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. A decrease in the Asda legacy business’ fuel sales was predominantly due to the lower average selling price of fuel in 2023 compared to 2022, which saw record and volatile commodity prices following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. This was partly offset by the additional fuel sales from the acquired businesses. _Foodservice_ The Group acquired 419 food service outlets in the EG UK Business, comprising franchises of brands including Greggs, Subway and Burger King, as well as one proprietary brand Leon. Food service sales of £40 million were recorded in 2023 following the completion of the EG UK Acquisition. We believe that the addition of foodservice to Asda’s portfolio is a strong strategic fit and complements our omni-channel retail offering, with further opportunity for growth and synergies within the store estate. _Other income_ Other income for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £70.9 million, an increase of £1.1 million, or 1.6%, compared to £69.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily a result of slightly increased rental income for the year ended December 31, 2022. _Operating costs_ Operating costs post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2023 were £25,119.2 million, an increase of £430.9 million, or 1.7%, compared to £24,688.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily a result of increases in the cost of goods sold as a result of higher sales, year-on-year increases in inventory losses, investments in colleague pay and a year-on-year increase in Project Future costs, as well as additional transaction costs relating to the EG UK Acquisition in the year ended December 31, 2023. _Finance income_ Finance income post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £52.5 million, a decrease of £2.9 million, or 5.2%, compared to £55.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to a £23.0 million decrease in interest receivable from a fellow subsidiary of the ultimate parent, after an exercise to settle intercompany loan receivables and payables was carried out in September 2022. This decrease was partially offset by a £20.6 million increase in bank interest receivable, driven by an increase in interest rates on short-term deposits, and higher average cash balances. This included the impact of £646 million of net proceeds in respect of the Sale and Leaseback Transaction, the majority of which was received approximately 11 weeks in advance of the completion of the EG UK Acquisition. 128 ----- _Finance costs_ Finance costs post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2023 were £440.8 million, an increase of £45.3 million, or 11.5%, compared to £395.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to higher costs on external borrowings, including 10 months’ worth of interest charged on the £200 million facility used in connection with the Arthur Acquisition at a rate of SONIA + 7.75bps, which was repaid in October 2023, compared to two months’ charged in the 2022; two months’ worth of interest on the Private Placement Facility at a rate of SONIA + 6.75bps entered into to fund the EG UK Acquisition; and two months’ worth of interest on the America Bridge Loan at a rate of SONIA + 7.00bps entered into to fund the EG UK Acquisition. The America Bridge Loan was repaid in December 2023 upon completion of the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. Interest on lease liabilities also increased to £177 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to £146 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to the interest on leases which were entered into as a result of the Sale and Leaseback Transaction. These increases were partly offset by a reduction in intercompany interest payable to a fellow subsidiary of the ultimate parent following the intercompany loan settlement exercise in September 2022 referred to under finance income above. _Reimbursement income_ Reimbursement income for the year ended December 31, 2023 was nil, compared to £49.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to a reimbursed settlement relating to historical tax reliefs in the year ended December 31, 2022. _Income tax credit/(expense)_ Income tax credit post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £14.2 million, a decrease of £63.4 million, or 81.7%, compared to a tax credit of £77.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This was due to increased amounts of deferred taxation in the year ended December 31, 2022. _Cash flow forward contracts reclassification during the period to income statement_ Cash flow forward contracts reclassification during the period to income statement for the year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to a gain reclassified to the income statement of £15.3 million, a change of £38.7 million compared to a loss reclassified to the income statement of £23.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This change was due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars and the settling of those forward contracts that occurred in the relevant period. The gain reclassified to the income statement in the year ended December 31, 2023 is a result of the GBP weakening versus the USD over the average forward contract life, whereas the loss reclassified to the income statement in the year ended December 31, 2022 is a result of the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the average forward contract life. _Cash flow forward contracts net gain/(loss) during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts_ Cash flow forward contracts net loss during the period of the not-yet-matured contracts for the year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to £36.3. million, a change of £50.7 million compared to a net gain of £14.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This change was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars in each financial year and the value of those contracts not settled at the end of the year based on the exchange rate at the end of the year. _Tax on cash flow forward contracts recognised directly in other comprehensive income_ Tax on cash flow forward contracts recognised directly in other comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2023 was a credit of £5.2 million, an increase of £3.7 million compared to a credit of £1.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase in this credit was due to net loss on cash flow forward contracts in 2023 compared to 2022 as described above. _Other comprehensive (expense)/income_ Other comprehensive expense for the year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to an expense of £39.5 million, a change of £50.5 million compared to income £11.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This 129 ----- change was primarily due to an increase in items to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result of cash flow hedges as described above. Results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2021

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Following restatement of certain financial information for the year ended December 31, 2022 in the 2023 Financial Statements, “other income” is presented below “revenue” in the consolidated income statement. For the year ended December 31, 2021, it remains as it was presented in the 2021 Financial Statements, which have not been restated. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Certain Restatements _and Reclassifications.”_ Unless otherwise specified, all results presented below for the year ended December 31, 2021 are on an actual basis, rather than annualized to reflect a full twelve months of trading. See “—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of _Operations—The Acquisition Transactions.” Revenue_ Revenue (including fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £24,477.8 million, an increase of £989 million, or 4.2%, compared to £23,489 million on an annualised basis for the year ended December 31, 2021. Actual revenue (including fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2021 was £20,710.4 million. This increase was primarily due to higher fuel prices in the year driven by inflation in oil prices, and higher fuel volume sales following lockdowns in the year ended December 31, 2021 impacting travel. Revenue (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £20,452 million, an increase of £28 million, or 0.1%, compared to £20,424 million on an annualised basis for the year ended December 31, 2021. Actual revenue (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2021 was £17,900 million. Revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 was broadly in line with the prior year. Performance in the first half of 2022 was challenging. In the context of growing inflation and cost of living pressures and exceptional sales in 2021 during COVID-19 lockdowns, we experienced a decline in like-for-like sales and some loss of market share. Performance recovered in the second half of the year and showed strong growth, driven by new initiatives to drive strategic objectives, including launching Dropped and Locked prices, Just Essentials and Asda Rewards. Market share recovered in the second half of the year and the total number of customer transactions increased. Further commentary below provides detail on the performance of our key categories. _Food_ In the first six months of the year ended December 31, 2022 we experienced like-for-like decline in sales due to the tailwind from COVID-19 related lockdowns in 2021 which led to an increase in at-home grocery consumption. The lockdown was in place for the majority of the first quarter of 2021, with some restrictions continuing into the 130 ----- second quarter of 2021 and beyond. We also experienced loss of market share over the first six months of the year ended December 31, 2022 which further contributed to like-for-like sales declines. From the second quarter of 2022 onwards, we experienced an improvement in sales momentum and recorded positive like-for-like results for the second half of the year. Food sales were boosted following the launch of Asda’s Dropped and Locked price campaign, which locked prices for customers in light of cost-of-living pressures. The campaign saw prices of a wide selection of family favourite products dropped and locked until the end of the year to give customers certainty around their shopping. In May 2022, Asda launched its new opening price point own brand range, Just Essentials by Asda. The range replaced Asda Smart Price, with new branding and products reformulated for taste and quality, doubling the number of items in the range and providing all the products customers need to keep the household running on a budget. Throughout the year ended December 31, 2022, we also continued our investment in mid-tier own-brand ranges. Following on from refreshing the produce range in the year ended December 31, 2021, we overhauled our bakery and meat, fish and poultry categories including expanding the range of products, improving the quality and refreshing the packaging. These categories are key signifiers of quality and are central to our strategic priority to make desirable products affordable, giving customers a reason to reappraise our offering and contributing to strong like-for-like sales growth in food in the last six months of year ended December 31, 2022. In August 2022, we rolled out our new loyalty programme Asda Rewards nationwide, following successful trials in a number of stores since the start of the year. Asda Rewards provides customers with Asda pounds, not points, for their loyalty through an app-based scheme. Customers earn cash back on their shopping, with regularly updated missions and star products enabling extra savings. _Non-food_ In non-food sales, performance in the second quarter of 2022 was similarly lower than the comparative period in 2021 when we benefited from non-essential retail stores being closed during COVID-19 lockdowns. Sales in both clothing and general merchandise were also impacted by supply chain challenges from the fourth quarter of 2021 which led to the wrong stock being in place in the early part of the year. Direction provided by new leadership contributed to significant improvement in sales momentum in the second quarter of 2022, in particular following the Queen Elizabeth’s Jubilee Weekend, when our proposition appealed strongly to customers and we delivered new relevant product. In the third quarter of 2022, clothing grew ahead of the market, with particular strengths in women’s wear and back to school sales, supported by improvements in merchandising and in-store shopping experience following reopening fitting rooms after COVID-19-related closures. In the fourth quarter of 2022, clothing sales were impacted by availability challenges resulting which arose during a major system upgrade. Some issues with the transfer to the new system led to challenges in visibility and allocating stock, preventing product from being distributed around the store network appropriately; however, sales recovered in December 2022 following resolution of these issues and have since continued in positive growth in line with expectations. In General Merchandise, the George Home range delivered strong performance in the second half of the year ended December 31, 2022, offering an affordable and stylish proposition to customers. Highlights included summer outdoor and seasonal ranges, with particular growth in energy-saving and winter products to support customers through the cost of living and energy crisis in the fourth quarter of 2022. _Online_ We have a strong market position in grocery home shopping, with around 16% of our food sales coming through online channels in the year ended December 31, 2022 (including home delivery and click and collect services). Online continues to be a key part of our omni-channel strategy to enable customers to shop wherever and however they choose. Online sales stabilised in the year ended December 31, 2022 following considerable growth in the channel during the COVID-19 pandemic; total online sales for the full year were slightly lower than the prior year and lower as a proportion of total sales, as more customers returned to shopping instore. We continue to invest in ways to optimise the online experience for customers, focusing on availability, range and service. 131 ----- _Other income_ Other income for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £69.8 million, a decrease of £2,863.6 million, compared to £2,933.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to the gain on bargain purchase of the Asda Group Limited by the Senior Notes Issuer of £2,654 million, and the gain on sale and leaseback of the warehouse assets of £279 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, which was not repeated in the year ended December 31, 2022. In the year ended December 31, 2022 other income was primarily related to rental income and concession and commission income. _Operating costs_ Operating costs post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2022 were £24,688.3 million, an increase of £4,425.8 million, or 21.8%, compared to £20,262.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to significant increase in inflation across our cost base, partially offset to a certain extent by cost saving initiatives such as bringing cleaning in-house from a third-party supplier, delivering operating efficiencies in our stores and depots and reduction in COVID-19-related costs. There has been a significant increase in supply side inflation in the year ended December 31, 2022, in particular following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Labour shortages, investment in colleague wages, increases in energy and fuel cost inflation have driven higher cost prices in our supply base and in our own cost base. In our non-food business, margins were also impacted by significant increases in freight, detention and demurrage costs as the global economy emerged from the pandemic, exacerbated by further lockdowns in China, and adverse movements in foreign exchange rates following the UK mini-budget in September 2022. In the selling, general and administrative cost base, we also saw notable cost increases which impacted profitability. These cost increases included energy costs for operating our stores, depots and offices and fuel costs in running our logistics and online operations. We also incurred additional exceptional costs in the year ended December 31, 2022 relating to our investment in Project Future, and transaction costs incurred in connection with the LBO Acquisition. _Finance income_ Finance income for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £55.4 million, an increase of £26.0 million, or 88%, compared to £29.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to approximately ten months’ interest being earned on the intercompany receivable balance which arose out of the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions, compared to approximately six months’ interest in the year ended December 31, 2021. _Finance costs_ Finance costs post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2022 were £395.5 million, an increase of £20.4 million, or 5%, compared to £375.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase of £40 million in interest payable on lease liabilities reflecting a full year of interest being recorded in relation to the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions which was largely completed in June 2021. This increase was partially offset by a reduction of £11 million in external interest payable driven primarily by settlement of the Forecourt Bridge Facility in November 2021 and a reduction of £8 million in intercompany interest payable driven by settlement of an amount owing to our immediate parent company during the year ended December 31, 2022. _Reimbursement income_ Reimbursement income post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £49.3 million compared to nil in the year ended December 31, 2021. In the year ended December 31, 2022 reimbursement income was primarily related to a reimbursed settlement relating to historical tax reliefs. _Income tax credit/(expense)_ Income tax post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2022 was a credit of £77.6 million, from an expense of £245.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This change was primarily due to a prior period deferred tax charge of £281 million arising from an increase in the headline corporation tax rate which was 132 ----- substantively enacted in May 2021. This change was partially offset by a one-off net credit in 2021 of £74 million relating to the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions. _Cash flow forward contracts reclassification during the period to income statement_ Cash flow forward contracts reclassification during the year to income statement for the year ended December 31, 2022 amounted to a loss of £23.4 million, a change of £65.7 million compared to a gain of £42.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This change was due to fluctuations in the USD/GBP exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars and the settling of those forward contracts that occurred in the relevant period: losses were caused by the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the year of forward contracts, resulting in the contracts being “out of the money.” The loss in the year ended December 31, 2022 is a result of the GBP strengthening versus the USD over the average forward contract life, whereas the gain in the year ended December 31, 2021 is a result of the pounds sterling weakening versus the USD over the average forward contract life. _Cash flow forward contracts net (loss)/gain during the year of the not-yet-matured contracts_ Cash flow forward contracts net gain during the year of the not-yet-matured contracts for the year ended December 31, 2022 amounted to £11.6 million, a change of £2.8 million compared to a net gain of £14.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This change was primarily due to fluctuations in the USD/ pounds sterling exchange rate between entering into forward contracts to purchase U.S. dollars in each financial year and the value of those contracts not settled at the end of the year based on the exchange rate at the end of the year. _Tax on cash flow forward contracts recognised directly in other comprehensive income_ Tax on cash flow forward contracts recognised directly in other comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2022 was an expense of £10.2 million, a change of £11.7 million compared to a credit of £1.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This change was primarily due to the reduction of the net gain on cash flow hedges in 2022 compared to 2021 as described above. _Other comprehensive (expense)/income_ Other comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2022 amounted to £11.0 million, a change of £30.1 million compared to an income of £41.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease in items to be reclassified to profit or loss in subsequent periods as a result in cash flow hedges as described above and our forward contracts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows and borrowings under our New Revolving Facility. Our cash-generative business, due to the nature of the grocery industry, together with our relatively low capital expenditure, has driven cash flow generation, including comparatively high unlevered free cash flow. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See “Risk _Factors.” We are a structurally negative working capital business driven by growth in payables, and the beneficial_ payment terms to suppliers versus payments received by consumers instantly on purchase. In 2023, we increased our focus on cash management, particularly related to working capital. We delivered a very strong net working capital performance in 2022 and 2023, with our active working capital management resulting in increased working capital inflows in those two years. These improvements in net working capital were driven partly through key supplier partner negotiations related to the deferral of cash payables. Stock was also more tightly managed and we began to see a more favourable trajectory for fuel price and volume. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings under our New Revolving Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated working capital and general corporate needs for the next 12 months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities 133 ----- or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, or to fund our other liquidity needs. The availability of our New Revolving Facility is dependent upon certain conditions, including compliance with a springing maintenance covenant as described further under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.” _Cash flows_ The table below presents a summary of the Group’s consolidated cash flows for the periods indicated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement shall, with effect on and from the Issue Date, provide for the multi-currency senior secured New Revolving Facility in an aggregate amount at least £747,722,727 (with a possible incremental commitment of £45,000,000 under the New Revolving Facility, which could be made available on or shortly after the Issue Date). The New Revolving Facility may be utilised by any Original Revolving Facility Borrower or Additional Revolving Facility Borrower (subject to certain exceptions) under the Senior Facilities Agreement. Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, a Lender may also provide Letters of Credit, Fronted Ancillary Facilities or Ancillary Facilities (in each case as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) on a bilateral basis in place of all or part of its Revolving Facility Commitment (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement). Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, loans made under the New Revolving Facility may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time. Such loans will be available to be used for, amongst other purposes, general corporate and working capital purposes of the Group (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, to fund certain permitted acquisitions and capital expenditure and to backstop existing ancillary facilities, letters of credit and/or hedging arrangements of the Group. The Group is subject to certain customary affirmative, negative and incurrence covenants under the Senior Facilities Agreement, which impose restrictions on, among other things, incurrence of other debt, making restricted payments, disposal of assets and granting of security, subject to certain agreed exceptions and permissions, qualifications and thresholds. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” The New Revolving Facility is expected to be undrawn at the Issue Date and the Original Revolving Facility has been undrawn since the first quarter of 2022. 135 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group offers suppliers the option to access uncommitted supply chain financing through certain thirdparty providers. These facilities allow suppliers to receive payments earlier than its standard payment terms and for the Group to defer its own payments. The total size of our supply chain financing facilities as of December 31, 2023 was £575.1 million across a number of banks and platforms. The level of utilisation is dependent on the individual supplier requirements and varies significantly over time, dependent on suppliers’ requirements. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Excludes £32 million of cash attributable to the Arthur Business, since its results were not included in the Group’s consolidated financials until the CMA lifted the IEO on May 30, 2023. _Cash flows from/(used in) operating activities_ Cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2023 increased by £69.0 million, to £1,245.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from £1,176.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2023 included a net working capital inflow of £223 million. This inflow was driven principally by an increase in trade and other payables of £281 million due to working capital improvement initiatives and payment timing benefits relating to weekly supplier payments and payroll. The increase was partially offset by an increase in trade and other receivables of £32 million due to an increase in supplier income and in inventory of £13 million driven by investment to improve availability, partially offset by prior year inventory build in non-food which followed a new system implementation in our George brand in 2022. Cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 increased by £254.80 million, to £1,176.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from £922.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase in trade and other payables of £408 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, due to strong like-for-like sales growth in the fourth quarter, improvements in supplier payment terms and favourable timing impacts of supplier payment runs relative to the year-end date. The increase was partly offset by an increase in inventory of £109 million, driven in part by inflationary cost increases, as well as a proactive decision to build the inventory position to protect availability. _Cash flows (used in)/ from in investing activities_ Cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2023 increased by £1,285.1 million, or 163.0%, to £2,073.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from £788.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase included the £2,000 million consideration paid for the EG UK Acquisition in 2023, as well as the purchase of property, plant and equipment and intangibles of £337 million. This increase was partially offset by a proportion of the proceeds from the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transaction of £136 million and cash acquired on consolidation of the EG UK Business and the Arthur Business of £31 million and £36 million, respectively Cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 decreased by £5,513.5 million, or 87.5%, to an outflow of £788.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from an outflow of £6,302.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due the cash consideration paid for the LBO Acquisition in the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to the cash flows used in investing activities in the year ended December 31, 2022, which were comprised primarily of purchase of property, plant and equipment and intangibles of £320 million (see “—Capital Expenditure”) and a cash outflow related to the Arthur Acquisition of £424 million (of which £200 million was funded through debt and the remainder from cash on balance sheet, net of £5 million bank fees). 134 ----- _Cash flows from/(used in) financing activities_ Cash flows from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2023 changed by £1,424.3 million, to an inflow of £1,193.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from an outflow of £231.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The change was primarily due to the proceeds from the draw down of external debt (net of fees) of £1,304 million in 2023, a proportion of the proceeds from the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions of £509 million and an increase in intercompany payables of £401 million, partially offset by the repayment of external debt of £500 million (including the America Bridge Loan), £188 million of interest payments on external debt and capital and interest payments of £324 million in respect of leases. Cash flows used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 decreased by £6,116.80 million from an inflow of £5,885.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to an outflow of £231.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily driven by proceeds from a drawdown of £4,920.6 million of external debt in the year ended December 31, 2021 related to the LBO Acquisition, compared to net cash outflows used in financing activities in the year ended December 31, 2022, which were primarily comprised of £(231) million from the drawdown on a corporate facility of £200 million to finance the Arthur Acquisition (net of £5 million bank fees), £150 million of interest payments on external debt and capital and interest payments of £277 million in respect of leases.

Subsubsection Text: The Group typically has relatively low capital expenditure requirements. Capital expenditure has on average amounted to 1.5% of sales (including fuel) between the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2023. Capital expenditure as disclosed in the consolidated statement of cash flows is the sum of the purchase of property, plant and equipment and purchase of intangible assets. We also use Capital Expenditure KPI as a key performance indicator, which is defined as the total costs of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets of which the Group takes ownership within a financial period (as opposed to the UK IFRS measurement of capital expenditure which is based on cash flows). It excludes capital expenditure on Project Future, our investment to separate from Walmart’s IT systems, since it is one-off and non-recurring in nature. For a reconciliation from Capital Expenditure KPI to capital expenditure as disclosed in the consolidated statement of cash flows see “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial _Information and Other Financial Data–Other Financial Indicators.” See also, “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.”_ We categorise our capital expenditure as essential, which includes capital expenditure for things such as essential asset replacement and maintenance, discretionary, which includes capital expenditure for things such as store upgrades and investment in systems to improve efficiency, or for Project Future. The following table presents a breakdown of our essential, discretionary and Project Future capital expenditures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Available to** **Available to** **Available to Utilised at** **be drawn at** **Utilised at** **be drawn at** **Utilised at** **be drawn at December 31,** **December 31,** **December 31,** **December 31,** **December 31,** **December 31, 2021** **2021** **2022** **2022** **2023** **2023
Subsubsection Text: _Forward currency hedging contracts_ The Group purchases goods and services denominated in currencies other than pounds sterling. Cash flows can be affected by movements in exchange rates, primarily US dollars and euro. Some purchases in US dollars are managed using forward contracts. The Group implements hedge accounting and has forward currency hedging contracts outstanding at December 31, 2023, designated as hedges of expected future purchases from suppliers in US dollars. The forward currency contracts are being used to hedge the foreign currency risk of future purchases. The terms of the forward currency hedging contracts have been negotiated to match the terms of the commitments and none exceed a period of more than 18 months after December 31, 2023. Amounts recognised in other comprehensive income are transferred to the income statement when the hedged transaction affects profit or loss. The cash flow hedges of the expected future purchases were assessed to be highly effective and at December 31, 2023, a net unrealised loss of £12.2 million (as compared to a net unrealised gain of £36.2 million at December 31, 2022 and a net unrealised gain of £43.7 million at December 31, 2021) was included in the hedge reserve in respect of hedging contracts. The net loss recognised in other comprehensive income during the year ended December 31, 2023 in respect of these hedging contracts was £15.8 million (as compared to a net loss of £7.5 million at December 31, 2022 and a net gain of £43.7 million at December 31, 2021) and a gain of £32.6 million was reclassified to retained earnings during the year ended December 31, 2023. This consists of a £36.3 million loss on not-yet-matured contracts during the year (as compared to a gain of £14.4 million at December 31, 2022 and a net gain of £11.6 million at December 31, 2021), £15.3 million of losses reclassified to the income statement during the year (as compared to £23.4 million of gains at December 31, 2022 and £42.3 million of losses at December 31, 2021) and a £5.2 million taxation credit (as compared to a £1.5 million taxation credit as at December 31, 2022 and a £10.2 million charge as at December 31, 2021). Under the Group’s hedging policy, forward currency contracts can be used for both goods for resale and goods not for resale. The only items for which forward currency contracts are in place as at December 31, 2023 are forecast purchases of goods for resale. The Group hedges up to 100% of forecast cash flows. Gains and losses attributable to forward contracts are transferred to cost of inventories recognised as an expense within the income statement at the point of sale. Forward contracts entered into which are not in line with forecast cash flows would be the principal source of hedge ineffectiveness. No instances of this have occurred during the year ended December 31, 2023 (which was also the case during the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022), therefore amounts recognised in the income statement in relation to ineffective forward contract hedges were £nil (which was also the case during the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022). At December 31, 2023, the Group held £1,234.4 million of outstanding forward foreign currency contracts, designated as cash flow hedges (as compared to £749.5 million as at December 31, 2022 and £699.9 million as at December 31, 2021). These forward contracts are largely in relation to purchases of US dollars (notional $1,470.0 million) and euros (notional €71.4 million) with varying maturities up to June 2025. For the above currencies the rates ranged from USD/GBP from 1.210 to 1.302 (as compared to 1.098 to 1.369 in the year ended December 31, 2022 and 1.315 to 1.420 in the year ended December 31, 2021) and euro/GBP 1.142 to 1.164 (as compared to 1.132 to 1.157 in the year ended December 31, 2022 and 1.165 to 1.189 in the year ended December 31, 2021). As the Group manages much of its foreign currency exposure using forward currency contracts, changes in exchange rates are not expected to have a significant impact on short-term profitability or cash flow. It is anticipated that a 5% movement in the US Dollar/pounds sterling exchange rate, which represents management’s assessment of a reasonably possible change, would give rise to a movement in the cash flow hedge reserve of £47.2 million at December 31, 2023 (as compared to a movement of £34.6 million in December 31, 2022 and a movement of £33.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2021). 140 ----- See note 21 (“Financial Instruments”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on foreign currency risk. _Cross-currency swap_ The Group has entered into Facility B (EUR) which is a floating rate euro denominated term loan facility. The non-pounds sterling interest and principal repayment cash flows from the euro debt agreement expose the Group to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates that impact the consolidated basis. Under the Group’s hedging policy, the Group hedges both the foreign exchange and interest rate risk associated with a portion of the Group’s existing euro foreign-currency denominated debt using EUR-GBP cross currency interest rate swap contracts to effectively eliminate variability in the Group’s functional currency equivalent cash flows due to variability in the EUR-GBP exchange rate and the variable interest rate. The hedge ratio is 100% on a current notional basis. The Group has excluded from the cross-currency interest rate swap both the time value and currency basis elements of the cross-currency interest rate swap. Ineffectiveness could arise from movements in counterparty credit spread, the non-zero fair value at the hedge designation date due to market changes that have occurred since the instrument’s inception and changes to critical terms (such as reset dates, index mismatches or payment dates). To test the hedge effectiveness, the Group uses the hypothetical derivative method and compares the changes in the fair value of the hedging instruments against the change in fair value of the hedged items attributable to the hedged risks. The amounts recognised in the income statement for the year ended December 31, 2023 relating to ineffectiveness and excluded items was less than £0.3 million (as compared to less than £0.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022). At December 31, 2023, the Group holds cross-currency interest rate swaps (“CCIRS”) with a total nominal value of €844.5 million, designated as cash flow hedges. These swaps result in a fixed pounds sterling interest rate ranging from 3.70% to 3.76% and EUR/GBP rate of 1.1412. On February 16, 2024, following the expiration of the CCIRSs in place as at December 31, 2023, the Group entered into new CCIRSs with an expiration date of February 16, 2025 with the same counterparty banks. This eliminates variability in the Group’s functional currency equivalent cash flows in relation to Original Facility B (EUR) for the Group for the 12-month period to February 16, 2025 and fixes the interest rate on Original Facility B (EUR) at fixed GBP interest rates of between 8.03% and 8.06%. The Group is also currently contemplating additional cross-currency swaps as well as interest rate swaps in respect of the unhedged portion of its ongoing EUR exposure and floating rate exposure respectively under the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes—Currency exchange rates _may have an impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.”_ The CCIRSs were assessed to be highly effective and as at December 31, 2023, a net unrealised gain of £3.1 million (as compared to £21.2 million at December 31, 2022 and £6.6 million at December 31, 2021) was included in the hedge reserve in respect of these swaps. The net loss recognised in the cash flow hedge reserve during 2023 in respect of these swaps was £18.1 million (as compared to a gain £14.5 million at December 31, 2022 and a gain of £7.3 million at December 31, 2021). This consists of a £2.5 million gain reclassified to the income statement during 2023 (as compared to £35.5 million gain at December 31, 2022 and £34.6 million loss at December 31, 2021), by a £21.8 million loss (as compared to a £54.9 million gain at December 31, 2022 and £25.5 million loss at December 31, 2021) on the fair value of the swaps at period end and a taxation credit of £6.3 million (as compared to £4.8 million at December 31, 2022 and £2.4 million at December 31, 2021). The value of the CCIRSs is sensitive to movements in EURIBOR and EUR/GBP exchange rates. A 0.5% change in EURIBOR would result in a £2.8 million change in value of the CCIRSs (as compared to £2.9 million at December 31, 2022 and £6.5 million at December 31, 2021) and a 5% change in the EUR/GBP exchange rates would result in a £47.2 million change in the value of the CCIRSs (as compared to £38.9 million at December 31, 2022 and £38.1 million at December 31, 2021). The amounts charged to the income statement are not sensitive to a change in interest rates but a 5% increase in the FX rate would increase the amount of ineffectiveness by £nil (as compared to £nil at December 31, 2022 and £0.4 million at December 31, 2021). Following the Transactions, we plan to re-evaluate the implementation of foreign exchange and interest rate hedging contracts in line with our historical approach. 141 -----

Subsubsection Text: The Group is subject to the risk that its capital structure may not be sufficient to support the growth of its business and maintain its existing credit rating. The capital structure of the Group consists of debt obligations (including the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Senior Notes) and equity (issued share capital, share premium and reserves). Part of the Group’s capital risk management strategy is to monitor a broad range of financial metrics and manage compliance with financial covenants relating to the Group’s debt obligations. As at December 31, 2023, there have been no breaches of financial covenants. See note 21 (“Financial Instruments”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on capital risk.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (A) Capital expenditure (excluding timing differences) does not include timing differences of £(17) million, £6 million and £(0.3) million for the years ended December 2021, 2022 and 2023. There are timing differences resulting from internal capital expenditure being presented on an accruals basis. During the year ended December 31, 2023 Capital Expenditure KPI was £302 million and capital expenditure was £337 million. The underlying spend was £320 million, consistent with the year ended December 31, 2022, with £16 million attributed to investment in the EG UK Business and Arthur Business, primarily on store conversions to the Asda Express brand. Approximately 51% of the Group’s investment in the year ended December 31, 2023 was on essential asset replacement and maintenance, including replacement of store refrigeration units and property maintenance costs, and 38% was focused on discretionary spend to drive growth, including upgrades to store environment and investment in systems to improve efficiency of operations. The remaining 11% was invested in 136 ----- Project Future, comprising investment in the detailed design, build and implementation of Asda’s standalone IT environment as we separate from previous owner Walmart’s IT systems. During the year ended December 31, 2022 Capital Expenditure KPI was £277 million. Approximately 53% of the Group’s investment in the year ended December 31, 2022 was on essential asset replacement and maintenance, including replacement of store refrigeration units and property maintenance costs, and 32% was focused on discretionary spend to drive growth, including upgrades to store environment and investment in systems to improve efficiency of operations. The remaining 15%, or £49 million, was invested in Project Future, comprising investment in the detailed design and initial build phase of the Group’s standalone IT environment as we separate from previous owner Walmart’s IT systems. During the year ended December 31, 2021, capital expenditure focused principally on replacing essential assets and refreshing our store estate, as well as investments in self-checkouts and our online proposition. Our capital expenditure requirements vary from year to year based on, among other factors, specific reinvestment requirements in relation to our sites and specific initiatives to develop our technologies, and as such, we cannot assure you that our level of capital expenditure will not increase significantly in the future. For the year ended December 31, 2024 we expect our capital expenditure to amount to between £450 million and £470 million, including Project Future. We expect total cumulative Project Future costs to be approximately £800 million, including approximately £300 million in 2024. Although we will continue deploying capital expenditures on Project Future throughout 2024, after the implementation of our new information technology systems, we expect to be able to reduce these levels of capital expenditures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, the Group had no material off balance sheet arrangements or funding arrangements that would be classified as a contingent liability under UK IFRS, except with respect to the ongoing Equal Value Claims. With respect to the Equal Value claims, the Group has not recognised a provision on the basis that any loss 137 ----- or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings cannot be reasonably estimated and any potential liability is only a possible obligation, as it has yet to be confirmed whether the entity has a present obligation that could lead to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits. As a result of the change of ownership on February 16, 2021, the Group has entered into an indemnification agreement which is guaranteed by the former ultimate parent of Asda Stores Limited, Walmart with respect to these claims. Walmart has indemnified the Group for these claims up to a contractually agreed amount. See note 29 (“Contingent liabilities”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on contingent liabilities. See “Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation” and “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of the Group’s business, it is exposed to a variety of market risks arising in relation to its financial assets and liabilities, including credit risk, interest rate risk, liquidity risk, foreign currency risk and capital risk. The Group has a risk management programme in place through which it seeks to mitigate the adverse effects of these market risks. In addition, the Group hedges interest and exchange rate exposure on foreign currency debt obligations. We do not enter into financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview
Subsubsection Text: We believe there is no significant credit risk within the Group. The maximum credit risk exposure relating to financial assets is included in their carrying value as at the balance sheet date. See note 18 (“Trade, other receivables _and derivative assets”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on trade receivables, intercompany_ receivables and details of recoverability. The Group has established procedures to minimise the risk of default in relation to trade receivables including detailed credit checks undertaken before a customer is accepted. Surplus cash is placed in both short-term deposits and money market funds with various global financial institutions. This is managed by the Group’s treasury function which actively monitors the market in order to identify the best terms of deposit in keeping with internal objectives. This includes monitoring the credit rating of counterparties and investing in accordance with our internal policy. Counterparty credit limits are reviewed on a monthly basis, and may be updated throughout the financial year. The limits are set to minimise the concentration of risk and are set taking into account the type of financial asset and the credit rating of the financial institution. Intercompany receivables have been considered in relation to the expected credit losses model under IFRS 9 and the impact is not material. As such, the provision for expected credit losses is less than £0.1 million (as compared to less than £0.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview
Subsubsection Text: The Group is exposed to interest rate risk on its floating rate liabilities (based on SONIA and EURIBOR) primarily composed of the Senior Facilities. During 2023, the Group was exposed to interest rate risk on a bridge facility entered into to partially fund the Arthur Acquisition (the “Arthur Additional Bridge Facility”), this was settled in full on October 23, 2023. The EURIBOR interest rate risk on Original Facility B is hedged through entering into cross-currency interest rate swaps to fix the interest payments in pound sterling at rates between 3.70% and 3.76% which expired on February 16, 2024. The SONIA interest rate risk on the Private Placement Facility entered into during 2023 is hedged through entering into interest rate swaps to fix a proportion of the interest payments at a fixed interest rate between 4.75% and 4.78% which expires on November 16, 2025. Interest on the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Unsecured Notes is charged at fixed rates between 3.25% and 4.50%. The Existing Senior Secured Notes are set at fixed rates of 3.25% and 4.50%. The Existing Senior Notes are set at a fixed rate of 4.00%. The Senior Secured Notes will also be a fixed rate instrument. 138 ----- The Group, after the impact of hedge accounting, is exposed to possible changes in SONIA on its outstanding floating rate loans. In the year ended December 31, 2023, it is anticipated that a 0.5% increase in the SONIA rate would give rise to a decrease in profit before tax of £1.8 million (as compared to £1.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 and £0.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021). The Group’s Original Facility A, and Original Revolving Facility have been impacted by the interest rate benchmark reform in 2022. The Group transitioned these agreements to the new UK risk-free rate benchmark, SONIA, which was applied to the Group’s interest period starting April 1, 2022 and which will also apply to New Facility A and the New Revolving Facility. See note 21 (“Financial Instruments”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on interest rate risk. _Interest rate swaps_ The Group has entered into the Private Placement Facility with interest rates calculated based on SONIA. The variable interest rate exposes the Group to interest rate fluctuations that impact the profit or loss on a consolidated basis. At December 31, 2023, the Group holds interest rate swaps (“IRS”) with a total nominal value of £540.0 million, designated as cash flow hedges. The hedge ratio is on a 79% current notional basis. These IRS result in a fixed GBP interest rate ranging from 11.50% to 11.53%. The IRS were assessed to be highly effective and as at December 31, 2023, a net unrealised loss of £4.8 million was included in the hedge reserve in respect of these swaps. The net loss recognised in other comprehensive income during the year in respect of these swaps was £4.8 million. This consists of a £0.4 million gain reclassified to the income statement during the year and a £6.0 million loss on the fair value of the swaps at year end and a taxation credit of £1.6 million. The value of the IRS is sensitive to movements in SONIA. A 0.5% change in SONIA results in a £10.9 million change in value of the IRS. Following the Transactions, we plan to re-evaluate the implementation of foreign exchange and interest rate hedging contracts in line with our historical approach.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Subsubsection Text: The Group’s treasury function ensures that the Group continues to have sufficient funding by monitoring rolling forecasts of the Group’s cash flows. The Group’s objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of funding and flexibility using operating cash flows and intercompany balances. At December 31, 2023, the Group held cash of £1,027.7 million (as compared to £662.5 million at December 31, 2022 and £505.5 million at December 31, 2021) to secure short-term flexibility. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the Group’s results of operations and financial condition as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, as derived from the Financial Statements. All references in this Offering Memorandum to the financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 shall be deemed to be to the financial information for the relevant period prepared in accordance with UK IFRS. This section includes forward-looking statements, including those concerning future sales, costs, capital expenditures and financial condition. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. Results of operations for prior years are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for the year ended December 31, 2024 or any future period. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.” The discussion and analysis below provides information that we believe is relevant to an assessment and understanding of our historical financial position and results of operations of the Group. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the Financial Statements and in the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial Data” and “Selected Consolidated Financial Information.” The following discussion of our results of operations also makes reference to Non-IFRS Measures. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The retail sector in the United Kingdom, across all sales channels, was estimated by Euromonitor in the Retail 2024 edition to have had sales of approximately £460.4 billion in 2023, compared to £439.3 billion in 2022 (based on a retail value retail sales price basis excluding sales tax (“Retail Value **RSP”) in current value terms), and to have grown at a CAGR of 3.0% between 2009 and 2023. According to Euromonitor, grocery retail – referring to the sum of hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, warehouse clubs, small local grocers and food/drink/tobacco specialists – is the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom. It represented £200.6 billion of Retail Value RSP (comprising approximately 44% of total retail sales) in 2023, compared to £190.7 billion of Retail Value RSP (comprising approximately 43% of total retail sales) in 2022. In the past fourteen years, grocery retail in the United Kingdom only experienced negative year-on-year growth in 2015 (negative 0.2%) and 2016 (negative 4.6%), in spite of macroeconomic, uncertainties and periods of food deflation measured by the consumer price index (“CPI”), according to the OECD. We operate in the retail market, offering a wide range of both food and non-food products and services from our supercentres, superstores, supermarkets, convenience and Asda Living stores, as well as through various online platforms. The origins of our business are in the UK grocery retail market and, while our business has grown and diversified into other markets including clothing retail and general merchandise retail, we remain focused on offering high-quality, value-based grocery retail options to our customers. Within the UK grocery retail market, we are the third-largest player in the UK grocery retail market (with a 13.7% market share) on the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. 143 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: The following chart illustrates the UK grocery market breakdown by channel on a Retail Value RSP basis and its development between 2009 and 2023, as well as the CAGRs between the years 2009 and 2016, 2016 and 2023, and 2009 and 2023. _(Source: Euromonitor: Retail 2024 Edition; Retail Value RSP excl. Sales Tax, GBP, Current terms. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels, including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, warehouse clubs, small local grocers as well as food/drink/tobacco specialists.)_ Grocery retail sales in the United Kingdom are made via multiple channels, including hypermarkets, supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retailers and online. We currently operate in the hypermarket, supermarket, convenience, forecourt and online channels. Hypermarkets are larger-format retail stores, frequently located on out-of-town sites or as anchor stores in a shopping centre, with a primary focus on selling food, beverages, tobacco and other groceries while offering a wide variety of non-grocery products, such as general merchandise and clothing. Supermarkets are smaller-scale retail stores that offer a wide variety of food, beverages and household products. Hypermarket formats are offered by the traditional grocers, while supermarket stores are offered by stores such as the Co-op, Waitrose and M&S, in addition to the traditional grocers. Based on Euromonitor data, the sum of hypermarket and supermarket channels constitute the largest share by Retail Value RSP of the UK grocery retail market, representing 54.1% of grocery Retail Value RSP in 2023. However, in the last five calendar years, growth for the sum of these two channels has slowed, with a combined CAGR of 2.3% between 2018 and 2023, according to Euromonitor. In contrast, over the past 15 years convenience stores such as Tesco Express, Sainsbury’s Local, Co-op On the Go, Little Waitrose and M&S Simply Food, have gained popularity. In 2023, they represented 19.0% of Retail Value RSP and are the second-largest channel in the grocery retail market, according to Euromonitor. The forecourt channel represented 3.0% of the total grocery retail market on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2023 and grew at a CAGR of 2.3% between 2016 and 2023, according to Euromonitor. This was driven by recent initiatives from forecourt operators to improve the food product quality and the foodservice offering. Forecourts also usually have longer opening hours compared to hypermarkets and supermarkets and are often in close proximity to end consumers. Based on Euromonitor, convenience retailers grew at a CAGR of 3.4% between 2015 and 2023. Excluding convenience retailers, the UK grocery retail market grew at a 2.5% CAGR between 2015 and 2023. The 2007-2009 global financial crisis and the resulting weakened customer sentiment thereafter helped discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) to gain a strong foothold in the UK grocery retail market. Between 147 ----- 2007 and 2015, discounters gained considerable scale and market share due to new store openings and increased footfall resulting primarily from product offerings targeted at increasingly price-conscious customers. According to Euromonitor, the discounters channel represented 14.0% of the total grocery retail market on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2023. For more information, see “—UK Grocery Retail _Key Trends.” Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK grocery retail market has seen an increasing shift away from physical stores to online purchasing, with online grocery sales having grown significantly faster than those of physical stores in recent years. According to Euromonitor, in 2023, the online channel (food & drink e-commerce) comprised 13.8% of the UK grocery retail market. The online channel, which has also reported strong Retail Value RSP growth historically, with a CAGR of 20.3% between 2018 and 2023, is driven by shoppers’ growing appetite for convenience and digital connectivity, as well as by service enhancements in online operations. Following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, this growth has been bolstered as customers increasingly turn to online groceries in order to maintain social distance, a trend which may result in a sustained change in preferences going forward. On the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, we are the third-largest player in the UK grocery retail market (with a 13.7% market share), according to Kantar Worldpanel. Other key players are Tesco (with a 27.3% market share), Sainsbury’s (with a 15.1% market share) and Aldi (with a 9.8% market share), in each case on the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. Together, the traditional grocers of Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury’s and Morrisons comprise 64.9% of the total market on the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. Other grocery retailers include Aldi, Co-op, Lidl and Waitrose. Waitrose operates at the premium end of the market and commands a lower share of the market at 4.5%, while the discounters Aldi and Lidl hold market shares of 9.8% and 7.6%, respectively, in each case according to Kantar Worldpanel and on the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024. The following chart sets forth the UK grocery market share of the main UK grocery retailers based on Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. _(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Till Roll.)_ 148 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The following chart sets forth the UK online grocery market share of the top six UK grocery retailers on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, compared to the 52-week periods ended December for the years 2017 to 2022, the 52-week period ended January 22, 2023 and the 52-week period ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. _(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, Online, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024. Note: “other” includes Amazon and other grocery retailers.)_ The largest players in the UK online grocery retail market are Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury’s, Ocado (which operates a 50/50 joint venture between Ocado Group and M&S) and Morrisons. According to Kantar Worldpanel, we had a 19.3% market share in the UK online grocery market measured on the basis of Total Grocery Absolute Sales for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, while Tesco, Sainsbury’s, Ocado and Morrisons had a market share of 36.4%, 17.8%, 14.4% and 6.1%, respectively.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The UK grocery retail market experienced industry-wide price deflation from 2014 to 2016, with deflation at negative 0.2% in 2014, negative 2.6% in 2015 and negative 2.4% in 2016, respectively, according to the OECD (measured by the CPI). Low or no inflation or deflation, along with weakening customer demand and lower real wage growth, contributed to discounters gaining a stronger foothold in the UK grocery retail market as they competed 149 ----- through low prices and store openings to attract more price-conscious customers. These combined factors resulted in downward pressure on our like-for-like sales growth from 2014 to 2016, as set forth in the following chart. _(Source: Company information with respect to Asda, OECD 2024 Inflation (CPI) indicator.)_ However, as food inflation in the United Kingdom has increased in more recent years, our LFL performance has improved.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The following chart sets forth the growth of the UK grocery retail market size on a Retail Value RSP basis in each calendar year from 2009 to 2023 according to Euromonitor. _(Source: Euromonitor: Retail 2024 Edition; Retail Value RSP excl. Sales Tax, GBP, Current terms. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels, including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, warehouse clubs, small local grocers as well as food/drink/tobacco specialists.)_ In 2023, grocery retail was the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom and was valued at £200.5 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis, according to Euromonitor. Between 2009 and 2016, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 2.2%. Between 2016 and 2023, the market grew at a CAGR of 3.1%. During the COVID-19 pandemic between 2019 and 2020, it grew at a CAGR of 4.6%. Generally, we believe that sales in the UK grocery retail market have demonstrated resilience and stability through economic cycles. According to the ONS, inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, rose by 4.2% in the United Kingdom in the twelve months ended January 2024 (down from 8.8% in the twelve months ended January 2023), driven by, among others, higher food costs and freight costs. Additionally, the reduction in lower-paid jobs compared to prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, led to a rise in average pay growth rates, which we believe will benefit the UK grocery retail market environment, as higher wage rates can be supportive of spending trends, some of which may trickle into grocery retail. According to the ONS, the United Kingdom’s real gross domestic product (“GDP”) amounted to £2.0 trillion in 2023. The following chart sets forth the historical and projected year-on-year real GDP growth in the United Kingdom for the period from 2007 to 2023. According to Fitch Solutions, although the United Kingdom’s GDP declined by 10.4% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP has rebounded in 2021 and returned to pre-COVID-19 levels in 2022, with an average expected real GDP growth CAGR of approximately 0.4% from 2023 to 2025. _(Sources: Fitch Solutions.)_ 144 ----- According to the ONS, as set forth in the following chart, the United Kingdom’s population reached 67.0 million in 2021 and is expected to grow at an approximate CAGR of 0.7% between 2021 and 2031. _(Source: ONS.)_ In 2022, UK households spent, on average, £62.20 per week on food and non-alcoholic drinks, comprising 11.8% of average weekly household expenditure according to the ONS. Between 2007 and 2022, the percentage of average household expenditure spent on food and non-alcoholic drinks ranged from 10.5% to 14.4%, as shown in the following chart. _(Source: ONS.)_ Furthermore, the split between at-home and out-of-home (“OOH”) food and drink consumption in the United Kingdom has remained relatively stable in recent years, with the exception of 2020 – 2021 given the COVID-19 pandemic. This change has yet to be reversed, with OOH consumption remaining around 1,000 basis points lower than pre-COVID-19 levels. _(Sources: ONS.)_ 145 ----- Moreover, as shown in the following chart, the UK grocery retail market has shown positive year-on-year market growth for 12 out of the past 14 years. This growth is reflective of the relatively essential nature of grocery purchases, which represent a necessary and regular household expenditure as compared to more discretionary spending categories, such as clothing, footwear and electronics. According to Euromonitor, the UK grocery retail market experienced solid growth of 5.2% between 2022 and 2023. _(Source: Euromonitor: Retail 2024 Edition; Retail Value RSP excl. Sales Tax, GBP, Current terms. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to the sum of channels, including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, warehouse clubs, small local grocers as well as food/drink/tobacco specialists.)_ While the overall UK grocery retail market has in recent years remained stable in many respects, market channels and customer habits have been changing. Customer preference has shifted away from larger, out-of-town formats towards smaller, proximity formats, with customers prioritising convenience and shopping habits shifting towards smaller basket sizes coupled with increased frequency of purchases. The industry has also seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) that compete through differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand products. According to Kantar Worldpanel, COVID-19 has accelerated the shifts towards online purchasing since lockdown measures were first introduced in the United Kingdom in March 2020, however, online channel growth started to slow down significantly and is now normalised since the reopening post COVID-19 period. For more information, see “—UK Grocery Retail Key Trends.” 146 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: UK Clothing and Footwear Retail Market
Subsubsection Text: The following chart below sets forth the development of the UK clothing and footwear retail market from 2009 to 2023 on a Retail Value RSP basis, including the breakdown between in-store and online sales, according to Euromonitor. _(Source: Euromonitor: Retail 2024 Edition; Retail Value RSP excl. Sales Tax, GBP, Current terms. Note: The UK Clothing and Footwear Retail Market is referring to the sum of Apparel and Footwear Specialist Retailers and Apparel and Footwear E-Commerce.)_ In addition to the grocery retail market, we operate in the UK clothing and footwear retail market, which includes the sale of a wide variety of clothing, footwear and accessories, through the George Clothing brand. According to Euromonitor, the UK clothing and footwear retail market was valued at £45.9 billion on a Retail Value RSP basis in 2023. During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, the UK clothing and footwear retail market declined as a result of rising unemployment, pressure on discretionary spending and weakened customer confidence. Furthermore, the market experienced a period of price inflation between 2010 and 2012. Between 2014 and 2019, the UK clothing and footwear retail market grew at a CAGR of 2.7%, with much of the growth driven by online channels, which had a CAGR of 11.3% between 2014 and 2019 in comparison to a CAGR of only 0.1% for in-store channels, 150 ----- each on a Retail Value RSP basis, as stated by Euromonitor. These results reflect an overall trend toward increased access to, and usage of, the internet coupled with a greater propensity to buy online and growing usage of social media to influence and facilitate clothing and footwear retail sales. The UK clothing and footwear retail market experienced a significant downturn in 2020 due to COVID-19 related lockdowns and reduced consumer demand for non-essential purchases which included clothing and footwear with the overall market down -20.0% in 2020, according to Euromonitor. During the first of such lockdowns which lasted from March 23, 2020 to July 4, 2020, all non-essential retail stores including all clothing and footwear stores were ordered to close by the UK government. Subsequently, the value of retail sales of clothing and footwear at current prices (seasonally adjusted) decreased by 12.0% in the first quarter of 2020 and 53.9% in the second quarter of 2020 respectively as compared to the same period a year earlier, according to ONS.
