Our current store design had not been updated for many years, so our near-term strategy includes modernising our stores to facilitate a better customer journey. In order to ensure our colleagues are equipped to offer a best-in-class customer experience, we are also investing in colleague hours in-store via a combination of additional temporary colleagues in stores and opportunities for existing colleagues to work over-time if they wish to. Increasing the numbers of hours being worked in store means that more colleagues are on hand to serve customers across the busy and peak periods (such as Christmas). Alongside value and choice, we believe that service is a key quality signifier for customers and impacts where they choose to shop. To help further this strategy, we also hired David Hills as our new Chief Customer Officer in September 2023, who brings a wealth of retail and grocery-sector experience to our business and will play a pivotal role in providing our shoppers a hassle-free and pleasurable experience when shopping at Asda.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Commitment to ESG targets and building a sustainable business for the long term
Subsubsection Text: Part of our strategy is to ensure our Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) commitments are fully integrated into our wider business transformation plans. We believe the sales opportunity driven by eco-active shoppers, or shoppers who are highly concerned about the environment and are actively taking actions to reduce their waste, is expected to reach approximately £2 billion across the market by the year 2027. We believe ESG is a key 172 ----- decision enabler for customers in deciding where to shop and that setting the right ESG plan is beneficial for our customers, colleagues and investors. Our ESG strategy is focused on four pillars: healthy and sustainable choices (providing our customers with a product mix that is healthier and with a lower environmental impact), energy and climate change mitigation (reducing our greenhouse gas emissions), nature positive (sourcing and farming which respects and restores) and waste (reducing food, product and packaging waste). In August 2023, we published our third ESG report (based on 2022 data), which provided an annual update on the progress we had made towards supporting these pillars and meeting our environmental targets and in October 2023, we received our first external assessment of our ESG strategy, with an entity score of 54 points and an overall rating of 3 (on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the strongest) by the financial services ratings’ agency Sustainable Fitch. Sustainable Fitch positively assessed our human and labour rights policies, gender balanced workforce and well-defined management systems, as well as our actions to increase the share of non-high fat, salt and sugar own-brand products and improve food nutrition labelling. Obtaining this rating is part of our ongoing commitment to transparently reporting on our efforts to achieve our ESG targets. For example, we have continued to reduce our operational carbon footprint, with emissions down 8% from 2021 to 2022 and 40% from 2015 to 2022, and we believe we are well on the way to achieving our commitment to reduce emissions 50% by 2025 and reaching net zero emissions by 2040. We have committed to setting a near-term science-based carbon reduction target, including a specific Forests, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) target. These targets have been submitted to the Science-Based Targets Initiative (“SBTi”) for validation. The proposed targets were submitted before the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition so reflect our footprint prior to these acquisitions. In terms of waste reduction, over 90% of our own brand packaging was recyclable in 2022, and we donated over 2,000 tonnes of surplus food through our charity partnerships, both reducing waste and supporting those in need during challenging times. We increased the proportion of our own-label packaging that can be recycled at the kerbside to 88% (with a further 4.7% recyclable in store) and introduced the Refill Price Guarantee on our in-store refill zones, guaranteeing that unpackaged products are cheaper than their packaged equivalents. We reused or repurposed 86% of our operational waste and sent zero operational waste to landfill in 2022. We believe we have made significant progress towards our ESG goals but that there is still much to do, and we will continue working to build a sustainable business for the long term.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our primary strategy is designed to provide great value for money and to bring brighter living within everyone’s reach. Our strategy is centred around four primary pillars which guide our business priorities and planning: proposition, product, location and experience. These pillars are underpinned by our commitment to running an efficient operating model, driving the business through improved data and systems and an ESG programme that builds a sustainable business for the long term. Through our strategy, we seek to maintain and extend our advantage in offering value for money by ensuring that our prices are competitive and reassuring shoppers on quality. We aim to provide a consistent, trusted experience, incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere through the creation of attractive store propositions and partnerships that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while increasing the number of self-serve opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth where customers care, expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience. We believe that our strategy provides a clear path to achieve our ambition of becoming the second-largest grocer in the United Kingdom by market share.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our retail business comprises a food segment, which consists of our grocery and foodservice business, and a non-food segment, which includes our well-known George Clothing and George Home brands, as well as a general merchandise and health and wellness offer. We operate our retail business through both brick-and-mortar retail sites and through online sales made, primarily, via groceries.asda.com and George.com. Our physical retail business operates under five distinct formats: supercentres and superstores, supermarkets, Asda Living, convenience sites and stand-alone foodservice sites. For more information on our store formats, see “— _Our Store Formats.”_ We aim to develop Asda as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of relevant branded products and services while also building on our existing capabilities such as logistics and the customer-facing ‘toyou’ proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of attractive store destinations, in which more customer missions can be accomplished under one roof. See “—Business Strategy.” 173 ----- _Food_ In 2023, our food segment accounted for 86.2% (£18.4 billion) of our total sales of £21.4 billion (excluding fuel). Within our food segment, in 2023, ambient food items and non-edible items accounted for 53.3% (£9.8 billion), and fresh/produce accounted for 46.7% (£8.6 billion), of our food sales. _Ambient_ Our ambient product category includes core grocery items (such as rice, pasta, baking supplies, canned goods, condiments and cereals), impulse grocery items (such as snacks, confectionary treats, biscuits and soft drinks), beer, wine, spirits, baby and toiletry items, non-edible grocery items (such as paper products, pet care supplies, cleaning supplies and laundry-related items), newspapers, magazines and other kiosk items, pharmacy (including health products and ambient medicines) and optical products. We believe that certain of our own-brand ambient products, such as our Little Angels nappies and our Shades toilet rolls, are among the most popular products of their kind on the market. We continue to expand the range of our plant-based and vegan food products within our overall ambient food selection. New items offered included vegan and plant-based proteins, cooking sauces, condiments, snacks and sweets marketed under our Plant Based by Asda and Asda OMV! offers that we released at the beginning of 2023. _Fresh_ Our fresh product category includes core chilled products (such as cheese, cooked meats, pies, salads and dips, eggs and dairy products), fresh proteins (such as fresh beef, fresh pork, fresh poultry, bacon, sausage and pre-packed fish), bakery (such as cakes, breads and morning goods bought and produced in store), in-store café (such as beverages, main meals, snacks and drinks), foodservice (such as sandwiches, snacks, confectionary treats, salads and drinks), serve-over and self-serve counters (such as rotisserie, pizza, Panku, Sushi Daily, Kulaba Kitchen, Asda takeaway and various local partners), frozen (such as frozen meat, chips, vegetables, desserts, ice cream and frozen meal solutions) fresh ready meals, soups and pizzas. _Foodservice_ Following the EG UK Acquisition, we expanded our foodservice offerings. Our foodservice partners include Greggs, Subway, Burger King and Sbarro, as well as our own proprietary brand, Leon. In addition to these Group-operated branded offerings, the sites acquired from the EG UK Acquisition will also continue to benefit from additional KFC and Starbucks branded offerings operated by third parties. Outside of our convenience and foodservice sites, we also work with a number of strategic partners that operate retail locations within our grocery stores, such as McDonalds and Sushi Daily. See “—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners.” 174 ----- We have 509 branded foodservice outlets across our foodservice and convenience sites. Certain of our sites have multiple brand offerings at an individual location. The following table shows the number of outlets by brand across our sites:

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Split by Store Format_** **_Split by Owner

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are an omni-channel retailer centred around a brick-and-mortar store network, which is geographically diversified across the United Kingdom, and our websites (primarily through groceries.asda.com and George.com). Our retail business comprises a food offer (which in turn comprises produce, ambient products and fresh food products (including our foodservice offerings)), a non-food offer (which in turn comprises clothing, homeware and general merchandise offers) and fuel. We also offer our customers other services, including, among other things, a mobile phone service, various financial products, parcel drop and collection and in-store pharmacies and opticians.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: (1) Operated by third parties on sites acquired from the EG UK Acquisition. (2) Includes one additional Leon site, located at our headquarters. _Produce_ Our produce product category includes fruit, vegetables, salads, nuts, plants and flowers. _Non-Food_ In 2023, our non-food segment accounted for 13.8% (£3.0 billion) of our total sales of £21.4 billion (excluding fuel), with clothing and general merchandise accounting for approximately 6.8% and 7.0% of our total sales (excluding fuel and other revenue from Asda Mobile sales, financial services sales and, until the EG UK Acquisition, Asda On The Move), respectively. _Clothing_ Our clothing product category includes the George Clothing line which offers a wide variety of clothing and apparel, including for baby, children, men, women, jewellery, footwear, socks and hosiery. _General merchandise_ Our general merchandise product category includes George Home (kitchenwares, housewares, electrical appliances, furniture, lighting, bath, kids items and furnishings and bedding), seasonal and occasions products and toys (cards, celebration products, stationary, toys, hobby items and festive and Halloween products), outdoor and essential items (sporting goods, automotive, hardware, paint, access products and home and garden products) and entertainment (electronics, books and telecoms products). _Fuel_ Our fuel category includes the fuel sold at our PFS locations. We have a total of 794 PFS locations (of which two have been closed) across our portfolio, 490 of which are attached to our convenience sites and 304 of which are attached to Asda grocery stores. We offer our fuel products and services to our customers pursuant to agreements with a number of partners, including prominent fuel brands such as Esso at 224 PFS sites, Shell at 87 PFS sites, Texaco at 37 PFS sites and BP at 29 PFS sites. 175 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: _Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians_ We operate complementary pharmacy and optical businesses that offer enhanced customer experiences and diversify our cash flows. As of December 31, 2023, we have 247 Asda Pharmacies offering NHS, locally commissioned and private services to our patients. These services include dispensing NHS and private prescriptions, electronic prescriptions and collection services as well as our Asda Pharmacy flu vaccine service for NHS and private patients. Examples of NHS services we offer include our New Medicine Service in England, Pharmacy First in Scotland and our Common Ailment scheme in Wales, each of which are commissioned by the home nations. Asda Opticians offers our customers access to optical services and products in 157 stores and has a dedicated online site selling contact lenses. In our stores, we complete eye examinations, contact lens examinations, provide additional NHS services and dispense optical appliances (spectacles and contact lenses). Our in-store spectacle pricing model does not charge extra to patients for prescription needs, including varifocals. We offer a wide contact lens portfolio of various brands, designs and modalities. We also offer safety spectacles, sunglasses, eye care products, accessories and contact lens solutions. _Asda Money_ We offer certain financial and insurance products on a commission-only basis. All products are provided through third-party partnerships. The products we offer include home insurance, car insurance, travel insurance, pet insurance, money transfer, breakdown cover, third-party gift cards, personal loans, credit cards and travel money. See also “Regulation—Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers.” _Asda Gift Cards_ We offer Asda branded gift cards for sale in our stores and on our dedicated websites, which can be used to buy goods in-store, on George.com or to purchase online groceries. Our gift card offer includes Asda’s Christmas Savings Card, an Asda-branded card that pays a bonus to customers in November based on how much they have saved on their card up to that date. We also participate in pre-paid card schemes through our business-to-business gift card programme, through which a commission is paid to businesses to encourage end-users to shop at Asda. Businesses who purchase Asda gift cards can also receive a discount on bulk purchases. _Asda Mobile_ Asda Mobile operates as a Mobile Network Virtual Operator, offering pay-as-you-go mobile services to customers. Asda Mobile was launched on the EE network. In 2020, we entered into an exclusive five-year agreement with Vodafone to begin operating Asda Mobile. Our mobile network transitioned to Vodafone during the first half of 2021, and Asda Mobile on the EE network ceased in September 2021. As of December 31, 2023, we have approximately 220,000 customers on the Vodafone network. We sell our SIM cards in our stores at dedicated bays alongside mobile handsets. We also operate a dedicated website where customers can order a SIM card. See also “Regulation—Regulations Relating to Our Mobile Offer.” _Other Service Offers_ We also offer our customers other services, including our ‘toyou’ service, which allows customers to collect and return orders from partner retailers at Asda locations, Asda Tyres (which sells tyres and connects customers to local tyre fitting services via a dedicated online shop), and Asda Media Partnerships (an advertising service helping brands to reach and influence Asda’s customers through digital, social, in-store and out-of-store advertising opportunities). 176 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We offer online grocery shopping through our online Asda groceries platform, including delivery services for our customers’ online orders, as well as our Click & Collect service. We also offer our popular George Clothing and homeware range online through George.com. For the year ended December 31, 2023, £3.6 billion of our sales were through our online platform (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales). _Asda groceries_ Asda groceries is our online groceries business. We sell our groceries through groceries.asda.com and our mobile application. Customers place an order either for delivery or for collection from one of approximately 460 Click & Collect sites. Delivery orders are fulfilled either from our home shopping centres, which are dedicated fulfilment centres for online grocery orders, or from Asda stores, depending on the customer’s location. This in-store online model proved effective in responding to rapid increases in demand during the COVID-19-related lockdowns in the United Kingdom and we believe this demonstrates our ability to scale our online offering quickly to meet customer demand. Our online delivery covers a comprehensive portion of the United Kingdom and delivery to customers is primarily made by Asda colleagues using our van fleet. For deliveries, customers book a delivery slot and can choose to either pay per delivery or to sign up for a monthly or annual delivery pass, allowing customers up to one delivery per day on orders over £40 for a fixed price. The COVID-19 pandemic increased the use of and engagement with our online platforms. In the first half of 2021, there were approximately 8.6 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with order growth from approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended February 28, 2020) to an average of more than 773,000 weekly orders in 2021 (based on the average weekly orders for the first 26 weeks of 2021) and a peak of more than 850,000 orders during the third lockdown (based on the 7 days to January 15, 2021). Although online engagement has fallen from the peaks experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic, we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). _George.com_ We sell George Clothing and George Home products online through George.com. Customers place an order either for delivery or collection from one of approximately 460 Click & Collect sites. Delivery of orders is provided by third-party couriers, with orders prepared at our three fulfilment centres. George.com also delivers to customers around the world. Following the Separation, Walmart has agreed to permit us to continue to use the George brand internationally. For more information about where we will be able to use the George brand following the Separation, see “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart—Trade Mark _Agreement.”_ In 2019, we launched the George Rewards loyalty scheme, through which customers earn points as they shop online and can use the points to unlock discounts. 177 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our value proposition is particularly attractive to value-seeking families, younger shoppers and lower-income customers. The following chart presents the life stage and income bracket distribution of our customer base. _(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Shoppers. Note: Income Brackets are classified based on the following: Class A: Higher managerial, administrative and professional; Class B: Intermediate managerial, administrative and professional; Class C1: Supervisory, clerical and junior managerial, administrative and professional; Class C2: Skilled manual workers; Class D: Semi-skilled and unskilled manual worker s; Class E: State pensioners, casual and lowest grade workers, unemployed with state benefits only.)_ A key component of our strategy is to provide great quality and value to our customers and we are focused on initiatives supporting our customers who are faced with cost-of-living pressures. In May 2022, we launched a new grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials by Asda. This range replaced the existing budget offering, Asda Smart Price, expanding the range from approximately 160 to 272 products with new branding and products reformulated for taste and quality. The total range is designed to enable customers to keep the household running on a budget. The range is a key part of our strategy to make desirable products affordable, giving customers the opportunity to reappraise our quality and value offering. Throughout 2022, our Asda Rewards programme was introduced as an indirect cost-saving scheme for customers to earn cash back on their shopping and we also ran our “Dropped and Locked” price campaign, which was aimed at supporting UK households tackling inflation. The “Dropped and Locked” campaign locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items, including fresh fruit and vegetables, fresh meat, store cupboard favourites like rice and noodles, as well as soft drinks, desserts, frozen products and non-HFSS (as defined below) products. As a result, prices on these products dropped by an average of 12% and locked until the end of 2022 to give customers certainty around their shopping in light of these cost-of-living pressures. In 2023, we continued our commitment to our customers through various price drop and freezing initiatives and in 2024, we introduced “Fab 5,” which offers our customers five of our “fabulous” quality fruit and vegetables (on a weekly basis) at a low price of under £1, both in store and online.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have particular strength with our own-brand food products, including, among others, Just Essentials by Asda (our opening price point brand), Asda (our mid-tier brand), Asda Farm Stores (our line of high-quality fresh and affordable food drawing on Asda’s long-standing farming heritage and working closely with our approved farms, growers and suppliers), Asda Extra Special (our premium product offer) and Asda Free From (our food offer for specific dietary requirements, such as gluten-free diets). In 2023, we also launched two new vegan ranges, Plant Based by Asda and Asda OMV! to meet increase customer demand for plant-based eating. The OMV! range offers indulgent meat-free meals and delicious snacks, whilst the Plant Based range provides healthy meat alternatives. In the 52 weeks ended January 26, 2024, our own-brand products accounted for 55.8% of our food volumes, which comprise the categories of core groceries, impulse groceries, bakery products, chilled products, fresh meat, poultry and fish, frozen products, meal solutions and produce, and 44.3% of our sales value, across the same categories. Our own-branded product offer includes approximately 7,800 SKUs. Our approach to range development and innovation enables us to identify and meet changing customer needs and resulted in the creation of many award-winning products; we launched approximately 950 new lines in 2021, 1,547 new lines in 2022 and 1,597 new lines in 2023, and approximately 3,858 lines were reformulated in 2023. We are focused on building more inclusive product ranges, as demonstrated by the launch of Plant Based by Asda and Asda OMV! in the first quarter of 2023. In our own-brand products, we are committed to sustainability: we have set goals of using an average minimum of 30% recycled content across all of our own-brand plastic packaging and to having 100% recyclable own-brand packaging by 2025. As of December 31, 2022, 93% of our own-brand packaging was recyclable at home or in our stores.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The George brand is another point of strength for us: George Clothing, which we sell in our stores and on George.com, was the number three clothing, footwear and accessories retailer by volume of units sold in the United Kingdom for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and is a complementary offer to our grocery business. We also sell George homewares in stores and online under George Home. The George brand was launched in 1990 and launched online in 2008. George Clothing is a sizeable, well-established and profitable business, with a leading market share and position in childrenswear. The graph below shows our market position and market share in the UK clothing, footwear and accessories market by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024. _(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Fashion, George, Clothing Footwear & Accessories, Volume % Share, 52 weeks ended January 7th 2024.)_ 179 ----- Clothing, which includes clothing, footwear and accessories, is a core component of our non-food offer and is a business line that benefits from strong margins when compared to food categories, as well as exclusive sourcing partnerships with third parties that has resulted in savings of £54 million in the last five years. In 2023, 49.4% of the value of our non-food sales were George Clothing sales and 25.3% of the value of our non-food sales were George Home sales. The George Clothing product line is a sizeable business with strong online growth. According to Kantar Worldpanel, in the 24 weeks ended January 7, 2024, 26.1% (37.7 million units) of our 144.3 million units in clothing, footwear and accessory sales were made online, with the remaining 73.9% (106.6 million units) being made in our stores. Online sales participation for George.com has improved in recent years. The chart below shows the online sales participation and year-on-year growth of George.com clothing sales for the periods presented. _(Source: Asda information.)_ The George Home brand is growing, having expanded to over £747.7 million of general merchandise sales since inception 10 years ago and contributing approximately 50.0% of general merchandise sales in the year ended December 31, 2023.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Leon is a fast-food chain based in the United Kingdom and was established in 2004. It touts itself a fast-food restaurant with a twist: serving fresh meals with healthy, nutritious food and a strong emphasis on vegan and vegetarian dishes complimented by high quality meat offerings. We acquired all of Leon’s owned and operated locations as part of the EG UK Acquisition, which excludes certain franchised locations for which we now act as franchisor. Our Leon operations include 54 locations, one of which is co-located at a PFS and one of which is co-located at our headquarters. See “Our Businesses—Our Retail Business—Food—Fresh—Foodservice.” We do not count the franchised locations among our 54 Leon outlets.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We operate generally under our well-known Asda brand, for groceries, and George brand, for clothing, footwear, general merchandise and homeware. 178 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We believe we have a well-invested and geographically diversified store estate. As of December 31, 2023, 77% of our asset portfolio was comprised of freeholds or long leaseholds, based upon attributable EBITDAR per property (less central allocations), with certain adjustments made to align the calculation methodology across the Group’s properties following the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition. Of this 77%, 12% is attributable to certain properties that are pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under the Ground Rent Facility. Alternatively, as of December 31, 2023 and calculated as the number of freehold operating retail units as a percentage of total number of operating retail units, 52.6% of our asset portfolio was freehold; freehold percentage also includes 180 ----- certain properties that are freehold with a partial leasehold or which are leasehold properties for which the leases have been classed as long leasehold for the purposes of this calculation as those leases have nil or a peppercorn ground rent. We have made around £500 million cumulative investment in the estate between 2021 and 2023. We operate five distinct store formats: (i) supercentres and superstores, (ii) supermarkets, (iii) Asda Living, (iv) convenience and (v) foodservice. - _Supercentres and superstores: Supercentres are our largest stores (typically exceeding a net sales area of 80,000 square feet), offering our extended range across food, George and non-food, often supported by partnership offers and an extended range of services through photo printing specialists, dry cleaners, pharmacies, opticians, cafés and fuel. Superstores are large supermarkets (with a net sales area ranging between 15,000 and 80,000 square feet), providing a more limited non-food offer and a smaller range of services than our supercentres including through photo printing specialists, dry cleaners, pharmacies, opticians, cafés and fuel. - Supermarkets: Supermarkets are our small, usually local, stores (with a net sales area of less than 15,000 square feet) typically providing customers with a selected food range that, offers general groceries such as food, beverage and household non-food products. Our supermarkets do not typically offer extended services apart from fuel. - Asda Living: Asda Living are dedicated general merchandise stores, containing selected non-food ranges including our George Clothing and George Home offers, home electronics, toys, homewares, health, and beauty products. - Convenience: Our convenience offering consists of two offerings. - Conveniently located small non-fuel stores (with a net sales area of less than 3,000 square feet) that offer a wide variety of food-for-now or food-for-later ranges and includes a selected ranges of household products. As of December 31, 2023, we have nine convenience stores. - Petrol filling station (“PFS”) usually complemented by a retail space for small consumable purchases. As of December 31, 2023, we have 490 PFSs. For more information on these retail spaces, see “Our Businesses—Our Retail Business—Food—Fresh—Foodservice.” - _Foodservice: Our foodservice stores format includes stand-alone stores containing either (i) a fast-food outlet offering a selection of branded fast-food counters, or (ii) a Leon food outlet, all located in convenient locations. For more information about our foodservice brand offerings, see “Our _Businesses—Our Retail Business—Food—Fresh—Foodservice.”_ The table below summarises the key data of our retail store formats.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We work with a number of tenants and strategic partners that operate retail locations within our grocery stores, such as McDonalds, Sushi Daily, Timpson, Decathlon and Claire’s, or provide other services to our customers, such as UberEats, Deliveroo and Just Eat which provide grocery home delivery.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we employed approximately 150,000 individuals. Our retail colleagues make up the largest proportion of this, with approximately 85% of our workforce serving customers in store, 9% in the distribution network, and 4% in home offices and 2% in other operations. Typically, our total number of colleagues increases during peak retail periods, such as Easter and Christmas, due to seasonal hires. We are committed to providing colleagues the training, education and incentives they need to strengthen their skills and become part of our community. Our colleagues are subject to standard employment terms, depending on their role, and are provided with colleague handbooks (where relevant) and policies. We have trade union agreements in Asda’s retail and distribution businesses as well as in Asda Express. In our retail business, we have a collective bargaining agreement for hourly-paid colleagues in Northern Ireland and a partnership agreement with the GMB Union (“GMB”) for hourly-paid colleagues who are GMB members in England, Scotland and Wales. In our distribution business, we have a collective bargaining agreement with the GMB for hourly-paid colleagues and a collective bargaining agreement with Unite the Union (“Unite”) and the United Road Transport Union for colleagues in our Lutterworth chilled distribution centre. For Asda Express, the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers (“Usdaw”) have collective bargaining agreements for hourly and salaried colleagues in sites acquired in connection with the Arthur Acquisition. We recently entered into a collective bargaining agreement with Usdaw for hourly-paid colleagues in Leon, in sites acquired in connection with the EG UK Acquisition and that will be in any new Asda Express site. The GMB partnership agreement covers eight legacy Asda Express sites. We are committed to offering competitive compensation in line with market practices and supporting our colleagues during this high inflationary environment. For example, in April 2023, we voluntarily increased our rate for hourly-paid store colleagues to £11.00 an hour and further increased this in July 2023 to £11.11 an hour. For stores inside the M25 and around Greater London, our rate for hourly-paid store colleagues increased to £12.28. For information related to certain ongoing legal proceedings relating to wages, please see “—Legal Proceedings—Equal _Value Litigation.” We also offer variable compensation to colleagues, including those working in retail and_ distribution, to encourage performance based on the fulfilment of business targets.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We operate a “hub and spoke” logistics network, with two hubs and two deconsolidation centres serving 23 depots across the United Kingdom. Our logistics model is designed to support our extensive store and online businesses. This approach starts with suppliers that provide goods to our hubs and depots as well as directly to our stores for certain products. Our hubs and depots supply our stores via our fleet. In addition to in-store purchasing, Asda and Asda Logistics Services (“ALS”) also offer customers home-delivery and Click & Collect services. - _Hubs. Our two hubs are split by category: our Lutterworth hub handles general merchandise and ambient goods, while our Doncaster hub, which is operated by a third party, handles general merchandise and ambient products. - Suppliers. We work closely with over 5,900 active supplier accounts as of December 31, 2023. The top 20 of our goods for resale (“GFR”) suppliers (excluding IPL and fuel) reflected approximately 29.5% 182 ----- of cost of goods sold to GFR suppliers (excluding VAT, for the year ended December 31, 2023), while the top 20 goods not for resale (“GNFR”) suppliers (excluding IPL and fuel) reflected approximately 51.8% of costs of goods sold to GNFR suppliers. These suppliers deliver goods either to a hub (such as for ambient and non-edible products and non-food products), direct to depots (such as for fresh food, produce and fast-moving ambient) or direct to stores (such as for bread). New suppliers undergo a number of checks and procedures managed via the shared service centre team. If a supplier is identified as a third-party intermediary, which is typically only relevant to goods not for resale suppliers presenting a bribery and corruption risk, further procedures are required as part of the on-boarding and ongoing management processes for that supplier, focused on anti-corruption. During the on-boarding of goods not for resale suppliers, we undertake a compliance risk review covering topics including, among others, modern slavery, information security and privacy. If compliance risks are identified, then we agree on and implement appropriate mitigation measures. Relationships with goods for resale suppliers are managed by the relevant buying team within the commercial team. Our buyers are responsible for negotiating key terms, including pricing, promotional activity, supplier income arrangements, and payment terms. For goods not for resale suppliers, the applicable business owners manage the contract terms and arrangements. We leverage supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity. - Ordering process. The purchase order process varies according to the category of goods. - _GFR: Automatic orders are generated with suppliers based on stock levels / stock availability, historical demand trends and forecast trends. This is applicable for the majority of food orders. The supply team has manual override capabilities for automatic orders, albeit limited and rarely required. Non-food products typically operate on a longer lead time. The orders are based on forecast sales numbers provided to the supply team by the buying team and the commercial finance team. - _GFNR: Purchase orders are raised by the procurement team or the applicable colleague and reviewed by the budget holder (the individual who is responsible for the budget to which the associated cost relates) within that colleague’s team. - _Logistics facilities. Logistics facilities receive, process, warehouse and distribute goods for sale at our stores. IPL, Forza and Kober are treated as suppliers and largely deliver to depots. In addition, we operate home shopping centres, which are fulfilment centres for online grocery orders. - Fleet. Our drivers deliver goods to stores and customers using fleet vehicles (1,367 leased tractors and 2,629 leased trailers), home shopping vans (3,401 leased vans) or occasional spot hire or use of thirdparty hauliers (figures as of December 31, 2023). - Stores. aside from in-store purchasing, we also offer our customers home delivery and Click & Collect service. **IPL** We believe we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via IPL and its two subsidiary companies, Forza and Kober, which enables a vertically integrated approach to procurement. IPL is an important asset that provides valuable sourcing differentiation. In 2023, £1,724 million was purchased through IPL, reducing our overall purchasing costs and delivering strong value to our customers. Our 2023 product mix sourced from IPL was 55.7% produce, 28.3% protein, 6.6% house plants and flowers, 6.1% beverages and 3.3% grocery. IPL employed over 3,700 colleagues as of December 31, 2023 across its group of companies, and only serves us. IPL receives products directly from producers and employs centralised sourcing, transportation and packing. This disintermediation of export agents, import agencies, suppliers and packers is the foundation of IPL’s cost price advantage: IPL sources fruit and vegetables, cooked meats, wine, nuts and dried fruit, plants and flowers and has a national footprint of nine processing facilities across the United Kingdom, supported by two overseas technical/logistical operations. IPL’s overseas offices provide us with the benefit of being close to our foreign grower partners, which we believe gives us greater insight and control over our supply chain, conferring on 183 ----- us a competitive advantage versus other retailers who do not benefit from comparable vertically integrated procurement. The map below shows IPL’s UK footprint. _(Source: Asda information.)_ IPL operates with five trading business units including produce (sourcing whole fruit and vegetables, potatoes and onions), protein (sourcing cooked meat and bacon), house plants and flowers (sourcing plants for the home and flowers), beverages (sourcing wine), grocery (sourcing snack nuts, desserts and baking products, cereal and other nuts and dried fruit), and with central functions to support these trading business units (by employing colleagues across IT, finance, legal and compliance and HR functions). The key countries of origin from which we source products via IPL include the United Kingdom, Spain, Denmark, the Netherlands and other European Union countries, Morocco, South Africa, Peru, Thailand and Egypt.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Our Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to providing customers with safe and high-quality products, including both our own-brand products and name brand products. We have a due diligence framework in place which covers, among other things, our supplier audit framework, our governance policies, product testing and our specification management system. Our supplier audit framework measures compliance, supplier performance against food safety hazard analysis and critical control point principles. In addition, we have a quality management system that measures how our products perform in terms of quality. To control the quality of the products we sell, we execute a number of quality control initiatives. We conduct regular quality controls on the acceptance of fresh food at our depots. In addition, we analyse own-brand product 184 ----- samples in our in-house sensory kitchens and through a third-party, Cambridge Market Research, to ensure that our products meet our customers’ expectations. All new own-brand suppliers must be Global Food Safety Initiative accredited and must pass a new supplier audit before proceeding. In addition, all own-brand suppliers will have an annual unannounced Asda Star Audit that measures their adherence to Asda policy. We conduct food safety audits twice a year at our superstores and home shopping centres, and once a year at our smaller supermarkets and depots, to ensure that each site meets our required standards for food safety and hygiene. We conduct essential training and department-specific training for store colleagues to ensure that they are trained in all relevant aspects of food safety related to their department, including allergen management. When deciding whether to work with an own-brand supplier, we monitor the quality of its products based on a control of samples delivered by the supplier during the selection phase. Following selection, we regularly evaluate the quality of the products the supplier offers, including through randomly selected samples. Our general supplier terms and conditions include a section dedicated to quality, safety, labelling and traceability. By signing these terms and conditions, our suppliers confirm that they are fully aware of, and comply with, our safety and quality standards. Furthermore, suppliers must adhere to our technical manufacturing guide and associated policies for food as well as work with our own-brand technical teams to ensure compliance with this guide and these policies.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Our Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies
Subsubsection Title: Health, Safety and Environmental Policies and Ethics
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to maintaining high standards of health and safety practices for our colleagues, customers, visitors, contractors and anyone affected by our business activities. We therefore consider good health, safety and environmental management as an essential part of our business performance and culture. We formally monitor health and safety incident rates. Our health and safety policies and procedures include: - managing risk and promoting a corporate culture that emphasises the benefits of health and safety; - appropriate training and education of all colleagues to support legal compliance and best practices; and - proactively conducting regular risk assessments and root cause analyses to provide and maintain safe and healthy working environments to significantly reduce occupational injuries or illnesses. We carry out a range of monitoring activities to provide assurance of the effectiveness of our policies and procedures. These activities are completed by both internal teams and external experts. We have a wide variety of health and safety and ethics policies that address topics such as Food Safety, Food Contamination, Warehouse Safety, Product Safety, Fire Safety, Privacy, Environment and Environmental Services, Anti-Money Laundering and Licences and Permits, among others. We also have a number of policies that relate specifically to waste management issues, such as Food and Drink Waste, Confidential Waste, Optical Waste and Pharmacy Waste.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Our Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies
Subsubsection Title: Our Environmental, Social and Governance Goals
Subsubsection Text: As a major retailer, we believe that we have the ability, and the responsibility, to make a significant impact on the topics that matter to our stakeholders, such as energy and climate change, food waste, plastic and packaging, healthy and sustainable choices and the support of local communities (together, our “ESG Priority Areas”), and our customers want us to play our part in creating solutions that work for everyone. By taking action, we intend to meet these expectations, but also to strengthen our business for the future so that we can continue to deliver the same value to our customers. In 2022, we reassessed our environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) programme to ensure it remains a critical pillar of our growth strategy. Our overarching ESG approach remains focused on providing access and affordability for customers as the business undergoes a period of transformation and takes account of the external environment in which we operate. 185 ----- In October 2023, we received our first external assessment of our ESG strategy with an overall rating of 3 (on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the strongest) by the financial services ratings’ agency Sustainable Fitch as part of our ongoing commitment to transparently report on our efforts to achieve our ESG targets. We also received an entity score of 54 (on a scale of 0 to 100). _Our ESG Priority Areas Energy and Climate Change Mitigation Carbon Emissions_ Our carbon footprint is nearly equally split between the transportation of goods and refrigerants and natural gas (Scope 1 emissions) and the electricity we use across our estate (Scope 2 emissions). Our Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions come from fleet, buildings and purchased energy, and we have undertaken numerous activities to reduce these, including through continuing to rollout gas-powered HGVs, electrifying the Asda Online delivery fleet and moving to lower-carbon refrigerants. For Scope 3 emissions, we continue to engage with our suppliers to reduce product-related emissions and work particularly closely with our largest suppliers on setting climate commitments for the products they sell us. To play our part in tackling climate change, we have been working to decarbonise our Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions since 2007 and in 2015, set our commitment to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2025. We have since reduced our greenhouse gas footprint for the United Kingdom by 41% to 564,247 tonnes CO2 equivalent (“tCO2e”) in 2023 (without giving effect to the Arthur Acquisition) compared to our baseline of 957,918 tCO2e in 2015. This reduction has been driven in part by a reduction in electricity and gas use, the continued transition of our heavy goods vehicles fleet to low or no carbon fuels and implementing lower carbon refrigeration and energy efficiency measures across our stores. In addition, in 2021 we stated our ambition to be a net-zero business, establishing a clear roadmap to achieving net-zero Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions within our own operations by 2040. We have committed to setting a near-term science-based carbon reduction target, including a specific Forests, Land and Agriculture target. These targets have been submitted to the Science-Based Targets Initiative (“SBTi”) for validation. The proposed targets were submitted before the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition so reflect our footprint prior to these acquisitions. In 2024, we will look to incorporate these acquisitions into our baseline and targets. In 2022, our total carbon footprint was 28,295,682 tCO2e (without giving effect to the Arthur Acquisition) including 51% from product emissions (including the farming of ingredients, processing products, through to packaging), 2% in connection with supply chain logistics, 2% from our sites and fleet, 4% from goods not for resale as well as our operational activity, 25% from customers using the fuel we sell them and the remaining 16% from customers using products (including cooking, washing clothes, disposing of products and packaging). _Nature_ Food production systems require a diverse range of plants, animals, bacteria and fungi, both for the direct supply of food and to sustain the underlying ecosystem processes that make agriculture possible – from water supply to soil fertility enhancement, pollination and natural pest control. We are mindful of the impact we have through our value chain on the natural capitals of air, water, soil and biodiversity, and are committed to working in partnership to better respect and restore nature. In recent years, we have encouraged farmers to keep soil covered and improve biodiversity and soil structure through the use of our bespoke seed mixture. These seeds create a wildlife habitat during the late spring and summer and the wildlife corridors can also be used as buffer strips to watercourses. We are committed to more sustainably sourcing key commodities and tracking performance against our most material impacts, including soy and palm, within our annual ESG Report. We support the principles of Integrated Farm Management (“IFM”) and, in early 2023, we committed to obtaining the global LEAF Marque Environmental Assurance System across all our fresh produce by the end of 2025. 186 ----- _Water Resources_ Water resources are under stress around the world, and we believe improving water use and building resilience in global supply chains is vital in order to sustainably feed a growing population with healthy and affordable products. In 2022, 22% of our fruit and vegetables were imported from Southern Spain. As part of a cross-industry group working with the British Waste & Resources Action Programme (“WRAP”), we have made a three-year commitment for funding to the ‘Water Stewardship in South Spain’ project, which is taking action to try to reduce water-related risks in the fruit and vegetable production areas of Andalusia, Murcia and Valencia. In addition, we work with many garment manufacturers who have taken a series of water saving measures to reduce water consumption such as using harvested/reused water for flushing toilets and excess steam pipe water being returned to the boiler for reuse. _Waste Food Waste_ We are committed to being a zero-waste business, which means that any waste we do generate is either reused, recycled or redistributed. We continue to work towards our 2025 waste reduction targets across food (20% reduction in waste), packaging (100% recyclable own brand packaging, 30% recycled content) and operational waste (90% diversion from energy and maintain zero to landfill). As part of our efforts to reduce food surplus, we created a new team dedicated to reducing food waste within our supply chain in 2019. This team scrutinises our food waste performance by individual product line, enabling us to create initiatives and to work with our suppliers to reduce food waste. As a result, we removed best before dates on almost 250 fresh fruit and vegetable products to help customers reduce food waste in the home and save money in 2022 and, in early 2023, we went further by changing the use by dates on over half of our own brand yoghurts to a best before date, aiming to reduce the volume of edible yoghurt thrown away each year (by all retailers). In 2022, we processed 32,923 tonnes of food surplus (redistribution/animal feed) and food waste (anaerobic digestion/energy from waste) from our stores and depots. Whilst our priority is to reduce the absolute volume of our food surplus being processed as waste, we are also committed to ensuring that we handle that surplus in the most value-adding way possible by directing as much as possible for human or animal consumption. To tackle operational food waste, we increased the number of charities we work with redistributing surplus food from our distribution sites and through our partnerships in 2022, our stores, depots and home offices donated 2,182 tonnes of food, the equivalent of more than 5.2 million meals. In addition to our Food Waster prevention efforts, we began working with our clothing factories and George Home suppliers to help us build a robust strategy and policy around waste, which we plan to report through our future ESG reports and our website. _Plastic and Packaging_ Although packaging plays a vital role in protecting goods and keeping food fresh for as long as possible, consumers increasingly want to see fewer single-use plastics, especially when it comes to fresh produce. Where packaging is vital, we are working to make it more sustainable. Removing packaging completely or shrinking it down to its lightest possible weight has allowed us to remove significant amounts of plastic from Asda Brand products and eliminate some types of single-use plastic products from our stores and offices completely. Where packaging cannot be reduced, we are working to make it more reusable. We introduced reusable or re-tillable solutions for packaging that allowed a shift towards fresh meat and produce being transited in reusable crates and introduced customer refills at our Middleton “sustainability store,” which is a concept designed to encourage customers to reuse and refill their products, allowing customers to bring and fill their own containers with products such as on core products such as cereals, tea, coffee and pet food. We have partnered with Unilever and WRAP to conduct research to make the refill experience easier and more enjoyable for our customers. 187 ----- Where packaging cannot be reused, we are working to make it more recyclable. _Healthy, Sustainable Choices_ At Asda, we are making nutritious food affordable and appealing, with health-focused communications, support for public health campaigns and innovation in our own-brand products. We recognise the importance of front-of-pack traffic lights to enable customers to manage their calorie intake and their intakes of nutrients of concern such as fat, saturated fat, sugar and salt. In October 2022, location restrictions on the sale of high fat, salt and sugar foods (“HFSS”) came into force in England across 13 categories, a measure which forms a key part of the UK Government’s strategy to tackle obesity by making unhealthy food less prominent in stores and online. Despite the operational challenges affecting the way foods in Asda are merchandised and the significant investment required, we used the HFSS legislation to accelerate our ability to collect HFSS data across brands for all products, which is essential to be able to report on healthy basket spend. We also recognise the importance of highlighting healthy choices to our customers with a focus on positive nutrients and health benefits, which is the motivation behind our 2020 launch of the Asda Live Better icon, which highlights the healthiest choices in our own-brand ranges. In the fourth quarter of 2023, approximately 876 products, including a wide range from the Just Essentials by Asda, bore the icon and we aim to have 1,200 products in the range by the end of 2024. _Supporting Local Communities Fundraising and Support_ We aim to build stronger communities and to connect others to make a collective impact on our customers. Through our network of Community Champions and fundraising initiatives, we take action to make a positive change to poverty, tackle breast cancer, support children and families in crisis and build more resilient communities. The Asda Foundation is an independent charity with more than 30 years’ of history helping people in local communities. Its mission is to transform communities and improve lives throughout the United Kingdom, complementing Asda’s ambition to be at the heart of local communities. The Asda Foundation supports grassroots organisations as well as local communities in emergencies, reacting quickly to help people in the immediate hours following a disaster. The Asda Foundation provides grants to small, local activities, funding a wide range of projects from school uniforms and Christmas lunches to refurbishing a community centre kitchen. Following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Asda and the Asda Foundation pledged £1.0 million to support displaced Ukrainian families in Europe and the United Kingdom and helped Ukrainian refugees by welcoming applications for roles in our stores, warehouses and within IPL, with a guaranteed job interview and specialist support for those recruited. The increasing cost of living is a growing issue in the United Kingdom and in 2022, Asda Foundation introduced a new Cost of Living grant to support local groups with increased running costs. In 2022 Asda Foundation invested £4,315,444 in local communities, supporting 7,119 groups with grants and colleague hardship payments. Over 14 million people in the United Kingdom live below the poverty line, and just under a third of those affected are children. At the same time, 4.4 million tonnes of edible food are wasted in the United Kingdom each year and as a food retailer, it is important to us to make a positive impact. Through its transformational three-year, Fight Hunger, Create Change programme, Asda partnered with FareShare and The Trussell Trust to create long-term positive change in the United Kingdom. Asda has since continued to support both FareShare and the Trussell Trust through donations of food, cause-related marketing initiatives, customer fundraising and top up donations. _Diversity & Inclusion_ Our mission is to be the UK’s most trusted retailer, which means building a business that is diverse and inclusive, creating a safe and supportive environment for our colleagues, customers and suppliers. We focus on providing the best possible learning opportunities for our colleagues, listening to their needs and promoting their health and wellbeing and as further support, we launched a course called “Inclusion Matters” in 2022 to help 188 ----- colleagues build an inclusive work environment. We encourage everyone to be allies through positive and conscious efforts and introduced an “Asda Allies” campaign to raise awareness on how our colleagues can help under-represented colleagues and its importance. Asda Allies is a key lens for all our internal campaigns and underpins that one does not have to be directly affected by discrimination or unfair treatment to challenge non-inclusive behaviour, advocate the need for change, and seek to understand the additional barriers that some people or communities face. We have set a target to increase the proportion of female store managers to 30% by 2025 and have established programmes to deliver this, such as our Retail Female Representation Working Group, which is tasked with looking at the barriers to increasing female store leadership and our Female Intentional Allyship programme that launched in 2022. In 2023, 290 of our colleagues participated in the Female Intentional Allyship programme. Over the years, we introduced 75 apprenticeship programmes, including degrees in data science, supply chain leadership and business management and were recognised in 2022 as one of the United Kingdom’s top 100 apprenticeship employers. In 2023, Asda was a finalist in the Macro Employer of the Year category of the National Apprenticeship Awards. _Supply Chain and Responsible Sourcing_ Ethics and compliance are at the heart of ensuring our business meets the expectations of our stakeholders in terms of conduct and behaviours. These behaviours and expectations extend to everyone who works with us, from our employees to our suppliers and contractors, requiring them to share our values and help promote a culture where people do the right thing as a matter of course. We have integrated supply chain policies into our processes and ways of working to obtain supply chain transparency and continue to work to ensure our supply chains are resilient and lead to positive change by sourcing responsibly, promoting human rights and eschewing modern slavery. Our Ethics and Compliance programme is designed to manage compliance risks with key areas relevant to the retail sectors including anti-corruption, anti-trust, consumer protection, environmental, anti-money laundering and financial services, food safety, health and safety, optical and pharmacy, labour and employment, licences and permits, privacy, product safety, responsible sourcing and trade sanctions. Since our separation from Walmart we have been transitioning to establish an Asda-specific approach to responsible sourcing and in 2022, we published our Human Rights Policy and completed a responsible sourcing risk assessment based on supplier compliance information to identify salient risks and themes including gender, modern slavery, vulnerable workers, worker representation and working hours as key topics to address and further integrate throughout our business.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our information systems are critical to our business operations. They provide management, analytical and performance evaluation tools that assist management at all levels to undertake business processes. Our technical infrastructure and computer applications are also used for the day-to-day management of our business, including purchasing, sourcing, distribution, online sales, data exploitation, invoicing, cash collection, reporting, consolidation and electronic data interchange. Our business depends on the ability of our colleagues to process transactions on secure information systems and our capacity to store, retrieve, process and manage information. Our information systems are highly integrated, covering most of our fundamental business service areas. The majority of our core systems are currently provided and managed by Walmart, and we are migrating off of these systems onto alternative solutions through Project Future. As of March 31, 2024, we have invested approximately £600 million in Project Future, comprising of both operating expenses and capital expenditure. We believe Project Future presents significant opportunities in terms of our efficiency, data capabilities, customer experience and competitive edge. We are in the third year of the four-year programme. We are progressing through the build and implement of Project Future, moving to in-depth testing and roll-out. We have successfully converted seven depots as of March 31, 2024 as part of our new Warehouse Management system “Manhattan” (with two more in progress) and have implemented our new store till systems across many stores. Our core back-office SAP system is also live, onto which we have recently transitioned our finance operations, and we are undertaking detailed testing to prepare for transitioning our commercial function to SAP in the second quarter of 2024. We have recently implemented our new core human resources and payroll systems across our entire network. In the second half of 2024, our inventory management and fulfilment systems will be rolled out across our commercial, supply chain and retail estate. We are targeting complete separation from Walmart by the end of 2024. We believe that our information systems are robust, adequate to support our activities and operate at standards that are comparable to other operators in our industry. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our 189 ----- _Acquisitions—Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives” and “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Our Publicity, Marketing and Customer Service
Subsubsection Text: Marketing is an integral part of the promotion of our brand, stores and products. We carry out a number of branding and advertising initiatives through our stores, websites and mobile applications, as well as through print, social and broadcast advertising campaigns. We work these through owned, earned and paid channels. The key focus of our messaging to our customers is an emphasis on value, the innovative, high-quality and well-priced products we offer and brand sentiment, services and ways to shop as well as a focus on corporate social responsibility. We also have an online and paper magazine, Asda MAG/Good Living, through which we promote our products and brand values, as well as encourage customer engagement with our brands and offers. We receive publicity for our innovations in product range and quality across own-brands, which helped us to win over 700 product awards, 378 food awards, 332 beer, wine and spirit awards and five retailer awards in 2023. Customer service is key to winning and retaining customers. We make customer service available in our stores, online and by telephone. We offer our George customers a loyalty programme, George Rewards, and in 2022, we launched our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards. The scheme is app-based and enables customers to earn cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store. The scheme also provides the opportunity to leverage data insights which enable to Group to better target investment in the customer proposition. Asda Rewards had 4.9 million active customers as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 30-day period (or 5.7 million active customers as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 13-week period) and continues to drive incremental sales. It is central to our strategic objective around proposition and creating more reasons to shop with us than anyone else.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We use a variety of trade names, service marks and trade marks in our business and rely on trade mark and copyright laws, confidentiality procedures and contractual provisions to protect our intellectual proprietary rights. Our key brands are, among others: Asda, George Clothing and George Home. We believe that the brand names of each of our various banners enjoy high brand recognition and are material to our business. Our intellectual property policy is centred around the protection of our brands, associated logos and our domain names. This policy involves filings and reservations on either a local country basis or in the full range of countries where we operate or wish to preserve and protect our rights. Certain intellectual property rights related to Asda, including trademarks, are owned solely by Walmart. In particular, intellectual property rights relating to the George brand are owned by a Walmart group company and used by both Walmart and Asda. Walmart has granted Asda a licence to use the George brand in the United Kingdom (for sale, marketing and distribution purposes on an exclusive basis); in certain specified countries in Europe (on a non-exclusive basis) where it is currently used as part of Asda’s business; and certain other territories outside the United Kingdom and such specified European countries (on a non-exclusive basis) in substantially the same way as and to the same extent the brand was used by Asda immediately prior to the date of the Acquisition Agreement, as specified in, and subject to the terms of, the TMA, in each case on and subject to the terms of the TMA, while Walmart will continue to own the brand and use it in other territories. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart,” “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions—Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We maintain insurance coverage against the risks inherent in our various businesses. Our insurance policies cover marine and cargo (including for our ‘toyou’ offer), directors and officers, core and non-core property, terrorism, cyber, combined liability (employee liability, public liability, products liability) including medical malpractice for our pharmacy business, motor, machinery movement and private medical insurance. 190 ----- To support the combined liability and motor policies (in particular the self-funding deductible and aggregate provisions), collateral such as letters of credit and bonds, are provided to our insurers for each policy year. These are amended from time to time to reflect the existing and anticipated book value in each policy year. We consider our policies adequate to cover the major risks of our business, and we believe that the level of insurance which we maintain is comparable, in each case, to that maintained by other companies in our primary markets operating in the same business area, but there can be no assurance that this coverage will be sufficient to cover the cost of defence or damages in the event of a significant claim. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and _Regulatory Matters—We may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance and could be exposed to significant financial risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have a number of lease agreements in place in connection with the Warehouse Sale and Leaseback Transaction, the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. For more detail on these leases and transactions, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Warehouse Asset Leases,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—2023 Sale and Leaseback Facility” and “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—Ground Rent Transactions – Ground Rent Facility.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation (Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the “Controlled Land

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a wide variety of laws, regulations and industry standards administered by local, national and other government entities. The following provides a brief description of the main laws and regulations that govern our activities. References and discussions to directives, laws, regulations and other administrative and regulatory documents are entirely qualified by the full text of such directives, laws, regulations and other administrative and regulatory documents themselves. We are in regular contact and dialogue with relevant regulators and have subject matter experts across the business who monitor and manage compliance with the regulatory frameworks within which we operate.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Title: Groceries Supply Code of Practice and Groceries Code Adjudicator
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice (the “GSCOP”), which is UK legislation designed to regulate the relationship between designated retailers and their grocery suppliers. GSCOP provides detail on how retailers should manage their relevant supplier relationships fairly. The Groceries Code Adjudicator is the independent regulator of GSCOP.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Title: Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer Protection
Subsubsection Text: We have food safety specialists in our compliance and technical and quality teams, to ensure food supply, handling and storage procedures are monitored closely to ensure product safety, quality standards and compliance with all applicable food safety and hygiene laws and regulations. In doing so this ensures all aspects of food safety risk are managed appropriately across supply, operations and foodservice. Scheduled internal and external audits are conducted by qualified, third-party food safety experts to ensure procedural compliance and adherence with our policies. This verification programme identifies and evaluates the hazards that are significant for food safety and hygiene, taking account of the Food Safety Act 1990, the Food Information Regulations 2014 (as amended) and Food Safety and Hygiene Regulations in place across England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales. In addition, the Food Information (Amendment) (England) Regulations 2022 and the Food Information (Scotland) Amendment Regulations 2021, also known as “Natasha’s Law,” took effect in October 2021 and requires businesses to list all the ingredients on individual packaging of products that are considered pre-packed for direct sale. 191 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Title: Regulation Relating to our Health and Wellness Offers (Asda Pharmacy and Asda Optical)
Subsubsection Text: With respect to our Optical offer, we are regulated by the General Optical Council (“GOC”). Asda Stores Limited is a registered Body Corporate with the GOC, which allows us to provide Optical services subject to the GOC Business Standards and the Opticians Act of 1989. Our professionals are registered as individual registrants with the GOC and are subject to GOC Standards for Individuals and the Opticians Act of 1989. We hold NHS mandatory contracts for all of our Asda Opticians locations and are subject to the terms of these contracts. In some of our English Asda Opticians locations, we also hold enhanced services contracts and are subject to the NHS standard contracts and local service level agreements. Enhanced services are defined as primary medical services other than essential services, additional services or out-of-hours services. With respect to our pharmacies, we are regulated by the General Pharmaceutical Council (“GPHC”) in England and Wales and Scotland, and the Pharmaceutical Society of Northern Ireland (“PharmaSNI”). Each of our individual pharmacies is registered with the GPHC or the PharmaSNI, as applicable. This allows us to carry out pharmaceutical activity from our registered premises subject to the Standards for Registered Pharmacies. Our pharmacists are registered with the GPHC as individual registrants and are subject to the GPHC Professional Standards or the PharmaSNI Professional Standards, as applicable.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Title: Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers
Subsubsection Text: _Financial Conduct Authority-authorised Entities_ Asda Stores Limited has been authorised by the FCA since 2017 and currently holds a limited permission to carry on credit brokerage activities (limited to secondary broking). As a result of this authorisation, Asda Stores Limited is regulated and supervised by the FCA. _Appointed Representatives_ The Group includes two introducer-appointed representatives: Asda Stores Limited and Asda Financial Services Limited. In addition to the FCA authorisation noted above, Asda Stores Limited is also payment services directive agent and introducer-appointed representative that is currently involved in insurance and payments intermediation. Asda Financial Services Limited is an introducer-appointed representative which is currently involved in credit and insurance intermediation. In respect of these roles, Asda Stores Limited and Asda Financial Service Limited are not directly authorised by the FCA but may instead perform certain regulated activities and act as agent for firms that are directly authorised by the FCA.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
