Subsubsection Title: Regulations Relating to Our Mobile Offer
Subsubsection Text: _OFCOM Regulations_ Asda is selling mobile communication services to consumers under the Asda Mobile brand using Vodafone’s network pursuant to a mobile virtual operator agreement with Vodafone. See also “Our Businesses—Our Other _Services—Asda Mobile.” The sale and supply of mobile communication services are regulated primarily by the Office_ of Communications (“OFCOM”), an independent regulator and competition authority for the UK communications industries, within the framework set by the various European directives, the UK Communications Act 2003 and other UK and European Union regulations and recommendations. Asda does not require a licence to operate the mobile communication services, however, it must comply with the provisions of OFCOM’s General Conditions of Entitlement that apply to such services. 192 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Text: Up until March 2021, we purchased our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary, which sold electricity back to the rest of the Asda Group companies. These electricity purchases were regulated by the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (“OFGEM”), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity markets in Great Britain. Since March 2021, we have purchased our electricity on a retail basis facilitated through a third-party agent and therefore the regulations relating to wholesale purchases do not apply to the retail purchases made thereafter. Following the switch from purchasing wholesale electricity (via the Power4All subsidiary) in March 2021, we withdrew from all the various utility regulatory bodies including the BSC, via Elexon. All industry parties were written to by OFGEM as part of the process to ensure we had no outstanding obligations. Once these confirmations were received, the licence was revoked in July 23. As a result, we are no longer a wholesale contracting party and we have no on-going responsibilities to report, or any liabilities with any industry party including HMRC, BEIS or National Grid in relation to Power4All.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Text: Through our in-store and online business, as well as certain of our other services (such as our money and pharmacy offers), we have access to and may process personal data relating to our customers and colleagues or any other individual in connection with the provision of our services (the “Relevant Data”). As such, we are subject to applicable laws and binding regulations on data protection and data privacy, including the UK GDPR (such laws and binding regulations together with the UK GDPR, “Applicable Privacy Laws”). We will continue to review and develop existing processes to ensure that we comply with Applicable Privacy Laws in relation to our processing of any Relevant Data.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we may enter into acquisitions or transactions that are subject to regulatory approval from the Competition and Markets Authority (the “CMA”) and may lead to investigations if the deal raises competition concerns. The CMA is the principal competition regulator in the United Kingdom and is a non-ministerial government department. It is responsible to strengthening business competition and preventing and reducing anti-competitive activities. _Green Claims Code_ In 2021, the CMA introduced the Green Claims Code, which is designed for businesses with consumer-facing products and services to ensure that their environmental claims align with UK consumer law. The Green Claims Code applies to advertising and any product or service, by any commercial entity, aimed at or supplied to a UK consumer, including by a non-UK business, a distributor or an online platform.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the foregoing regulations, in the ordinary course of our business, our operations and properties are subject to international, national, regional and local laws and regulations of general applicability, such as labour laws, laws on advertising, regulations governing our relations with our suppliers and distributors, anti-bribery, food and product safety, environmental, health and safety matters (including regulations specific to the fuel market, such as for petroleum storage certificates, the management and disposal of hazardous materials, air emissions and water discharge and the clean-up of contaminated sites), among others. We operate a vehicle fleet that is subject to an Operator’s Licence issued by the relevant local Traffic Commissioner, the conditions of which are enforced through the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency in England and Wales and Scotland, and through the Driver and Vehicle Agency (NI) in Northern Ireland. We are also subject to road transport legislation and regulations that determine, among other issues, the maximum weight that large goods vehicles and light vans can carry, and the maximum number of hours a driver can work or drive over defined periods. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters.” 193 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Asda Stores Limited is a defendant in approximately 52,923 equal value claims (the “Equal Value Claims”) that began in 2008 and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester (the “Employment Tribunal”) in the United Kingdom on behalf of current and former Asda store colleagues, and further claims may be asserted in the future. There are also 8,147 claims filed in the High Court which are stayed pending the outcome of the Equal Value Claims. The claimants allege that the work performed by colleagues in Asda’s retail stores is of equal value in terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of colleagues working in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities, that the difference in pay between these job positions disparately impacts women because more women work in retail stores while more men work in warehouses and distribution facilities, and that the pay difference is not objectively justified. The claimants are requesting differential back pay based on higher wage rates in the warehouse and distribution facilities and higher wage rates on a prospective basis. In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could compare their positions in Asda’s retail stores with those of colleagues in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities. On March 26, 2021, the Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision, that the work of hourly-paid workers in distribution centres and the work of hourly-paid workers in stores can be compared. The litigation is currently in the equal value stage when the Employment Tribunal Claimants are proceeding in the next phase of their claims. That phase will determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal value to the work performed by colleagues in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities. The equal value hearing is scheduled to take place from September 9, 2024 to December 13, 2024 at the Manchester Employment Tribunal. At present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed and cannot reasonably estimate any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no assurance as to the scope and outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows. We believe we have substantial factual and legal defences to these claims and intend to defend the claims vigorously. Under a separate indemnity undertaking, Walmart has agreed to indemnify the LBO Purchaser in respect of a portion of costs and losses incurred by the Asda Group from Equal Value Claims filed with employment tribunals, up to an agreed cap. If the Asda Group is ultimately unsuccessful in defending any of the Equal Value Claims, we do not believe that such an outcome would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and/or results of operations nor our ability to meet our debt service obligations, including on the Senior Secured Notes, or other financial obligations as they become due. As of December 31, 2023, the Group had material off balance sheet arrangements or funding arrangements that would be classified as a contingent liability under UK IFRS with respect to the ongoing Equal Value Claims. Despite the above-mentioned Supreme Court ruling, the Group has not recognised a provision on the basis that any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings cannot be reasonably estimated and any potential liability is only a possible obligation, as it has yet to be confirmed whether the entity has a present obligation that could lead to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits. See “Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value _Litigation” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.”_ 194 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: On July 29, 2022, the CMA publicly announced that they would be investigating environmental claims made in relation to certain products within our George clothing range, and ranges of two other clothing retailers with operations in the United Kingdom. Initial findings relevant to Asda were presented to us on a confidential basis in May 2023. In presenting its findings, the CMA required all information to be specific and visible to customers at the time of their purchasing decision. We opted to negotiate a set of voluntary undertakings (with no admission of liability) with respect to the way environmental claims are made going forward, rather than face court-based enforcement (which could include costs, negative publicity and exposure to significant fines for breach of consumer protection laws (up to 10% global annual turnover under incoming legislation)). These undertakings were concluded and announced in March 2024, simultaneously with the other two investigated retailers. 195 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: At any given time, we may be party to litigation or be subject to non-litigated claims arising out of the normal operations of our business, including but not limited to colleague claims, disputes with our suppliers and customers and disputes with our lessors and landlords as part of our real estate management operations. A description of material legal proceedings and investigations to which we are party is below. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal _and Regulatory Matters—From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: _This Offering Memorandum contains statistical data, estimates and forecasts that are based on independent industry publications, such as those published by Euromonitor International Limited (“Euromonitor”): Retail 2024 Edition, Kantar Worldpanel and the Office for National Statistics (“ONS”), or other publicly available information, as well as other information based on our internal sources Information in this Offering Memorandum on the retail market from independent market research carried out by Euromonitor or Kantar Worldpanel should not be relied upon in making, or refraining from making, any investment decision. With respect to Kantar Worldpanel data presented in this Offering Memorandum, references to the “United Kingdom” do not include Northern Ireland. This information involves many assumptions and limitations, and you are cautioned not to give undue weight to these estimates or place undue reliance on this information. This information has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but some information may be derived from estimates or subjective judgments or may not have been subject to audit or validation. We have not independently verified the accuracy or completeness of the data contained in these industry publications nor other publicly available information and we cannot provide any assurances as to their accuracy. In addition, we believe that data regarding the industry, industry market and sales positions, shares, market sizes and growth provide general guidance but are inherently imprecise. None of the industry publications referred to in this Offering Memorandum were prepared on our behalf nor on behalf of our affiliates nor at our expense. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding any third-party information presented in this Offering Memorandum, the figures are based in part on official statistics, trade associations, trade press, company research, trade interviews and trade services, and as such have not been independently verified by us in each case. The industry in which we operate is subject to a high degree of uncertainty and risk due to a variety of factors, including those described in the section titled “Risk Factors,” that could cause results to differ materially from those expressed in these publications and other publicly available information, including “Forward-Looking Statements” which are not guarantees of future performance. This Offering Memorandum also contains illustrations and charts derived from our internal information, which has not been independently verified unless specifically indicated. See “Historical and Current Market and Industry Data.”_

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: Bellis Topco 2 Limited is the statutory entity at which Asda Group’s strategic board (the “Board,” being Asda’s principal governance body) sit. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the members of the Board are as follows:

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Mohsin Issa CBE is a co-founder and the co-chief executive officer of EG Group. Mr. Mohsin Issa has been
Subsubsection Text: active in the forecourt industry since the acquisition of his first petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom, in 2001 together with his brother, Mr. Zuber Issa, and other members of the Issa family. The Issa family built EG Group to be the largest owner-managed forecourt retailer in the United Kingdom. Prior to founding EG Group, Mr. Mohsin Issa held senior leadership roles at various Issa family businesses. He was jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom alongside his brother Zuber Issa and honoured in the late Queen Elizabeth II’s Birthday Honours List 2020 for his contribution to business and charity.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Zuber Vali Issa CBE is a co-founder and co-chief executive officer of EG Group. He has also been Director
Subsubsection Text: of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited since its incorporation in September 2020. Mr. Zuber Issa has been active in the forecourt industry since the acquisition of his first petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom, in 2001 together with his brother, Mr. Mohsin Issa and other members of the Issa family. The Issa family built EG Group to be the largest owner-managed forecourt retailer in the United Kingdom. Prior to founding EG Group, Mr. Zuber Issa established a number of enterprises including a chain of newsagents in mall locations in the Northwest of England. Mr. Zuber Issa was jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom alongside his brother Mohsin Issa and honoured in the late Queen Elizabeth II’s Birthday Honours List 2020 for his contribution to business and charity.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Gary Lindsay joined TDR Capital in June 2008 and is co-Managing Partner. Mr. Lindsay has also been a
Subsubsection Text: director of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited since its incorporation in September 2020. As Managing Partner, Mr. Lindsay is involved in the day-to-day management of TDR Capital and is heavily involved in TDR Capital's investments in EG Group, Asda and Aggreko (where he sits on the board of each) as well as the origination of new deals. Mr. Lindsay has more than 20 years’ private equity and investment banking experience. Prior to joining TDR Capital, Mr. Lindsay worked at both Citi and Bear Stearns in London and New York. Mr. Lindsay holds a master’s degree in Finance, with distinction, from the University of Strathclyde and a master’s degree in Chemistry, with first class honours, from the University of Edinburgh.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Lord Stuart Rose is a non-executive director and the chairman of Bellis Topco 2 Limited. Lord Rose has
Subsubsection Text: worked in retail for over 40 years and has held chief executive officer positions at Argos, Booker, Iceland, Arcadia Group and Marks & Spencer and chairman positions at Marks & Spencer and Ocado Group. Lord Rose was knighted in 2008 for services to the retail industry and corporate social responsibility and granted a life peerage in August 2014.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Dame Alison Carnwath is a non-executive director of the Board. Dame Alison has served as chairwoman of
Subsubsection Text: Land Securities and as a director at BP, Friends Provident, Gallaher, Barclays and Man Group. Dame Alison is a trustee of the Economist Group and a former member of the United Kingdom Takeover Panel. Dame Alison is a chartered accountant and has two honorary doctorates. Dame Alison was awarded a Dame Commander of the British Empire in 2014 for services to a business and received a lifetime achievement award at the 2020 Non-Executive Director of the Year Awards. 197 -----

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Robert Hattrell is a director of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited since December 19, 2023. Mr. Hattrell joined TDR
Subsubsection Text: Capital in September 2022 as Head of Digital. Prior to TDR Capital, Mr. Hattrell was a senior vice president for eBay Europe, in charge of its European business strategy and operations. Prior to eBay, Mr. Hattrell spent 7 years at Tesco in various roles including leading its general merchandise business and as its national chief information officer. Mr. Hattrell began his career at Accenture where he focused on technology-led transformation projects for retail clients globally. Mr. Hattrell holds a bachelor’s degree in Geography from Oxford University.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Courtney Naudo is a director of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited and a senior executive of Walmart currently serving
Subsubsection Text: as the chief people officer for Walmart International. Prior to her current role, Mrs. Naudo served as Walmart’s senior vice president of strategic portfolio management, supporting the delivery of strategic initiatives, partnerships, and corporate development activities across the international portfolio of businesses. She joined Walmart in 2019 as the vice president of international technology, leading product and engineering teams to deliver technology solutions for merchandising, back office, global sourcing, and operations. Before joining Walmart, Mrs. Naudo was a partner at Deloitte Consulting, having almost 20 years’ experience in global management consulting and corporate finance advisory. Mrs. Naudo holds a Bachelor of Business Administration degree from Southern Methodist University.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Title: Michael Gleeson is the chief financial officer of the Group. Mr. Gleeson joined Asda in May 2023 as our
Subsubsection Text: chief financial officer, having previously held a similar role at another supermarket. Mr. Gleeson joined Morrisons in 2014 initially as the group’s financial controller and then as its supermarkets finance director until 2017, when he became its trading director for ambient, frozen, dairy, fuel and services offerings before being appointed as its chief financial officer in February 2020. Prior to that, Mr. Gleeson worked for Tesco in a number of senior finance roles including as the group financial planning and analysis director and as the chief financial officer of Tesco.com. Mr. Gleeson holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree and a master’s degree in management science from University College Dublin, and he is a chartered accountant, having qualified with Arthur Andersen in Dublin.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below is information concerning the Group’s executive management team as of the date of this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: In 2022, management shares in the immediate parent company of the Group, Bellis Midco 4 Limited, were issued to eligible members of senior management employed by the Group as part of a Management Incentive Plan (“MIP”), in exchange for proceeds determined by an independent calculation of fair value at the issue date. Under the MIP, an intermediate holding company of the Group, Bellis Midco 2 Limited, has entered into an agreement with the holders of MIP management shares (“MIP scheme members”) whereby MIP scheme members are granted put options which, when exercised, enable them to sell their management shares to Bellis Midco 2 Limited or another non-Group entity for a value which is based on an independent valuation determined at the exercise date. MIP scheme members are required to be employed by the Group at the grant date of the MIP shares. If a member of the scheme ceases to be employed by the Group during the vesting period, Bellis Midco 2 Limited, a parent of Bellis Finco PLC, has the option to repurchase, or nominate another entity of the Group to repurchase, the shares during the 12-month period after the member’s leave date. As such, directors of the Group have determined that the MIP scheme falls within the scope of IFRS 2. The difference between the IFRS 2 fair value and the fair value paid by MIP scheme members at the grant date is expensed over the vesting period (i.e., the period from date on which the MIP shares are granted to the estimated exercise date) as an expense in the consolidated Income Statement. As neither MIP shares nor put options over MIP shares are issued by entities within the Group, and as there is no recharge agreement in place which requires any entity within the Group to settle liabilities in respect of MIP shares, changes in the fair value of MIP shares are accounted for on an equity-settled basis. 198 -----

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: The directors received remuneration of £51,964 (2022: £48,571; 2021: £11,895) in respect of their services to the Group in the year ended December 31, 2023. The highest paid director received £51,964 (2022: £48,571; 2021: £11,895) during the year ended December 31, 2023. The Group currently has a customary directors’ and officers’ insurance policy.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: We have a range of committees with board-delegated authority that meet regularly to manage day-to-day operations and decision-making on behalf of the Board. The areas of responsibility of each group are described below. Committees are chaired and attended by members of the Board and Executive Committee as appropriate, and other relevant members of senior management. These committees operate under clearly documented terms of reference and the remit of each is regularly reviewed, and the terms of reference are updated as and when required.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: On a day-to-day basis, Asda is run by an executive committee (the “Executive Committee”), a group of senior leaders who provide strategic direction and operational management across Asda’s business.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: The Audit Committee sits at the level of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Audit Committee’s objectives are to provide oversight and effective governance over the appropriateness and integrity of the financial reporting of the Group, the internal financial controls and risk management systems, compliance with laws and regulations, and the effectiveness of the internal audit function and external auditor. The Audit Committee meets at least four times a year aligned with the external reporting and audit cycle and is chaired by non-executive director Dame Alison Carnwath.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: The Nomination and Remuneration Committee sits at the level of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Nominations and Remuneration Committee meets twice a year and is chaired by non-executive director and chairman Lord Stuart Rose. Its remit includes evaluating the balance, experience, knowledge and skills of the Board, succession planning, monitoring independence of non-executive directors, monitoring trends and compliance with corporate governance best practice, and recommending remuneration strategy and policies for the Group. A separate nominations and remuneration committee for Asda Group Limited and its subsidiaries is chaired and attended by members of the Executive Committee. It is responsible for setting remuneration policies for the business more broadly, including decisions around bonus and hourly pay.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: The Disclosure Committee sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo 2 and its subsidiaries. The Disclosure Committee is responsible for managing the disclosure of material non-public information (MNPI) to Asda’s bond investors and lenders. It meets quarterly aligned with the quarterly investor reporting cycle and on an ad hoc basis as required when potentially material events arise. It is chaired by the Chief Financial Officer and attended by the General Counsel, Disclosure Officer, and senior directors in investor relations and communications.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsection Title: Liquidity and Financial Risk Management (“LARM”) Committee
Subsubsection Text: The LARM Committee sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo 2 and its subsidiaries. The LARM Committee meets on a monthly basis and is chaired by Mr. Gleeson as our chief financial officer. Its role is to review and make recommendations to the Board with respect to cash, liquidity, financial risk management, and any other area relating to risks arising out of financial transactions, including investment decisions, interest rate and foreign currency exposure. 199 -----

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsection Title: Compliance, Ethics, Risk and Audit (“CERA”) Committee
Subsubsection Text: The CERA Committee sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo 2 and its subsidiaries. The CERA Committee meets monthly and is chaired by Asda’s general counsel and attended by Mr. Gleeson as the chief financial officer and a non-executive director. Its role is to oversee review and monitoring of Asda’s systems of internal controls and risk management, the internal audit process, and compliance with laws, regulations and ethical codes of practice.

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsection Title: Asda Real Estate and Investment Committee (“AREIC”)
Subsubsection Text: AREIC sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo 2 and its subsidiaries. AREIC meets monthly and is chaired by the chief financial officer, Mr. Gleeson. It is responsible for reviewing and providing recommendation to the Board on capital investment and real estate matters, including overseeing the annual capital planning process, reviewing and providing recommendation of approval on material projects, and identifying risks and opportunities within the plan. 200 -----

Section Title: THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES ISSUER
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a public limited company incorporated and existing under the laws of England and Wales. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is resident in the United Kingdom for tax purposes. Since the date of its incorporation, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s activities have related only to acting as an investment and financing holding company. The registered name of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Bellis Acquisition Company plc, and it was incorporated on September 3, 2020 under registration number 12855280 and re-registered as a public limited company on December 18, 2020 for the purpose of consummating the LBO Acquisition Transactions. Its registered and its principal place of business is Asda House, Great Wilson Street, Leeds, England, LS11 5AD, United Kingdom. The current directors of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer are Mohsin Issa CBE (appointed on January 15, 2021), Zuber Vali Issa CBE (appointed on September 3, 2020), and their business address is Asda House, Great Wilson Street, Leeds, England, LS11 5AD, United Kingdom. The Group is not aware of any conflicts of interest between any duties or private interests of its directors and those duties they owe to us and no sums have been paid or have been agreed to be paid to any director to induce them to become or qualify them as a director, or otherwise for services rendered by the director in connection with this offer. The secretary of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Helen Kathryn Selby of Asda House, Great Wilson Street, Leeds, England, LS11 5AD, United Kingdom. The authorised share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is £50,000 divided into 50,000 ordinary shares of £1.00 each of which 50,000 shares are issued and held by the Senior Notes Issuer. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating activities of its own and no business operations, and its primary assets relate to its shares in Acquisition 2 and its primary liabilities relate to inter-group balances with the Senior Notes Issuer, commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the issuance of the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the guarantees of the Existing Senior Notes and the Transactions. 196 -----

The issued share capital of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited consists of ordinary shares, senior shares and a special participation share. The following table sets forth certain beneficial ownership information regarding holders of the shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited and the percentage owned by each shareholder.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsubsection Text: Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger of their UK-based Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP’s EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was established. The business, globally headquartered in Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery & merchandise and foodservice offer across the United Kingdom and Ireland, the USA, continental Europe and Australia. The Issa Brothers were honoured as Commanders of the Order of the British Empire by Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II in her Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution to business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom. TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over €15.0 billion of committed capital across four European buyout funds. Founded in 2002, TDR Capital LLP has been creating value by applying a high-impact approach to investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven value-based and operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and operating professionals from its single office in London. TDR’s strong returns have been driven by combining ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital preservation. TDR 201 ----- Capital LLP takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional support. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, TDR has invested in 25 portfolio companies across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors. Walmart Inc. is a people-led, technology-powered omni-channel retailer dedicated to helping people around the world save money and live better - anytime and anywhere - by providing the opportunity to shop in retail stores and through eCommerce, and to access our other service offerings. Each week, Walmart serves over 240 million customers who visit approximately 10,500 stores and numerous eCommerce websites in 19 countries. Walmart is engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S., Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China, India and Mexico.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsubsection Text: On February 12, 2021, Able Holdings Limited (a company owned by Zuber Vali Issa CBE and Mohsin Issa CBE), Optima Group S.à r.l., Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco entered into a shareholders’ agreement (the “Shareholders’ Agreement”), which governed various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco in relation to their direct shareholding in Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco and indirect shareholding in the Group. On December 31, 2021, Able Holdings Limited, Optima Group S.à r.l., Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco entered into a Deed of Amendment relating to the Shareholders’ Agreement (as amended, the “Amended and

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Restated Shareholders’ Agreement”), to reflect the fact that Property Newco had become a wholly-owned
Subsubsection Text: subsidiary of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Amended and Restated Shareholders’ Agreement, to which Property Newco is not a party, governs the various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo Limited in relation to their direct shareholding in Bellis TopCo Limited and indirect shareholding in the Group. Pursuant to the Amended and Restated Shareholders’ Agreement, Able Holdings Limited (the “Individual

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Investors Shareholder”), on the one hand, and Optima Group S.à r.l. (the “TDR Shareholder”), on the other hand,
Subsubsection Text: is entitled to appoint or remove directors in certain circumstances. The Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder is each entitled to appoint and remove (i) two members of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited so long as such shareholder, together with its affiliates, hold 35% or more of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited, or (ii) one member of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited so long as such shareholders, together with its affiliates, hold between 15% and 35% of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited. The maximum number of directors for the board of Bellis TopCo Limited will be five and, subject to certain actions which required the consent of the Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder, as summarised below, all decisions of the board of directors may be made by a majority of the votes cast. The Amended and Restated Shareholders’ Agreement provides that certain actions in relation to the Group may not be taken without the consent of both the Individual Investors Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by it) and the TDR Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by it). These include amendments to the organisational documents of any member of the Group, variations to the rights attaching to the shares in any member of the Group, the declaration or payment of any dividend or distribution by any Group company (other than to Bellis TopCo Limited or another Group company which is wholly-owned by Bellis TopCo Limited), a material change in the nature or scope of the Group’s business and the winding-up or dissolution of Bellis TopCo Limited, any of its subsidiaries or any other Group company. The Shareholders’ Agreement contains certain restrictions on the transfer by the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder of its shares in Bellis TopCo Limited or any other member of the Group, including (other than transfers to certain permitted transferees, including affiliates) an obligation to first offer any shares to the other shareholder before offering them for sale to a third party. At any time on or after the third anniversary of the LBO Acquisition Completion Date and prior to the fifth anniversary of LBO Acquisition Completion Date, either the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder may propose an exit event involving the Bellis Group and the Group, including the sale of shares in Bellis TopCo Limited; the sale by Bellis TopCo Limited or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of the Group’s business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo Limited or any other 202 ----- Group company which owns substantially all of the assets of the Group at the time; and the winding up of Bellis TopCo Limited, in each case on specified terms and subject to the occurrence of certain conditions (an “Exit”). The recipient of such proposal regarding an Exit shall consider such proposal in good faith, but shall not be obliged to accept such proposal. At any time on or following the fifth anniversary of the LBO Acquisition Completion Date either the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder may propose an Exit involving the Bellis Group and the Group. The recipient of such proposal shall be required to accept such proposal provided that certain conditions are satisfied.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Walmart Senior Shares and Special Participation Share
Subsubsection Text: On the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, Bellis TopCo Limited and Global Pinnacle Corporation (among others) entered into a shareholders’ agreement (the “Topco 2 Shareholders’

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: Agreement”), which governs various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited in relation to their direct
Subsubsection Text: shareholding in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited and indirect shareholding in the Group. On June 16, 2021, Global Pinnacle Corporation transferred its shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited to Bellis Holding LLC (“BHL”) and BHL adhered to the TopCo 2 Shareholders’ Agreement. The terms of the Topco 2 Shareholders’ Agreement provide for BHL to hold two classes of shares: (i) the Senior Shares; and (ii) the Special Participation Share. Unless otherwise agreed between the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (or where such transfer is made to a permitted transferee in accordance with the terms of the TopCo 2 Shareholders’ Agreement or with the consent of the shareholders), neither the Special Participation Share nor any of the Senior Shares may be transferred to any person unless there is a simultaneous transfer of all of the Senior Shares and the Special Participation Share to the same transferee. Pursuant to the TopCo 2 Shareholders’ Agreement, BHL, as holder of the Senior Shares, is entitled to appoint or remove one director to or from the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (the “Senior Shareholder Director”). The holder of the Senior Shares will have no voting rights as shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, other than in relation to certain matters that would materially adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Senior Shares. The holders of the Senior Shares have the right to receive an annual fixed cumulative senior dividend. Such dividend is payable on the principal amount of the Senior Shares plus accrued but unpaid dividends. Bellis TopCo 2 Limited may elect to pay such dividend in cash or for such dividend to accrue unpaid. The Senior Shares will be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited upon the occurrence of certain events, including upon an exit event involving Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. Such exit events include: the sale of the ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited; the sale by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of the Group’s business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of all or substantially all of the ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, of all or substantially all shares in any other Group company representing all or substantially all of the Group’s business, assets and undertaking or of all or substantially all of the shares of any company which is a direct or indirect holder of all or substantially all ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited; or a change of control of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Senior Shares will further be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited on the seventh anniversary of the issuance of the Senior Shares, being February 16, 2028. The expected repayment amount that would be required to be made in cash to Walmart by Bellis TopCo 2 on February 16, 2028, including any accrued and unpaid interest, is approximately £900 million. Bellis TopCo 2 Limited may voluntarily redeem the Senior Shares at any time subject to paying a make-whole amount. Pursuant to the Topco 2 Shareholders’ Agreement, BHL, in its capacity as holder of the Special Participation Share, has no right to appoint or remove directors to the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, but will have the right to appoint a board observer if no Senior Shareholder Director has been appointed. The holder of the Special Participation Share, in its capacity as holder of the Special Participation Share, has no voting rights as a shareholder of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, other than in relation to matters that would materially adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Special Participation Share. The holder of the Special Participation Share has the right to participate in 10% of any dividends paid by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited to the ordinary shareholders and any exit proceeds payable to the ordinary shareholders. On the occurrence of a public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, the holder of the Special Participation Share will have the right to redeem the Special Participation Share at a price equal to 10% of the listing 203 ----- value of the fully diluted issued share capital of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited following the completion of such public offering, subject to a minimum hurdle amount. 204 -----

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsubsection Text: All of the outstanding shares of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer are held by the Senior Notes Issuer. All of the outstanding shares of the Senior Notes Issuer are held by Bellis Midco 4 Limited, all of the outstanding ordinary shares of which are held by Bellis Midco 2 Limited. Bellis Midco 4 Limited is indirectly owned by Bellis TopCo Limited, a company that is 50% owned by Able Holdings Limited (a company jointly owned by Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Issa CBE) and 50% owned by funds managed by TDR Capital LLP (via Optima Group S.à r.l.). The shareholders are involved in active discussions regarding Zuber Issa ceasing to continue as a shareholder of the Group and disposal of his 50% ownership in Able Holdings Limited. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Strategic _Discussions Regarding Shareholder Changes.”_ Bellis TopCo Limited was incorporated in Jersey on September 4, 2020, and its registered office is at PO Box 536, 13-14 Esplanade, St. Helier, Jersey, JE4 5UR. The issued share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited consists of ordinary shares. The following table sets forth certain beneficial ownership information regarding holders of the shares in Bellis TopCo Limited and the percentage owned by each shareholder as of the date of this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Transactions** **Related to the EG UK Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: On May 30, 2023, EG Group (contracting by EG Finco Limited) (“EG”) announced its binding agreement to sell a substantial majority of its fuel, foodservice and grocery and merchandise business in the United Kingdom to Asda, by way of a corporate sale and subject to various adjustments and agreement upon a precise transaction perimeter. Following discussions between Asda and EG on the perimeter of the EG UK Acquisition and discussions with relevant brand partners, EG and Asda agreed that EG’s franchise businesses carried on under the Starbucks brand and the KFC brand in the United Kingdom and Ireland (the “Starbucks Business” and the “KFC Business,” respectively), together with their employees, would not transfer to Asda as part of the EG UK Acquisition. As a result of these discussions, the EG UK Acquisition was completed on October 31, 2023 for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion. On the EG UK Completion Date, EG Group (using EG Corporate Services Limited) entered into a transitional services agreement with Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited (together with its subsidiaries, the “Acquired EG UK Target

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Group”), pursuant to which EG agreed to continue to provide access to or cover the costs of all centralised shared
Subsubsection Text: services (such as IT, HR, accounting, payroll, compliance and tax functions), that were, in the 12 months prior to completion of the EG UK Acquisition, provided to the Acquired EG UK Target Group by EG, for a transitional period (the “EG TSA”). The initial term of the EG TSA is for a period of up to two years from the EG UK Completion Date, subject to certain rights for the Acquired EG UK Target Group to terminate, or transition away from, services early or to extend the initial term for an aggregate period of up to a further 12 months (in 3 months increments). During the term of the EG TSA, EG will also provide certain of the IT services that will continue to be provided to the Acquired EG UK Target Group to Asda, for the benefit of certain other convenience retail sites that Asda and its affiliates own from time to time, including those branded as “Asda Express.” The services provided by EG to the Acquired EG UK Target Group will be deemed to be subject to a service credit for the first two years of the EG TSA, as a result of which the Acquired EG UK Target Group will not be required to make any payment to EG for the services (subject to certain limited exceptions) and thereafter will be provided for a fee based on the actual cost to EG of providing the services, plus an agreed margin that will be applied to any non-third party costs. The services provided to Asda in respect of convenience retail sites that are not part of the Acquired EG UK Target Group will be provided for a fee payable to EG based on the actual cost to EG of providing the services, plus an agreed margin that will be applied to non-third party costs. EG’s liability for provision of the services will be subject to limitations customary for an agreement of this nature, including an annual financial cap on EG’s liability of £12.2 million for most liabilities. In connection with such transitional arrangements, and as further consideration for the EG UK Acquisition, EG also agreed to cover certain other centralised costs, including redundancy costs, and integration costs during the transitional period. The EG Seller has provided certain guarantees in favour of entities transferred to Asda as part of the EG UK Acquisition, or to the Purchaser, in respect of the obligations of EG under: (i) the EG TSA; and (ii) certain business sale agreements entered into by certain transferred entities and members of EG in connection with reorganisations effected prior to completion of the EG UK Acquisition. On the EG UK Completion Date, the EG Seller and Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited also entered into a transitional brand licence agreement which took effect immediately following the EG UK Completion Date (the “EG Brand Licence Agreement”). Pursuant to the EG Brand Licence Agreement, EG granted the Acquired EG UK Target Group a non-exclusive right to use certain of EG’s brands, including the ‘EG’ and ‘Euro Garages’ brands, for a period of three years, royalty free, to allow the Acquired EG UK Target Group to rebrand its sites and businesses (subject to earlier termination rights). Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited will have a right to extend the term of the brand licence for a further two years, in increments of 12 months at a time, if it has not completed this debranding process by the end of the expiry of the initial three-year term, subject to the parties agreeing a royalty fee for the use of such brands during such extension. On May 30, 2023, the EG Seller, the America Purchaser and Asda Stores Limited entered into a side letter in connection with the electric vehicle charger business, which is part of EG’s retained UK&I business (the “EVPoint

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Side Letter”). Under the EVPoint Side Letter, the EG Seller, the America Purchaser and Asda have documented their
Subsubsection Text: intention that EV Point Services Limited (a subsidiary of EG) or an affiliate will be appointed as sole provider, operator 205 ----- and installer of electric vehicle charging points at Asda sites (including the sites held by the Acquired EG UK Target Group) and have agreed to use reasonable endeavours to agree the terms and conditions of such appointment including the terms of a framework agreement under which that appointment will be documented following completion of the EG UK Acquisition. The EVPoint Side Letter will (in addition to certain earlier termination rights and events) terminate if the framework agreement has not been entered into by the date falling 24 months from completion of the EG UK Acquisition. Commercial discussions remain ongoing. The EG Seller and the America Purchaser are in discussions regarding the terms on which EG will, in respect of its retained UK&I business, occupy sites that are owned by the Group, or the Group will occupy sites that are owned by EG, including sites where the operations of EG’s retained UK&I business and the Acquired EG UK Target Group are co-located. This will include rights of occupation in respect of sites on which electric vehicle charging points, including ‘evpoint’-branded chargers, have, prior to completion of the EG UK Acquisition, been installed by EG and certain lease arrangements relating to the Starbucks Business and the KFC Business.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Under the terms of the TMA, Walmart, as licensor, granted Asda Stores Limited a licence to continue to use certain of Walmart’s trade marks, domain names and brand-related intellectual property. The scope of the TMA includes licences of the George, Scan & Go, Smart Price and Rollback trade marks, certain domain names, including George.com, as well as certain other Walmart-owned trade mark rights used by a member of the Asda Group between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date (the “Licensed IP”). The TMA permits Asda Stores Limited to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted sub-licensees, including members of the Asda Group, existing franchisees to which Asda Stores Limited has granted a licence of the Licensed IP under franchise agreements in place as at the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement and certain specified companies that are also owned by the shareholders or funds managed by TDR Capital LLP, provided Walmart is given written notice and the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms that are no less onerous than the TMA. Additionally, Walmart cannot unreasonably withhold, delay or condition consent for Asda Stores Limited to sub-license the Licensed IP to certain other entities including those that are controlled by the shareholders of Asda Stores Limited’s ultimate holding company, provided that the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms no less onerous that the TMA. Manufacturing or packaging of goods bearing the Licensed IP may take place worldwide. The scope of the licence for sale, marketing and distribution purposes is the United Kingdom only (on an exclusive basis) and, for the George brand only, also specified countries in Europe as set out in the TMA (on a non-exclusive basis). These licences are perpetual and irrevocable, subject to the termination rights summarised below. The TMA includes a non-exclusive licence to use the George brand in substantially the same way as the brand was used immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement in certain territories outside the United Kingdom and the specified European countries in which Asda Stores Limited has been selling George-branded goods under a specified third-party e-commerce fulfilment contract immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement (the “George RoW

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: On February 16, 2021, in connection with the LBO Acquisition, Walmart (and its affiliates) and the LBO Seller entered into several transitional agreements with Asda Group, Asda Stores Limited and the LBO Purchaser. Those agreements included, amongst others, a trade mark agreement (the “TMA”) and a transitional services agreement (the “TSA”) entered into between Asda Stores Limited and Walmart. The LBO Seller, the LBO Purchaser and Walmart (among others) further entered into a transitional pensions deed (the “TPD”). The TMA, the TSA and the TPD are referred to collectively in this Offering Memorandum as the “Transitional Agreements.”

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Licence”). All use of the Licensed IP (other than use of the George mark in the United Kingdom) is to be in the same
Subsubsection Text: Under the TSA, Walmart provides certain information technology services to Asda Stores Limited on a transitional basis with effect from the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. The services comprise all information technology and telecommunications services (and related operational system processes) that Walmart Group Companies provided to the Asda Group in the 12 months prior to the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, and each such service is to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of Asda Stores Limited from Walmart; and (ii) termination of the TSA in accordance with its terms by one of the parties (as summarised below). The services are arranged into six categories (referred to as “service towers,” which relate to stores, supply chain, merchandising, back office, e-commerce and infrastructure/security) for charging and migration purposes. Asda Stores Limited has the right to terminate any service tower, or the TSA in its entirety, on three months’ notice. In addition, either party has the right to terminate the TSA following the insolvency of its counterparty or a 207 ----- material breach of the terms of the TSA (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent applicable). In addition, Asda Stores Limited has the right to request a “Change Freeze” which it did in respect of five of the six service towers from May 1, 2021, and in respect of the sixth tower (e-commerce) from 2023. This means that Asda ceases to benefit from changes and a change request service that it would otherwise receive on Walmart’s group operating model (this is not defined but really is benchmarked by the service Asda has received to date). From the freeze, Walmart has absolute discretion to reject any “Change Requests” made by Asda in relation to a “frozen” service tower unless that change relates to a “Mandatory Change” (i.e., a change in relevant Regulations or a change required for compliance or security reasons) or a usage change. The TSA includes customary warranties concerning the corporate existence and capacity of the parties and an undertaking to provide information and participate in discussions in connection with the delivery of the services. Walmart agrees to provide each service to a standard and in a manner that is consistent with Walmart’s provision of the equivalent service in the 12 months prior to the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. Walmart is not required to provide the services to, or to meet, any more onerous standard or service level. Walmart is required to use reasonable endeavours to obtain and maintain third-party consents that are required for the provision of the services. Where a third-party consent is not obtained or maintained, Walmart is not required to provide the relevant service (and the TSA will terminate in respect of the relevant service without liability on the part of Walmart) and the parties will work together to agree a workaround (including replacement, in-sourcing or early migration) in order to enable Asda Stores Limited to continue to receive the benefit of the affected service. All reasonable one-off or ongoing costs of obtaining and maintaining third-party consents or implementing workarounds are to be borne by Asda Stores Limited, subject to Walmart consulting with Asda Stores Limited before incurring these costs. Asda Stores Limited and Walmart have a separation plan in place and the separation costs (excluding internal costs of the Walmart Group) are borne by Asda Stores Limited. The charges for the TSA services for the first year following the LBO Acquisition Completion Date were initially capped at £142 million (excluding any VAT), and the cap on service charges subsequently rises by 1% per year thereafter. The charges payable for services in subsequent years are equal to the charges for such services for the previous contract year (subject to any reduction as summarised below) subject to an inflationary increase of 2% per year. The charges per service tower are split on a fixed cost and variable cost basis. The variable proportion of the charges reduce to the extent that Asda Stores Limited is able to achieve certain agreed milestones in its separation plan and ramp down usage of the relevant service tower. The initial terms of the TSA stated that for any service to be provided beyond a long stop date of three years from the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, being February 2024, the charges for any remaining services will ratchet up by 10% every six months (the “TSA Ratchet”). However, we have received a deferral of the TSA Ratchet until February 16, 2025. If we have not substantially completed Project Future by February 16, 2025, Walmart may be entitled to back-charge us any TSA Ratchet payments that would have been due under the original terms of the TSA after February 2024. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Acquisitions—Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation process, particularly system cutovers, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives.”_ The liability of the parties under the TSA is limited, where service-specific, to the amount of fees paid or payable in respect of the relevant service tower during the relevant contract year. In the case of liabilities that are not related to a specific service tower, the liability of the parties under the TSA is limited to the total amount of fees paid or payable during the relevant contract year. Each party’s aggregate liability for each contract year is limited to the amount of fees paid or payable during the relevant contract year. These limitations are subject to limited exceptions, including in the case of fraud. Neither party is liable for any indirect or consequential losses or loss of profit or loss of revenue and, to the extent Walmart’s breach is caused by a third-party default, Walmart’s maximum liability to Asda Stores Limited is limited to the amount that Walmart can recover from the third party (or an equitable proportion thereof to reflect the loss suffered by the Asda Group as compared to the Walmart Group). Walmart is not liable to Asda Stores Limited to the extent the relevant liability is caused by a failure on the part of the Asda Group to perform its obligations under the TSA. 208 -----

Subsubsection Text: Under the TPD, the LBO Seller indemnifies the LBO Purchaser in respect of any losses incurred by Asda in respect of the Asda Group Pension Scheme, subject to certain exclusions including that the indemnity will not apply if the losses arise from a voluntary act by Bellis TopCo Limited (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited), including failure by Asda to comply with its obligations under the documentation governing the Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In. Walmart is party to the TPD and guarantees the obligations of the LBO Seller in respect of this indemnity. The LBO Purchaser and Bellis TopCo Limited indemnify Asda and Walmart in respect of any losses incurred by either of them in respect of the Asda Group Pension Scheme if the losses arise from, broadly, a voluntary act by Bellis TopCo Limited (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited), including failure by Asda to comply with its obligations under the documentation governing the Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In. Liability under both indemnity arrangements terminates on the later of: (i) three years after completion of the buyout of the Asda Group Pension Scheme; (ii) the date of completion of the winding-up of the Asda Group Pension Scheme; or (iii) (in respect of losses relate to tax only) five years after the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. As part of the arrangements in respect of the buy-in of the Asda Group Pension Scheme Asda Stores Limited agreed to make a loan facility available to the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme. Under the TPD, in the event that a funding obligation arises under the loan facility which Asda is unable to satisfy, Walmart Inc agrees to use reasonable endeavours to provide short-term funding to Asda to allow Asda to meet the funding obligation. A buy-out of the Asda Group Pension Scheme was executed on July 9, 2021 which extinguished the Group’s responsibility to fund the Asda Group Pension Scheme as sponsoring employer. See “Management’s Discussion & Analysis—Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In.”

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Licence”). All use of the Licensed IP (other than use of the George mark in the United Kingdom) is to be in the same
Subsubsection Text: manner and style of usage as used between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, except in respect of the George RoW Licence and licence of the Walmart spark logo, which must be used in the same way as such branding was used immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date respectively. In addition, the TMA includes an exclusive, royalty-free licence from Asda Stores Limited to Walmart of the Extra Special brand (that is owned by Asda) to enable Walmart to continue selling, marketing and distributing products sold by Walmart under such brand on a perpetual and irrevocable basis in specified countries in Central America and 206 ----- in Mexico. The licence to Walmart of the Asda Stores Limited brand referred to above is subject to similar sub-licensing and termination provisions as the licence to Asda Stores Limited of Licensed IP. Asda Stores Limited is not required to pay any royalties in respect of the above licence of the George brand (other than George RoW Licence), the licences of the Scan & Go, Rollback and Smart Price brands or the transitional licence of the Walmart spark logo and “Save Money Live Better” (other than a nominal £1 royalty fee). The George RoW Licence is royalty-free for up to 12 months and thereafter subject to an annual royalty of 2% of the Net Sales Revenue in the relevant territory. In respect of all other Licensed IP, Asda Stores Limited is required to pay an annual royalty equal to 3.5% of the net sales revenue received by Asda Stores Limited and any sub-licensees in connection with the use of such Licensed IP. The TMA includes restrictions and quality control covenants from Asda Stores Limited including ensuring that the products sold by Asda Stores Limited under the Licensed IP maintain certain standards, complying with brand guidelines in relation to visual style and formatting and limiting Asda Stores Limited’s use of the Licensed IP and its ability to register the Licensed IP. These covenants include not committing or knowingly omitting acts which would bring the Licensed IP into disrepute or damage, or weaken or be detrimental to the Licensed IP in any material respect. Asda Stores Limited is also prevented from maintaining an online or e-commerce presence of any of the businesses (excluding the George business in the United Kingdom) in respect of which the Licensed IP is permitted to be used except in substantially the same manner and to substantially the same extent as the presence those businesses had in the period between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date (or in respect of the George RoW Licence, immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement). Asda Stores Limited is also expected to indemnify the Walmart Group against any losses resulting from use of the Licensed IP in material breach of the TMA and losses related to actual or alleged defect in products or services using the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback branding), recalls of defective products and actual or alleged mislabelling or food safety issues related to the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback brands). There is no cap on Asda Stores Limited’s liability under these indemnities or limit on the heads of loss recoverable. The TMA includes warranties on the corporate existence and capacity of the parties to enter into the TMA but no other warranties or representations (and any implied warranties, terms or conditions implied by statute or common law are excluded to the fullest extent permitted by law). The term of the TMA is perpetual (other than: (i) the George RoW Licence, which Walmart may terminate on a per country or per goods/services basis where Walmart itself intends to use or authorise the use of the relevant Licensed IP in that country (or if required by law), and (ii) in respect of the transitional licences described above). Either party is able to terminate the licences granted to Asda Stores Limited under the TMA on a per-licence basis following the insolvency of its counterparty or a material breach or repeated non-material breaches of the terms of the TMA (in respect of the relevant licence and/or the relevant Licensed IP) (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent applicable). Walmart also has the right to terminate the licences granted to Asda Stores Limited under the TMA on a per-licence basis if Asda Stores Limited challenges the validity of the relevant Licensed IP or following certain change of control events, or with respect to specific trade marks or specific categories or sub-categories of goods or services on 30 days’ notice if the relevant Licensed IP is not put to material use for a period of two years. Asda Stores Limited, but not Walmart, is permitted to terminate the licences granted to Asda Stores Limited under the TMA at any time without cause subject to a three-month notice period. The licence to Walmart of Asda-owned brands is separately terminable, under similar terms.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On February 24, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer issued £2,250 million in aggregate principal amount of 3.25% Senior Secured Notes due 2026 (the “Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes”). The Existing Senior Secured Notes are governed by the indenture dated as of February 24, 2021, governing the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, as amended from time to time (the “Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes Indenture”). The Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes mature on February 16, 2026. On November 5, 2021, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer issued £500 million in aggregate principal amount of 4.500% Senior Secured Notes due 2026 (the “Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes,” and together with the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes, the “Existing Senior Secured Notes”). The Existing Senior Secured Notes are governed by the indenture dated as of November 5, 2021, governing the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes, as amended from time to time (the “Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes Indenture” and together with the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the “Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures”). The Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes mature on February 16, 2026. The Existing Senior Secured Notes are guaranteed by the Guarantors on a senior basis. The Existing Senior Secured Notes and the guarantees thereof are, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, secured by first-priority security interests over the Collateral (as defined in the applicable Existing Senior Secured Notes Indenture). At any time prior to February 24, 2023, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or, from time to time, a part of the outstanding Existing Senior Secured Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable redemption date, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium. At any time prior to February 24, 2023, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes (including the principal amount of any additional Existing Senior Secured Notes), with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of 103.25% of the principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable redemption date; provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the principal amount of the original principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes (including the principal amount of any additional Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) remains outstanding. At any time prior to February 24, 2023, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes (including the principal amount of any additional Existing Senior Secured Notes), with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of 104.500% of the principal amount of the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable redemption date; provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the principal amount of the original principal amount of the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes (including the principal amount of any additional Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes) remains outstanding. At any time prior to February 24, 2023, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, on one or more occasions during each 12-month period, up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Existing Senior Secured Notes outstanding (including the principal amount of any additional Existing Senior Secured Notes outstanding) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Existing Senior Secured Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including the redemption date. 210 ----- At any time on or after February 24, 2023, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes at the redemption prices set forth below:

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: 2023 101.625% 2024 100.813% 2025, and thereafter 100.000% At any time on or after February 24, 2023, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes at the redemption prices set forth below: 2023 101.250% 2024 100.125% 2025, and thereafter 100.000% In connection with any tender offer for the Existing Senior Secured Notes (including any Change of Control Offer or Asset Disposition Offer (each as defined in the applicable Existing Senior Secured Notes Indenture)), if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the outstanding Existing Senior Secured Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Existing Senior Secured Notes in such tender offer and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, purchases all of the Existing Senior Secured Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, all of the holders of the Existing Senior Secured Notes will be deemed to have consented to such tender or other offer and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Existing Senior Secured Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price (excluding any early tender fee) offered to each other holder of Existing Senior Secured Notes in such tender offer. Upon the occurrence of certain defined events constituting a change of control, each holder of the Existing Senior Secured Notes may require the Senior Secured Notes Issuer to repurchase all or a portion of its Existing Senior Secured Notes at a price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. The Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures provide for covenants and events of default that are consistent with the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. The Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures are governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Existing Senior Secured Notes are listed and admitted to dealing on the Official List of the Exchange. As described in “Use of Proceeds”, to the extent not used to repurchase and cancel Existing Senior Secured Notes in connection with the Richmond Tender Offer, prepay and cancel the Original Facility B in full and pay the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions, we intend to hold the New Financing Proceeds on balance sheet (in cash or cash equivalents) until applied to repay any Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, as applicable, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which were not targeted under the Richmond Tender Offer, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes will remain outstanding following the Transactions.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On February 24, 2021, the Senior Notes Issuer issued £500 million in aggregate principal amount of 4.00% Senior Notes due 2027 (the “Existing Senior Notes”). The Existing Senior Notes are governed by the Existing Senior Notes Indenture. The Existing Senior Notes mature on February 16, 2027. 211 ----- The Existing Senior Notes are guaranteed by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Guarantors on a senior subordinated basis. The Existing Senior Notes and the guarantees thereof are, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, secured by (i) first-priority security interests over (a) all the issued capital stock of the Senior Notes Issuer, (b) the material intra-group receivables owing by the Senior Notes Issuer to Bellis Midco 4 Limited and (c) the Senior Notes Issuer’s material bank accounts located in England and Wales, and (ii) second-priority interests in the Shared Security. At any time prior to February 24, 2023, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or, from time to time, a part of the outstanding Existing Senior Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable redemption date, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium. At any time prior to February 24, 2023, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Existing Senior Notes (including the principal amount of any additional Existing Senior Notes), with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of 104.00% of the principal amount of the Existing Senior Notes redeemed; provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the principal amount of the original principal amount of the Existing Senior Notes (including the principal amount of any additional Existing Senior Notes) remains outstanding. At any time on or after February 24, 2023, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Existing Senior Notes at the redemption prices set forth below:
