Subsubsection Text: relevant hedge counterparty), on a pro rata basis and ranking pari passu between paragraphs (A) and (B) above, or, if the Super Senior Discharge Date has occurred, for application towards the discharge of: (1) the Senior Lender Liabilities and liabilities to arrangers thereof; (2) the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities; (3) the Cash Management Facility Liabilities; and (4) the Hedging Liabilities which are not Super Senior Hedging Liabilities, on a pro rata basis and ranking pari passu between paragraphs (A), (B), (C) and (D) above; (i) if the Designation Date has not occurred, for application towards the discharge of: 242 ----- (1) the Senior Lender Liabilities and liabilities to arrangers thereof; (2) the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities; (3) the Cash Management Facility Liabilities; and (4) the Hedging Liabilities, on a pro rata basis and ranking pari passu between paragraphs (A), (B), (C) and (D) above; (ii) for application towards the discharge of (x) the Second Lien Lender Liabilities and liabilities to arrangers thereof, and (y) the Second Lien Notes Liabilities, on a pro rata basis and ranking pari _passu between themselves;_ (iii) solely to the extent such proceeds are from the realisation or enforcement of the Topco Shared Security and any guarantees provided by a Topco Guarantor that is a member of the Group or Third-Party Security Provider in respect of the Topco Liabilities, for application towards the discharge of (A) the Topco Facility Liabilities and liabilities to arrangers thereof, and (B) the Topco Notes Liabilities, on a pro rata basis and ranking pari passu between themselves; (iv) if none of the Debtors or Third-Party Security Providers is under any further actual or contingent liability under any Debt Document relating to the Senior Secured Liabilities, the Second Lien Liabilities or the Topco Liabilities, in payment to any other person whom the Security Agent is obliged to pay in priority to any Debtor or Third-Party Security Provider; and (v) the balance, if any, in payment to the relevant Debtor, _provided_ _that, all amounts from time to time received or recovered by the Security Agent from or in respect_ of a Topco Borrower pursuant to the terms of any Debt Document (other than in connection with the realisation or enforcement of the Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security) shall be held by the Security Agent on trust to apply at any time as the Security Agent sees fit, in the following order of priority: (1) in accordance with paragraph (i) above; (B) in accordance with paragraph (ii) above; (2) in accordance with paragraphs (iii), (iv), (v) and (vi) above (in each case only to the extent there are liabilities due from the relevant Topco Borrower to such creditors); (3) if none of the Debtors is under any further actual or contingent liability under any Secured Debt Document, in payment to any other person whom the Security Agent is obliged to pay in priority to any Debtor or Third-Party Security Provider; and (4) the balance, if any, in payment to the relevant Debtor. _Order of Application—Topco Independent Transaction Security_ Subject to certain provisions set out in the Intercreditor Agreement, all amounts from time to time received or recovered by the Security Agent pursuant to the terms of any Topco Finance Document in connection with the realisation or enforcement of Topco Independent Transaction Security or any guarantees provided by a Topco Guarantor (other than a member of the Group) (the “Topco Recoveries”) shall be applied at any time as the Security Agent sees fit, in the following order of priority: (i) in discharging any sums owed to the Security Agent and any receiver or delegate, on a pari passu basis, and then any Agent Liabilities in respect of the Topco Liabilities (to the extent related to such Topco Recoveries), on a pari passu basis; (ii) in payment of all costs and expenses incurred by any agent or Topco Creditor in connection with any realisation or enforcement of the Topco Independent Transaction Security taken in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement or any action taken at the request of the Security Agent 243 ----- under the Intercreditor Agreement; (iii) for application towards the discharge of: (1) the Topco Facility Liabilities; and (2) the Topco Notes Liabilities, on a pro rata basis and ranking pari passu between paragraphs (A) and (B) above; (iv) if none of the Debtors or Third-Party Security Providers or Topco Independent Obligors is under any further actual or contingent liability in respect of the Secured Liabilities, in payment to any other person whom the Security Agent is obliged to pay in priority to any Debtor or Third-Party Security Provider; and (v) the balance, if any, in payment to the relevant Debtor.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On May 28, 2021, Asda Group Limited executed a reimbursement agreement (the “Chubb Reimbursement

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Agreement”) with Chubb European Group SE (“Chubb”) in connection with deductibles payable by Asda Group
Subsubsection Text: Limited from time to time under an insurance policy provided by Chubb to Asda Group Limited with respect to employer liability, general liability and certain motor claims. The Chubb Reimbursement Agreement was effective as of May 1, 2021 (the “Commencement Date”) and covers losses incurred under the insurance policy from May 1, 2004, the first date of coverage, onward. The Chubb Reimbursement Agreement required Asda Group Limited to provide, within 30 days of the Commencement Date, security with respect to the payment of its obligations thereunder in the form, initially, of a £30,000,000 letter of credit facility and a £19,000,000 surety bond. Chubb may require Asda Group Limited to adjust, with 30 days’ notice, the amount of the letter of credit if Chubb determines, in its sole discretion, that such adjustment 246 ----- is necessary to secure Asda Group Limited’s outstanding obligations under the Chubb Reimbursement Agreement. As of December 31, 2023, the liability was reduced to £34,100,000 supported by letters of credit provided by Rabobank (£14.1 million) and RBS NatWest (£20 million) with a renewal date of June 30, 2024. The Chubb Reimbursement Agreement has no fixed term. It can be terminated by either party upon 30 days’ notice, subject to the survival of the provisions of the agreement until all liabilities thereunder have been fully discharged.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with its obligations under the Chubb Reimbursement Agreement, on May 20, 2021, Asda Group Limited entered into an uncommitted letter of credit facility agreement with National Westminster Bank Plc (“NatWest”) (the “NatWest Letter of Credit Facility Agreement”) pursuant to which NatWest issued a standby letter of credit facility of up to an aggregate limit of £30,000,000 in favour of Chubb on behalf of Asda Group Limited (the “NatWest Letter of Credit Facility”). In August 2023, the amount available under the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility in favour of Chubb, on behalf of Asda Group Limited, was reduced to an aggregate limit of £20,000,000. Asda Group Limited pays a commission on the maximum liability under the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility at a rate of 2.20% per year (or such other rate as agreed between Asda Group Limited and NatWest from time to time). The NatWest Letter of Credit Facility has no fixed term. Either party may cancel the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility Agreement at any time, with 10 days’ prior notice being required should the cancellation right be exercised by NatWest. In connection with the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility, on May 20, 2021, Asda Group Limited provided a counter indemnity in favour of NatWest (the “NatWest Counter Indemnity”) pursuant to which, among other things: (i) Asda Group Limited agreed that at all times while NatWest’s commitments under the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility remain in place, it will keep NatWest indemnified in respect of all losses, costs and liabilities that NatWest may sustain or incur in connection with any failure by Asda Group Limited to comply with its obligations or any non-payment under the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility; and (ii) Asda Group Limited agreed to pay NatWest on demand any amounts due from Asda Group Limited to NatWest with, in the event that Asda Group Limited does not maintain an account with NatWest from which NatWest can elect to debit such amounts, interest of 3.00% per year above NatWest’s base rate from the date of demand, compounded monthly. Should the credit rating of Asda Group Limited fall below BB- (according to Fitch) or Ba3 (according to Moody’s), NatWest has the right to demand payment on account or cash collateral to cover all or part of the obligations of Asda Group Limited under the NatWest Counter Indemnity. The NatWest Counter Indemnity has no fixed term. NatWest acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Cash Management Facility Lender and the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility was designated a Cash Management Facility under the Intercreditor Agreement on May 20, 2021. Consequently, the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility constitutes a Senior Finance Document under the Intercreditor Agreement and is secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes on the Collateral, and NatWest qualifies as a Senior Creditor under the Intercreditor Agreement. The NatWest Letter of Credit Facility is governed by English law. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the NatWest Letter of Credit Facility has been utilised in the amount of £20,194,194.80. In addition to the above, NatWest provided a separate cash pooling facility to Asda Group Limited and other members of the Group on April 8, 2021. Such facility has a gross limit of £100,000,000 and was guaranteed by certain members of the Group, but is otherwise unsecured.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On April 11, 2022, Asda Group Limited entered into an uncommitted letter of credit facility agreement with Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. trading as Rabobank London (“Rabobank”) (the “Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Agreement”) pursuant to which Rabobank issued a standby letter of credit facility up to an aggregate limit of
Subsubsection Text: 247 ----- £50,000,000 to support the liabilities of the Asda Group Limited group from time to time including with respect to certain insurance policy deductible liabilities and certain fuel contract purchase payment obligations (or as otherwise agreed between the Rabobank and Asda Group Limited from time to time) (the “Rabobank Letter of Credit

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: An issuance fee is payable by Asda Group Limited under the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility at a rate of 1.80% per year. The Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility has no fixed term. Either party may cancel the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility Agreement at any time, on no less than 5 business days’ prior notice to the other party. In connection with the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility, Asda Group Limited, provides Rabobank with an indemnity against any cost, loss or liability incurred by Rabobank in acting as the issuing bank under any letter of credit requested by (or on behalf of) Asda Group Limited. If a change of control has occurred, the Rabobank may by written notice to Asda Group Limited (i) cancel the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility whereupon the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility shall immediately be cancelled and no longer available for further utilisation; and (ii) promptly and, in any event, within 5 business days of the notice being received, require, at the option of Asda Group Limited either payment on account or cash collateral in the currency and face value of any letter of credit or an unconditional and irrevocable guarantee, indemnity, counter-indemnity or similar assurance against financial loss to be issued in respect of all amounts due under any letter of credit and the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility from a bank or financial institution which has a long term credit rating BBB- (according to Fitch) or Baa3 (according to Moody’s) or by any other institution satisfactory to the Rabobank. Rabobank acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Cash Management Facility Lender and the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility was designated a Cash Management Facility under the Intercreditor Agreement on April 11, 2022. Consequently, the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility constitutes a Senior Finance Document under the Intercreditor Agreement and is secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes on the Collateral, and Rabobank qualifies as a Senior Creditor under the Intercreditor Agreement. The Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility is governed by English law. On October 26, 2023, an irrevocable on demand guarantee was issued at the request of Asda Stores Limited with Esso Petroleum Company Limited as beneficiary (the “Esso Guarantee (Rabobank)”). The Esso Guarantee (Rabobank) became effective on the date of issuance and will remain effective until one year after the date of issuance at 5 PM Amsterdam time or such other expiry date agreed by Rabobank. The limit under the Esso Guarantee (Rabobank) is £25,000,000. Subject to the terms of the Esso Guarantee (Rabobank), Esso Petroleum Company Limited may request a drawing or drawings and on the second business day of receipt of a demand, Rabobank has undertaken unconditionally and irrevocably to pay to Esso Petroleum Company Limited the amount which is demanded. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Rabobank Letter of Credit Facility is partially drawn in the amount of £39,100,100.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Title: Markel International Insurance Company Limited Bond
Subsubsection Text: On December 6, 2023, Asda Group Limited, Asda Stores Limited and Euro Garages Limited as indemnitors (the “Indemnitors”), and Markel International Insurance Company Limited (“Markel”) entered into a deed of indemnity (the “Markel Deed of Indemnity”). The Markel Deed of Indemnity contains a mechanic pursuant to which other members of the Group may also accede as indemnitors. Under the Markel Deed of Indemnity, the Indemnitors agree to indemnify Markel against all demands, claims, liabilities and losses that Markel has sustained or incurred or sustains or incurs under or in connection with any “Bond” defined as any bond, guarantee, undertaking, indemnity or other obligatory instrument (including any counter guarantee unconditional obligations in the nature of letters of credit in whatever form or any “on demand” bond or guarantee pursuant to which payment may be demanded without further 249 ----- proof or condition). The Markel Deed of Indemnity contains a mechanic pursuant to which other members of the Group may also accede as indemnitors. The Indemnitors also agree to place Markel in funds upon written demand by Markel in respect of all outstanding Bonds and all amounts which the Surety may now or in the future owe or pay to any person under any such Bond after the occurrence of any of the following events: insolvency, in solvency proceedings, non-payment, breach of the Markel Deed of Indemnity or a security document in connection with Markel Deed of Indemnity or a bond, material adverse effect, change of business, change of control. In all cases, the Indemnitors are required to provide payment within three Business Days of demand by Markel. The Markel Deed of Indemnity does not have a fixed term. On December 15, 2023, Markel International Insurance Company Limited (“Markel International”) issued an on-demand guarantee at the request of Asda Group Limited with Esso Petroleum Company Limited as beneficiary (the “Esso Guarantee (Markel)”). The Esso Guarantee (Markel) became effective on December 15, 2023 and shall expire one year after the issue date at 5 PM London time. Esso Petroleum Company Limited may request a demand under the Esso Guarantee (Markel) at an amount or amounts not exceeding in aggregate £23,750,000. Markel International acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Cash Management Facility Lender and the Esso Guarantee (Markel) was designated a Cash Management Facility under the Intercreditor Agreement with effect from December 15, 2023. Consequently, the Esso Guarantee (Markel) constitutes a Senior Finance Document under the Intercreditor Agreement and is secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes on the Collateral, and Markel International qualifies as a Senior Creditor under the Intercreditor Agreement. The Esso Guarantee (Markel) is governed by English law.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On October 13, 2023, Asda Group Limited executed a reimbursement agreement (the “Aviva

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: On May 28, 2021, Asda Group Limited and Asda Stores Limited as indemnitors, and Liberty Mutual Insurance Europe SE (“Liberty Mutual”) entered into a deed of indemnity (the “Deed of Indemnity”). Under the terms of the Deed of Indemnity, Liberty Mutual agreed to consider, on an uncommitted basis, at Asda Group Limited and Asda Stores Limited’s requests from time to time to issue a “Guarantee” (a “Liberty Mutual Guarantee”) as defined in the Deed of Indemnity, defined as a bond, guarantee, undertaking, stipulation, indemnity or other obligatory instrument on behalf of a member of the Asda Group. The Deed of Indemnity contains a mechanic pursuant to which other members of the Group may also accede as indemnitors. Liberty Mutual may, in its sole discretion, decline to issue any such Liberty Mutual Guarantee or cancel any issued Liberty Mutual Guarantee that is cancellable in accordance with its terms for whatever reason. Under the Deed of Indemnity, Asda Group Limited and Asda Stores Limited agree to indemnify Liberty Mutual against all claims, liabilities and losses that Liberty Mutual may sustain or incur in respect of any Liberty 248 ----- Mutual Guarantee and under related documentation. Asda Group Limited and Asda Stores Limited also agree to place Liberty Mutual in funds upon demand by Liberty Mutual if a claim is made, or is reasonably likely to be made, in respect of a Liberty Mutual Guarantee or if Liberty Mutual has paid any sum under a Liberty Mutual Guarantee. Additionally, following a Cash Cover Event (defined to include non-payment, insolvency, breach of the Deed of Indemnity or a document governing a Liberty Mutual Guarantee, change of control, cross default, material adverse effect and failure to remedy non-compliance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement within 20 Business Days of becoming aware of such non-compliance), Liberty Mutual may demand cash cover from the indemnitors. In all cases, the indemnitors are required to provide payment within three Business Days of demand by Liberty Mutual. The Deed of Indemnity does not have a fixed term. Liberty Mutual acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Cash Management Facility Lender and Deed of Indemnity was designated a Cash Management Facility under the Intercreditor Agreement with effect from June 2, 2021. Consequently, the Deed of Indemnity constitutes a Senior Finance Document under the Intercreditor Agreement and is secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes on the Collateral, and Liberty Mutual qualifies as a Senior Creditor under the Intercreditor Agreement. The Deed of Indemnity is governed by English law. On February 27, 2023, a Liberty Mutual Guarantee was issued at the request of Asda Stores Limited with Smartestenergy Limited as beneficiary (the “Smart Guarantee”). The Smart Guarantee became effective on the date of issuance until March 31, 2024 (the “Expiration Date”) unless a non-renewal notice has been issued. If no nonrenewal notice is sent 60 days prior to the Expiration Date, the Expiration Date will automatically be extended annually from the Expiration Date on the same terms, but always subject to the Long-Stop Expiration Date (as defined therein). The Total Guarantee Amount (as defined therein) under the Smart Guarantee is £60,000,000. On February 1, 2024, Smartestenergy reassessed the value of the Smart Guarantee and confirmed that the Total Guarantee Amount should be adjusted down and have requested the Smart Guarantee to be issued on the same terms but for a value of £45,000,000 with effect from April 1, 2024. Subject to the terms of the Smart Guarantee, Smartestenergy Limited may request a drawing or drawings and within ten business days of receipt of a demand, Liberty Mutual unconditionally and irrevocably to pay to Smartestenergy Limited the amount which is demanded. On September 5, 2023, a Liberty Mutual Guarantee was issued at the request of Asda Stores Limited with Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A as beneficiary (the “Assicurazioni Guarantee”). The Assicurazioni Guarantee became effective from July 1, 2023, to June 30, 2024. The Assicurazioni Guarantee will be automatically renewed annually unless a 60 days prior non-renewal notice has been issued. The guarantee amount under the Assicurazioni guarantee is £10,000,000. Subject to the terms of the Assicurazioni Guarantee, Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A may request a drawing or drawings and within ten business days of receipt of a demand, Liberty Mutual unconditionally and irrevocably to pay to Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A the amount which is demanded. On September 5, 2023, a Liberty Mutual Guarantee was issued at the request of Asda Group Limited with Aviva Insurance Limited as beneficiary (the “Aviva Guarantee”). The Aviva Guarantee became effective from July 1, 2023, to June 30, 2024. The Aviva Guarantee will be automatically renewed annually unless a 60 days prior nonrenewal notice has been issued. The guarantee amount under the Aviva Guarantee is £11,856,095. Subject to the terms of the Aviva Guarantee, Aviva Insurance Limited may request a drawing or drawings and within ten business days of receipt of a demand, Liberty Mutual unconditionally and irrevocably to pay to Aviva Insurance Limited the amount which is demanded. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, no demand has been made for the Liberty Mutual Guarantee to be paid.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Reimbursement Agreement”) with Aviva Insurance Limited (“Aviva”) in connection with deductibles payable by
Subsubsection Text: the Asda Group Limited from time to time under an insurance policy provided by Aviva to Asda Group Limited with respect to certain motor claims. The Chubb Reimbursement Agreement was effective as of October 23, 2023 (the “Chubb Commencement Date”) and covers losses incurred under the insurance policy from July 1, 2023 to June 30 2024. The Aviva Reimbursement Agreement required Asda Group Limited to provide, within 21 Business Days of Chubb Commencement Date, guarantees to be provided to Aviva for the value of £23,216,000 being £9,716,000 in respect of the period May 1, 2022 to June 30, 2023 and £13,500,000 in respect of the period July 1, 2023 to June 30, 2024. Where Aviva makes a claims payment which falls within the single event limit (being £100,000 for each and every loss) or aggregate limit (being, £18,602,550 or £3,702 per vehicle), the Asda Group Limited agrees to pay to Aviva by way of reimbursement an amount equivalent to the claims payment. The Aviva Reimbursement Agreement has no fixed term and shall continue until the date on which Aviva issues a notice to the Asda Group Limited that Asda Group Limited’s liability to make reimbursement has been extinguished or discharged. On expiry or cancellation of the insurance policy, the Aviva Reimbursement Agreement shall remain in full force and effect and the parties shall continue to be liable to reimburse each other for claims payment pursuant to the terms set out therein. On December 18, 2023, Aviva issued a motor insurance deductible guarantee to AVIVA Insurance Limited, t/a Aviva Global Corporate Specialty as beneficiary (the “Aviva Motor Guarantee”). The Aviva Guarantee became effective from December 18, 2023, and will be automatically renewed annually unless cancelled or a 60 days prior non-renewal notice has been issued. The guarantee amount under Aviva Motor Guarantee is £23,216,000.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Asda Stores Limited and Lloyds Bank Plc (“Lloyds”) entered into a buyer supply chain agreement on November 1, 2021 (the “Lloyds Supply Chain Facility Agreement”), under which Lloyds, on an uncommitted basis, purchase and discount invoices from selected suppliers (at a price determined in Lloyds’s sole discretion) which 250 ----- regularly supply Asda Stores Limited (or its selected affiliates) to support supply chain trading activities in an aggregate amount of no more than £394,500,000 (the “Lloyds Supply Chain Facility”). The Lloyds Supply Chain Facility Agreement does not have a fixed term. It may be terminated by either Asda Stores Limited or Lloyds on not less than 60 days’ written notice (subject to a dispute resolution procedure), or without notice where an insolvency event has occurred and is continuing in respect of Asda Stores Limited or Lloyds (or an affiliate of Asda Stores Limited that has entered into contracts of sale under which receivables subject to the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility arise). Additionally, Lloyds may, subject to the dispute resolution procedure, terminate the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility where an insolvency event has occurred and is continuing in respect of a company in the Asda Stores Limited group where Lloyds makes a commercially reasonable determination that such insolvency is reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect on Asda Stores Limited (or an affiliate of Asda Stores Limited that has entered into contracts of sale under which receivables subject to the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility arise). Asda Stores Limited provides Lloyds with an indemnity under the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility Agreement on demand against any losses, costs, liabilities, expenses and damages incurred by Lloyds as a consequence of amongst other things, any breach by Asda Stores Limited of its obligations under the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility Agreement. Lloyds acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Cash Management Facility Lender and the Barclays Trade Loan Facility was designated a Cash Management Facility under the Intercreditor Agreement on November 1, 2021. Consequently, the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility constitutes a Senior Finance Document under the Intercreditor Agreement and is secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes on the Collateral, and Barclays qualifies as a Senior Creditor under the Intercreditor Agreement. The Lloyds Supply Chain Facility Agreement is governed by English law. As of December 31, 2023, the Lloyds Supply Chain Facility is partially drawn in the amount of £305,657,300.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Asda Stores Limited and HSBC Bank Plc (“HSBC”) entered into an approved invoice buyer agreement on July 9, 2014 (as subsequently novated by HSBC Bank Plc to HSBC UK Bank Plc pursuant to a novation agreement dated October 6, 2021, the “HSBC Supply Chain Facility Agreement”), under which HSBC Bank Plc agreed to provide trade related facilities to Asda Stores Limited to support supply chain trading activities in an aggregate amount of $190,000,000 (the “HSBC Supply Chain Facility”). Pursuant to the HSBC Supply Chain Facility Agreement, HSBC provides payment administration and management services to Asda Stores Limited for the purposes of remitting payments and settling amounts due to its suppliers under certain trade invoices, provided that Asda Stores Limited furnishes to HSBC the requisite invoice information specified therein. The HSBC Supply Chain Facility Agreement does not have a fixed term. It may be terminated by either Asda Stores Limited or HSBC on not less than 30 days’ written notice or unilaterally by HSBC should Asda Stores Limited commit a material breach of the agreement (to the extent capable of remedy or if not remedied within 14 days) or is dissolved, becomes insolvent or unable to pay its debts as they become due. Asda Stores Limited provides HSBC with an indemnity under the HSBC Supply Chain Facility Agreement on demand against any claim for any damages, losses, costs and expenses incurred by HSBC as a consequence of any breach by Asda Stores Limited of the HSBC Supply Chain Facility Agreement or the use by Asda Stores Limited of the agreed communications channel under such agreement. HSBC acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Cash Management Facility Lender and the HSBC Supply Chain Facility was designated a Cash Management Facility under the Intercreditor Agreement on November 1, 2021. Consequently, the HSBC Supply Chain Facility constitutes a Senior Finance Document under the Intercreditor Agreement and is secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes on the Collateral, and Barclays qualifies as a Senior Creditor under the Intercreditor Agreement. The HSBC Supply Chain Facility Agreement is governed by English law. As of December 31, 2023, the HSBC Supply Chain Facility is partially drawn in the amount of $131,157,392. 251 -----

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Asda Stores Limited entered into a vendor prepay service programme (the “Standard Chartered Vendor

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: SCF”) with Standard Chartered Bank (“SCB”) pursuant to an agreement dated February 14, 2019 (the “Standard Chartered SCF Agreement”).
Subsubsection Text: Pursuant to the Standard Chartered SCF Agreement, SCB agreed to, amongst other things, accept presentation of any invoices, transport documents or documents of title in connection with any merchandise and services provided to Asda Stores Limited by a supplier of goods and/or services to Asda Stores Limited (and as previously notified to SCB) (a “Selected Vendor”) from that supplier’s bank and to handle such documents in accordance with the International Chamber of Commerce’s Uniform Rules for Collection. The Standard Chartered SCF Agreement relates to Selected Vendors that are located and/or incorporated in Bangladesh and is in an aggregate amount of $40,000,000. Pursuant to the Standard Chartered SCF Agreement, Asda Stores Limited is required to determine acceptance and notify SCB by providing copies of the requisite invoices and/or details of the relevant accounts relating to a trade payable owing by Asda Stores Limited to a Selected Vendor (a “Trade Payable”). Upon such notification, Asda Stores Limited is required to credit a specified account in the amount required to satisfy the relevant Trade Payable with instructions to promptly pay the supplier of goods and/or services (subject to deduction of SCB fees). SCB has the option to purchase a Trade Payable and, in such circumstances, shall immediately remit to the bank of the Selected Vendor the amount required to satisfy the Trade Payable less discounting and other charges agreed with the Selected Vendor. If SCB otherwise decides not to purchase the Trade Payable, Asda Stores Limited will authorise SCB to debit from the specified account the amount required to satisfy the Trade Payable on the due date, which shall constitute the satisfaction of Asda Stores Limited’s obligations to SCB in respect of such Trade Payable. SCB has to comply with any request of Asda Stores Limited to make payment on its behalf in respect of a Trade Payable repurchase by a Selected Vendor and, in respect of a Trade Payable assigned to and owned by an affiliate of SCB, to make payment on Asda Stores Limited’s behalf to such affiliate. Pursuant to the Standard Chartered SCF Agreement, Asda Stores Limited shall indemnify SCB on demand against any losses incurred and which arise from any breach by Asda Stores Limited of, or failure to comply with, the terms of such agreement. After all Asda Stores Limited’s accounts are closed the Standard Chartered SCF Agreement will no longer be effective. The Standard Chartered SCF Agreement does not have a fixed term. It may be terminated by either Asda Stores Limited or SCB on not less than 30 days’ written notice or unilaterally by SCB should Asda Stores Limited commit a breach of the agreement or become subject to any insolvency proceedings, if it is (or is likely to become) unlawful for Asda Stores Limited or SCB to perform their respective obligations under the agreement, if complying with the agreement causes SCB to breach any law or upon exception circumstances affecting Asda Stores Limited or the service provided by SCB under the agreement. The Standard Chartered Vendor SCF is unsecured and not subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. The Standard Chartered Vendor SCF is governed by English law. As of December 31, 2023, the Standard Chartered Vendor SCF remains partially drawn in the amount of $22,477,536.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The whole (or substantially the whole) of the landlord’s reversionary (or, as applicable, registered) interest.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The term of the Warehouse Asset Leases is 25 years from and including the date of the Warehouse Asset Leases (or, in relation to the Warehouse Asset Leases in Scotland, the date of commencement of the Warehouse Asset Leases), which for the majority of the Warehouse Asset Lease is July 13, 2021. The Warehouse Asset Leases contain an option to renew (or, in relation to the Warehouse Assets in Scotland extend) for a term of 10 years which can be exercised during the term of the relevant Warehouse Asset Lease on not less than nine months’ written notice prior to the expiry of the term of each Warehouse Asset Lease. The renewal leases (or, as applicable, extended lease) will contain one further option to renew for a further 10 years.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Warehouse Asset Leases each reserve a different rent payable by the Tenant in equal instalments on the usual quarter days in each year. The Warehouse Asset Leases contain an RPI linked rent review, calculated annually with a minimum 1% and maximum 4% uplift. On commencement of any renewal lease the passing rent will be reviewed to the higher of the existing rent and the open market rent. Interest is payable at 3% per annum above the Barclays base rate on any sums (including but not limited to rent) not paid by the tenant by 15 working days after the date they are due. The Tenant is also required to pay insurance rent, utilities, service media, business rates and taxes.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Warehouse Asset Leases benefit from security of tenure under the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for the Warehouse Asset Leases of the Scottish assets). This means that the Tenant has a right to renew the Warehouse Asset Leases in England & Wales at the end of the term, subject to some limited grounds of opposition available to the landlord pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: There is no guarantor party to the Warehouse Asset Leases in respect of the Tenant’s obligations.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Tenant may only use the Warehouse Assets for (1) in relation to the England & Wales leases only uses within Class B1(b), B1(c), B2 or B8 of the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 and as ancillary to such use and in relation to the Scottish leases only uses within Class 4, 5 and 6 of the Town & Country Planning (Use Classes) (Scotland) Order 1997 (as at 31 August 2020) and as ancillary to such use; and (2) any other use approved by the landlord (such approval not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed (and in relation to the England & Wales leases only, it shall be reasonable for the landlord to withhold consent where the landlord reasonably believes that the proposed use would result in a diminution in value of the landlord’s interest in the relevant Warehouse Asset). In relation to the England & Wales leases only, if any alteration or change of use creates a community infrastructure levy, the Tenant will be liable for such levy.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Tenant may assign (in whole only) or sublet (in whole or in part) the Warehouse Asset Leases, as set out below. 253 ----- _Assignment_ Assignment of the whole is permitted with landlord consent, not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed (and where a renewal lease has been granted in relation to the Warehouse Assets Leases in England & Wales, such renewal lease must also be assigned at the same time). The landlord may (i) withhold consent if the proposed assignee does not have, or would reasonably be expected to have (were it rated), a rating of at least Ba3 by Moody’s or BB- by Fitch (or a reasonably equivalent rating from a successor rating business) (the “Warehouse Rating Criteria”) and does not provide a guarantor of the assignee’s obligations (excluding an authorised guarantee agreement) which meets the Warehouse Rating Criteria; (ii) require both an authorised guarantee agreement and a guarantee of such authorised guarantee agreement, where the proposed assignee has a rating below Baa3 by Moody’s, BBB by Fitch or BBB by Standard & Poor (or a reasonably equivalent rating from a successor rating business). The landlord may also refuse consent to assignment on any other reasonable ground or impose any other reasonable condition on its consent. _Subletting_ The Tenant may underlet (i) the whole of a Warehouse Asset; (ii) part of a Warehouse Asset which is selfcontained and capable of separate occupation; (iii) a substation; or (iv) electric vehicle charging points, provided that (among other conditions) there are no more than five separate and concurrent occupancies of a Warehouse Asset (noting that (i) substations; (ii) electric vehicle charging points; (iii) any group or associated company occupying pursuant to the permitted sharing provisions and (iv) licencees of the car park occupying pursuant to the permitted sharing provisions shall not count as one of the five occupancies). All underleases must not benefit from the statutory right of renewal contained in the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for the Warehouse Asset Leases of the Scottish assets) and all undertenants must covenant directly with the landlord to (i) comply with the tenant covenants under the relevant Warehouse Asset Lease and tenant covenants to be contained in the underlease; and to (ii) (not applicable for Warehouse Asset Leases of the Scottish assets) apply to cancel notice of such underlease within one month of the end of the term of the underlease. The relevant underlease must also contain specific terms, including but not limited to: (i) the rent being not less than market value; (ii) the term not extending beyond the expiry of the term of the relevant Warehouse Asset Lease: (iii) rent reviews being upwards only and (iv) including various restrictions in relation to further assignment and subletting. _Charging_ The Tenant may charge its interest in respect of the whole of each Warehouse Asset Lease only (and where a renewal lease has been granted, such renewal lease must also be charged at the same time). _Declarations of Trust_ In relation to the England & Wales leases only, the Tenant shall not execute any declaration of trust over the whole or any part of its interest in the Warehouse Asset Leases. _Group Sharing_ Sharing occupation with group companies and associated companies is permitted provided that no relationship of landlord and tenant is created.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Warehouse Asset Leases permit all non-structural and many structural alterations without the need for landlord consent. The Warehouse Asset Leases set a maximum capital expenditure for structural alterations (which varies between the Warehouse Asset Leases), below which consent is not required, provided that the Tenant has provided full written details of the proposed alterations and confirmation that the capital expenditure is equal to or less than the maximum amount, and provided that the landlord has not objected in writing if it reasonably believes the alterations might result in a diminution in the value of its interest. There are various restrictions on all alterations to the premises, including, but not limited to, not making any alterations which would (i) involve the demolition of the premises; (ii) lower the energy performance rating of the premises; or (iii) involve works to the cold storage equipment (noting that not all of the Warehouse Asset Leases 254 ----- contain the restriction in relation to cold storage). The Tenant may not make alterations to service media without landlord consent and in carrying out permitted alterations, must comply with various conditions, including (i) obtaining any required consents; (ii) giving the insurers notice of the work; (iii) procuring that the works are carried out in a good and workmanlike manner; (iv) making good any physical damage caused by the works; and (v) giving the landlord access to inspect the works.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Warehouse Asset Leases contain a repairing covenant requiring the Tenant to keep the premises in good and substantial repair and condition, except where damage is caused by insured risks (unless insurers withhold insurance money due to act or omission of the Tenant) or uninsured risks. The tenant is to ensure that minimum energy performance criteria are met.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Tenant is required to return the Warehouse Asset Leases at the expiry of the term having removed all fixtures and free from any underleases, concessions and third party rights of occupation created by the Tenant other than those where the landlord consented expressly to such occupier remaining after the expiry of the term. Alterations are to be reinstated by the Tenant at the end of the term of the Warehouse Asset Leases unless otherwise agreed by the landlord. The Tenant is also required to provide an exit survey and conduct a site inspection with the landlord.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The landlord insures, save in circumstances where the original tenant (being Asda Stores Limited or a group company) is tenant in which case the Tenant is to insure provided it has an insurance policy compliant with the terms of the Warehouse Asset Leases, and provided the Tenant complies with the obligations relating to insurance. Where the Tenant insures, the Tenant must insure against insured risks (which includes standard insured risk events including fire, lightning, explosion, earthquake, landslip, heave, subsidence, riot, act of terrorism, civil commotion, aircraft (other than hostile aircraft), storm, flood, bursting and overflowing of water tanks, apparatus or pipes, malicious damage and such other risks reasonably required by the landlord or the Tenant) for full reinstatement cost. The reinstatement obligations as set out below also apply to the Tenant where the Tenant insures. Where the landlord insures, the landlord must insure against the insured risks as set out above for full reinstatement cost and loss of rent for not less than three years. The Tenant will pay, among other costs, the insurance rent, excesses and the amount which insurers refuse to pay following damage by an insured risk because of any act or omission of the Tenant in breach of the Warehouse Asset Lease. The landlord is obliged to use all reasonable endeavours to obtain any consents required to reinstate insured damage. All insurance monies will belong to the landlord. The Warehouse Asset Leases contain rent suspension provisions (unless the tenant insures) and termination rights which apply in certain circumstances where reinstatement of the Warehouse Assets as a result of damage caused by insured risks has occurred and such damage has not been reinstated. _Termination due to damage by Insured or Uninsured Risks_ The Warehouse Asset Leases contain provisions dealing with damage or destruction to the Warehouse Assets caused by uninsured risks. The Tenant may elect to reinstate the premises, and if the Tenant does not elect to do so, the landlord may elect to reinstate the premises. If neither party elects to do so, either party may terminate the relevant Warehouse Asset Lease. If the premises are not reinstated within three years of a party electing to do so, either party may elect to terminate the relevant Warehouse Asset Lease.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The landlord has the right to forfeit a Warehouse Asset Lease if either (a) the rent or any other sum payable under the Warehouse Asset Lease remains unpaid for 15 business days, (b) the Tenant materially fails to comply with the terms of the Warehouse Asset Lease or (c) the Tenant or its guarantor suffers an insolvency event (unless, in respect of a guarantor's insolvency event, the Tenant meets a minimum rating criteria). 255 ----- The Warehouse Asset Leases contain mortgagee protection provisions which require the landlord to provide 30 working days’ advance notice of intended forfeiture to the Tenant's mortgagee.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: There are extensive obligations on the Tenant in relation to compliance with environmental laws, providing data to the landlord in relation to environmental performance, and taking any required remedial action at the end of the term to return the relevant Warehouse Asset in a standard required under environmental law. The Tenant provides an indemnity to the landlord against all loss arising from the breach of any Tenant covenant or obligation; including costs reasonably incurred by the landlord to mitigate any such loss.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: - **Scotland: a kilted form of the Warehouse Asset Leases for the stores in Scotland follows largely the same format as the Warehouse Asset Leases for the stores in England & Wales, with the following changes: o Statutory references have been amended to applicable Scottish law. In particular, references to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 have been removed as the act is not applicable in Scotland, meaning that the Tenant has no statutory right to renew. o The renewal option in the England & Wales leases is amended to a lease extension option under the Scottish leases (for the same term and on the same notice as under the England & Wales leases). o The assignment condition is amended to remove the option for the current Tenant to provide an authorised guarantee agreement and all other references to authorised guarantee agreement as authorised guarantee agreements are not applicable in Scotland. - The underletting provisions are amended to remove requirements on the undertenant to enter into deeds of covenant directly with the landlord. In respect of the Warehouse Asset at Grangemouth, a £1 rent lease has also been entered into on terms substantially similar to the Warehouse Asset Leases (but excluding all provisions in relation to insurance, rent review and environmental matters, and with bespoke (more restrictive) provisions in relation to repair, alterations, yield up and alienation), subject to the terms of the lease under which the aforementioned separate leasehold interest is held, to demise certain land used by this Warehouse Asset but held as a separate leasehold interest and for the purposes of laying and retaining a pipeline with ancillary connections for the purposes of discharging surface water from the Warehouse Asset to the waste water network. The £1 lease is linked to the main Warehouse Asset Lease at Grangemouth insofar as the £1 lease must only be assigned, sublet and charged simultaneously with (and to the same assignee or sublessee as) the main Warehouse Asset Lease, and the £1 lease will terminate at the same time as the main Warehouse Asset Lease. The Tenant under the £1 lease must pay the service charge payable under the relevant headlease and must observe the tenant’s obligations under such headlease (other than to pay rents) and not do anything which would put the landlord in breach of its obligations under such headlease. - The Asda Group has retained ownership to the Select Retail Assets (save for in respect of the Shaw Oldham store which was included in the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction) and the Substitute Retail Assets (save for in respect of the Canterbury and Boldon sites which were included in the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction). - The Lutterworth CDC Warehouse Asset Lease contains bespoke additional obligations on the Tenant, being (i) an obligation to pay a service charge (being such amount payable by the landlord under the superior lease); (ii) not to apply for planning permission in relation to alterations, unless the works would not trigger an overage under the HCA Deed (undefined), or unless the tenant has agreed to pay such overage; and (iii) to be liable for any environmental liability in relation to a leakage of fuel from the Diesel UST tank in the north east of the premises which was decommissioned in or about 2015. The Lutterworth CDC, Lutterworth IDC, Washington ADC and Doncaster GM Warehouse Asset Leases contain obligations to comply with all tenant covenants in the relevant headlease (other than to pay rents) and additional provisions in relation to circumstances in which superior landlord consent is required. The Lutterworth IDC Warehouse Asset Lease also contains an obligation to pay a service charge, being such amount payable by the landlord under the superior lease. 256 ----- The Doncaster GM Warehouse Asset Lease contains a bespoke obligation on the Tenant to pay a service charge, being such amount as the landlord is liable to pay under the superior lease on maintenance of the Redhouse Interchange estate. The Tenant’s obligation to insure under the Doncaster GM Warehouse Asset Lease is also subject to the superior landlord having consented to the tenant insuring. The Wakefield ASC and CDC Warehouse Asset Leases contain bespoke provisions in relation to a right of way in favour of the Wakefield ASC premises over the Wakefield CDC premises. The Erith CDC and Bedford CDC Warehouse Asset Leases both contain a bespoke obligation on the Tenant to pay a service charge (being such amount payable by the landlord under 2004 transfer documents in relation to the Erith CDC lease and under a 2022 deed in relation to the Bedford CDC lease). The Bedford ASC Warehouse Asset Lease contains an obligation to pay proper costs incurred by the landlord in relation to contributions under a 1997 conveyance and 2005 transfer. The Didcot ADC Warehouse Asset Lease contains an obligation on the Tenant to pay a service charge, being such amount as the landlord is liable to pay under a 2004 transfer document. The Warrington (Omega South) ADC Warehouse Asset Lease contains bespoke obligations on the Tenant, being an obligation to pay any service charge under a deed entered into with the Homes and Communities Agency (HCA) in 2013, as well as any overage which becomes due as a result of an act of the Tenant (or associated / group company or person) under such deed. Similarly, the Washington ASC Warehouse Asset Lease contains obligations to pay any overage which becomes due as a result of an act of the Tenant (or associated / group company or person) under a deed entered into with the HCA in 2008. The Tenant under both aforementioned Warehouse Asset Leases is also prevented from making any change of use or applying for planning permission for alterations which would cause an overage to be payable under the relevant HCA deed. The Site A Falkirk Warehouse Asset Lease contains a bespoke obligation on the Tenant to pay a service charge, being such amount as the landlord is liable to pay under deed of condition registered in the Land Register of Scotland under Title Number STG53196 on August 28, 2019. The IPL Westry Warehouse Asset Lease states that no title guarantee is given in relation to one of the titles out of which part of the IPL Westry Warehouse Asset Lease is granted (being title number CB395942, which is a possessory freehold title). This part of the demise of the IPL Westry Warehouse Asset Lease is a small piece of boundary land. The Chepstow ADC Warehouse Asset Lease contains a bespoke obligation on the Tenant to pay (1) any overage and other sums which become due (including indemnifying the landlord against the same) pursuant to a 1999 transfer; and (2) a service charge payable under transfers dated May 27, 1999.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions, the Warehouse Assets (other than the sites of Heston and Dartford) are leased to Asda Stores Limited (the “Tenant”) by (i) Alaska Propco GP Limited; (ii) Alaska Propco GP 2 Limited; (iii) Alaska Propco Nominee Limited; and (iv) Alaska Nominee 2 Limited, all being entities 252 ----- managed by Blackstone Group Inc. on substantially the following terms (the “Warehouse Asset Leases” and each a “Warehouse Asset Lease”).The Warehouse Asset Leases were originally entered into between Bellis Select Warehouse Limited and the Tenant, however, the reversionary interest in each Warehouse Asset Lease has since been transferred to the entities listed above since the Warehouse Asset Leases were entered into in 2021.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the SLB Purchase Agreement, on August 2, 2023, Asda Stores Limited, as tenant (the “Tenant”), along with McLagan Investments Limited as Landlord entered into 22 SLB Master Leases (and subsequently entered into the SLB Master Leases of the Kings Hill, Poole and Swindon (Haydon) properties on (respectively) November 7, 2023, September 5, 2023 and August 21, 2023) (each a “Master Lease” and collectively, the “SLB Master Leases”) encumbering the properties located in Blackpool, Blackwood, Bolton, Bootle Orrell Lane, Colchester, Doncaster, Dunbar, Farnborough, Frome, Glasshoughton, Grangemouth, Greenhithe, Kings Hill, Leicester, Linwood, Plymouth, Poole, Robroyston, Sheffield Mosborough, Stafford, Swindon (Haydon), Totton, Wakefield, Weston Super Mare and Wolverhampton (the “SLB Properties” and each an “SLB Property”) and McLagan Investments Limited as Transferor subsequently transferred the reversion in each SLB Master Lease to RI MDC UK080 Limited (“Realty”) for consideration of £645,607,637.51. 257 -----

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _Post-Closing Obligations_ Following the consummation of the sale-leaseback transaction, McLagan Investments Limited must use reasonable endeavours to resolve certain diligence items at certain of the SLB Properties. The resolution of those diligence items included cladding issues at the Poole property, keeping Realty informed in respect of ongoing negotiations to sell a parcel of land at or near the Doncaster property to a third party, transfer of certain shares in an estate management company relating to the management of the Kings Hill property and dealings with a pre-emption agreement that encumbers part of the Poole property.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _Term_ The initial term of the SLB Master Leases is for a term of years commencing on August 2, 2023 and expiring on and including August 9, 2048 for the initial 22 properties (with the (inclusive) term dates for the three latercompleted properties being – Kings Hill: November 7, 2023 to November 14, 2048; Poole: September 5, 2023 to September 12, 2048; and Swindon (Haydon): August 21, 2023 to August 29, 2048). In addition, each Master Lease contains two (2) renewal options (or in relation to the SLB Master Leases of the Scottish assets an option to extend) for a term of ten (10) years each which can be exercised during the term of each of the SLB Master Leases (and subsequent first renewal or extension lease) but not less than six (6) months’ prior to expiry of the term of each of the SLB Master Leases (and subsequent first renewal or extension lease). _Rent_ The SLB Master Leases each reserve a different rent payable by the Tenant in equal instalments on February 28, May 31, August 31 and November 30 in each year. The rent is subject to an annual review which is upwards-only, linked to the percentage change in Consumer Price Index for the period from the immediately preceding rent review date to the current rent review date subject to a cap of 4% and a collar of 1%. Interest is payable at 3% per annum above the Barclays base rate on any sums (including but not limited to rent) not paid by the Tenant on the date they are due. The Tenant is also required to pay all outgoings (including but not limited to business rates, taxes and utilities) and landlord fees. _Landlord and Tenant Act 1954_ In addition to the contractual options to extend the SLB Master Leases, the SLB Master benefit from a Tenant statutory right of renewal pursuant to the provisions of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for the Master Leases of the Scottish assets). The Tenant has a right to renew the SLB Master Leases in England & Wales at the end of the term, subject to some limited grounds of opposition available to the landlord pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954. _Guarantor_ There is no guarantor party to the SLB Master Leases in respect of the Tenant’s obligations. _Use_ The Tenant may only use the SLB Properties as (1) retail stores within Class E of the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 (and certain specified ancillary uses to such use); (2) any use to which the SLB Properties were used as at the date of the relevant Master Lease; and (3) any other use approved by the landlord (such approval not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed where the proposed use would not have a material adverse effect on the value of the landlord’s interest). The Tenant may also permit undertenants to use a part of the premises for any lawful use within Class E or various uses within Class F, provided that such uses within Class F are limited to a maximum aggregate area of 5% of the gross internal area of the buildings on the premises. 258 ----- _Maintenance, Alterations and Expansion_ Pursuant to the SLB Master Leases, the Tenant is obligated to repair, replace and maintain each SLB Property. The Tenant may make de minimis alterations (which include both non-structural and specific minor structural alterations such as creation of new entrances and exterior canopies and internal division walls required for subletting) subject to various conditions, including but not limited to (i) obtaining any planning permissions; (ii) giving the insurers of the relevant SLB Property notice of the work; (iii) procuring that the works are carried out by reputable contractors in a good and workmanlike manner; (iv) making good any defects arising out of the works; and (v) giving the landlord records in line with CDM regulations and drawings of alterations). The Tenant may make minor alterations (which include structural alterations which do not increase the gross external area of buildings on the premises by more than 40%) subject to the above conditions, as well as subject to supplying the landlord full written details of the proposed alterations and confirmation that such alterations are not part of a wider scheme of works and that all requisite consents have been or will be obtained. The Tenant may make major alterations (being any alterations or any structural additions to the properties that are not minor alterations or de minimis alterations) subject to the conditions which apply to minor alterations as well as subject to receiving landlord consent, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. The Tenant must also procure warranties in favour of the landlord (to the extent the Tenant has the ability to call for such warranties) for major alterations or minor alterations where new buildings / extensions are erected. There are various restrictions on all alterations to the premises, including, but not limited to, not making any alterations which would (i) prejudice the structural integrity of the premises; (ii) lower the energy performance rating of the premises; or (iii) have a material detrimental effect on the value of the landlord’s interest. _Yield Up_ The Tenant is required to return the SLB Properties at the expiry of the term having removed all fixtures and signage installed by the Tenant, as well as any alterations made during the term, except that the Tenant shall not be required to remove buildings or permanent structures if their continued presence beyond the end of the Term would not have a material detrimental effect on the estimated rental value of the landlord’s reversionary interest in the relevant SLB Property or the Tenant (in its discretion) elects instead to pay a sum equivalent to the detrimental effect on the estimated rental value of the landlord’s reversionary interest. Any alterations which have not been completed at the end of the term must be reinstated to the landlord’s reasonable satisfaction. The Tenant must also return the SLB Properties free from any underleases, concessions and third-party rights of occupation created by the Tenant other than those where the landlord consented expressly to such occupier remaining after the expiry of the term. _Tenant’s right of First Offer_ In the event that the landlord, whether or not for money or money’s worth, wishes to sell or exchanges their reversionary interest in any of the SLB Properties (whether in part or in whole) or grant a lease or agreement for lease in respect of any of the SLB Properties (whether in part or in whole) at a premium or with the intention or effect of realising capital value from any of the SLB Properties to a third party, the landlord must first offer to sell the relevant SLB Property which is the subject matter of the proposed disposal to the Tenant, being Asda Stores Limited or any group company (the right of first offer is personal to the original tenant and its group companies). The right of first offer is conditioned upon there being no event of default that would give rise to a right for the landlord to forfeit the Master Lease then occurring under the subject Master Lease. _Assignment_ The SLB Master Leases contain assignment and subletting rights in favour the Tenant. The Tenant may assign (in whole only) or sublet (in whole or in part) the Master Lease of the relevant SLB Property subject to landlord consent, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed. The landlord may impose certain conditions in respect of giving consent to an assignment. The landlord may impose that (i) the proposed assignee enters into a deed of covenant with the landlord to comply with the terms of the 259 ----- Master Lease; (ii) there are no arrears of rents due to the landlord that are not the subject of a legitimate dispute about their payment; and (iii) the proposed assignee either (a) where it is in a group of companies which owns or controls a brand which is ranked as being in the top four grocery retailers in Great Britain by Kantar Group, has a financial strength rating of at least either (A) B by Standard and Poor’s; (B) B2 by Moody’s or (C) B by Fitch (or a reasonably equivalent rating from a successor rating business or alternative major rating agency acceptable to the landlord), or (b) where it is not in a group of companies which owns or controls a brand in the top four grocery retailers, has a financial strength rating of at least (A) BBB- by Standard and Poor’s; (B) Baa3 by Moody’s; or (C) BBB- by Fitch (or a reasonably equivalent rating from a successor rating business or alternative major rating agency acceptable to the landlord); or, in relation to both the foregoing (a) and (b), where the proposed assignee does not have such a rating, it obtains a shadow rating from one of these agencies which would otherwise satisfy the above criteria (the “Rating

Subsection Title: Criteria”). Alternatively, where the Tenant or any guarantor meets the Rating Criteria, the tenant or such guarantor
Subsubsection Text: Transaction documentation for certain of the SLB Properties differs from those master transaction document templates which are described in the section above. This sub-section briefly sets out any such material differences on a site-by-site basis. - **Blackpool: the Master Lease for the store in Blackpool contains bespoke insurance and alterations provisions due to certain third-party restrictive covenants registered on the title of the Blackpool store. Accordingly, insurance is in place covering the risk of breach or enforcement of these third-party restrictive covenants. As a consequence, if alterations or implementing or applying for planning permission would fall foul of the exclusions within the title insurance policy, the Tenant is required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer and confirmation from the insurer that the title insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration or implementation of planning permission, or (ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same third party restrictive covenant risks and which would not be voided by the aforementioned alterations or application for or implementation of any planning permission. The Tenant was also required to enter into a deed of covenant at the date of the lease to comply with various obligations contained in a 2015 transfer. The Tenant cannot assign the Blackpool Master Lease unless the assignee enters into a deed of covenant on the same terms. - **Bolton: the Master Lease for the store in Bolton contains bespoke insurance and alterations provisions due to the fact that several car parking spaces may encroach on land which is not owned by the landlord (which the tenant acknowledges under the terms of the Master Lease and confirms that it will not be entitled to claim in respect of derogation from grant in relation to such gap). Accordingly, insurance is in place covering the risk of the owner of the relevant land claiming ownership or bringing a claim for damages. As a consequence, if alterations or implementing or applying for planning permission would fall foul of the exclusions within the title insurance policy, the Tenant is required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer and confirmation from the insurer that the title insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration or implementation of planning permission, or (ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same risk and which would not be voided by the aforementioned alterations or application for or implementation of any planning permission. - **Frome: McLagan Investments Limited has retained a large nature reserve at the Frome property. The Master Lease for the Frome property allows Asda Stores Limited or any group company (being any company or companies which is and/or are for the time being a member of the same group of companies as the Tenant within the meaning of Section 42(1) of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954) to use parking at the Frome property for visitors to the neighbouring nature reserve retained by McLagan Investments Limited. - **Glasshoughton: the Master Lease for the store in Glasshoughton contains bespoke insurance and alterations provisions due to the fact that part of the land is unregistered. Accordingly, the landlord only leases the unregistered land with such right, title and interest as the landlord has in the premises as at the date of the Master Lease (rather than with full title guarantee), and title insurance is in place to cover the risk of a third party claiming ownership of the unregistered land. As a consequence, if alterations or implementing or applying for planning permission would fall foul of the exclusions within the title insurance policy, the Tenant is required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer and confirmation from the insurer that the title insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration or implementation of planning permission, or (ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same risk and which would not be voided by the aforementioned alterations or application for or implementation of any planning permission. - **Kings Hill: the Master Lease for the store in Kings Hill contains bespoke service charge provisions due to the fact that there is an estate service charge payable to a third-party estate management company by the landlord. The Tenant is required to pay any such service charge to the landlord within twenty (20) working days of written demand. The Tenant was also required to enter into a deed of covenant at the date of the lease to comply with various obligations contained in various transfers dated 2004 and 2013 and to create various new restrictive covenants over the premises. The Tenant also entered into a separate deed of covenant to pay estate charges and comply with various additional covenants. The Tenant cannot assign the Kings Hill Master Lease unless the assignee enters into deeds of covenant on the same terms. 263 ----- - **Leicester: the Master Lease for the store in Leicester contains an acknowledgement by the Tenant that there may be a gap between the north western boundary of the property and the adopted highway and that the Tenant will not be entitled to claim in respect of derogation from grant in relation to such gap. - **Poole: the Master Lease for the store in Poole is an underlease and therefore contains additional obligations on the Tenant to comply with all tenant covenants in the headlease insofar as they relate to the Poole store (other than to pay rents) and additional provisions in relation to circumstances in which superior landlord consent is required. The Master Lease permits the use of certain parts of the property to be used for residential use. - **Swindon Haydon: the Master Lease for the store in Swindon Haydon contains bespoke service charge provisions due to the fact that there is an estate service charge payable to a third-party estate management company by the landlord (where is it not paid direct to the third party estate management company by the Tenant). The Tenant is required to pay any such service charge to the landlord within twenty (20) working days of written demand. - **Wolverhampton: the Master Lease for the store in Wolverhampton contains bespoke insurance and alterations provisions due to the fact that part of the land was unregistered at the time the lease was entered into. Accordingly, insurance was put in place covering the risk of a third party claiming ownership of the unregistered land and provisions were inserted in the lease stating that if the tenant’s alterations or implementing or applying for planning permission would fall foul of the exclusions within the title insurance policy, the Tenant was required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer and confirmation from the insurer that the title insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration or implementation of planning permission, or (ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same risk and which would not be voided by the aforementioned alterations or application for or implementation of any planning permission. The relevant land was registered at the HM Land Registry in September 2023 with title absolute and therefore (1) the title insurance in relation to this risk ceased to apply; and (2) the site-specific provisions inserted in the lease also ceased to apply (save in the event that there was any antecedent breach). - **Scotland: a kilted form of the SLB Master Leases for the stores in Scotland follows largely the same format as the SLB Master Leases, with the following changes: o Statutory references have been amended to applicable Scottish law. In particular, references to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 have been removed as the act is not applicable in Scotland, meaning that the tenant has no statutory right to renew. o The renewal option in the England & Wales leases is amended to a lease extension option under the Scottish leases (for the same term and on the same notice as under the England & Wales leases). o The assignment condition is amended to remove the option for the current Tenant to provide an authorised guarantee agreement (and therefore requires the assignee to either meet the Rating Criteria or to provide a guarantor). o The event of default for breach of lease is amended so that if such breach is capable of remedy, the Tenant has a reasonable period to remedy the breach following receipt of a notice from the landlord before an event of default is triggered. o The underletting provisions are amended to remove requirements on the undertenant to enter into deeds of covenant directly with the landlord. o The environmental provisions are also amended to reflect the underlying Scottish legislative regime, and where there is title indemnity insurance benefitting the premises, the alterations provisions prevent the Tenant applying for or implementing any planning permissions without obtaining an endorsement amending the insured use to cover the proposed works.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Criteria”). Alternatively, where the Tenant or any guarantor meets the Rating Criteria, the tenant or such guarantor
Subsubsection Text: may give the landlord an authorised guarantee agreement under Section 16 of the Landlord and Tenant (Covenants) Act 1995 guaranteeing the obligations of the proposed assignee or if the proposed assignee does not meet any of the Rating Criteria, the proposed assignee may provide a guarantor for its obligations, such guarantor entity meeting any of the Rating Criteria. The landlord may withhold consent to any assignment of the Master Lease where (i) in the landlord’s reasonable opinion, the proposed assignee (when assessed together with any proposed guarantor of the proposed assignee other than under an authorised guarantee agreement) is not of sufficient financing standing to pay the rent and other sums payable under the Master Lease and to company with the Tenant’s covenants in the Master Lease; (ii) the proposed assignee or its guarantor is a company incorporated in or an individual resident in a country outside the United Kingdom and there is no treaty for the mutual enforcement of judgements between the United Kingdom and that country; (iii) the proposed assignee or its guarantor is a person who enjoys sovereign or state immunity, unless a department, body or agency of the United Kingdom; or (iv) (a) the proposed assignee is a person or entity controlled by a person designated under the OFAC, United Nations, European Union or His Majesty’s Treasury sanctions regimes or (b) the proposed assignee is a politically exposed person (PEP), a PEP’s family member or a known close associate of a PEP (all such terms as defined in regulation 35(1) of The Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017). _Subletting_ The Tenant may underlet the whole or any part of the relevant SLB Property provided that it obtains the prior written consent of the landlord, which will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. The undertenant is to enter into a direct deed of covenant in favour of the landlord both (i) to comply with the undertenant’s covenants in the underlease whilst it remains an undertenant; and (ii) to procure that any proposed assignee of the underlease enters into a direct deed of covenant with the landlord on an assignment of the underlease. Any underlease is to be granted (i) without reserving a fine or premium; (ii) at the open market rent reasonably obtainable at the time of the grant of the underlease for the premises underlet; (iii) where the term exceeds five years, containing provisions for the review of rent consistent with open market practice at the relevant time; and (iv) including covenants which are not inconsistent with or impair the performance and observance of the covenants of the Tenant in the Master Lease provided that the Tenant is able to allow the undertenant a rent free or concessionary rent period or provide an inducement or other incentive payment to take the underlease so far as is consistent with normal market practice. Any underlease must not benefit from the statutory right of renewal contained in the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 and must be for a term which expires before the expiry of the Master Lease (not applicable for the Master Leases of the Scottish assets). No underlease of part of the relevant SLB Property shall permit creation of further underleases of part of the relevant SLB Property that is underlet but may allow (i) further underleases of whole subject to obtaining the prior consent of the landlord where it would be required to such underletting under the Master Lease (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed) and such further underlease shall not permit any further underletting of whole or part of the relevant SLB Property and (ii) granting of licences or other rights to share occupation of part of areas of the carpark or units of the store as set out under ‘Concessions’ below which do not create any relationship of landlord and tenant. 260 ----- The Tenant may without the landlord’s consent enter into underleases of (i) any individual unit located outside the footprint of the main store forming part of the relevant SLB Property for a term not exceeding ten years or (ii) for automated teller machines or electrical vehicle charging points or (iii) of any individual unit located within the footprint of the main store forming part of the relevant SLB Property for terms not exceeding ten years at a rent that may not correspond to the passing rent under the relevant Master Lease and which may permit the undertenant to trade in its own name or under franchise arrangements (the “Permitted Underleases”) provided that (in relation to all Permitted Underleases): (a) the asset rating (as defined under the Energy Performance of Buildings (England and Wales) Regulations 2012 (as amended) (Asset Rating) is not adversely affected; (b) any underlease does not benefit from the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for the Master Leases of the Scottish Assets); (c) any underlease shall terminate on or
