before the termination of the Master Lease and shall contain a provision by which it shall automatically terminate upon the determination (including forfeiture) of the Master Lease; (d) the terms of the underlease are not inconsistent with, nor impair the due performance by the Tenant of its obligations in the Master Lease and (e) unless it is granted at a rent that the landlord has confirmed is the open market rental value of the underlet premises at the date of the grant of the underlease any such underlease must contain a statement by the Tenant and undertenant that they are not acknowledging the rent reserved by the underlease is the open market rental value of the underlet premises at the date of grant of the underlease (provided that where such underlease is granted pursuant to an agreement for lease or other contractual agreement which pre-dates the date of the relevant Master Lease, the Tenant shall use reasonable endeavours to seek the agreement of the relevant undertenant to the inclusion of such a statement). _Concessions_ The Tenant may without the landlord’s consent grant licences or other rights to share occupation in relation to (a) any individual unit or area of the car park located outside the footprint of the main store forming part of the relevant SLB Property and (b) any individual unit located within the footprint of the main store forming part of the relevant SLB Property, in both cases (i) so long as the relevant SLB Property retains the appearance of a single trading store and (ii) the relevant SLB Property retains its asset rating under the Energy Performance of Buildings (England and Wales) Regulations 2012 or, in relation to the Master Leases of the Scottish assets the equivalent legislation in place in Scotland. _Maximum Area subject to Subletting and Concessions_ The Tenant may only grant concessions of areas of the carpark or units of the store as set out under ‘Concessions’ above and/or Permitted Underleases (i) in relation to premises outside the footprint of the main store forming part of the relevant SLB Property over an aggregate area of up to (and including) 40% in total of the aggregate of gross external area (as measured in accordance with the Code of Measuring Practice issued by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors) of the buildings on the relevant SLB Property as at the date of the relevant Master Lease, (ii) in relation to unbuilt upon areas of the relevant SLB Property (including landscape area and car park, if applicable) over an aggregate area (at any one time) of up to (and including) 40% in total of the unbuilt upon areas of the relevant SLB Property as at the date or the relevant Master Lease and (iii) in relation to premises within the footprint of the main store forming part of the relevant SLB Property, over an aggregate area (at any one time) of up to (and including) 30% in total of the then current gross internal area (as measured in accordance with the Code of Measuring Practice issued by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors) of the buildings on the relevant SLB Property. _Charging_ The Tenant may charge its interest in respect of the whole of the Master Lease to reputable lending institutions to secure debt but cannot charge its interest in respect of only part of the Master Lease. _Events of Default_ The SLB Master Leases contain a customary event of default (forfeiture) provision, which include: (i) failure of the Tenant to pay the rent or any other sums due under the SLB Master Leases within 15 working days after the due date; (ii) the Tenant breaches any of its obligations in the SLB Master Leases; (iii) the bankruptcy of the Tenant or any guarantor, including liquidation, the appointment of an administrator or receiver, entry into a scheme of an arrangement with creditors or is subject to a winding up order under Part IV of the Insolvency Act 1986 unless for the purposes of a solvent amalgamation or reconstruction of the company; (iv) disclaimer of the SLB Master Leases by the Crown or by a liquidator or trustee in bankruptcy of the Tenant; (v) the Tenant or any guarantor is struck off the 261 ----- Register of Companies; (vi) the Tenant or any guarantor ceases to exist provided that (in respect of any of (i) – (vi)) in relation to any guarantor the landlord’s right of forfeiture shall only arise (i) where the Tenant at the time of the right arising does not meet the Rating Criteria and (ii) the Tenant fails to provide a replacement guarantor (to the extent relevant). There are standard mortgagee protection provisions in respect of the events of default relating to nonpayment of rent and breach of tenant obligations only (and only where such breach is remediable) which oblige the landlord to give notice to any mortgagee of the remedial actions required to remedy the relevant event of default and allow the mortgagee 28 days to complete the remedial actions following the service of such notice. _Insurance_ If the Tenant elects not to insure the relevant SLB Property, the landlord is obliged to insure the relevant SLB Property demised pursuant to the relevant Master Lease against insured risks (which includes standard insured risk events including fire, lightning, explosion, earthquake, landslip, heave, subsidence, riot, damage caused by terrorism, civil commotion, aircraft, aerial devices, storm, flood, water, bursting and overflowing of water tanks, apparatus or pipes, theft, impact by vehicles, malicious damage and third party liability and any other risks reasonably required by the landlord or the Tenant) to cover full rebuilding, site clearance, VAT and three (3) years’ loss of rent. The Tenant will pay the premium, as well as the cost of insurance valuations, excesses and the cost of rebuilding the relevant SLB Property if insurance monies are irrecoverable due to the Tenant’s breach of the lease. The landlord is obliged to use all reasonable but commercially prudent endeavours to obtain any consents required to reinstate insured damage. If it is not possible to reinstate the insured damage all insurance monies will belong to the landlord. _Termination due to damage by Insured or Uninsured Risks_ The landlord (subject to having complied with its obligations to reinstate) or Tenant may immediately determine the relevant Master Lease if at the expiry of the three (3) year rent suspension period following destruction or damage by an insured risk (which includes standard insured risk events including fire, lightning, explosion, earthquake, landslip, heave, subsidence, riot, damage caused by terrorism, civil commotion, aircraft, aerial devices, storm, flood, water, bursting and overflowing of water tanks, apparatus or pipes, theft, impact by vehicles, malicious damage and third party liability and any other risks reasonably required by the Landlord or the Tenant) the relevant SLB Property has not been substantially made good and remains unfit for occupation and or inaccessible by giving notice within six (6) months of the expiry of the three (3) year rent suspension period. In respect of damage to an SLB Property caused by uninsured damage (being damage caused by an uninsured risk) which causes the SLB Property to be incapable of occupation and use or to be inaccessible (i) the rent will not be suspended and will remain payable by the Tenant in accordance with the terms of the relevant Master Lease; (ii) where the uninsured damage occurs before August 10, 2043 in the case of the initial 22 SLB Properties (or November 15, 2043 for Kings Hill, September 13, 2043 for Poole and August 30, 2043 for Swindon (Haydon)), the Tenant shall reinstate or rebuild the Premises (iii) where the uninsured damage occurs on or after August 10, 2043 (or the relevant dates referred to in (ii) above, as applicable) the Tenant may elect to reinstate or rebuild the SLB Property or at any point four (4) months after the date of uninsured damage, subject to the Tenant not electing to reinstate or rebuild the SLB Property, the landlord may elect to reinstate or rebuild the SLB Property. If the uninsured damage occurs in the last five (5) years of the term of the SLB Master Leases and neither the landlord or Tenant have elected to rebuild or reinstate the SLB Property, the Tenant shall ensure that the SLB Property is kept in a safe secure and tidy condition. _Other Material Provisions_ There are extensive obligations on the Tenant in relation to compliance with environmental laws, providing data to the landlord in relation to environmental performance, and taking any required remedial action at the end of the term to return the relevant SLB Property in a standard required under environmental law. The landlord is not liable for any existing contamination at the SLB Properties. The Tenant provides an indemnity to the landlord against all loss arising from (i) the breach of any Tenant covenant or obligation; (ii) any works carried out to the relevant SLB Property by the Tenant; (iii) any act or default of a person in the relevant SLB Property with the express or implied consent of the Tenant; or (iv) the use of the relevant SLB Property by the Tenant or any person authorised by the Tenant. The landlord must take reasonable steps to mitigate any such loss, however, this is at the Tenant’s proper cost. 262 -----

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Ground Rent Transactions – Ground Rent Facility
Subsubsection Text: Asda Propco Limited (“Propco”) was incorporated to acquire 55 properties owned by Mclagan Investments Limited. The list of properties is as follows: 264 ----- Accrington, Ashington, Barnsley, Beeston (Leeds), Boldon, Bradford West, Breck Road, Bromborough, Bury St Edmunds, Canterbury, Carterton, Chatham, Cheltenham, Chorley, Clacton on Sea, Clayton Green, Corby, Darlaston, Eastbourne, Fareham, Fleetwood, Gateshead, Golborne, Gosforth, Grimsby, Harrogate, Hartlepool, Hereford, Huddersfield, Hull (Hessle Road), Keighley, Lancaster, Leeds Middleton, Newark, Oadby, Oldbury, Pentym, Pilsworth, Radcliffe, Rotherham, Runcorn, Shaw Oldham, Sittingbourne, Skelmersdale, South Wooton (Kings Lynn), Spennymoor, St Leonards on Sea, Cumbernauld (Scotland), Dalgety Bay (Scotland), Edinburgh (Scotland), Elgin (Scotland), Forfar (Scotland), Larkhall (Scotland), Perth (Scotland), Toryglen (Scotland) (together the “Initial CGR Properties” and together with any other properties which are acquired by Propco, the “CGR

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Asda Holdco 2 Limited (“Holdco 2”) was incorporated as a holding company for Propco, and Asda Holdco Limited (“Holdco”) was incorporated as a holding company for Holdco 2. Holdco 2’s only assets are the shares in Propco and its interest in intercompany loans it has made to Propco. Holdco’s only assets are the shares in Holdco 2 and its interest in intercompany loans it has made to Holdco 2. Prior to the transfer of the Initial CGR Properties to Propco, Mclagan Investments Limited entered into 99 year CGR Ground Leases (the “CGR Ground Leases” and each a “CGR Ground Lease”) in respect of the Initial CGR Properties with Asda Stores Limited (the “Tenant”). The Initial CGR Properties were transferred from Mclagan Investments Limited to Propco subject to and with the benefit of the CGR Ground Leases. The consideration payable by Propco to Mclagan Investments Limited for the acquisition of the Initial CGR Properties amounted to £646,660,032 and was funded in part by third party financing of £400,000,000 from the CGR Financing Lender (the “CGR

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Financing”) with the remainder funded by subordinated debt. Propco provided all assets security for the CGR
Subsubsection Title: The Economic Terms of the CGR Financing
Subsubsection Text: _Facilities and Term_ The CGR Financing was utilised in full on December 20, 2023. It comprises a facility A term loan, in the amount of £275,000,000 (“CGR **Facility A”) and a facility B term loan, in the amount of £125,000,000 (“CGR

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Financing”) with the remainder funded by subordinated debt. Propco provided all assets security for the CGR
Subsubsection Text: Financing, including but not limited to mortgages over its interests in the Initial CGR Properties, over its interest in the CGR Ground Leases, over its insurance policies and over its bank accounts. Holdco 2 provided security over its shares in Propco and in its intercompany debt owed to it by Propco. Propco and Holdco 2 also entered into an agreement subordinating that intercompany debt to the indebtedness under the CGR Financing. Propco’s only source of income is amounts received by it from the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases. The CGR Financing Lender’s source of funds to make the Facilities (as defined below) available was the proceeds of notes issued to certain third-party investors on or about the date of entry into the CGR Financing (the “CGR Notes”). Certain features of the CGR Financing reflect the responsibility of Propco for maintaining a rating in respect of the CGR Notes and for paying costs in respect of the CGR Notes structure. Two classes of Notes were issued: £275,000,000 of Class A CGR Notes due 2068 (the “Class A CGR Notes”) and £125,000,000 of Class B CGR Notes due 2073.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Title: Representations and Undertakings under the CGR Financing
Subsubsection Text: The CGR Financing is documented under a suite of finance documents based on Loan Market Association and other market precedents for limited recourse real estate financing transactions. The documentation includes provisions of a type typically included in real estate finance transactions in the European market, including but not limited to cost and indemnity provisions in favour of the finance parties. The CGR Financing loan agreement also includes representations and undertakings of a type seen in European real estate financing transactions. As such, there are broad restrictions on (amongst other things) Propco incurring further indebtedness, making acquisitions and making disposals. Outside the substitution and release regimes (see “—Substitution mechanics under the CGR Financing” and “—Release of CGR Properties on redemption of CGR Notes”), Propco is restricted from disposing of the CGR Properties and acquiring properties. Propco is subject to restrictions on taking non-ordinary course actions under the CGR Ground Leases (including changing, amending, terminating, forfeiting of the CGR Ground Leases). Propco and Holdco 2 are required to maintain the appointment of an independent director to their respective boards through the term of the CGR Financing. As is common in financings of this nature, certain undertakings and covenants of the CGR Financing require Propco to procure that the transaction obligors take or refrain from taking certain actions. Propco does not have any contractual, corporate or other legal ability to control the actions of the other transaction obligors and so their actions or inactions could cause a breach without Propco having any recourse or ability to prevent it. By way of mitigation, all of the transaction obligors are also controlled by the wider Asda group. The transaction obligors under the CGR Financing are (as well as Propco), Asda Holdco 2 Limited, Asda Group Limited and (for so long as it is an affiliate of Propco) Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited. Asda Group Limited and Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited are not considered as transaction obligors in all instances, but there are nonetheless situations where Propco has procurement obligations in their regard.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: On June 30 in each calendar year beginning on June 30, 2029, certain trigger events may require Propco to deposit cash (from subordinated debt, equity injection or free cash in the general account) as additional collateral for the CGR Financing or substitute applicable Affected Portfolio Stores (as defined below). The trigger events are: (i) fixed charge cover ratio of less than 2.5x; (ii) the CGR Notes are rated BBB+ or lower; (iii) portfolio gearing is greater than 30%; (iv) any stores has an average historical sales density that is in the lowers 10% of average historical sales densities of all superstores (being any store operated by Asda Group Limited or any of its subsidiaries) which has a net sales area of 15,000 square feet or more (“Superstores”) (“Affected Portfolio Stores”); (v) loan to value (vacant possession) is greater than 65%; and (vi) no more than seven Affected Portfolio Stores have been substituted out. The amount of cash required to be deposited depends on the percentage of stores operated on CGR Properties (“Portfolio Stores”) that are Affected Portfolio Stores. It ranges from (if the Affected Portfolio Stores represent less than 15% of such rent for all Portfolio Stores) 12 months’ of rent for all Affected Portfolio Stores for the year to June 30 (“Allocated Rent”) to double the Allocated Rent (if Affected Portfolio Stores represent 50% or more of portfolio Allocated Rent). 268 ----- If Propco opts to substitute, it has 80 business days to do so. Otherwise, Propco has 90 business days to deposit the cash or deliver an acceptable letter of credit. Such cash call collateral will be released to Propco’s general account if (i) any Portfolio Store is no longer in the lowest 15% of all average historical sales densities of all Superstores and (ii) there are no other Affected Portfolio Stores, (or if a letter of credit has been delivered, it will be returned). The cash collateral will also be released (or the letter of credit returned) if: (a) the relevant CGR Property is substituted out; or (b) vacant possession loan to value is less than 65%.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Title: Events of Default under the CGR Financing
Subsubsection Text: The CGR Financing is subject to market standard events of default, subject in some cases to grace periods, materiality qualifiers and other negotiated qualifiers in favour of Propco, certain of which are described in more detail below. There are events of default in respect of amongst other things certain breaches of the finance documents, misrepresentation and insolvency. The events of default triggered by compulsory purchase or major damage are subject to the ability to substitute the effective CGR Property and therefore avoid an event of default occurring. Certain events of default can be triggered by circumstances relating to transaction obligors under the CGR Financing (see “—Representations and Undertakings under the CGR Financing”). It is an event of default under the CGR Financing if ASDA Group Limited or any of its subsidiaries fails to comply with its obligations under the CGR Financing tax deed of covenant or breaches any representation and/or warranty set out therein. Market standard events of default are also included for (1) non-compliance of any transaction obligor with any provisions of the Finance Documents; (2) misrepresentation by a transaction obligor; (3) cross default of any financial indebtedness of a transaction obligor; (4) insolvency (but not of Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited); (5) insolvency proceedings (but not of Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited), (6) creditor’s process (but not of Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited); (7) cessation of business (but not of Asda Group Limited or Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited); (8) unlawfulness and invalidity; and (9) repudiation and rescission of agreements. Events of default are included for the insolvency of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases, and for persistent non-payment under or material breach of the CGR Ground Leases. In the case of the latter, such an event of default will not arise unless a notice of intended forfeiture under s.146 Law of Property Act 1925 (or an irritancy warning notice in respect of CGR Properties in Scotland) has been served on the Tenant and the Tenant has not complied with such notice, and Propco has not substituted the affected CGR Property. It is an event of default if a judgment of a court, arbitral body or agency which is reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect is issued against Propco, Holdco 2 or the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases. It is an event of default if at any time Propco does not maintain the Expenses Reserve Amount. This event of default is subject to a five business day grace period if there is a shortage of funds available in the rent account to top up the reserve, but all amounts under the CGR Ground Leases have been paid in full. It is an event of default if the CGR Notes are no longer rated and such failure causes the CGR Financing Lender to cease to be a “note-issuing company” within the meaning of Regulation 5 Taxation of Securitisation Company Regulation 2006 (SI 2006/3296). It is also an event of default if any of the CGR Notes are not rated, subject to a carve-out where Propco is in compliance with its obligations under the CGR Financing that relate to maintaining the rating, and a replacement rating is obtained within 90 days. No event of default arises in the event of a deterioration in the rating of the CGR Notes.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Title: Substitution mechanics under the CGR Financing
Subsubsection Text: Propco can elect to substitute a CGR Property rather than applying capital proceeds relating to that CGR Property in prepayment of the loans, which attracts a make whole payment. Propco can request to substitute a CGR Property for another property at any time, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions including the provision of certain documentary conditions precedent. Any costs associated with the substitution process itself and any increase in the budget resulting from the substitution must be funded in advance into the bank accounts structure from subordinated debt or an equity injection. 269 ----- Propco can request to remove a CGR Property from the transaction perimeter for cash (in an amount equal to the portion of the loans that corresponds to the proportion the vacant possession value of the outgoing CGR Property bears to the overall vacant possession value of all CGR Properties, plus a make-whole amount that would apply on the application of such amount in prepayment of the CGR Financing), subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. Following such removal, Propco has the ability to bring a new property into the structure within six months (subject to satisfaction of certain documentary conditions precedent), in which case the cash is released to Propco. If no new property is substituted in with six months, the cash is swept in prepayment of the loans and payment of the associated make-whole.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Title: Release of CGR Properties on redemption of CGR Notes
Subsubsection Text: At any time following redemption of the Class A CGR Notes, or within six months of a mandatory prepayment of the CGR Financing due to a redemption of the CGR Notes for taxation, illegality, change of control or recharacterisation of the CGR Financing as a securitisation for the purposes of relevant EU Securitisation Regulation Rules and UK Securitisation Regulation Rules, Propco may request the release of certain CGR Properties from the CGR Financing Transaction. Any costs associated with the release process itself and any increase in the budget resulting from the release must be funded in advance into the bank accounts structure from subordinated debt or an equity injection. The release of the relevant CGR Properties is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including the provision of certain documentary conditions precedent.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the Initial CGR Properties, it is intended that Pyle Asda (title number WA385790, address Asda supermarket at Land to the east of Pyle Road, Pyle, CF33 6BU) will be added as an additional Property on or before June 30, 2024. Propco has deposited £713,462 into a lender-controlled account, and the amortisation schedule has been amended by a commensurate amount from the original amortisation schedule. If Pyle Asda is not added to the CGR Financing on or before June 30, 2024 with the result that the aggregate principal rent for all CGR Properties increases by £300,000 (disregarding indexation), then the £713,462 will be swept in repayment of the financing without attracting a make-whole and the CGR Financing will revert to the original amortisation schedule.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: On or before June 30, 2024, in respect of the CGR Properties at Harrogate and Fleetwood, Propco is required either to (a) have engaged Delta Simmons to carry out environmental due diligence and provided evidence that such properties are rated as less than “moderate”; or (b) to have substituted those CGR Properties (see “—Substitution _mechanics under the CGR Financing”)._ On or before December 15, 2024, in respect of the CGR Properties at Radcliffe, Hartlepool and Barnsley, Propco is required either to (a) have engaged Delta Simmons to carry out environmental due diligence and provided evidence that such properties are rated as less than “moderate”; or (b) to have substituted those Properties (see “— _Substitution mechanics under the CGR Financing”)._ In all cases, the environmental due diligence or substitution (as applicable) will be at Propco’s cost. Propco has elected the substitute the CGR Properties referred to above and intend to acquire the following properties from Mclagan Investments Limited: Sefton Park, Bodmin, Pyle, Dewsbury, Quedgeley, Harworth, Ayr Resite and Bishopbriggs.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: The CGR Financing Lender, Propco and Asda Group Limited have entered into a tax deed of covenant for the purposes of managing certain group level tax compliance obligations. The tax deed of covenant provides for a framework to manage, among other things, the surrender of group relief in and out of Propco, the corporate interest restriction position for Propco as a member of the wider Asda group, the application of transfer pricing between Propco 270 ----- and other members of the wider Asda Group and the accounting consolidation of the CGR Financing Lender. The purpose of such provisions is to ensure that the tax profile of Propco is in line with the financial model assumptions. In addition to the management of certain group level tax compliance obligations, the tax deed of covenant contains a tax indemnity given by Asda Group Limited to Propco to cover the imposition of unexpected tax liabilities arising in connection with the Asda group. For example, the tax deed of covenant contains an indemnity covering the imposition of any secondary liability taxes or the imposition of any de-grouping charge. The purpose of such tax indemnities is to ensure that there are no unexpected liabilities which would impact the tax profile of Propco and cause deviations from the financial model.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: Asda Group Limited has provided an indemnity in favour of the CGR Financing Lender for any increased costs it incurs itself, and for any liability for increased costs incurred by noteholders in each case in the event the transaction is recharacterised as a securitisation under UK Securitisation Regulation Rules or EU Securitisation Regulation Rules. In addition, Asda Group Limited undertakes to take such actions as are within its control to comply with UK Securitisation Regulation Rules and EU Securitisation Regulation Rules, and to procure that Propco and any relevant affiliate does likewise.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: “EU Securitisation Regulation Rules” means Regulation (EU) 2017/2402 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 December 2017 laying down a general framework for securitisation and creating a specific framework for simple, transparent and standardised securitisation, and (i) all regulatory technical standards and implementing technical standards made pursuant thereto or otherwise applicable in relation thereto; (ii) all official guidance published, or otherwise applicable, in relation thereto; and (iii) all related national implementing measures, all, except as otherwise expressly stated, as amended, varied, substituted, replaced or superseded from time to time. “UK Securitisation Regulation Rules” means Regulation (EU) 2017/2402 as it forms part of the domestic law of the United Kingdom by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, as amended by the Securitisation (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 and (i) all technical standards made pursuant thereto or otherwise applicable in relation thereto, and (ii) all official binding guidance published, or otherwise applicable, in relation thereto, all, except as otherwise expressly stated, as further amended, varied or substituted from time to time.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: The CGR Ground Leases were originally entered into between McLagan Investments Limited and Asda Stores Limited, however, the reversionary interest in each CGR Ground Lease was transferred to Asda Propco Limited shortly after the CGR Ground Leases were entered into. _Scotland_ A kilted form of the CGR Ground Leases for the stores in Scotland follows the same format as the CGR Ground Leases with references to equivalent legislation (where relevant) applicable to property in Scotland. _Term_ The initial term of the CGR Ground Leases is for a term of years commencing on December 12, 2023 to and including December 11, 2122. _Rent_ The CGR Ground Leases each reserve a different rent payable by the Tenant, payable in equal instalments on the first day of each calendar month. The rent is subject to an annual review on December 1 in each year of the term of the CGR Ground Leases which is, linked to the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index for the period from the immediately preceding rent review date to the current rent review date subject to a cap of 4% and a collar of 0%. Interest is payable at 3% per annum above the Barclays base rate on any sums (including but not limited to rent) not paid by the tenant on the date they are due. The Tenant is also required to pay all outgoings (including but not 271 ----- limited to business rates, taxes, gas and electricity) and landlord fees. For the period of December 12, 2023 to November 30, 2024, the aggregate rent payable under the CGR Ground Leases is £23,173,323 (and will increase slightly following the substitution of certain CGR Properties, which is anticipated to take place on or about April 30, 2024). _Landlord and Tenant Act 1954_ The CGR Ground Leases in England & Wales benefit from a Tenant statutory right of renewal pursuant to the provisions of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable to the CGR Ground Leases of the Scottish assets). The Tenant has a right to renew the CGR Ground Leases in England & Wales at the end of the term, subject to some limited grounds of opposition available to the landlord pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954. _Guarantor_ There is no guarantor party to the CGR Ground Leases in respect of the Tenant’s obligations. _Use_ The Tenant may only use the CGR Ground Leases as (1) retail stores within Class E of the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 and as ancillary to such use; and (2) any other use (other than specifically excluded uses, including but not limited to manufacturing of tobacco products or weapons, any illegal or immoral purposes, or residential use) where the Tenant has demonstrated to the reasonable satisfaction of the landlord that such use would not materially adversely affect the landlord’s interest. The Tenant may also permit undertenants to use a part of the premises for any use within Class E or Class F which is commonly found in supermarkets from time to time (other than the same specifically excluded uses as above). _Maintenance, Alterations and Expansion_ The Tenant, at its sole expense, is to keep and maintain the relevant CGR Property demised under the CGR Ground Leases in good and substantial repair and condition. The Tenant must commission regular fire safety risk assessments no less than every four (4) years and implement any recommendations from such reports. The Tenant must, following service of any notice by the landlord (in respect of the Tenant’s maintenance, alterations and repair obligations under the CGR Ground Leases) or public authority, commence any repairs to the relevant CGR Property required by that notice within a reasonable period. If the Tenant does not comply with such notice (save for in respect of minor repairs) and continues to fail to comply twenty (20) working days after service of a further notice by the landlord then the landlord (upon giving the Tenant 14 days’ notice) may enter the relevant CGR Property to carry out the repairs. The costs incurred by the landlord in carrying out such repairs are to be borne by the Tenant. The Tenant must indemnify the landlord in respect of injury or death to any person or damage to property arising from the state of repair and condition of the premises arising from any act, default or negligence of the Tenant in breach of the lease. The Tenant may carry out all alterations, including major alterations (those being demolition of structures or any structural additions to or creation of any new buildings the net effect of which either (i) increases the gross external area and/or the gross internal area of the buildings by more than 50%; (ii) decreases the gross external area and/or the gross internal area of the buildings by more than 50% or (iii) would involve the demolition of more than 50% of the gross external area and/or the gross internal area of the buildings) if the Tenant (i) provides the landlord with at least 20 working days’ notice of the proposed alterations; (ii) obtains any required planning authority; (iii) carries out the works in a good and workmanlike manner and in compliance with permissions and applicable statute; (iv) keeps and provides access to the landlord to CDM regulation records and drawings of alterations; and (v) in the case of major alterations, prior to commencement, demonstrates to the reasonable satisfaction of the landlord that such major alterations would not materially adversely affect the landlord’s interest in the relevant CGR Property and thereafter permits the landlord to inspect progress of the works. The Tenant may not carry out any alterations which will adversely affecting any asset rating, EPC rating or environmental performance of the relevant CGR Property or materially adversely affect the Landlord’s interest in the relevant CGR Property. 272 ----- _Yield Up_ The Tenant is required to return the CGR Properties at the expiry of the term (1) with all additions and improvements to the premises and all fixtures and fittings in the premises, other than the Tenant’s fixtures and fittings which the Tenant shall be entitled to remove; and (2) free of any third party occupation or third party occupational rights. The Tenant is not required to demolish or remove any buildings or alterations carried out in accordance with the terms of the relevant CGR Ground Lease, nor remove any plant, machinery, lifts, flooring, etc. _Assignment_ The CGR Ground Leases do not permit the Tenant to assign the CGR Ground Leases. _Subletting_ The CGR Ground Leases contain broad subletting rights in favour of the Tenant. The Tenant may underlet the whole or part of the CGR Properties (other than to an individual, company or entity that (i) manufacture tobacco products; (ii) derives 25% or more of its revenue from the wholesale distribution of tobacco products and/or (iii) derives 25% or more of its revenue from the retail sale of tobacco products) ((i) to (iii) inclusive being “Excluded

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent
Subsubsection Text: facility agreement (the “Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement”). - The maturity date for CGR Facility A is December 12, 2068. - The maturity date for CGR Facility B is December 12, 2073. _Principal indexation and amortisation_ CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B each amortise monthly. The outstanding principal balance of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B (and each repayment instalment) are subject to annual indexation in December of each year. The rate of indexation is calculated as current ‘all items’ CPI divided by the ‘all items’ CPI as at the previous annual review date. It is subject to a floor of 1x and a ceiling of 265 ----- 1.04x, meaning that on each annual indexation date the principal amount and reinstalments will either stay the same or be multiplied by a maximum 1.04 times. Rental payments under the CGR Ground Leases are subject to indexation at the same time annually and in accordance with the same formula such that increases in amounts due under the CGR Financing in respect of interest and amortisation are matched by increases in rent under the CGR Ground Leases. _Interest_ Interest is payable monthly and comprises margin and the benchmark rate. For CGR Facility A the margin is 2.8% and the benchmark rate is 0.990%. For CGR Facility B the margin is 2.944% and the benchmark rate is 1.021%. Default interest accrues on overdue amounts at a rate that is 3% per annum higher than the rate that would otherwise have applied. _Fees and Make whole_ Periodic fees are paid to the agency, security agent and cash manager under the terms of the CGR Financing. A make whole fee is payable on prepayment or cancellation of commitments. The amount of the fee is the sum of the present value of the aggregate scheduled principal and interest payments that would have accrued and become due and payable in respect of the amount prepaid or cancelled from the date of prepayment or cancellation up to the relevant maturity date, discounted to the date of prepayment or cancellation at a rate equal to the reinvestment yield for the relevant Ground Rent Facility plus 0.5%. The ‘reinvestment yield’ is the yield to maturity implied by (a) the ask-side yields reported, as of 10.00 A.M. (London time) on the second Business Day preceding the Settlement Date on the display designated “Page PXUK” on Bloomberg Financial Markets (or such other display as may replace “Page PXUK” on Bloomberg Financial Markets) for actively traded index linked gilt-edged securities having a maturity of the Discount Period; or (b) if such yields are not reported as of such time or the yields reported are not ascertainable, the average of the ask-side yields as determined by the index linked gilt-edged market makers (as registered with the Bank of England). Such implied yield will be determined, if necessary, by: (i) converting quotations to bond-equivalent yields in accordance with accepted financial practice; and (ii) interpolating linearly between the ask-side yields for the (1) actively traded index-linked gilt-edged security with the maturity closest to and greater than the Discount Period and (2) actively traded index-linked gilt-edged security with the maturity closest to and less than the Discount Period. In this paragraph the “Discount Period” is the period between the applicable prepayment/cancellation date and the applicable maturity date. For the purposes of the make-whole, no indexation is assumed after the date of the prepayment or cancelation (as applicable). The make-whole does not apply in the case of prepayment due to illegality, or note level illegality, a tax event or a securitisation regulatory event. The make-whole also does not apply on the periodic amortisation payments. The make-whole does apply to other mandatory prepayments, including from lease prepayment proceeds, insurance prepayment proceeds, compensation prepayment proceeds in respect of compulsory purchase and recovery prepayment proceeds from claims against report providers. If such amounts are received, Propco has the option to substitute the affected CGR Property out of the CGR Financing. If the substitution occurs within six months of receipt of the relevant payment, then the amount will not be swept in prepayment and therefore no make-whole will apply. In addition, certain compensation proceeds, insurance proceeds and report recovery proceeds are excluded from the mandatory prepayment requirement. _Costs and indemnities_ Market standard cost and indemnity provisions are included under the terms of the CGR Financing, including requirements to pay costs and increased costs relating to the CGR Financing and the CGR Notes structure. This includes ongoing operating costs, amendment costs and enforcement and preservation costs. 266 ----- Propco is required to pay reasonably incurred costs of the finance parties in connection with substitutions and with release of security following redemption of the CGR Notes. Propco is required to pay the costs of valuations required under the terms of the CGR Financing, as well as the costs of any valuation required in connection with a substitution or the release of collateral on maturity of the CGR Notes. _Cashflows and Reserves_ The CGR Financing requires Propco to retain bank accounts with a bank with a requisite rating. The bank accounts are subject to security and (other than a Propco-controlled general account) are controlled by a cash manager on behalf of the finance parties. Net rental income and other amounts received by Propco must be paid into the bank accounts and there are detailed provisions in the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement as to the application of cash flows, including payment of operating costs, interest, amortisation. The transaction has been modelled such that all outgoings of Propco are intended to be funded by receipts under and in respect of the CGR Ground Leases. _Payments waterfall_ Net rental income and certain other receipts must be paid into Propco’s rent account. A monthly cashflow payments waterfall is run by a cash manager. This provides for payment of (1) capital receipts to be applied in mandatory prepayment; (2) finance party and account bank costs, fees and expenses; (3) taxes and general corporate maintenance costs of Propco, Holdco 2 or the CGR Financing Lender (subject in the case of such corporate maintenance costs, to a cap of £250,000 per annum annually adjusted by CPI); (4) standby servicer and step-in servicer costs, fees and expenses; (5) costs, fees and expenses due to the finance parties; (6) interest due under the CGR Financing; (7) principal due under the CGR Financing; (8) payment of increased costs in respect of the lenders under the CGR Financing, and increased costs in respect of the holders of the CGR Notes; (9) topping up the debt service reserve (see below); (10) any budgeted amount required to pay ongoing operating/structural costs not already paid above, and any costs and expenses related to a CGR Property substitution or release of collateral; (11) other amounts due to the finance parties under the CGR Financing; and (12) any excess to Propco’s general account unless a cash trap event is continuing in which case such surplus is transferred to the cash trap account. It is a cash trap event if at any time the historic debt service coverage ratio is less than 1.05x on a twelve-month lookback basis. If a cash trap event is continuing on two consecutive interest payment dates, the cash manager is required to apply the monies in the cash trap account in prepayment of the Ground Rent Facility (together with the make-whole (see section 4 above)). If a cash trap event is not continuing on two consecutive interest payment dates, the cash manager shall release the monies to the Propco-controlled general account. _Debt Service Reserve_ A 12-month reserve in respect of items (2) through (6) listed and the amount projected to be payable pursuant to item (7) over the next 12 interest payment dates under “—Payments waterfall” must be maintained by Propco in the debt service account at all times, or alternatively a letter of credit may be provided in an equivalent amount. The debt service reserve is held on trust for the original lender under the CGR Financing and will not form part of Propco’s estate in an insolvency. Any excess so reserved on any monthly interest payment date is released to Propco’s general account (and such excess does not form part of the trust property). _Expenses Reserve_ Propco must prepare an annual budget detailing the ongoing costs of Propco, Holdco 2, the CGR Financing Lender and certain other costs associated with CGR Financing together with the costs associated with any scheduled substitutions of the CGR Properties. Propco must at all times maintain a 12-month reserve in respect of any such costs (the “Expenses Reserve Amount”). 267 ----- _Cures_ Provided the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases is in compliance with all obligations to pay rent, Propco is permitted to use the proceeds of subordinated debt or equity injections or free cash in the general account to make up for any shortfalls in amounts available to make the payments under the debt service waterfall (see “Cashflows and _Reserves—Payments waterfall”). This may be done within the period between the rental payment date under the CGR_ Ground Leases and the date falling four business days before the next monthly interest payment date. Otherwise Propco is restricted from receiving amounts by way of subordinated debt or equity injection.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Occupiers”) without landlord consent provided that: (a) any underletting is not granted for a premium; (b) any
Subsubsection Text: The Shaw CGR Ground Lease includes an additional obligation on the Tenant to investigate the relevant property to determine the extent of any Japanese knotweed present at the premises and to take action at its own cost as necessary to treat or remove such Japanese knotweed. (i) Clayton; (ii) Keighley; (iii) Lancaster; (iv) Pilsworth; (v) Radcliffe and (vi) St Leonards-on-Sea: these CGR Ground Leases contain various carve outs in the provisions relating to underletting or renewal of an existing occupational lease (which is defined by reference to the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement). (i) Chorley; (ii) Gateshead; (iii) Huddersfield; (iv) Newark and (v) Shaw: the reversionary interests in these CGR Properties are leasehold properties therefore the CGR Ground Leases for these CGR Properties include an obligation on the Tenant to observe and comply with the tenant obligations under the terms of the relevant headlease and obtain superior landlord consents where necessary under the terms of the relevant headlease insofar as they relate to the relevant store. 275 -----

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Occupiers”) without landlord consent provided that: (a) any underletting is not granted for a premium; (b) any
Subsubsection Text: underletting must expire before expiry of the CGR Ground Leases; (c) any underletting is consistent with normal market practice, including as to incentives, inducements, tenant covenants and rent review; (d) any underletting must include covenants which are not inconsistent with or impair due performance and observance of the tenant covenants in the CGR Ground Leases; (e) any underletting includes provisions as to forfeiture for non-payment of rent, breach of covenant and insolvency; (f) any underletting of part must not permit the undertenant to create further underleases of part but may allow further underleases of whole (subject to obtaining the landlord’s consent, not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed), so long as such underlease is not to an Excluded Occupier and otherwise complies with the underletting requirements in the CGR Ground Leases; (g) any underletting of the whole of the relevant CGR Property or store must (i) be for a term which does not exceed 25 years; (ii) not benefit from the statutory right of renewal pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for CGR Properties in Scotland) and (iii) be for a rent which is the market rent reasonably obtainable at the time of the grant of the underlease and contains provisions for the review of rent consistent with market practice at the time of the grant of the underlease; (h) if any underletting is to a tenant group company or affiliate of the tenant then the underletting must (i) not benefit from the statutory right of renewal pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for CGR Properties in Scotland); (ii) contain a break right in favour of the landlord of the underlease, exercisable if a CGR Ground Lease is terminated or otherwise comes to an end and at the time the break right arises the tenant of the underlease is a group company or affiliate of the Tenant of the CGR Ground Lease; (i) any underletting must not have a material adverse effect on the value of the landlord’s interest in the relevant CGR Property; (j) any underletting must contain the same rights reserved to the landlord in the relevant CGR Ground Lease; (k) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease must take reasonable steps to remedy any underlessee’s breach of terms of the CGR Ground Lease if such breach has the potential to materially adversely affect the landlord’s interest in the premises; (l) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease shall take reasonable steps to enforce the performance and observance of the covenants by the undertenant contained in any underlease; (m) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease shall ensure that the rent payable under any underlease shall not be reduced or paid more than one quarter in advance and (n) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease shall ensure that the rent under any underlease is reviewed in accordance with the terms of the underlease. In respect of any underlease of the whole of the relevant premises or store, the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease must not vary or waive the terms without the CGR Ground Lease landlord’s consent (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed) or where such variation results in the terms of the underlease being inconsistent with the assignment and subletting provisions contained in the CGR Ground Lease or breaching the conditions for underleases. If a tenant under any underlease of the relevant CGR Property becomes a group company of the tenant, or if a Tenant under an underlease of whole or any part of the relevant store becomes an affiliate of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease, within 12 months, the relevant underlease must be varied to contain a landlord break right permitting the landlord under the underlease to terminate the underlease if (i) the CGR Ground Lease is terminated or otherwise comes to an end in any way and (ii) at the time that the break right arises the tenant of such underlease is a group company or affiliate of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease. 273 ----- If a tenant under an underlease of part of the relevant CGR Property that is not located within the relevant stores becomes an affiliate of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease, on and from such date the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease must use reasonable endeavours to ensure that the relevant underlease is varied to include a landlord break right permitting the landlord under the underlease to terminate the underlease if (i) the CGR Ground Lease is terminated or otherwise comes to an end in any way and (ii) at the time that the break right arises the tenant of such underlease is a group company or affiliate of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease. _Sharing Occupation_ The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may permit a group company (so long as such group company is not an Excluded Occupier) to share occupation provided that no relationship of landlord and tenant is created and such occupation ceases as soon as the companies cease to be group companies or, if earlier, the date on which the CGR Ground Lease expires or otherwise comes to an end. The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may share occupation of part of the relevant premises with a concessionaire, franchisee or licensee (so long as such concessionaire, franchisee or licensee is not an Excluded Occupier) provided no relationship of landlord and tenant is created. _Charging_ The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may not charge part of the relevant CGR Property. The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may charge the whole of the relevant CGR Property provided that prior to such charging the chargee has been supplied with full copies of any documents made supplemental or collateral to the CGR Ground Lease and the Tenant shall use reasonable endeavours to procure that an acknowledgement of that is documented in the charging document. _Events of Default_ The CGR Ground Leases contain customary event of default and forfeiture provisions. The landlord may reenter and forfeit the CGR Ground Lease if (i) the whole or any part of the rent or any other sums due under the CGR Ground Lease remain unpaid more than 60 days after the due date for payment or (ii) the Tenant materially fails to perform or observe any of the Tenant’s material covenants in the CGR Ground Lease and fails to remedy the breach within a reasonable period of time (the landlord giving the Tenant written notice of the aforesaid breach together with details of anything necessary to be in done in order to remedy the aforesaid breach) or (iii) if (A) the Tenant is a company or a limited partnership: (i) a meeting of the Tenant’s creditors or any of them is summoned under Part I of the Insolvency Act 1986 and/or (ii) the Tenant enters into a compromise, scheme or arrangement or restructuring under Part 26 or Part 26A of the Companies Act 2006 or (B) if the Tenant is a partnership, it is subject to an event similar to any listed in (A) (together with (A), a “Credit Event”) and as a consequence of any such Credit Event there is a reduction in the rent paid or payable by the Tenant under a CGR Ground Lease (including any changes to the rent after any rent review as contemplated by the CGR Ground Lease)– this event of default was added by way of a deed of variation (which is not registered at HM Land Registry) dated December 20, 2023 to all of the CGR Ground Leases. Where the Tenant has charged its interest in the CGR Ground Lease to a mortgagee and the landlord has notice of such charge, before commencing any forfeiture proceedings in relation to the CGR Ground Lease or exercising any right of re-entry the landlord shall give notice of the breach and details of anything necessary to be done in order to remedy the aforesaid breach to the mortgagee and if the mortgagee confirms in writing to the landlord within fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice that it wishes to remedy the breach, allow the mortgagee (i) in respect of non-payment of rent or other sums due under the CGR Ground Lease, thirty (30) days; and (ii) in respect of a breach of any condition or Tenant covenant in the CGR Ground Lease, sixty (60) days or such longer period as be reasonable in view of the nature of the breach, to complete the remedial actions following the service of such notice. _Insurance_ The Tenant shall insure and keep insured the relevant premises against damage or destruction by insured risks (such risks include fire, lightning, explosion, earthquake, landslip, heave, subsidence, riot, damage caused by terrorism, civil commotion, aircraft, aerial devices, storm, flood, water, bursting and overflowing of water tanks, apparatus or pipes, theft, impact by vehicles, malicious damage and third party liability and any other risks reasonably 274 ----- required by the landlord or the Tenant) and such insurance shall cover the relevant premises (excluding Tenant’s fixtures and fittings) for full reinstatement cost, as well as cover third party liability and public liability at the relevant premises and shall comply with the obligations of the landlord (in its capacity as borrower) under the Facility Agreement. If the Tenant does not maintain insurance pursuant to the terms of the CGR Ground Lease, the landlord may effect the insurance (at the Tenant’s expense). _Damage by Insured or Uninsured Risks_ The Tenant is obliged to reinstate the relevant CGR Property if the relevant CGR Property is damaged or destroyed by an insured or uninsured risk and the Tenant must make up any shortfall of costs out of its own resources where no or insufficient insurance monies are available. The Tenant shall procure deeds of collateral warranty from any contractors or sub-contractors involved in completing the reinstatement works, such deeds of collateral warranty being for the benefit of the landlord and any funder. If it is not possible for the Tenant to reinstate the relevant CGR Property due to reasons beyond the reasonable control of the Tenant, then the Tenant shall only be obliged to keep the relevant CGR Property in a safe condition and in compliance with any statutory requirements and shall direct the insurer to pay to the landlord the proportion of insurance proceeds which would have been applied towards reinstatement. At all times while the CGR Financing is subsisting, any insurance proceeds received by the Tenant or landlord which relate to reinstatement shall be dealt with as required under the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement. _Other Material Provisions_ There are extensive obligations on the Tenant in relation to compliance with environmental laws, providing data to the landlord in relation to environmental performance, and taking any required remedial action at the end of the term to return the relevant CGR Property in a standard required under environmental law. The landlord is not liable for any existing contamination at the CGR Properties. The Tenant provides an indemnity to the landlord against all loss arising from (i) the breach of any Tenant covenant or obligation in the relevant CGR Ground Lease or any other agreement affecting the relevant CGR Property (entered into by the Tenant or to which the Tenant consents); and (ii) any breach by the landlord of the superior lease that is caused by an act or default by the Tenant. There are no rent cessation provisions in the event of (among other causes) any damage or destruction to the CGR Properties, any interference with the use of the CGR Properties, any default by the landlord under the CGR Ground Leases, or any other cause whatsoever. The Tenant shall not terminate the CGR Ground Leases and waives any right to reduce any rent or other sums payable under the CGR Ground Leases. The Tenant acknowledges that the landlord may charge the CGR Ground Leases and that no amendment or waiver of any provision in the CGR Ground Leases shall have effect without the mortgagee’s prior written consent.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Scotland: a kilted form of the CGR Ground Leases for the stores in Scotland follows largely the same format
Subsubsection Text: as the CGR Ground Leases for the stores in England & Wales, with the following changes: o Statutory references have been amended to applicable Scottish law. In particular, references to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 have been removed as the act is not applicable in Scotland, meaning that the tenant has no statutory right to renew. o The mortgagee protection rights in relation to forfeiture of the lease are slightly different to reflect applicable Scottish law. o All references to superior leases are removed throughout the CGR Ground Leases in Scotland, because there are no superior leases. o The alteration provisions are amended to remove the landlord’s step in rights and to expressly confirm that the Tenant’s obligations apply regardless of the cause of damage or destruction, even if the cause is a latent or inherent defect again, to reflect applicable Scottish law. o The underletting provisions are amended to remove the requirement for a landlord break right in the event of any underleases of the whole of the premises or of the whole of the store to group or affiliate companies. 276 -----

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a summary of the material terms of the Group’s principal financing arrangements in addition to the Senior Secured Notes Indenture after giving effect to the Offering. The following summaries do not purport to describe all of the applicable terms and conditions of such arrangements and are qualified in their entirety by reference to the actual agreements. The Group recommends you refer to the actual agreements for further details, copies of which are available upon request._

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, secured as set forth under “—Security”; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future Indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Senior Secured Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s Guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation (including obligations to trade creditors) of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its Subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness only, including liabilities in connection with the America Ground Rent Transaction and secured lease liabilities; - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the Subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that are not Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors and liabilities in connection with the America Ground Rent Transaction and lease liabilities; and - be guaranteed, on the Issue Date, on a senior basis, by the Guarantors, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and the limitations described herein and in “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Capital _Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness—Each Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit its validity and enforceability” and “Certain Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Holders of the Senior Secured Notes will receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral on a pari passu basis with all Indebtedness that is secured on an equal and ratable basis with the Senior Secured Notes, including obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes and certain Hedging Obligations, and in priority to any Indebtedness that is secured on a junior basis to the Senior Secured Notes, including, with respect to Shared Security, obligations under the Existing Senior Notes; _provided, however,_ that under certain circumstances, certain Indebtedness and Hedging Obligations may be re-designated as “super senior” obligations under the Intercreditor Agreement, and following such redesignation, Holders will only receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral after the obligations thereunder have been paid in full. See “—Security—Priority,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor _Agreement” and “—Certain Definitions—Permitted Collateral Liens.”_

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors, subject to the Agreed Security Principles. In addition, if required by the covenant described under “—Certain Covenants—Additional Notes Guarantees,” certain other Restricted Subsidiaries may provide a Notes Guarantee in the future. Each Notes Guarantee will: - be a general senior obligation of the applicable Guarantor, secured as set forth under “—Security”; 278 ----- - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing or future Indebtedness of the applicable Guarantor that is not subordinated in right of payment to the applicable Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Senior Secured Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing or future Indebtedness of the applicable Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the applicable Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s Guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the applicable Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes Guarantee to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness or obligation only, including liabilities in connection with the America Ground Rent Transaction and secured lease liabilities; - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation of the Subsidiaries of the applicable Guarantor that are not Guarantors, including their obligations to trade creditors, and liabilities in connection with the America Ground Rent Transaction and lease liabilities; and - be subject to the limitations described herein and in “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Capital _Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness—Each Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit its validity and enforceability” and “Certain Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ The obligations of the Guarantors will be contractually limited under the applicable Notes Guarantees to reflect limitations under applicable law with respect to maintenance of share capital, corporate benefit, fraudulent conveyance, financial assistance and other legal restrictions applicable to the Guarantors and their respective shareholders, directors and general partners, and as further stipulated in the Agreed Security Principles. For a description of such contractual limitations, see “Certain Insolvency Considerations and _Limitations on Validity and _Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.” By virtue of these limitations, a Guarantor’s_ obligation under its Notes Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Senior Secured Notes. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our _Indebtedness—The insolvency laws of England and Wales and other jurisdictions may not be as favourable to you as the_ _U.S. bankruptcy laws and may preclude holders of the Senior Secured Notes from recovering payments due on the Senior Secured Notes.”_

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsubsection Text: As of the Issue Date, all of our Subsidiaries will be “Restricted Subsidiaries” for purposes of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. However, under the circumstances described under “—Certain Definitions—Unrestricted _Subsidiary,” we will be permitted to designate certain of our Subsidiaries as “Unrestricted Subsidiaries.” Our_ Unrestricted Subsidiaries will not be subject to any of the restrictive covenants in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue £1,750 million in aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes on the Issue Date. The Senior Secured Notes will mature on    , 2030. The Senior Secured Notes will be issued in minimum denominations of £100,000 and in integral multiples of £1,000 in excess thereof.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsubsection Text: Interest on the Senior Secured Notes will accrue at the rate of      % per annum. Interest on the Senior Secured Notes will: - accrue from the Issue Date or, if interest has already been paid, from the date it was most recently paid; - be payable in cash semi-annually in arrears on each      and     , commencing on     , 2024 _provided that the final interest payment date in respect of the Senior Secured Notes will be on      ;_ 279 ----- - be payable to the holder of record of such Senior Secured Notes on the Business Day immediately preceding the related interest payment date (for Senior Secured Notes held in global form); and - be computed on the basis of actual days elapsed in a 365-day year. The interest amount will be calculated by applying the applicable rate of interest to the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the Senior Secured Notes. Each interest period shall end on (but not include) the relevant payment date. The rights of Holders to receive the payments of interest on the Senior Secured Notes are subject to applicable procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsection Title: Methods of Receiving Payments on the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Text: Principal, interest, premium and Additional Amounts, if any, on the Global Senior Secured Notes (as defined below) will be payable at the specified office or agency of one or more Paying Agents; provided that all such payments with respect to the Senior Secured Notes represented by one or more Global Senior Secured Note registered in the name of or held by a nominee of a common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, as applicable, will be made by wire transfer of immediately available funds to the account specified by the Holder or Holders thereof. Principal, interest, premium and Additional Amounts if any, on any certificated securities, which shall be in registered form for U.S. federal income tax purposes (“Definitive Registered Notes”) will be payable at the specified office or agency of one or more Paying Agents maintained for such purposes. In addition, interest on the Definitive Registered Notes may be paid by bank transfer to the person entitled thereto as shown on the register for the Definitive Registered Notes. See “—Paying Agent, Registrar and Transfer Agent for the Senior Secured Notes.” If the due date for any payment in respect of any Senior Secured Notes is not a Business Day at the place at which such payment is due to be paid, the Holder thereof will not be entitled to payment of the amount due until the next succeeding Business Day at such place, and will not be entitled to any further interest or other payment as a result of any such delay.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsection Title: Paying Agent, Registrar and Transfer Agent for the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will maintain one or more Paying Agents for the Senior Secured Notes (the “Principal Paying Agent” or “Paying Agent”). The initial Paying Agent will be Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will also maintain a registrar (the “Registrar”) and a transfer agent (the “Transfer Agent”). The initial Registrar will be Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. and the Transfer Agent will be Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. The Registrar, Transfer Agent and Paying Agent, as applicable, will maintain a register reflecting ownership of the Definitive Registered Notes outstanding from time to time, if any, and, together with the Transfer Agent, will make payments on and facilitate transfers of the Definitive Registered Notes on behalf of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer may change any Paying Agents, Registrars or Transfer Agents for the Senior Secured Notes without prior notice to the Holders of the Senior Secured Notes. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer or any of its Subsidiaries may act as Paying Agent or Registrar in respect of the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF THE SENIOR SECURED NOTES
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors, subject to the Agreed Security Principles. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Guarantors represented 98% of the Group’s consolidated revenue. The obligations of the Guarantors will be contractually limited under the applicable Notes Guarantees to reflect limitations under applicable law with respect to maintenance of share capital, corporate benefit, fraudulent conveyance and other legal restrictions applicable to the Guarantors and their respective shareholders, directors and general partners, and as further stipulated in the Agreed Security Principles. For a description of such contractual limitations, see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness—The 280 ----- _insolvency laws of England and Wales and other jurisdictions may not be as favourable to you as the U.S. bankruptcy laws and may preclude holders of the Senior Secured Notes from recovering payments due on the Senior Secured Notes,” “ Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our Indebtedness—Each Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit its validity and enforceability,” and “Certain Insolvency Considerations and_ _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the_ _Security Interests.”_ The operations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer are and will be conducted through its Subsidiaries. Claims of creditors of non-Guarantor Subsidiaries, including trade creditors, secured creditors and creditors holding debt and guarantees issued by those Subsidiaries, and claims of preferred and minority stockholders (if any) of those Subsidiaries generally will have priority with respect to the assets and earnings of those Subsidiaries over the claims of creditors of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Guarantors, including Holders of the Senior Secured Notes. The Senior Secured Notes and each Notes Guarantee therefore will be structurally subordinated to creditors (including trade creditors) and preferred and minority stockholders (if any) of Subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (other than such Subsidiaries that are Guarantors). Although the Senior Secured Notes Indenture limits the Incurrence of Indebtedness by Restricted Subsidiaries, the limitation is subject to a number of significant exceptions. Moreover, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture does not impose any limitation on the Incurrence by Restricted Subsidiaries of liabilities that are not considered Indebtedness under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. See “—Certain Covenants— _Limitation on_ _Indebtedness” and “—Certain Definitions—Indebtedness.”_ In addition, as described under “—Certain Covenants—Additional Notes Guarantees” and subject to the Intercreditor Agreement and the Agreed Security Principles, each Restricted Subsidiary that guarantees any Indebtedness Incurred under any Syndicated Term Facilities, any other Credit Facility that provides for aggregate lending commitments in excess of £50.0 million at the relevant date of determination or any Public Debt shall also enter into a supplemental indenture as a Guarantor of the Senior Secured Notes. The Agreed Security Principles apply to the granting of guarantees and security in favour of obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities and the Senior Secured Notes. The Agreed Security Principles include restrictions on the granting of guarantees where, among other things, such grant would be restricted by general statutory or other legal limitations or requirements, financial assistance, corporate benefit, fraudulent preference rules, “thin capitalisation” rules, capital maintenance rules, retention of title claims and similar matters, where the time and cost of granting the guarantee or security would be disproportionate to the benefit accruing to the Holders or where security would be granted over the Capital Stock, liabilities, property or other assets of any member of the Regulated Group. Each Notes Guarantee will be limited to the maximum amount that would not render the Guarantor’s obligations subject to avoidance under applicable fraudulent conveyance provisions of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or any comparable provision of foreign or state law, or as otherwise stipulated under the Agreed Security Principles, including to comply with corporate benefit, financial assistance and other laws. By virtue of this limitation, a Guarantor’s obligation under its Notes Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Senior Secured Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Notes Guarantee.
